description: Adobe Illustrator Creative Cloud is used by both artists and graphic designers to create vector images both in print and digital form. It is typically used to create illustrations, charts, graphs, logos, diagrams, cartoons of real photographs. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
descriptionMD: Adobe Illustrator Creative Cloud is used by both artists and graphic designers to create vector images both in print and digital form. It is typically used to create illustrations, charts, graphs, logos, diagrams, cartoons of real photographs. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: Illustrator CC 2017
subtitle: Graphics Design Application

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne introduce Adobe Illustrator CC 2017. They discuss the uses of Illustrator, explain raster and vector information, and review differences of Illustrator on a Mac and Windows operating systems.
episodes.title: Introduction to Illustrator

00:06:48.720 --> 00:06:53.680
72 is the magic number for

300 is the magic number for

00:07:09.600 --> 00:07:13.500

enough pixels to get this resolution up

00:07:13.500 --> 00:07:15.300

things in the native file format,

344
00:17:38.905 --> 00:17:40.125
that's why kinda throw down here,

345
00:17:40.125 --> 00:17:43.995
working with images within Adobe
products keep a native format.

346
00:17:43.995 --> 00:17:45.725
I like to keep that in there.

347
00:17:45.725 --> 00:17:49.765
Placing AI files in InDesign,

348
00:17:49.765 --> 00:17:53.495
that kinda gives you an extra
level of things to work with.

349
00:17:53.495 --> 00:17:55.480
So that's why I threw it over here.

350
00:17:55.480 --> 00:17:59.420
EPS, Encapsulated Postscript File
that is another one.

351
00:17:59.420 --> 00:18:04.140
It is a vector file format and so
a lot of times you want to go ahead and

352
00:18:04.140 --> 00:18:07.950
send that as your logo,
especially with t-shirts.

353
00:18:07.950 --> 00:18:11.100
>> I was just about to say that,
I was like I can contribute to this one.

354
00:18:11.100 --> 00:18:13.900
When you design a t-shirt that's
what they are gonna ask for.

355
00:18:13.900 --> 00:18:16.900
For but a lot of times often you'll
need it for other things too.

356
00:18:16.900 --> 00:18:20.010
>> Yeah that's what they
always want because it's more,

357
00:18:20.010 --> 00:18:23.890
it's AI, Illustrator that's going
to need Illustrator to open it.

358
00:18:24.980 --> 00:18:30.190
EPS is like a generic,
neutral file format that is rastered,

359
00:18:30.190 --> 00:18:32.882
nope, sorry,
vector based that they can use.

360
00:18:32.882 --> 00:18:34.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it usually equates to whatever type

361
00:18:34.990 --> 00:18:37.280
of machinery and
things that they're going to use that way.

362
00:18:37.280 --> 00:18:38.980
>> Yeah, and
I think even if you're on a Mac too,

363
00:18:38.980 --> 00:18:40.810
that'll open up just in your preview.

364
00:18:40.810 --> 00:18:42.442
Whereas, if I try and open up an EPS file,

365
00:18:42.442 --> 00:18:45.382
sometimes I find that to be a little
bit frustrating cuz I'm not like, no,

366
00:18:45.382 --> 00:18:48.393
I don't want it in preview, I want it
to go ahead and open up in Illustrator.

367
00:18:48.393 --> 00:18:54.019
So it kind of depends if you are on a Mac
versus a PC how that's kinda open up.

368
00:18:54.019 --> 00:18:58.810
>> The whole Mac preview thing, if you
don't have, it opens up PDFs in preview.

369
00:18:58.810 --> 00:19:00.960
And I have to tell people like no,

370
00:19:00.960 --> 00:19:06.010
don't let it open up in it's
native association or file type.

371
00:19:06.010 --> 00:19:07.510
Go ahead and right click on that and

372
00:19:07.510 --> 00:19:10.440
open it up with Adobe Reader because
I want them to fill out forms or

373
00:19:10.440 --> 00:19:11.960
something like that, and
they're like I don't have reader.

374
00:19:11.960 --> 00:19:14.100
Well it's free go download it.

375
00:19:14.100 --> 00:19:16.580
So that's what we got and
of course the PDF.

376
00:19:16.580 --> 00:19:19.810
That's what I usually send all of my

377
00:19:19.810 --> 00:19:24.838
print ready files to my commercial
printer, I send it to them in a PDF.

378
00:19:24.838 --> 00:19:28.820
But just saving something as a PDF doesn't
automatically make it print worthy,

379
00:19:28.820 --> 00:19:30.350
you have to start with a base.

380
00:19:30.350 --> 00:19:36.740
If I have a 72 PPI,
RGB image in an illustrator file and

381
00:19:36.740 --> 00:19:41.220
I save it as a PDF and
I even do the high print export options,

382
00:19:41.220 --> 00:19:45.450
they're still gonna say this is
the wrong resolution this isn't right.

383
00:19:45.450 --> 00:19:49.760
But I saved as a PDF,
as a higher print thingy in the presets.

384
00:19:49.760 --> 00:19:53.770
No it goes back to the core,
the base information,

385
00:19:53.770 --> 00:19:59.250
if that image is not print ready,
doesn't matter what the PDF does.

386
00:20:00.480 --> 00:20:02.955
So I think few do I have anything else.

387
00:20:02.955 --> 00:20:04.840
Nope, bunch of white space, so

388
00:20:04.840 --> 00:20:09.090
that concludes this particular file and
Illustrator,

389
00:20:09.090 --> 00:20:14.430
giving you all the base information
of the file formats resolution.

390
00:20:14.430 --> 00:20:18.500
Again I threw out a lot of theory,
if you want to say, to you, and

391
00:20:18.500 --> 00:20:20.940
it will take some time to absorb.

392
00:20:20.940 --> 00:20:23.820
Take little chunks take a little bit,
it will take practice,

393
00:20:23.820 --> 00:20:25.150
you'll still mess it up as you go.

394
00:20:25.150 --> 00:20:29.145
You'll send files to the printer wrong,
I still do it sometimes.

395
00:20:29.145 --> 00:20:31.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's even worse and

396
00:20:31.130 --> 00:20:33.640
it's at the print shop
my husband works at.

397
00:20:33.640 --> 00:20:36.990
I'm so sorry I'm so
ashamed, so embarrassed.

398
00:20:36.990 --> 00:20:39.610
>> No honestly it really
does take a long time.

399
00:20:39.610 --> 00:20:42.210
It's It's complicated kind
of going through this stuff.

400
00:20:42.210 --> 00:20:45.140
You're seeing numbers and all these things
that you never really thought that you

401
00:20:45.140 --> 00:20:48.460
were gonna have to deal with, maybe,
when you opened up Illustrator.

402
00:20:48.460 --> 00:20:51.322
And it does make a tremendous
difference in your file size, so

403
00:20:51.322 --> 00:20:53.420
I've been working with this for
a long time.

404
00:20:53.420 --> 00:20:56.170
And there's a reason why I
pitched this one to Vonne and

405
00:20:56.170 --> 00:20:57.760
said, you can handle that.

406
00:20:57.760 --> 00:20:58.790
Because it's just so

407
00:20:58.790 --> 00:21:02.190
complicated, I really wanted to make
sure that it was explained well.

408
00:21:02.190 --> 00:21:03.860
And I think you did a fantastic job.

409
00:21:03.860 --> 00:21:04.670
>> Why thank you so much.

410
00:21:04.670 --> 00:21:05.870
>> So thank you so much.

411
00:21:05.870 --> 00:21:09.280
Thank you for wrapping up the file
types and the resolution and

412
00:21:09.280 --> 00:21:10.530
kinda going through all that with us.

413
00:21:10.530 --> 00:21:12.970
But I think with that, we will wrap it up.

414
00:21:12.970 --> 00:21:17.040
So, signing off for CreativeProTV,
I've been your host, Emily Ramsey.

415
00:21:17.040 --> 00:21:18.014
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

416
00:21:18.014 --> 00:21:20.121
>> And we'll see you next time.

417
00:21:20.121 --> 00:21:20.621
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily review the Illustrator workspace. They demonstrate how to work with the panels, toolbox, control panel (also know as the options bar) , and preset workspaces.  They also show how to create custom workspaces as well as zooming techniques and shortcuts.
episodes.title: Navigating in Illustrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:07.166
[NOISE]

2
00:00:07.166 --> 00:00:11.133
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.133 --> 00:00:14.750
Hello, everyone and welcome to another
exciting edition of Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:14.750 --> 00:00:20.260
I'm your host Vonne Smith, and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:20.260 --> 00:00:23.980
In this episode we're gonna get you
started with navigating in illustrator.

6
00:00:23.980 --> 00:00:28.640
And here to help us navigate through
these waters is Ms. Emily Ramsey.

7
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:32.540
Hi. [LAUGH] >> So clever, navigate
through these waters, that was cute.

8
00:00:32.540 --> 00:00:33.470
I like it I like it.

9
00:00:33.470 --> 00:00:37.289
So yeah, we're gonna go ahead and
actually look at Illustrator and

10
00:00:37.289 --> 00:00:39.370
see what is kinda going on with this.

11
00:00:39.370 --> 00:00:42.540
So what i wanna do,
I wanna go ahead and just, straight up,

12
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:46.370
start with opening up Illustrator and
see exactly what we're looking at here.

13
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:48.790
So, everything that we have,

14
00:00:48.790 --> 00:00:52.160
this whole thing is known as
our workspace in Illustrator.

15
00:00:52.160 --> 00:00:55.440
The whole gamut is known as our workspace.

16
00:00:55.440 --> 00:00:58.650
Now, we're gonna have a couple different
little pieces and parts to this.

17
00:00:58.650 --> 00:01:01.540
That if you're just kinda getting started,
you'd really be like why

18
00:01:01.540 --> 00:01:04.320
does it matter if I know what these
things are called or what they do.

19
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:07.980
It's going to make a tremendous difference
in your work flow if you have somewhat of

20
00:01:07.980 --> 00:01:10.740
an understanding of each of
these different pieces and

21
00:01:10.740 --> 00:01:12.820
what you can do with them.

22
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:16.485
So what we're looking at here again
this entire here thing is known as our

23
00:01:16.485 --> 00:01:17.320
workspace.

24
00:01:17.320 --> 00:01:21.600
This top section here, this I feel
like I have many different names for.

25
00:01:21.600 --> 00:01:24.290
I think technically it's
referred to as your options bar.

26
00:01:24.290 --> 00:01:28.130
I usually call it your control panel or
your control bar.

27
00:01:28.130 --> 00:01:32.150
>> From everything I've ever done,
and this is going way back in

28
00:01:32.150 --> 00:01:35.930
really old earlier versions of
Illustrator, it was the control panel.

29
00:01:35.930 --> 00:01:36.650
>> Yeah.

30
00:01:36.650 --> 00:01:38.040
>> Yeah, and
then we were talking about this.

31
00:01:38.040 --> 00:01:40.840
It was like I think they call it
the options bar now, I'm like, hm.

32
00:01:40.840 --> 00:01:43.490
Okay, and we'll just call it the bar at
the top that gives you all the stuff.

33
00:01:43.490 --> 00:01:44.035
>> Yeah, yeah.

34
00:01:44.035 --> 00:01:45.340
>> [LAUGH]
>> As soon as I'm telling you that

35
00:01:45.340 --> 00:01:47.120
you need to learn all the proper names for
these,

36
00:01:47.120 --> 00:01:50.356
I'm like let me start off with the one
that I [LAUGH] don't know very well.

37
00:01:50.356 --> 00:01:53.220
But that's basically what it does
is it gives you the options.

38
00:01:53.220 --> 00:01:57.650
It's kind of the default, always there,
it's gonna have different options,

39
00:01:57.650 --> 00:02:00.020
different controls that you
can use in Illustrator.

40
00:02:00.020 --> 00:02:04.420
>> You might wanna throw out right here
that, the resolution of your monitor does

41
00:02:04.420 --> 00:02:10.165
make a difference on how much you see up
in that control panel, I'll go with that.

42
00:02:10.165 --> 00:02:11.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because the lower the resolution,

43
00:02:11.850 --> 00:02:15.230
the less things you're gonna have because
everything looks a little bigger.

44
00:02:15.230 --> 00:02:18.250
The higher the resolution everything
looks a little smaller, so

45
00:02:18.250 --> 00:02:19.060
you might have other options.

46
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:22.430
So through the different episodes,
if you're looking at yours and

47
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:25.210
like, hey I've got a lot more
things on there, that's fine.

48
00:02:25.210 --> 00:02:28.760
We try to keep our resolution at
a place where it makes it easier for

49
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:29.780
you to see on the screen.

50
00:02:29.780 --> 00:02:31.755
>> Yeah, yeah,
I think that's a great point too,

51
00:02:31.755 --> 00:02:34.280
cuz that's definitely something that
I've been noticing in this setup.

52
00:02:34.280 --> 00:02:36.720
I'm like, wait a second,
that's normally there, and now it's not.

53
00:02:36.720 --> 00:02:38.311
And it's because I've
changed my resolution so

54
00:02:38.311 --> 00:02:41.010
that you guys can see it on
the screen a little bit better.

55
00:02:41.010 --> 00:02:43.670
Now, we have that top panel on
the right-hand side over here,

56
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:45.570
these are known as our panels.

57
00:02:45.570 --> 00:02:49.620
So our panels, I want to say they're
the heart of Illustrator, but

58
00:02:49.620 --> 00:02:52.688
I don't wanna take away
from the stuff on the left.

59
00:02:52.688 --> 00:02:55.710
Your panels are going to be something that
you're going to refer to all the time.

60
00:02:55.710 --> 00:02:58.460
I'm going to try to introduce
you guys to how they work.

61
00:02:58.460 --> 00:03:02.240
But just know that as I'm working in
Illustrator and as your kind of going

62
00:03:02.240 --> 00:03:05.970
through these episodes you're going to see
me interacting in my panels all the time.

63
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:08.125
So if we don't touch
through everything here,

64
00:03:08.125 --> 00:03:11.170
you're probably going to see me do
something in one of those future episodes.

65
00:03:11.170 --> 00:03:15.910
So what I can do with my panels, you're
seeing I'm looking at all of these icons.

66
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:18.390
This has to do with
the workspace that I have set.

67
00:03:18.390 --> 00:03:21.820
You may have some different ones and
we'll kinda talk through that here.

68
00:03:21.820 --> 00:03:24.070
But something else that I
want to point out here,

69
00:03:24.070 --> 00:03:25.430
if you're just looking at the icons and

70
00:03:25.430 --> 00:03:28.550
you're thinking, how am I ever gonna
remember what each of those means?

71
00:03:28.550 --> 00:03:32.610
See how if I kinda hover along the side
here, I get two double-pointed arrows?

72
00:03:32.610 --> 00:03:35.850
Don't hover right next
to one of the icons, but

73
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:39.000
hover just kind of between them and
I get those double-pointed arrows.

74
00:03:39.000 --> 00:03:42.620
I can pull those out and you guys can
actually start to see the names of those.

75
00:03:42.620 --> 00:03:46.030
Now, just because I'm accustomed
to working in Illustrator,

76
00:03:46.030 --> 00:03:49.890
I tend to keep that kind of pushed off
to the side, I'd rather have more space.

77
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:53.570
I don't know the names,
just because I'm so familiar with it.

78
00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:56.200
But I would definitely say, when you're
starting out, try to make sure that you

79
00:03:56.200 --> 00:03:58.720
have those names there, just so that
can give you a little bit of a preview.

80
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:01.980
Now our panels essentially
act like drawers.

81
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:04.210
So it's kinda fun,
you go ahead and click on one.

82
00:04:04.210 --> 00:04:07.090
It's gonna go ahead and
pop out all of this other information.

83
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:10.330
If I click over here it's all
gonna look a little bit different.

84
00:04:10.330 --> 00:04:12.150
And you can kinda keep going.

85
00:04:12.150 --> 00:04:16.160
And then the other thing with these
drawers is that I can kinda pull one out.

86
00:04:16.160 --> 00:04:18.640
So I'm gonna go ahead and
take this swatches panel.

87
00:04:18.640 --> 00:04:22.440
If I just click right on this word,
swatches, I'm not over here in my panels

88
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:25.900
over here, but I'm just looking
specifically at the swatches panel.

89
00:04:25.900 --> 00:04:29.150
If I wanna click hold and drag,
and just kinda pull that out,

90
00:04:29.150 --> 00:04:32.300
I can now separate the swatches
panel from everything else.

91
00:04:32.300 --> 00:04:34.690
Now if I wanna give myself
a little bit more space,

92
00:04:34.690 --> 00:04:38.575
see those two double-pointed arrows,
what's now left in my symbols panel,

93
00:04:38.575 --> 00:04:41.880
cuz those were all kinda grouped together,
we'll talk about it in a second.

94
00:04:41.880 --> 00:04:44.520
My symbols panel is now
the one that's left open.

95
00:04:44.520 --> 00:04:48.510
If I click on those two double pointed
arrows, that'll go ahead and tuck that in.

96
00:04:48.510 --> 00:04:50.600
So now I can move this
swatches panel out and say,

97
00:04:50.600 --> 00:04:52.310
okay maybe I want it to move over there.

98
00:04:52.310 --> 00:04:54.760
I can also use the double-pointed
arrows at the bottom.

99
00:04:54.760 --> 00:04:56.570
Go ahead and drag that out,

100
00:04:56.570 --> 00:05:00.430
you'll see you have some kind of hidden
information there in your swatches panel.

101
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:03.560
Now say, I want to go ahead and
tuck this back in.

102
00:05:03.560 --> 00:05:06.580
I can go ahead and do that,
I'm tired of having my swatches panel out.

103
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:10.190
So I can go ahead and click,
hold, and drag and drag that in.

104
00:05:10.190 --> 00:05:10.780
Now you'll see,

105
00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:14.340
depending on where I'm hovering,
it's giving me different options here.

106
00:05:14.340 --> 00:05:18.100
So I can kind of hover over here, and
it's gonna link that back where it was.

107
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:20.600
Now you may notice,
it's kind of hard to see on my screen,

108
00:05:20.600 --> 00:05:22.530
you may notice these kind of lines here.

109
00:05:22.530 --> 00:05:25.465
It's kind of like everything is
in these chunks or these groups.

110
00:05:25.465 --> 00:05:28.857
Like I see swatches, brushes,
symbols in one chunk,

111
00:05:28.857 --> 00:05:31.790
color-color guide in another chunk.

112
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:34.950
I could move the swatches over
to the color and color guide.

113
00:05:34.950 --> 00:05:37.750
Which, when we get into that,
will kinda make sense.

114
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:40.070
I can kind of put it in
between those two sections,

115
00:05:40.070 --> 00:05:42.530
see how I'm getting that
little line there right now?

116
00:05:42.530 --> 00:05:45.210
And I can go ahead and
put the swatches on it's own.

117
00:05:45.210 --> 00:05:48.775
So you can really organize these
to your hearts content, as you go.

118
00:05:48.775 --> 00:05:52.550
>> Yeah and, like you just said,
it is up to you how and

119
00:05:52.550 --> 00:05:55.270
where you want to put things and
where you want to group them or

120
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:59.520
make a single panel be in it's own group,
it's totally up to you.

121
00:05:59.520 --> 00:06:02.365
And I know that they used to,
and they might still be able to,

122
00:06:02.365 --> 00:06:06.480
if you kind of hover a little bit further
past, you can almost make like a double

123
00:06:07.670 --> 00:06:10.980
panel docking area, in the sense
of where it's like you get the-

124
00:06:10.980 --> 00:06:12.010
>> This little guy?

125
00:06:12.010 --> 00:06:12.750
>> That little guy, yeah.

126
00:06:12.750 --> 00:06:14.530
>> Is that what you're talking about?

127
00:06:14.530 --> 00:06:15.690
>> Yeah, or where you're dragging.

128
00:06:15.690 --> 00:06:19.320
If you drag off to the side,
and then you move that over.

129
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:21.570
>> Yes, if I kinda drag it here.

130
00:06:21.570 --> 00:06:22.070
>> That one.
>> Okay.

131
00:06:22.070 --> 00:06:23.000
>> The vertical blue line.

132
00:06:23.000 --> 00:06:24.748
>> I got you now, all right.

133
00:06:24.748 --> 00:06:25.417
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

134
00:06:25.417 --> 00:06:27.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> I've had people do that, and

135
00:06:27.560 --> 00:06:29.550
be like I don't know what I did.

136
00:06:29.550 --> 00:06:33.380
Because you can have double
columns if you want of say,

137
00:06:33.380 --> 00:06:36.000
of panels where you can kind
of organize it that way.

138
00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:40.930
Because, there's actually a lot of
panels in Illustrator as opposed

139
00:06:40.930 --> 00:06:45.200
to other programs that are on by
default You can customize it and

140
00:06:45.200 --> 00:06:49.800
take any of the ones that you don't want
out and close them or make them go away.

141
00:06:49.800 --> 00:06:50.500
But just to let you know,

142
00:06:50.500 --> 00:06:55.995
that there is a second docking station
in your panel stuff over there.

143
00:06:55.995 --> 00:06:57.691
[LAUGH]
>> I had totally forgotten about that.

144
00:06:57.691 --> 00:06:58.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

145
00:06:58.410 --> 00:06:59.690
I'm glad you mentioned it, thank you.

So, that's definitely from
my own personal preference.

375
00:17:33.233 --> 00:17:37.201
>> Yeah, that the see-through-ness
as I call it, of the whole program.

376
00:17:37.201 --> 00:17:39.772
There's no, there's no back to it.

377
00:17:39.772 --> 00:17:44.145
And this is one specifically with
illustrator that it does that,

378
00:17:44.145 --> 00:17:45.983
for some reason, on a MAC.

379
00:17:45.983 --> 00:17:47.508
So just make sure you always
do an application frame.

380
00:17:47.508 --> 00:17:49.012
It's a little weird.

381
00:17:49.012 --> 00:17:52.111
And I, honestly, I can't remember
if its on by default or not.

382
00:17:52.111 --> 00:17:53.224
>> Yeah.

383
00:17:53.224 --> 00:17:56.775
Just letting you know that it's there,
cuz it's been an area of contention for

384
00:17:56.775 --> 00:17:57.724
some people.

385
00:17:57.724 --> 00:17:58.500
>> Yes, yes.

386
00:17:58.500 --> 00:18:00.677
I think it's just, again,
it's your own personal preference.

387
00:18:00.677 --> 00:18:03.204
It's kinda the same way
that looks very similar to

388
00:18:03.204 --> 00:18:05.077
the way other programs on a MAC work.

389
00:18:05.077 --> 00:18:07.954
If I think about Microsoft Word, or
something like that, it looks like that.

390
00:18:07.954 --> 00:18:10.358
But, I just can't handle
it with the illustrator, so

391
00:18:10.358 --> 00:18:11.624
I've got to work with this.

392
00:18:11.624 --> 00:18:14.805
Now, there's one other thing that I want
to mention here in talking about zooming.

393
00:18:14.805 --> 00:18:16.802
So I'm gonna look at this here.

394
00:18:16.802 --> 00:18:18.956
Now, you'll see one
thing else to point out,

395
00:18:18.956 --> 00:18:21.065
is that I have multiple
files open right now.

396
00:18:21.065 --> 00:18:23.720
So you can kind of see what that's
going to start to look like,

397
00:18:23.720 --> 00:18:25.162
when you open up multiple files.

398
00:18:25.162 --> 00:18:28.075
We'll certainly discuss that
in our file new episode.

399
00:18:28.075 --> 00:18:32.137
But I'm gonna jump over to this move and
zoom, just so we can talk

400
00:18:32.137 --> 00:18:37.120
about some of our Zooming methods and
kinda how to move around in Illustrator.

401
00:18:37.120 --> 00:18:39.590
So, one thing that we wanna talk about,

402
00:18:39.590 --> 00:18:43.090
as always using our
keyboard shortcuts to zoom.

403
00:18:43.090 --> 00:18:45.501
So we're big fans of keyboard
shortcuts right here.

404
00:18:45.501 --> 00:18:48.890
I have a lot of this written out,
we can certainly make this available in

405
00:18:48.890 --> 00:18:52.576
the exercise files if you wanna kind of
read through them and and look at that.

406
00:18:52.576 --> 00:18:54.932
But I'm just gonna point out
a couple of my favorites.

407
00:18:54.932 --> 00:18:59.098
If I wanna go ahead and zoom in,
I am gonna to use a command or

408
00:18:59.098 --> 00:19:00.554
control plus sign.

409
00:19:00.554 --> 00:19:03.753
So a command on a MAC and control on a PC.

410
00:19:03.753 --> 00:19:05.547
You'll probably hear me say that a lot.

411
00:19:05.547 --> 00:19:07.343
Command on a MAC, control on a PC.

412
00:19:07.343 --> 00:19:10.155
And I'm gonna go ahead and
hit command or control plus sign, and

413
00:19:10.155 --> 00:19:11.469
that's gonna zoom in for me.

414
00:19:11.469 --> 00:19:15.724
Now say I really want to get that yellow
circle that I had there at the bottom.

415
00:19:15.724 --> 00:19:17.674
I'm gonna hold down my spacebar.

416
00:19:17.674 --> 00:19:21.509
My space bar is going to
toggle to my hand marquee.

417
00:19:21.509 --> 00:19:25.622
I'm gonna go ahead and hold that down,
and then now I can click, hold, and drag.

418
00:19:25.622 --> 00:19:30.280
See how that hand as I single click
kinda grabs onto my art board?

419
00:19:30.280 --> 00:19:33.590
And I can go ahead and Select that there.

420
00:19:33.590 --> 00:19:37.447
So I can toggle back and
forth as I'm using that.

421
00:19:37.447 --> 00:19:38.862
So again, that is your spacebar.

422
00:19:38.862 --> 00:19:43.053
It's not command spacebar, it's not
shift space bar, it's just spacebar.

423
00:19:43.053 --> 00:19:45.030
Now say I wanna go ahead and
get out of this.

424
00:19:45.030 --> 00:19:47.265
I have two different
options that I can choose.

425
00:19:47.265 --> 00:19:51.285
I can do command or Ctrl minus sign,
or just the hyphen, I guess,

426
00:19:51.285 --> 00:19:53.325
is what it is on your keyboard.

427
00:19:53.325 --> 00:19:54.845
And to get out of this,

428
00:19:54.845 --> 00:19:59.460
but say, it's like I go too far or
I go too far in, or whatever.

429
00:19:59.460 --> 00:20:02.696
What do I do if I just want to
kinda get back to a neutral?

430
00:20:02.696 --> 00:20:06.935
The keyboard shortcuts should just
fit in window or fit in art board,

431
00:20:06.935 --> 00:20:11.628
is technically what we're working with
here, is command or control zero.

432
00:20:11.628 --> 00:20:15.467
So that's another one, again, that you'll
want to go ahead and pay attention to.

433
00:20:15.467 --> 00:20:19.745
Now there are a couple other ones you can
use, another one that I use that's pretty

434
00:20:19.745 --> 00:20:22.171
popular is this spacebar command or
control.

435
00:20:22.171 --> 00:20:26.069
Note how this one,
typically with everything in Illustrator,

436
00:20:26.069 --> 00:20:30.917
I always say command or control first,
and then I say something like spacebar.

437
00:20:30.917 --> 00:20:33.582
This one's kind of weird, again,
this is kind of max Pacific.

438
00:20:33.582 --> 00:20:37.122
If you were on a MAC and you try and
use the keyboard shortcut,

439
00:20:37.122 --> 00:20:40.387
I guess if I do it the opposite way,
command or control,

440
00:20:40.387 --> 00:20:43.670
and then space bar,
it pulls up your spotlight search.

441
00:20:43.670 --> 00:20:46.095
That's cool and
that's great if you're on a MAC but

442
00:20:46.095 --> 00:20:49.585
not gonna be very helpful if you're
trying to work on a specific document.

443
00:20:49.585 --> 00:20:52.313
What I've found is that if you
hold down your spacebar first.

444
00:20:52.313 --> 00:20:56.096
And then command or control and
that will toggle to our zoom method.

445
00:20:56.096 --> 00:20:58.409
[LAUGH].

446
00:20:58.409 --> 00:21:00.162
And Vonne is just.

447
00:21:00.162 --> 00:21:03.233
[LAUGH]
>> It's good you didn't switch the camera

448
00:21:03.233 --> 00:21:04.690
to me because I'm just like, ahh.

449
00:21:04.690 --> 00:21:07.440
[LAUGH]
>> I couldn't tell if you were yawning,

450
00:21:07.440 --> 00:21:09.007
I was like, am I that boring?

451
00:21:09.007 --> 00:21:14.094
>> No because this is one of those
where soon it becomes the teacher,

452
00:21:14.094 --> 00:21:16.784
the teacher becomes the student.

453
00:21:16.784 --> 00:21:19.901
I always tell people to turn
that off in your presences.

454
00:21:19.901 --> 00:21:20.452
>> [LAUGH].

455
00:21:20.452 --> 00:21:24.592
>> In your MAC because you can go into
your keyboard and just uncheck that,

456
00:21:24.592 --> 00:21:26.119
cuz I'm always using it.

457
00:21:26.119 --> 00:21:29.620
Cuz these short cuts that we're talking
about are across the board in all of your

458
00:21:29.620 --> 00:21:30.414
Adobe products.

459
00:21:30.414 --> 00:21:34.315
So I was like well I'm gonna use it all
the time, so I'm gonna turn it off.

460
00:21:34.315 --> 00:21:39.148
Just do the space bar and then that's
what I like freaking out about over here.

461
00:21:39.148 --> 00:21:40.359
Just turn it in reverse.

462
00:21:40.359 --> 00:21:42.524
Cause yeah I don't always
do commands space bar no.

463
00:21:42.524 --> 00:21:43.818
Space bar command.

464
00:21:43.818 --> 00:21:45.165
I don't have to turn off
my search light [LAUGH].

465
00:21:45.165 --> 00:21:47.388
Cause I really like that.

466
00:21:47.388 --> 00:21:48.971
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

467
00:21:48.971 --> 00:21:53.176
In fairness You can pretty much
always hit the control key first in

468
00:21:53.176 --> 00:21:56.705
illustrator before you,
I get where that comes from.

469
00:21:56.705 --> 00:21:59.340
So yes, you can hit spacebar and
then command.

470
00:21:59.340 --> 00:22:02.761
Now if you're on a PC, probably not going
to matter if you hit command or control,

471
00:22:02.761 --> 00:22:05.501
but, I guess if you're on a PC
then you would be hitting control.

472
00:22:05.501 --> 00:22:07.635
Spacebar, order's not
gonna make a difference.

473
00:22:07.635 --> 00:22:11.173
It's just us complicated MAC
users that have a problem.

474
00:22:11.173 --> 00:22:13.887
So you'll see that's gonna
toggle to my zoom tool.

475
00:22:13.887 --> 00:22:17.557
So what I can do, if there's something
specifically that I wanna zoom in on,

476
00:22:17.557 --> 00:22:20.944
I can just kinda single-click on that,
or I think you can even, yeah,

477
00:22:20.944 --> 00:22:22.822
you can kinda click, hold, and drag.

478
00:22:22.822 --> 00:22:26.680
If I'm just single-clicking on my mouse,
holding and dragging,

479
00:22:26.680 --> 00:22:29.532
that will allow me to zoom
in on a specific object.

480
00:22:29.532 --> 00:22:33.501
So if I really wanted to make sure I got
in that circle as opposed to if I just go

481
00:22:33.501 --> 00:22:35.456
back with a command or control zero.

482
00:22:35.456 --> 00:22:39.147
The plus sign, and
then kinda move around with the hand.

483
00:22:39.147 --> 00:22:42.329
That will get me into one specific spot.

484
00:22:42.329 --> 00:22:45.433
So definitely,
this is one of those things.

485
00:22:45.433 --> 00:22:49.507
This is part of the reason why we don't
actually do anything in Illustrator in

486
00:22:49.507 --> 00:22:53.455
this first episode, because I feel like so
much to it is just getting an idea

487
00:22:53.455 --> 00:22:56.858
of where you're at and
kind of what everything is looking like.

488
00:22:56.858 --> 00:22:59.429
So-
>> Yeah, and my other favorite,

489
00:22:59.429 --> 00:23:04.138
because we've talked about this as well,
I can't design with a touchpad.

490
00:23:04.138 --> 00:23:07.444
I have to have my mouse
when I'm doing things.

491
00:23:07.444 --> 00:23:11.452
And so the Alt or Option Scrolly-wheel up,
Scrolly-wheel down,

492
00:23:11.452 --> 00:23:15.127
that's another one of my favorites,
kind of zoom in and out.

493
00:23:15.127 --> 00:23:19.815
Because I am using that, and
it all depends on where your mouse is on

494
00:23:19.815 --> 00:23:23.106
the the document if you
wanna stay right here.

495
00:23:23.106 --> 00:23:25.182
And then you can scroll back.

496
00:23:25.182 --> 00:23:28.688
I love doing that, and
that's kinda one of my favorites.

497
00:23:28.688 --> 00:23:30.220
And all these toggles, yeah.

498
00:23:30.220 --> 00:23:33.274
And over on that left hand side
that she had, like there are tools.

499
00:23:33.274 --> 00:23:34.508
You can go to the hand tool.

500
00:23:34.508 --> 00:23:35.347
You can go to the zoom tool.

501
00:23:35.347 --> 00:23:37.663
But that's just so, [LAUGH].

502
00:23:37.663 --> 00:23:38.965
>> Yes, so why would I go ahead and

503
00:23:38.965 --> 00:23:42.086
do something the hard way when I could
just do it with a keyboard shortcut?

504
00:23:42.086 --> 00:23:46.454
So, there are gonna be those
time in Illustrator when we say,

505
00:23:46.454 --> 00:23:50.486
yes the tool exists or
yes I could do this in my view menu but

506
00:23:50.486 --> 00:23:53.941
why do that when you could
do it ten times easier?

507
00:23:53.941 --> 00:23:57.025
So I hope this has been
a good introduction for you,

508
00:23:57.025 --> 00:23:59.264
in terms of working in Illustrator.

509
00:23:59.264 --> 00:24:02.110
I know you're probably itching

510
00:24:02.110 --> 00:24:04.608
I think it's really important
to take this step and

511
00:24:04.608 --> 00:24:08.404
really learn what the workspace is all
about, and kind of start navigating.

512
00:24:08.404 --> 00:24:10.358
And now, I promise the fun will begin.

513
00:24:10.358 --> 00:24:11.600
At least shortly.

514
00:24:11.600 --> 00:24:13.418
>> [LAUGH]
>> The fun will begin.

515
00:24:13.418 --> 00:24:15.929
>> [LAUGH]
>> We have a few more episodes of us

516
00:24:15.929 --> 00:24:17.131
getting started.

517
00:24:17.131 --> 00:24:20.651
Introducing you into Illustrator but
you make a great point of it.

518
00:24:20.651 --> 00:24:23.146
Just go ahead and practice those zooming.

519
00:24:23.146 --> 00:24:26.927
It seems kinda trivial right now and
make sure you get familiar with workspace.

520
00:24:26.927 --> 00:24:30.371
Like knowing where the panel is and
how to tear it up and everything.

521
00:24:30.371 --> 00:24:34.066
It's like, we're all kind of guilty of,
I am as well.

522
00:24:34.066 --> 00:24:36.402
You don't read the introduction
chapter in the book.

523
00:24:36.402 --> 00:24:36.926
Yeah.

524
00:24:36.926 --> 00:24:38.664
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, you don't read the directions.

525
00:24:38.664 --> 00:24:39.868
You kinda know all about that.

526
00:24:39.868 --> 00:24:41.810
As an instructor and a teacher, I do, too.

527
00:24:41.810 --> 00:24:44.334
It's like I read it right
there in the directions.

528
00:24:44.334 --> 00:24:46.893
But she just jumped right in and
did everything and didn't read it.

529
00:24:46.893 --> 00:24:48.559
That's okay.
That's what we're doing.

530
00:24:48.559 --> 00:24:49.452
Practice it.

531
00:24:49.452 --> 00:24:51.006
Get all those shortcuts down.

532
00:24:51.006 --> 00:24:52.070
Memorize them.

533
00:24:52.070 --> 00:24:53.100
It won't take you long.

534
00:24:53.100 --> 00:24:56.333
Honestly, as soon as you start doing more,
you will get it.

535
00:24:56.333 --> 00:24:58.208
All right, I think that was
a great introduction as well.

536
00:24:58.208 --> 00:25:00.602
But we are going to wrap this one up.

537
00:25:00.602 --> 00:25:03.360
Signing off, for Creative Pro Tv,
I have been your host Vonne Smith.

538
00:25:03.360 --> 00:25:04.202
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

539
00:25:04.202 --> 00:25:05.548
>> And we will see you soon.

540
00:25:05.548 --> 00:25:10.336
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne demonstrate how to create a new file In Illustrator.  They review file presets, measurement units, artboards, and advanced options. They also explain the importance of saving a file in its native version of Illustrator.
episodes.title: File New
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:06.564 --> 00:00:10.743
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.743 --> 00:00:15.415
Hello, welcome back to another
exciting edition of Creative Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.415 --> 00:00:19.295
I'm your host Vonne Smith and we are
continuing on with illustrator CC 2017.

4
00:00:19.295 --> 00:00:24.840
In this episode, we are going to get
you started with creating a new file,

5
00:00:24.840 --> 00:00:26.553
and how do you do that?

6
00:00:26.553 --> 00:00:27.527
File > New.
>> [LAUGH]

7
00:00:27.527 --> 00:00:29.417
>> And here to help us is Ms Emily Ramsey,

8
00:00:29.417 --> 00:00:31.045
so glad to have you back!

9
00:00:31.045 --> 00:00:35.795
>> Yes, thank you, I feel like File >
New is one of our more creative episode

10
00:00:35.795 --> 00:00:38.960
titles, that's basically what we're doing.

11
00:00:38.960 --> 00:00:42.710
So if we think about when we look at
the workspace and things like that.

12
00:00:42.710 --> 00:00:47.280
I already had File > Open, now you're
probably saying to me okay, yeah,

13
00:00:47.280 --> 00:00:50.430
I know how to create a new file,
like File > New, right?

14
00:00:50.430 --> 00:00:53.090
And even if you don't, it's probably
something that you're a little bit

15
00:00:53.090 --> 00:00:54.630
familiar, you may be
able to figure it out.

16
00:00:54.630 --> 00:00:59.740
But there is some of those little things
about it that I just wanted to point out.

17
00:00:59.740 --> 00:01:03.760
So let's go ahead and
look at my screen here and what I have,

18
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:05.385
I just pulled Illustrator up.

19
00:01:05.385 --> 00:01:09.250
Now just by default in Illustrator
you'll see your recent files,

20
00:01:10.400 --> 00:01:13.244
this is something that you can change.

21
00:01:13.244 --> 00:01:16.800
Now I'll get to that in a second,
the reason why I have this left up here

22
00:01:16.800 --> 00:01:19.080
typically when I'm teaching or
showing my screen.

23
00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:21.990
I don't have any of my recent files
because I don't want you to see my client

24
00:01:21.990 --> 00:01:23.230
work or anything like that.

25
00:01:23.230 --> 00:01:27.451
But these are all things that I've
created for this particular show.

26
00:01:27.451 --> 00:01:31.459
So you're looking at some of the files
that you've probably seen or

27
00:01:31.459 --> 00:01:34.140
will see as we go through the episode.

28
00:01:34.140 --> 00:01:37.210
What I wanna point out
to you with this is one,

29
00:01:37.210 --> 00:01:39.725
if I wanna go ahead and
just jump back into one of these.

30
00:01:39.725 --> 00:01:41.705
All I have to do is just click on that but

31
00:01:41.705 --> 00:01:47.795
then also notice I have an AI intro dot
AI but I also have an AI intro dot PDF.

32
00:01:47.795 --> 00:01:50.875
So saving as a PDF is
gonna be something that

00:01:50.875 --> 00:01:54.855
is gonna be really common in
Illustrator more than likely.

34
00:01:54.855 --> 00:01:58.249
And do note that although this doesn't
happen for everything, like if I'm saving

35
00:01:58.249 --> 00:02:00.926
as an image or something like that
it might be a little different.

36
00:02:00.926 --> 00:02:03.723
My PDF saves separately from my AI file,
so

37
00:02:03.723 --> 00:02:08.010
Illustrator is gonna treat them
almost as two different things.

38
00:02:08.010 --> 00:02:11.404
So I don't typically point this out
right when I'm doing a File > New but

39
00:02:11.404 --> 00:02:15.203
because it's right here for you to look
at I definitely did wanna point that out.

40
00:02:15.203 --> 00:02:19.047
And we'll see what that looks like
here but I can go ahead here, this is

41
00:02:19.047 --> 00:02:23.170
an option that I can change, so if you
want more you can go ahead and do that.

42
00:02:23.170 --> 00:02:24.910
Or if you wanna get rid of that entirely,

43
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:27.920
say you're in a weird situation like I am
where you're showing people your screen

44
00:02:27.920 --> 00:02:30.790
all the time,
you can go to Illustrator preferences.

45
00:02:30.790 --> 00:02:32.760
And then I believe,

46
00:02:32.760 --> 00:02:37.725
I always forget which one it is in,
we'll try User Interface, we'll go there,

47
00:02:37.725 --> 00:02:41.685
nope I think it's under File > Handling,
yes, File > Handling and Clip Art.

48
00:02:41.685 --> 00:02:45.465
You can change the number of recent
files to display automatically,

49
00:02:45.465 --> 00:02:49.775
it's gonna be set at 20, you can adjust
it to your own personal preference.

50
00:02:49.775 --> 00:02:52.655
>> Yeah, and the preferences, there's
a lot of things in the preferences.

51
00:02:52.655 --> 00:02:55.425
We might touch on those things here and
there throughout the episodes,

52
00:02:55.425 --> 00:02:58.630
like you can change
something in Preferences.

53
00:02:58.630 --> 00:03:02.226
And anyways, just make sure that you
go there, there are options there,

54
00:03:02.226 --> 00:03:04.671
I think in a PC though,
isn't it in the Edit menu?

55
00:03:04.671 --> 00:03:07.590
>> It's the Edit menu I think,
you took the words right out of my mouth.

56
00:03:07.590 --> 00:03:09.249
