270
00:14:48.990 --> 00:14:52.780
nowadays this is not really so much of
a problem as it used to be back then.

271
00:14:52.780 --> 00:14:55.720
It used to be that you would
get Illustrator installed on

272
00:14:55.720 --> 00:14:57.400
your computer with a CD.

273
00:14:57.400 --> 00:15:01.520
And that people didn't update quite
as frequently as they typically

274
00:15:01.520 --> 00:15:02.450
do with the CC.

275
00:15:02.450 --> 00:15:05.790
Now that that Illustrator CC has
been out for a few years and

276
00:15:05.790 --> 00:15:07.770
you can constantly keep updating.

277
00:15:07.770 --> 00:15:10.930
You don't have the issue that
we used to have which would be.

278
00:15:10.930 --> 00:15:15.760
If I have a version that's newer than
yours and I'm trying to send you a file,

279
00:15:15.760 --> 00:15:19.250
you're not necessarily gonna be able
to open it with full capabilities.

280
00:15:19.250 --> 00:15:22.530
So again, it's not really something
you really see quite as often now but

281
00:15:22.530 --> 00:15:23.890
it's still something worth pointing out.

282
00:15:23.890 --> 00:15:27.820
If I'm trying to send this CC
file to somebody with CS6 or

283
00:15:27.820 --> 00:15:30.520
CCS5 or anything like that.

284
00:15:30.520 --> 00:15:36.450
I need to go ahead and save my file with
that particular version applied to it.

285
00:15:36.450 --> 00:15:39.937
So it's just gonna depend, sometimes
I'll send something to my client and

286
00:15:39.937 --> 00:15:42.673
they'll be like,
yeah I have illustrator on my computer.

287
00:15:42.673 --> 00:15:45.058
And they probably installed
it ten years ago but

288
00:15:45.058 --> 00:15:47.330
they need to be able to open up the file.

289
00:15:47.330 --> 00:15:49.530
So sometimes, you do want to
have to pay attention to that or

290
00:15:49.530 --> 00:15:51.090
you do need to use that.

291
00:15:51.090 --> 00:15:54.310
I'm just gonna go ahead and hit OK, and
now you're gonna see, I didn't give it

292
00:15:54.310 --> 00:15:58.270
a name so it's just called untitled 5 but
you can see what that would be like there.

293
00:15:58.270 --> 00:16:02.725
And then if I do this File > Save As and
I go here and I save as a PDF, I can do

294
00:16:02.725 --> 00:16:07.960
a File > Save As as a PDF,
cool, everything looks good.

295
00:16:07.960 --> 00:16:09.820
I usually do a vPDF after saving,

296
00:16:09.820 --> 00:16:13.070
I select that option, and
I can see that's saved there.

297
00:16:13.070 --> 00:16:17.660
Now what I will notice is that you
are now working on untitled5.PDF so

298
00:16:17.660 --> 00:16:23.610
any changes that I make to this are gonna
be separate from that untitled5.ai file.

299
00:16:23.610 --> 00:16:26.150
And I just wanted to point that out
cuz I know that that's something that

300
00:16:26.150 --> 00:16:26.820
trips people up.

301
00:16:26.820 --> 00:16:30.780
So typically if you're working and
you have to save something as a PDF.

302
00:16:30.780 --> 00:16:34.800
Just wait until you're done with it or
wait till the very end to go ahead and

303
00:16:34.800 --> 00:16:35.950
save it as a PDF.

304
00:16:35.950 --> 00:16:41.120
>> Yeah, that's a huge one right there,
it seems very slight but it's big because

305
00:16:41.120 --> 00:16:46.590
Illustrator can open and
read EPS files, PDF files.

306
00:16:46.590 --> 00:16:50.190
You can get a File > Open on a PDF and
get into all sorts of stuff,

307
00:16:50.190 --> 00:16:54.250
I can mess me up a PDF really well
if I open it up in Illustrator.

308
00:16:54.250 --> 00:16:58.788
But yes, definitely keep notice of that,
and I have done that where I've saved it

309
00:16:58.788 --> 00:17:04.170
as the EPS version because somebody needed
that particular file format for my logo.

310
00:17:04.170 --> 00:17:07.560
I didn't pay attention, I'm working on the
EPS, I changed some colors and everything,

311
00:17:07.560 --> 00:17:08.980
save it and go back.

312
00:17:08.980 --> 00:17:11.890
The next day, I open up my AI file,

313
00:17:11.890 --> 00:17:14.990
my native file that I'm
always supposed to work with.

314
00:17:14.990 --> 00:17:15.820
And then I'm like,

315
00:17:15.820 --> 00:17:18.880
wait I thought I changed that to pink,
why didn't I do that?

316
00:17:18.880 --> 00:17:24.018
I did it on the EPS and didn't even
notice that I wasn't on that native file.

317
00:17:24.018 --> 00:17:30.330
You always wanna keep your source native
files in the AI format to be on that one.

318
00:17:30.330 --> 00:17:35.940
Don't work on your finished version files,
and just always make sure you do that,

319
00:17:35.940 --> 00:17:40.886
always, I'm telling you, I've got myself
up a creek really fast that way so.

320
00:17:40.886 --> 00:17:43.280
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
it'll trip you up pretty easy,

321
00:17:43.280 --> 00:17:47.170
that's why we bring it up now to try and
hopefully avoid those problems later.

322
00:17:47.170 --> 00:17:50.197
But I really think that's it
in terms of File > New and

323
00:17:50.197 --> 00:17:52.640
looking through and working through that.

324
00:17:52.640 --> 00:17:56.570
As we move, we'll probably point out some
other things throughout these episodes but

325
00:17:56.570 --> 00:17:57.970
I think that'll give us a good start.

326
00:17:59.130 --> 00:18:03.868
>> Always a good place to start, File >
New, save your file and know your formats.

327
00:18:03.868 --> 00:18:06.790
>> Yes.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I think that covers

328
00:18:06.790 --> 00:18:11.345
everything for this episode, so we're
going to wrap this one up and sign off for

329
00:18:11.345 --> 00:18:13.610
CreativeProTV, I've been
your host Vonne Smith.

330
00:18:13.610 --> 00:18:14.540
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

331
00:18:14.540 --> 00:18:15.546
>> We will see you soon.

332
00:18:15.546 --> 00:18:21.329
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Selecting elements in an Illustrator file is key.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to select multiple objects and understand the meaning of the colors shown on the screen. They also review the layers panel and selection shortcuts.
episodes.title: Basic Selections
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.352
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.352 --> 00:00:11.190
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.190 --> 00:00:15.670
Hello everyone and welcome to another
exciting edition of CreativePro.TV.

4
00:00:15.670 --> 00:00:19.570
I'm your host Vonne Smith and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:24.703
And in this episode, we're gonna get you
started with basic selection techniques.

6
00:00:24.703 --> 00:00:28.803
Sounds very simple, but there's little,
little things, like seriously,

7
00:00:28.803 --> 00:00:30.367
little things, to look for.

8
00:00:30.367 --> 00:00:33.733
And to help us find those tiny things, is
Miss Emily Ramsey, thank you so much for

9
00:00:33.733 --> 00:00:34.933
having us, having us here?

10
00:00:34.933 --> 00:00:37.475
Having you here with us.

11
00:00:37.475 --> 00:00:39.666
[LAUGHING]
>> Welcome to my home, yes, [LAUGH] no,

12
00:00:39.666 --> 00:00:41.890
I'm glad to be here, thank you.

13
00:00:41.890 --> 00:00:43.430
I knew what you were getting at,
[LAUGH] so

14
00:00:43.430 --> 00:00:48.330
yeah, we're gonna be talking
about basic selections today.

15
00:00:48.330 --> 00:00:49.736
So kinda what does that mean?

16
00:00:49.736 --> 00:00:54.044
Some of it I think sounds like, okay,
do we really need to talk about that?

17
00:00:54.044 --> 00:00:55.800
Like, can I not figure that out?

18
00:00:55.800 --> 00:00:58.794
Well, [SOUND] couple little things that
you wanna kinda point out with it.

19
00:00:58.794 --> 00:01:01.190
So let's go ahead and
pop into my screen here.

20
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:04.208
And I think we can make this one available
in one of the exercise files as well so

21
00:01:04.208 --> 00:01:05.990
you can kinda be working with this too.

22
00:01:05.990 --> 00:01:08.490
I am starting out in my black arrow tool.

23
00:01:08.490 --> 00:01:12.710
My black arrow tool is going to
be just my general selection,

24
00:01:12.710 --> 00:01:16.020
if I can say that, tool that I wanna use.

25
00:01:16.020 --> 00:01:19.150
Now I've got a couple, a little

26
00:01:21.090 --> 00:01:24.270
different things going on in
my Illustrator Artboard here.

27
00:01:24.270 --> 00:01:26.950
Just to kinda show you some of
the different selection methods, and

28
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:29.630
how this kinda changes
depending on what I have.

29
00:01:29.630 --> 00:01:31.480
Now you can kinda scroll through here.

30
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:35.350
Well, this is my cat Ollie,
well meet him again in a future episode.

31
00:01:35.350 --> 00:01:38.050
Don't worry, this will not be
your only experience with my cat.

32
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:41.000
But you can kind of see
what happens when I hover

33
00:01:41.000 --> 00:01:42.920
over each of these individual pieces.

34
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:45.500
I'm starting to see a couple
of differences here.

35
00:01:45.500 --> 00:01:48.350
Now we'll start off with just
kind of our most basic shape.

36
00:01:48.350 --> 00:01:50.640
I have a shape with a fill and a stroke.

37
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:54.603
And what we're gonna look at here is how
our arrows are gonna change depending on

38
00:01:54.603 --> 00:01:57.519
what I have kind of selected,
or what I'm hovering over.

39
00:01:57.519 --> 00:02:00.780
And what Illustrator's gonna tell
me just with my cursor icon.

40
00:02:00.780 --> 00:02:04.170
So you can see when I'm hovering over
here, and I'm hovering over nothing,

41
00:02:04.170 --> 00:02:08.810
I'm gonna get that standard just
kind of arrowhead type cursor.

42
00:02:08.810 --> 00:02:12.510
And then when I hover over something
that can be selected, I'm gonna get that

43
00:02:12.510 --> 00:02:15.490
arrowhead, but then I'm also gonna
get a little black square at the end.

44
00:02:15.490 --> 00:02:17.770
That's just kind of a little
tail that let's me know,

45
00:02:17.770 --> 00:02:21.110
okay, I'm hovering over
something that I can select.

46
00:02:21.110 --> 00:02:22.910
Now, when I go ahead and
actually select that,

47
00:02:22.910 --> 00:02:24.536
you're gonna see a couple things happen.

48
00:02:24.536 --> 00:02:28.569
One, I'm gonna see that path outline,
so you see that circle,

49
00:02:28.569 --> 00:02:30.746
I see that blue outline around it.

50
00:02:30.746 --> 00:02:34.340
Or in this case, blue, it might be
different color on something else.

51
00:02:34.340 --> 00:02:38.470
And then you're also gonna see that my
cursor changed from that v with the tail,

52
00:02:38.470 --> 00:02:41.680
to a v and kind of like a box
with a bunch of points on it.

53
00:02:41.680 --> 00:02:45.290
That's just basically letting you
know that you have a path selected.

54
00:02:45.290 --> 00:02:48.770
So that's just Illustrator's way of
giving you a couple kinda tips on that.

55
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:52.210
And you may be thinking, okay,
like do I really need to know that?

56
00:02:52.210 --> 00:02:53.210
Is that really helpful?

57
00:02:53.210 --> 00:02:55.490
Well what happens when I swirl over here?

58
00:02:55.490 --> 00:02:57.520
See how, okay,
I'm in the middle of the circle,

59
00:02:57.520 --> 00:02:59.900
shouldn't I be able to select something?

60
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:03.450
You can see Illustrator's not giving
me that tail at the end of that.

61
00:03:03.450 --> 00:03:07.000
So I'm just hovering over something and
I can't select it.

62
00:03:07.000 --> 00:03:09.030
Now why can I not select it?

63
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:13.300
Because what I'm hovering over has
a stroke color applied to it, but

64
00:03:13.300 --> 00:03:16.590
there is no fill,
there's no color in the middle of this.

65
00:03:16.590 --> 00:03:18.940
So what I have to do
because it has a stroke and

66
00:03:18.940 --> 00:03:22.550
no fill, I need to select it somewhere
on the outsiders of the path.

67
00:03:22.550 --> 00:03:25.800
I think you can also select
it in the direct center,

68
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:28.650
I typically just go somewhere
on the outside edge of the path.

69
00:03:28.650 --> 00:03:30.580
And sometimes this can
kinda throw people off,

70
00:03:30.580 --> 00:03:33.150
especially I have a pretty
thick stroke here.

71
00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:35.890
But if you don't, sometimes it
can be a little hard to select.

72
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:37.510
A little tip that I would use,

73
00:03:37.510 --> 00:03:41.500
just kinda go somewhere off to the side
in the negative space, if you will.

74
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:45.310
Click, hold, and drag over that, and
it will go ahead and select that for you.

75
00:03:45.310 --> 00:03:48.500
So if you're having trouble
pinpointing exactly where that is.

76
00:03:48.500 --> 00:03:50.740
Like we're gonna see
the same thing over here.

77
00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:53.910
It might be kinda hard, well,
of course I just did it immediately.

78
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:56.610
But I'm pretty accustomed
to working in Illustrator.

79
00:03:56.610 --> 00:03:59.760
It might be kinda hard to select that,
cuz that's a little bit thinner.

80
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:03.230
And they can even get thinner than that,
that's still only a 1 point,

81
00:04:03.230 --> 00:04:05.220
I can go down to 0.25 or
something like that.

82
00:04:05.220 --> 00:04:05.960
Just click hold and

83
00:04:05.960 --> 00:04:09.240
drag off to the side if you're having
a little bit of an issue there.

84
00:04:09.240 --> 00:04:12.572
Now a couple other things that I wanted
to point out, okay, looking at this text.

85
00:04:12.572 --> 00:04:15.201
What is text look like when I go ahead and
select it?

86
00:04:15.201 --> 00:04:18.171
Looking at that image I kinda
pointed that out before you can see,

87
00:04:18.171 --> 00:04:20.175
okay that gets that
little x through there.

88
00:04:20.175 --> 00:04:25.090
But still otherwise looks about the same,
now you'll kinda notice as I'm selecting

89
00:04:25.090 --> 00:04:29.610
these things, look at the way my control
panel changes, or that options bar.

90
00:04:29.610 --> 00:04:32.020
Or whatever you wanna call it,
this top section here.

91
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:34.980
A lot of information
about what I'm selecting

92
00:04:34.980 --> 00:04:37.720
is gonna come out in the way
that our control bar changes.

93
00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:40.850
So, you can see here if I look all
the way on the left hand side that's

94
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:42.340
letting me know that I have a linked file.

95
00:04:42.340 --> 00:04:45.560
We'll talk about what a linked
file means in a separate episode.

96
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:47.830
I select this text, it's gonna say type.

97
00:04:47.830 --> 00:04:51.157
I select this, it's gonna say symbol
static, you're gonna be like,

98
00:04:51.157 --> 00:04:52.910
what the heck does that mean?

99
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:55.355
Don't worry about it, but
that's what I've got.

100
00:04:55.355 --> 00:04:58.257
I've got another one over here,
I've got this, ellipse, but

101
00:04:58.257 --> 00:05:00.536
it's got the same issue with that center,
okay.

102
00:05:00.536 --> 00:05:03.790
I'm clicking here, I'm trying to click
in the center, nothing's happening.

103
00:05:03.790 --> 00:05:05.360
Now something else that
you'll notice with this one,

104
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:09.640
when I was selecting everything else,
I had a blue path outline.

105
00:05:09.640 --> 00:05:12.900
What happened to that blue path outline,
why is this one red?

106
00:05:12.900 --> 00:05:16.470
This one's red because technically
I'm working on a different layer.

107
00:05:16.470 --> 00:05:20.000
Now again layers are something that we're
gonna discuss in a different episode but

108
00:05:20.000 --> 00:05:23.910
I don't want it to trip you up
thinking what did I do is this one bad

109
00:05:23.910 --> 00:05:26.215
is that why it's red, is something wrong.

110
00:05:26.215 --> 00:05:29.930
No, nothing's wrong it's just that it's
kind of organized in a different way.

111
00:05:29.930 --> 00:05:33.560
So don't let that bother you, again, we'll
talk about layers in a different episode

112
00:05:33.560 --> 00:05:36.200
and you can kind of start to
understand what some of that means.

113
00:05:36.200 --> 00:05:38.060
Selecting multiple objects,

114
00:05:38.060 --> 00:05:40.950
so if I had different things
that I wanna select together.

115
00:05:40.950 --> 00:05:43.140
Obviously, you're not always
gonna just select one thing and

116
00:05:43.140 --> 00:05:44.400
then select another and move it, so on.

117
00:05:44.400 --> 00:05:46.780
Sometimes you want to
move things as a unit.

118
00:05:46.780 --> 00:05:51.530
What I can do to select multiple objects,
I can either select something and

119
00:05:51.530 --> 00:05:54.160
then shift click to select something else.

120
00:05:54.160 --> 00:05:58.700
And then shift click to select another
object and then move it from there.

121
00:05:58.700 --> 00:06:02.290
Or what I can do, and this is probably
what I do most often unless I

122
00:06:02.290 --> 00:06:04.280
really need to pinpoint something.

123
00:06:04.280 --> 00:06:07.485
I can select everything by just
click hold and drag around it.

124
00:06:07.485 --> 00:06:10.890
Kinda create a little marquis
box if you will, around it, and

125
00:06:10.890 --> 00:06:12.898
that will go ahead and
select everything for you.

126
00:06:12.898 --> 00:06:15.240
>> Yeah, and then the nice thing
about that like click, hold,

127
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:18.630
drag make a selection marquis,
you might hear us refer to,

128
00:06:18.630 --> 00:06:22.020
is you don't have to fully encompass it.

129
00:06:22.020 --> 00:06:24.270
And you can just like
just barely touch it,

130
00:06:24.270 --> 00:06:27.010
you don't have to get
all the way around it.

131
00:06:27.010 --> 00:06:28.990
So just a little tip on that one.

132
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:30.259
>> Yeah.
>> Just kinda like how

133
00:06:30.259 --> 00:06:32.546
you did with the squiggly
line up at the top.

134
00:06:32.546 --> 00:06:35.092
You didn't have to
completely go around it,

135
00:06:35.092 --> 00:06:38.777
you just got a little section of it and
it was able to select it, and

136
00:06:38.777 --> 00:06:41.870
that's a lot of the ways that I do it too,
definitely.

137
00:06:41.870 --> 00:06:45.443
But if something's way far apart and it's
like on the other side of the picture, and

138
00:06:45.443 --> 00:06:46.953
I didn't' wanna get the picture,

139
00:06:46.953 --> 00:06:50.760
that's something that I would probably use
the shift click, and that right there.

140
00:06:50.760 --> 00:06:52.910
Did you see how when she
selected that one and

141
00:06:52.910 --> 00:06:57.450
that one,
that the selection box looks really big?

142
00:06:57.450 --> 00:07:00.140
But it looks like it has like the flower,
and the text,

143
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:03.700
and the pink circle,
those aren't selected.

144
00:07:03.700 --> 00:07:07.520
Those don't have like a little
outlines that she was talking about.

145
00:07:07.520 --> 00:07:10.650
Yes, there's the bounding box
as sometimes we refer to it as,

146
00:07:10.650 --> 00:07:12.820
that's showing everything that
you could like move and size and

147
00:07:12.820 --> 00:07:16.430
stuff like that, but
those are the only two things selected.

148
00:07:16.430 --> 00:07:18.710
>> Yeah, exactly,
that's a good thing to point out.

149
00:07:18.710 --> 00:07:22.610
I don't have all this, you're not seeing
any of that kind of color outline,

150
00:07:22.610 --> 00:07:23.590
that's how that lets us know.

151
00:07:23.590 --> 00:07:28.620
Now another thing that I wanted to point
out was this concept of isolation mode.

152
00:07:28.620 --> 00:07:33.420
So what happens here if I double click on
something, whether it be an individual

153
00:07:33.420 --> 00:07:36.210
item or what I'm looking at here which
is technically known as a group.

154
00:07:36.210 --> 00:07:38.960
You can see group in
the top left hand corner.

155
00:07:38.960 --> 00:07:40.670
Don't need to know what
a group is right now.

156
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:43.970
Whether or not I double click on
an individual item or I double click over

157
00:07:43.970 --> 00:07:48.070
here onto this thing known as a group it's
gonna take me into this isolation mode.

158
00:07:48.070 --> 00:07:49.620
So how do we know we're in isolation mode?

159
00:07:49.620 --> 00:07:53.280
A couple things going on, one, everything
else in the background kind of faded out.

160
00:07:53.280 --> 00:07:58.310
Now because I was selecting a group,
two items stayed kind of highlighted.

161
00:07:58.310 --> 00:08:02.090
If I were to select on an individual item,
only one thing gets highlighted.

162
00:08:02.090 --> 00:08:04.980
But, that doesn't necessarily matter,
we can deal with that later.

163
00:08:04.980 --> 00:08:06.119
Everything else is kind of faded out.

164
00:08:06.119 --> 00:08:10.118
I also see it right here, so okay,
in this top left hand section just below

165
00:08:10.118 --> 00:08:13.227
my control bar, I have layer two and
then I have ellipse.

166
00:08:13.227 --> 00:08:15.070
That's just letting me know where I'm at.

167
00:08:15.070 --> 00:08:18.260
Now, If I get here on accident it's okay,

168
00:08:18.260 --> 00:08:20.670
all we have to do is just
double click somewhere else.

169
00:08:20.670 --> 00:08:23.850
Try not to double click on
an actual object or a path.

170
00:08:23.850 --> 00:08:26.110
Try to just double click kind
of off in your pace board or

171
00:08:26.110 --> 00:08:27.870
some of the negative space area.

172
00:08:27.870 --> 00:08:30.990
And you can go ahead and
get yourself out of isolation mode.

173
00:08:30.990 --> 00:08:34.482
So those are just a couple little things
that we wanted you guys to be aware of as

174
00:08:34.482 --> 00:08:36.064
you're working in Illustrator.

175
00:08:36.064 --> 00:08:38.800
And things that you need to kinda pay
attention to with your selection.

176
00:08:38.800 --> 00:08:42.360
So again, it may not necessarily seem like
a big deal, but when you get caught up in

177
00:08:42.360 --> 00:08:46.590
a situation where you're trying to select
something and it's just not working.

178
00:08:46.590 --> 00:08:48.460
You need to kinda be aware
of some of those tips.

179
00:08:48.460 --> 00:08:53.373
>> Yeah, and those little things,
like that dot or tail or the little

180
00:08:53.373 --> 00:08:58.570
kind of square thing on the bottom
right hand of the mouse cursor icon.

181
00:08:58.570 --> 00:09:01.494
Super tiny but
very important to understand that,

182
00:09:01.494 --> 00:09:03.740
that's where we're over something.

183
00:09:03.740 --> 00:09:07.780
And if you don't see a dot, then you're
not over it, and you can't select it.

184
00:09:07.780 --> 00:09:10.900
And the same thing when like when you're
moving, if you have something selected and

185
00:09:10.900 --> 00:09:13.990
you don't see that little like
a box with the points, or

186
00:09:13.990 --> 00:09:15.320
whatever that little thing was.

187
00:09:15.320 --> 00:09:18.190
And you try to start moving something,
it's not gonna move, okay.

188
00:09:18.190 --> 00:09:23.670
Because everything depends on what
your mouse cursor icon looks like.

189
00:09:23.670 --> 00:09:27.680
That's why I always tell people
in every single program, stop,

190
00:09:27.680 --> 00:09:29.950
take a breath, look at what's happening.

191
00:09:29.950 --> 00:09:31.010
What's on the screen?

192
00:09:31.010 --> 00:09:33.135
Cuz that's gonna tell
you what's gonna happen.

193
00:09:33.135 --> 00:09:33.800
>> Mm-hm.

194
00:09:33.800 --> 00:09:36.010
>> Yep, that's why we wanted
to throw this one out there.

195
00:09:36.010 --> 00:09:38.570
Nice little brief
introduction to selections.

196
00:09:38.570 --> 00:09:43.909
You'll be seeing you selecting all day
long or however long these episodes are.

197
00:09:43.909 --> 00:09:44.649
>> However long you wanna watch it, yeah.

198
00:09:44.649 --> 00:09:46.766
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, lots and

199
00:09:46.766 --> 00:09:48.762
lots of selections going on.

200
00:09:48.762 --> 00:09:52.697
But I think that's enough for now, we're
gonna go ahead and wrap this one up and

201
00:09:52.697 --> 00:09:56.246
signing off for our CreativePro TV,
I've been your host Vonne Smith.

202
00:09:56.246 --> 00:09:57.299
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

203
00:09:57.299 --> 00:09:57.930
>> We will see you soon.

204
00:09:57.930 --> 00:10:02.216
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to make basic shapes. They review the different tools to make open and closed paths as well as basic formatting.  They also review the meaning and importance the selection and the direct selection tools.
episodes.title: Basic Shapes and Formatting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.034 --> 00:00:06.339
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.339 --> 00:00:11.179
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.179 --> 00:00:14.605
Hello everyone, and welcome back to
another great episode of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:14.605 --> 00:00:16.147
I'm your host, Vonne Smith.

5
00:00:16.147 --> 00:00:20.822
And we're continuing on with
our Illustrator CC 2017 series.

6
00:00:20.822 --> 00:00:23.424
In this episode,
we're gonna be talking about shapes.

7
00:00:23.424 --> 00:00:25.966
And here to help us, is Miss Emily Ramsey.

8
00:00:25.966 --> 00:00:27.116
Hello, how are you doing today?

9
00:00:27.116 --> 00:00:28.056
>> Hey, good, how are you?

10
00:00:28.056 --> 00:00:29.681
>> I'm doing swimmingly.

11
00:00:29.681 --> 00:00:31.157
>> You're excited to make something?

12
00:00:31.157 --> 00:00:31.911
>> I am!

13
00:00:31.911 --> 00:00:34.652
Yes, so we're doing shapes.

14
00:00:34.652 --> 00:00:37.200
So I feel like we're going back
to kindergarten, aren't we?

15
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:39.901
>> Right, right, yeah, circle,
squares, and all that exciting stuff.

16
00:00:39.901 --> 00:00:40.451
>> Yes.
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:40.451 --> 00:00:41.412
>> And I don't have to use

18
00:00:41.412 --> 00:00:42.934
the left-handed scissors, do I?

19
00:00:42.934 --> 00:00:43.830
>> No.

20
00:00:43.830 --> 00:00:45.350
>> Okay, they didn't work.

21
00:00:45.350 --> 00:00:46.232
>> I was not so good with the scissors.

22
00:00:46.232 --> 00:00:48.218
>> Me neither, I was so
used to right-handed scissors.

23
00:00:48.218 --> 00:00:51.075
And they would always try to make,
I'm like, this doesn't work for me.

24
00:00:51.075 --> 00:00:51.818
>> Yeah.

25
00:00:51.818 --> 00:00:52.956
>> We'll be all right.

26
00:00:52.956 --> 00:00:54.697
>> I'm glad we can relate.

27
00:00:54.697 --> 00:00:57.788
>> [LAUGH]
>> So where are we going to start?

28
00:00:57.788 --> 00:00:58.845
What are we gonna do?

29
00:00:58.845 --> 00:01:03.024
>> We're just gonna start off with some
basic square, circle, all of those kind of

30
00:01:03.024 --> 00:01:06.403
simple shapes that you would do and
you think of it and you go like,

31
00:01:06.403 --> 00:01:10.240
I say the word basic and simple and
it kind of makes it seem like it's okay.

32
00:01:10.240 --> 00:01:11.370
This is kind of lame but

33
00:01:11.370 --> 00:01:15.350
really this is gonna be the foundation
of anything that you do in Illustrator.

34
00:01:15.350 --> 00:01:19.010
So you'll look at like some of these
famous logos, think about the Target logo.

35
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:23.480
The Target logo is two circles, things
like that, are all just really simple but

36
00:01:23.480 --> 00:01:26.488
are gonna be the foundation for
everything that you do in Illustrator.

37
00:01:26.488 --> 00:01:28.860
So we're gonna now start off with
creating those basic shapes,

38
00:01:28.860 --> 00:01:32.710
getting some basic editing done and then
also just kind of applying some color and

39
00:01:32.710 --> 00:01:35.120
getting into more of the fun
stuff of Illustrator.

40
00:01:35.120 --> 00:01:37.910
So let's go ahead and get started.

41
00:01:37.910 --> 00:01:39.760
In Illustrator,
what we're looking at here,

42
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:43.760
pretty much everything works off of
either a closed path or an open path.

43
00:01:43.760 --> 00:01:47.350
These aren't gonna be essential that you
know necessarily right off the bat, but

44
00:01:47.350 --> 00:01:49.280
it's just kind of nice to
know the correct terminology.

45
00:01:49.280 --> 00:01:52.540
So a closed path is gonna be,
basically what you're looking at.

46
00:01:52.540 --> 00:01:55.320
It's anything that's kind of a closed,
square shape.

47
00:01:55.320 --> 00:01:58.150
You see we have four sides, you know
you can see it's kind of filled in,

48
00:01:58.150 --> 00:01:59.320
something like that.

49
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:01.816
And open path is basically just gonna
be anything that kinda looks like

50
00:02:01.816 --> 00:02:02.920
a straight line.

51
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:06.080
So it's open, there's nothing kinda
connecting it, ending it, starting it,

52
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:07.530
all that stuff.

53
00:02:07.530 --> 00:02:09.400
So when we are making shapes,

54
00:02:09.400 --> 00:02:11.860
pretty much all this is gonna
be working off of the Tool bar.

55
00:02:11.860 --> 00:02:14.405
So we're gonna go ahead and
kinda start on the left-hand side.

56
00:02:14.405 --> 00:02:18.006
On our toolbar, pretty much any
time you see something, like for

57
00:02:18.006 --> 00:02:20.441
here I'm gonna look at the Rectangle Tool.

58
00:02:20.441 --> 00:02:24.288
But you'll notice with the Rectangle Tool
we have that little arrow there kinda next

59
00:02:24.288 --> 00:02:26.490
to it in the bottom right hand corner.

60
00:02:26.490 --> 00:02:29.510
Any time you see that arrow that basically
let's you know that you have some

61
00:02:29.510 --> 00:02:31.390
hidden shapes underneath that.

62
00:02:31.390 --> 00:02:35.170
So in our case if I click on that
Rectangle Tool and hold it down, that's

63
00:02:35.170 --> 00:02:38.280
where I'm gonna get all of the other
basic shapes that I'm working with here.

64
00:02:38.280 --> 00:02:42.270
So we have a rounded Rectangle Tool,
our Ellipse Tool, yadda yadda yadda.

65
00:02:42.270 --> 00:02:45.246
What I can also do with this,
if you're one of these kind of people,

66
00:02:45.246 --> 00:02:47.597
I could click on this arrow
on the right-hand side and

67
00:02:47.597 --> 00:02:50.337
that's gonna kinda pull it off,
so I can separate those out.

68
00:02:50.337 --> 00:02:53.262
I'm not really one to do this,
it's not my thing, but

69
00:02:53.262 --> 00:02:55.176
you can do it if you're welcome to.

70
00:02:55.176 --> 00:02:56.455
>> I love the tear off.

71
00:02:56.455 --> 00:02:57.291
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

72
00:02:57.291 --> 00:02:59.647
>> I'll have tons of them over there.

73
00:02:59.647 --> 00:03:03.240
And it's just, I don't know,
that's just the way I like to do it.

74
00:03:03.240 --> 00:03:06.011
And I'm making sure,
you still have to like click and

75
00:03:06.011 --> 00:03:09.769
hold down which is different than
Photoshop where you click and let go and

76
00:03:09.769 --> 00:03:12.432
like the little menu if you want to say,
stays out.

77
00:03:12.432 --> 00:03:15.637
You have to hold the mouse button down or
it goes away.

78
00:03:15.637 --> 00:03:18.521
>> Right, that is kind of one of
the weird things with getting used to.

79
00:03:18.521 --> 00:03:20.181
Or no, actually no I lied.

80
00:03:20.181 --> 00:03:22.038
Now I think they changed it and
you can click it.

81
00:03:22.038 --> 00:03:23.269
Yes, I'm so accustomed to it.

82
00:03:23.269 --> 00:03:25.382
I think back in the day
they had it like that.

83
00:03:25.382 --> 00:03:28.140
And then now you can click hold and
down and let go.

84
00:03:28.140 --> 00:03:32.100
But yeah, if you're one of those people,
you wanna do the tear off,

85
00:03:32.100 --> 00:03:33.207
then by all means.

86
00:03:33.207 --> 00:03:34.111
>> I think that's what it's called.

87
00:03:34.111 --> 00:03:34.971
>> Yeah, yeah.

88
00:03:34.971 --> 00:03:36.270
[LAUGH]
>> At least that's what it was called.

89
00:03:36.270 --> 00:03:38.546
They like to change the names on us a lot,
so it's like okay.

90
00:03:38.546 --> 00:03:39.649
>> Right, it's just mean.

91
00:03:39.649 --> 00:03:42.478
[LAUGH] So if you wanna do that,
you're fine.

92
00:03:42.478 --> 00:03:44.460
I'm not gonna do that today, but you can.

93
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:48.020
So pretty much anything that we're
gonna be talking about here is

94
00:03:48.020 --> 00:03:52.010
all going to apply the same,
from our Rectangle Tool to our Star Tool.

95
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:54.860
Now, the Flare Tool, totally different.

96
00:03:54.860 --> 00:03:57.850
This is gonna be the thing that's like,
I'm gonna tell you not to push the button.

97
00:03:57.850 --> 00:03:59.370
And because I told you
not to push the button,

98
00:03:59.370 --> 00:04:01.810
you're gonna be like, yeah,
I wanna open up my Flare Tool.

99
00:04:01.810 --> 00:04:02.530
And I understand.

100
00:04:02.530 --> 00:04:05.040
But the Flare Tool, for
some reason, is just way different.

101
00:04:05.040 --> 00:04:08.010
So for right now, let's start with
a rectangle through the square and

102
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:09.150
kinda go through there.

103
00:04:09.150 --> 00:04:11.410
So anything that I'm gonna say,
I'm gonna start off with a Rectangle Tool,

104
00:04:11.410 --> 00:04:13.980
but anything I'm gonna say
will apply to all of these.

105
00:04:13.980 --> 00:04:16.050
So I'm gonna grab my Rectangle Tool and

106
00:04:16.050 --> 00:04:19.450
just to create a basic shape
we have two different methods.

107
00:04:19.450 --> 00:04:21.670
We can either single click or
click, hold, and drag.

108
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:23.010
So I'll start off with a single click.

109
00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:24.340
I've grabbed my Rectangle Tool.

110
00:04:24.340 --> 00:04:28.940
I'm gonna single click anywhere on my
art board, or really anywhere is fine.

111
00:04:28.940 --> 00:04:31.460
And the nice thing about this
method is that you can go ahead and

112
00:04:31.460 --> 00:04:32.850
type in some specific dimensions.

113
00:04:32.850 --> 00:04:35.910
So if you know,
I have to have a three by five rectangle.

114
00:04:35.910 --> 00:04:36.970
You can go ahead and type that in.

115
00:04:36.970 --> 00:04:39.040
So I'll type in three by five.

116
00:04:39.040 --> 00:04:39.990
Go ahead and hit OK.

117
00:04:39.990 --> 00:04:42.556
Well, bam,
I have a three by five rectangle.

118
00:04:42.556 --> 00:04:46.462
Or if you're like me and
maybe you just kinda wanna play around and

119
00:04:46.462 --> 00:04:49.030
fiddle with it till you
find what you like.

120
00:04:49.030 --> 00:04:51.700
You can click hold and drag and

121
00:04:51.700 --> 00:04:55.350
kinda just create something
that looks about appropriate.

122
00:04:55.350 --> 00:04:57.500
So those are your two different methods.

123
00:04:57.500 --> 00:04:59.030
Now with these methods, and

124
00:04:59.030 --> 00:05:01.790
I'm just gonna delete these,
I'll show you how to do that in a second,

125
00:05:01.790 --> 00:05:04.640
you have two different kind of keyword
shortcuts that you can work with.

126
00:05:04.640 --> 00:05:06.110
So two different options.

127
00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:07.930
One, say I wanna make a perfect square.

128
00:05:07.930 --> 00:05:10.640
Right here I've been kinda
just doing whatever, but

129
00:05:10.640 --> 00:05:14.630
if I wanna make a perfect square, what I'm
gonna do is I'm gonna hold down my Shift

130
00:05:14.630 --> 00:05:17.010
key as I'm drawing out and
creating a new square.

131
00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:21.220
So anytime I hold down my Shift key in
Illustrator, or other Adobe programs,

132
00:05:21.220 --> 00:05:25.492
it's pretty similar, what's that's gonna
do is it's gonna maintain proportion.

133
00:05:25.492 --> 00:05:28.340
So that's gonna be a little bit different
later when we get into editing but

134
00:05:28.340 --> 00:05:33.070
as far as creating a new shape,
it's going to create a perfect square or

135
00:05:33.070 --> 00:05:38.770
again likewise perfect circle, perfect
star if you wanted to, anything like that.

136
00:05:38.770 --> 00:05:40.422
So that's definitely one
that you wanna remember.

137
00:05:40.422 --> 00:05:42.080
You wanna go ahead and
remember your Shift key.

138
00:05:42.080 --> 00:05:46.575
Now the other one, you'll notice that all
of your shapes by default are created from

139
00:05:46.575 --> 00:05:49.220
the top left hand corner down.

140
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:51.420
If for
some reason you're not feeling that,

141
00:05:51.420 --> 00:05:53.560
that's not what you wanna
work with that day.

142
00:05:53.560 --> 00:05:56.690
What you can also do is you can also
hold down your Alt or Option key.

143
00:05:56.690 --> 00:05:59.400
It's gonna be Alt on a PC,
Option on a Mac.

144
00:05:59.400 --> 00:06:02.480
Or if you're like me I'm on a Mac and
I call it Alt anyway.

145
00:06:02.480 --> 00:06:06.700
You can hold down your Alt or Option key
to create something from the center out.

146
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:10.390
So that's also an option that
you have when working here.

147
00:06:10.390 --> 00:06:12.380
Now, as far as editing goes,

148
00:06:12.380 --> 00:06:15.310
editing is always gonna be
done in our Black Arrow Tool.

149
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:17.139
So you have to remember, back to black.

150
00:06:17.139 --> 00:06:18.672
You were the one that taught me that.

151
00:06:18.672 --> 00:06:19.194
>> Yes.

152
00:06:19.194 --> 00:06:21.377
>> [LAUGH]
>> I was like, she remembers.

153
00:06:21.377 --> 00:06:24.329
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's my favorite little saying.

154
00:06:24.329 --> 00:06:25.374
Back to black.

155
00:06:25.374 --> 00:06:28.625
That's always gonna be where I'm
gonna do my editing in Illustrator.

156
00:06:28.625 --> 00:06:33.262
And so what we have, Illustrator it's
kinda nice they give these little

157
00:06:33.262 --> 00:06:37.762
kinda visual cues to what you're
gonna be working with your editing.

158
00:06:37.762 --> 00:06:42.215
So you'll see when I have just kinda
hanging out over here anywhere my art

159
00:06:42.215 --> 00:06:45.062
board my workspace,
I have just kinda that V,

160
00:06:45.062 --> 00:06:48.840
that V is just kinda my neutral cursor,
if you will.

161
00:06:48.840 --> 00:06:52.938
When I hover over something that can be
selected you'll see a hover over here,

162
00:06:52.938 --> 00:06:54.440
I get a little dot at the end.

163
00:06:54.440 --> 00:06:56.977
That's just letting me know that I'm
hovering over something that can

164
00:06:56.977 --> 00:06:57.491
be selected.

165
00:06:57.491 --> 00:07:00.631
And then when I go ahead and
select that I'm gonna get to that V but

166
00:07:00.631 --> 00:07:03.847
then I'm gonna get kinda like
a little box thing there at the end.

167
00:07:03.847 --> 00:07:07.839
And that's just letting me know that the
shape that I'm hovering over is something

168
00:07:07.839 --> 00:07:08.932
that I have selected.

169
00:07:08.932 --> 00:07:12.171
Now you can also see it because
you see the blue path outlines.

170
00:07:12.171 --> 00:07:14.806
You know they're gonna have several
different ways that they're kinda giving

171
00:07:14.806 --> 00:07:15.404
this away to you.

172
00:07:15.404 --> 00:07:18.422
But then when you'll see when you
kinda hover around, basically for

173
00:07:18.422 --> 00:07:21.141
right now I'm just gonna say
hover around these white boxes.

174
00:07:21.141 --> 00:07:25.370
When I hover around these white boxes I
see kinda some of the standard things that

175
00:07:25.370 --> 00:07:26.640
you're kinda used to.

176
00:07:26.640 --> 00:07:28.660
So I can see if I hover here,

177
00:07:28.660 --> 00:07:33.458
I get the double pointed arrows in
the corner, double pointed arrows there.

178
00:07:33.458 --> 00:07:37.920
If you hover slightly on the outside,
you can see the rotate option.

00:18:25.490 --> 00:18:28.880
I can change my stroke color,
I can change my stroke options.

402
00:18:28.880 --> 00:18:30.440
I'm gonna take off this dash line,

403
00:18:30.440 --> 00:18:33.740
just cuz I think it'll show
it a little bit better.

404
00:18:33.740 --> 00:18:35.410
And I'm gonna go ahead and
show you that Round Cap.

405
00:18:35.410 --> 00:18:39.700
You see how that kinda rounds it off
a little bit, you can see also, I believe,

406
00:18:39.700 --> 00:18:42.800
Projecting Cap is the other
option that you have.

407
00:18:42.800 --> 00:18:44.490
And you can kinda see
how that's gonna change.

408
00:18:44.490 --> 00:18:45.870
Now, you're not gonna see the alignment or

409
00:18:45.870 --> 00:18:49.970
the corner as much with this one
as you are with a closed path.

410
00:18:49.970 --> 00:18:51.597
But, you will see it in your open ones.

411
00:18:51.597 --> 00:18:54.936
>> Yeah, and way when you first started,
that it was blue and dash,

412
00:18:54.936 --> 00:18:58.480
that was because it's kind of
remembering like the format you used.

413
00:18:58.480 --> 00:19:00.128
>> Yes.
>> It's not gonna always do that if you're

414
00:19:00.128 --> 00:19:01.540
starting off with a blank document.

415
00:19:01.540 --> 00:19:03.197
>> Yeah, yeah, thank you for
pointing that out, yeah,

416
00:19:03.197 --> 00:19:04.613
you're not always gonna
get a blue dash line.

417
00:19:04.613 --> 00:19:06.605
>> [LAUGH]
>> Wouldn't that be fun, every time,

418
00:19:06.605 --> 00:19:07.790
blue dash line.

419
00:19:07.790 --> 00:19:10.808
No it'll pretty much just start off
with whatever settings that you had

420
00:19:10.808 --> 00:19:11.469
the last time.

421
00:19:11.469 --> 00:19:13.936
>> And
another thing that has tripped me up,

422
00:19:13.936 --> 00:19:18.235
like if I don't have anything selected and
everything is clicked off and

423
00:19:18.235 --> 00:19:21.915
I start changing stuff up in
the control panel or up at the top.

424
00:19:21.915 --> 00:19:27.245
Then that becomes like the default setting
for the next thing that you draw and

425
00:19:27.245 --> 00:19:32.830
it kind of, I'm like why does it keep on
going black or why is it always being red.

426
00:19:32.830 --> 00:19:37.728
Deselect everything, change everything
back up at the top to where you want it to

427
00:19:37.728 --> 00:19:41.130
start as the new default,
and then it goes from there.

428
00:19:41.130 --> 00:19:45.210
So that's just trial and error of
things that I've learned of like it'll

429
00:19:45.210 --> 00:19:47.193
drive you crazy until you
realize what you did.

430
00:19:47.193 --> 00:19:48.204
[LAUGH]
>> All right,

431
00:19:48.204 --> 00:19:50.410
that has driven me nuts several times.

432
00:19:50.410 --> 00:19:53.600
So yeah, I'm glad you pointed that out,
yeah, just always make sure to,

433
00:19:53.600 --> 00:19:58.740
if I have nothing selected, and I go here,
and change whatever, these colors.

434
00:19:58.740 --> 00:20:03.860
The next time I go to do something, I'm
gonna be like, why is that pink and blue.

435
00:20:03.860 --> 00:20:05.550
>> Yeah.
>> And, it will drive you nuts.

436
00:20:05.550 --> 00:20:09.300
But I think that was pretty much it for,
as far as getting started,

437
00:20:09.300 --> 00:20:11.200
for our closed paths and our open paths.

438
00:20:11.200 --> 00:20:14.610
So, yeah, just kinda play around and have
fun and again, remember you can really

439
00:20:14.610 --> 00:20:19.750
create so many things,
with just that basic, basic material.

440
00:20:19.750 --> 00:20:22.620
And again anything we did
with our closed paths,

441
00:20:22.620 --> 00:20:25.780
same thing is gonna apply to circles.

442
00:20:25.780 --> 00:20:30.620
I'm trying to click down on some paper
here, so it's not wanting to be my friend.

443
00:20:30.620 --> 00:20:33.680
Circles, polygons, stars,
anything like that, so

444
00:20:33.680 --> 00:20:35.700
that's all gonna apply to the same thing.

445
00:20:35.700 --> 00:20:38.220
>> Awesome,
well I mean that's a great way to start.

446
00:20:38.220 --> 00:20:39.890
We've done our circles and our squares,

447
00:20:39.890 --> 00:20:42.120
I feel like we've maybe
graduated kindergarten.

448
00:20:42.120 --> 00:20:45.347
[LAUGH] And now we're gonna move on
to first grade and second grade and

449
00:20:45.347 --> 00:20:48.700
do a lot more advanced things, but
it's always a good place to start.

450
00:20:48.700 --> 00:20:53.410
And this is also a good place to end, so
we're gonna go ahead and wrap this up.

451
00:20:53.410 --> 00:20:56.110
Signing off for CreativeProTV I've
been your host, Vonne Smith.

452
00:20:56.110 --> 00:20:56.960
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

453
00:20:56.960 --> 00:20:57.903
>> And we'll see you soon.

454
00:20:57.903 --> 00:21:01.270
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue with shapes showing the star, line, arc, spiral, rectangular grid, and polar grid tools. They show some handy shortcuts to use with these tools as well as new ways to close paths with the line tool.
episodes.title: Basic Shapes and Formatting Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:05.302 --> 00:00:07.361
[SOUND]

2
00:00:07.361 --> 00:00:11.075
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.075 --> 00:00:15.040
Hello, and welcome back to another
exciting edition of CREATIVEPRO.TV.

4
00:00:15.040 --> 00:00:19.571
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and
this is Illustrator CC 2017, and

5
00:00:19.571 --> 00:00:23.227
we are on part two of creating
basic shapes and formating.

6
00:00:23.227 --> 00:00:25.837
So we're kinda still in
kindergarten right now,

7
00:00:25.837 --> 00:00:28.640
we're like in the second
semester of kindergarten.

8
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:29.584
>> Yes.
>> I don't even know if

9
00:00:29.584 --> 00:00:32.475
they have semesters in kindergarten,
[LAUGH] but here to help us is Ms.

10
00:00:32.475 --> 00:00:33.790
Emily Ramsey, hello.

11
00:00:33.790 --> 00:00:34.780
>> Hey, thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:34.780 --> 00:00:38.415
Yeah, we're moving on to like later
in the school year of kindergarten.

13
00:00:38.415 --> 00:00:39.402
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> I like that,
I like that.

14
00:00:39.402 --> 00:00:43.006
Now, this is actually, it's really fun,
it's still our basic shapes and

15
00:00:43.006 --> 00:00:43.690
formatting.

16
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:46.762
But this is actually one of the tricks
that we're going to start off with with

17
00:00:46.762 --> 00:00:49.175
our basic shapes is one of my
favorite things to talk about.

18
00:00:49.175 --> 00:00:52.022
And I don't know,
I just think it's so exciting.

19
00:00:52.022 --> 00:00:53.330
>> It's the star tool, isn't it?

20
00:00:53.330 --> 00:00:53.898
>> Yeah, yeah, yeah!
>> I know, yay!

21
00:00:53.898 --> 00:00:55.148
>> She's like, I know it's coming,
I know it's coming. >> [LAUGH]

22
00:00:55.148 --> 00:00:55.658
>> So yeah, so

23
00:00:55.658 --> 00:00:58.006
we're going to start off
with those basic shapes, and

24
00:00:58.006 --> 00:01:00.260
kind of expanding upon
that a little bit more.

25
00:01:00.260 --> 00:01:02.833
But then we're going to get a little
bit more into those open paths.

26
00:01:02.833 --> 00:01:07.001
So you guys may have noticed that there
are some hidden things under our line

27
00:01:07.001 --> 00:01:07.870
segment tool.

28
00:01:07.870 --> 00:01:09.773
And we're gonna kind of expand
upon those a little bit more.

29
00:01:09.773 --> 00:01:14.180
So what we're gonna do, we're gonna start
off with the star tool, the exciting one.

30
00:01:14.180 --> 00:01:16.767
Now that I've kind of gotten
all the hype up about it.

31
00:01:16.767 --> 00:01:20.619
[LAUGH] And the first thing that we need
to do, you'll see I have no fill and

32
00:01:20.619 --> 00:01:22.700
no stroke applied here.

33
00:01:22.700 --> 00:01:25.716
I could do this with no fill and
no stroke, but what's gonna happen is,

34
00:01:25.716 --> 00:01:26.991
I'm not gonna see anything.

35
00:01:26.991 --> 00:01:31.624
So what I wanna do is I wanna go ahead and
just find a fill color, it doesn't matter,

36
00:01:31.624 --> 00:01:34.623
or if you want to get crazy,
you can do a stroke color.

37
00:01:34.623 --> 00:01:37.067
I'm just gonna make it orange,
and then, like I said,

38
00:01:37.067 --> 00:01:38.950
we're gonna start off with our star tool.

39
00:01:38.950 --> 00:01:42.798
So we're gonna go ahead and just click and
hold on that rectangle tool.

40
00:01:42.798 --> 00:01:46.027
And, again, you can let go, we remembered
that little handy trick there.

41
00:01:46.027 --> 00:01:46.932
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

42
00:01:46.932 --> 00:01:48.605
>> Click and hold on our rectangle tool,

43
00:01:48.605 --> 00:01:50.810
and then our star tool is
hidden underneath that.

44
00:01:50.810 --> 00:01:53.588
It's just above that forbidden
flair tool that we talked about.

45
00:01:53.588 --> 00:01:56.744
So, I'm going to grab that star tool,
and then, of course,

46
00:01:56.744 --> 00:01:58.160
it just works the same way.

47
00:01:58.160 --> 00:02:00.709
We can either click hold and
drag, single click,

48
00:02:00.709 --> 00:02:03.148
you can do whatever you
want to create the star.

49
00:02:03.148 --> 00:02:06.089
But, where it gets really
exciting is when we add

50
00:02:06.089 --> 00:02:08.570
in our keyboard shortcuts with this.

51
00:02:08.570 --> 00:02:12.486
So, what we can do, say we have
a typical five-point star to begin with.

52
00:02:12.486 --> 00:02:16.400
But what if you want something with all
kinds of crazy little points on it?

53
00:02:17.420 --> 00:02:21.617
Fun thing, what we can do, as I am click,
hold, drag, creating my star,

54
00:02:21.617 --> 00:02:23.830
I can use a couple keyboard shortcuts.

55
00:02:23.830 --> 00:02:27.760
So similar to the way that we held down
the shift key to create a perfect square.

56
00:02:27.760 --> 00:02:31.197
We're now going to use, we're going
to move over on our keyboard, and

57
00:02:31.197 --> 00:02:32.704
use the up and down arrow keys.

58
00:02:32.704 --> 00:02:35.603
If I, while I'm creating my star.

59
00:02:35.603 --> 00:02:36.594
>> And
you're still holding the mouse right now?

60
00:02:36.594 --> 00:02:37.719
>> Yes.
>> You do not let go.

61
00:02:37.719 --> 00:02:42.890
>> Yes, that's essential, I'm still
holding down my mouse, thank you.

62
00:02:42.890 --> 00:02:46.842
I am going to hold my up arrow key,
or click my up arrow key, and

63
00:02:46.842 --> 00:02:49.124
you can see I can add my star.

64
00:02:49.124 --> 00:02:50.745
>> [LAUGH]
>> I love it.

65
00:02:50.745 --> 00:02:52.744
[LAUGH]
>> Whenever I teach this to people,

66
00:02:52.744 --> 00:02:53.284
they're like!

67
00:02:53.284 --> 00:02:53.877
>> Yeah.

68
00:02:53.877 --> 00:02:56.641
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think this is the moment where people

69
00:02:56.641 --> 00:02:58.777
kind of see how fun Illustrator can be,

70
00:02:58.777 --> 00:03:01.600
cuz it really is just
a really fun program.

71
00:03:01.600 --> 00:03:05.566
And this is kind of where it's that
breakthrough moment, it's like, my gosh,

72
00:03:05.566 --> 00:03:07.790
look at all the cool things we can do,
so yeah.

73
00:03:07.790 --> 00:03:10.480
>> But yet, there's more, aren't there?

74
00:03:10.480 --> 00:03:11.657
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, there's so

75
00:03:11.657 --> 00:03:13.260
much more, yeah.

76
00:03:13.260 --> 00:03:14.992
So I'll do that again,
just so you can kind of see.

77
00:03:14.992 --> 00:03:19.783
I know sometimes it's a little bit wonky
to get used to holding down your mouse,

78
00:03:19.783 --> 00:03:22.440
but also clicking things on your keyboard.

79
00:03:22.440 --> 00:03:26.067
I think that's kind of one of the just
kind of learning curves when you're

80
00:03:26.067 --> 00:03:27.363
working in Illustrator.

81
00:03:27.363 --> 00:03:29.936
Especially Illustrator, but
other Adobe programs as well.

82
00:03:29.936 --> 00:03:32.325
So what I'm going to do,
I'm going to start off the same way.

83
00:03:32.325 --> 00:03:35.637
Now you'll notice, when I click,
hold and drag again,

84
00:03:35.637 --> 00:03:38.190
I'm not going back to
that five point star.

85
00:03:38.190 --> 00:03:41.030
Illustrator is going to keep those
settings that we had before, so

86
00:03:41.030 --> 00:03:42.663
I don't know how many points this is.

87
00:03:42.663 --> 00:03:46.612
I'm not going to count, but you can see
it kind of kept their same setting.

88
00:03:46.612 --> 00:03:51.451
So, again, click, hold, drag, still
holding down my mouse, I'd show you, but

89
00:03:51.451 --> 00:03:53.240
I just can't lift up that far.

90
00:03:53.240 --> 00:03:56.337
And so what I'm gonna do now,
I'm gonna use my down arrow key,

91
00:03:56.337 --> 00:03:59.230
while I'm still holding down my mouse.

92
00:03:59.230 --> 00:04:02.737
And I can see I can kinda get back
down to that original five point star.

93
00:04:02.737 --> 00:04:07.193
So it is important to remember that
these settings are going to keep, so

94
00:04:07.193 --> 00:04:10.335
if I do something like this,
and then go in later.

95
00:04:10.335 --> 00:04:13.356
Way later, an hour so from now,
continue to work, and

96
00:04:13.356 --> 00:04:17.181
then I'm gonna be like, why am I
getting all these points on my star?

97
00:04:17.181 --> 00:04:20.110
It's because Illustrator is
going to remember that, so,

98
00:04:20.110 --> 00:04:21.640
that's one important thing.

99
00:04:21.640 --> 00:04:25.672
And again, make sure that you're
still holding down your mouse while

100
00:04:25.672 --> 00:04:28.004
you are using that up and down arrow key.

101
00:04:28.004 --> 00:04:31.839
There's another method for doing this,
if that's not working for you, and

102
00:04:31.839 --> 00:04:33.670
we'll talk about that in a second.

103
00:04:33.670 --> 00:04:36.752
So, what I'm gonna do now, though, so

104
00:04:36.752 --> 00:04:42.207
you'll see right now all of the kind
of points are creating it the same.

105
00:04:42.207 --> 00:04:46.773
Technically, the radius is the correct
term here, I like to call them legs,

106
00:04:46.773 --> 00:04:49.950
because that's basically
what they look like to me.

107
00:04:49.950 --> 00:04:52.024
They're all kind of
creating at the same point,

108
00:04:52.024 --> 00:04:54.054
what if I wanted to extend
those out really far?

109
00:04:54.054 --> 00:04:57.108
So you get kind of like a-
>> Long legged star.

110
00:04:57.108 --> 00:04:58.505
[LAUGH]
>> Right, right, yeah.

111
00:04:58.505 --> 00:05:02.501
I'm thinking of a children's book with
a little starry night or something, yeah.

112
00:05:02.501 --> 00:05:04.973
>> Or the first or, long legged star.

113
00:05:04.973 --> 00:05:06.815
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, long legged star.

114
00:05:06.815 --> 00:05:09.417
So if you want a long legged star,
or a short legged star,

115
00:05:09.417 --> 00:05:12.690
if you want a short star, what you can do,
it's gonna be very similar.

116
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:15.280
I'm gonna click, hold and
drag to create a new star.

117
00:05:15.280 --> 00:05:19.868
But this time I'm gonna hold down my
Command or CTRL key on my keyboard, so

118
00:05:19.868 --> 00:05:21.801
Command on a Mac, CTRL on a PC.

119
00:05:21.801 --> 00:05:24.734
If I hold that down, again, same method,

120
00:05:24.734 --> 00:05:28.570
I'm holding down my mouse
right now as I'm using this.

121
00:05:28.570 --> 00:05:31.090
And then I'm just kinda
slowly dragging out.

122
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:34.800
And you don't wanna go crazy,
I mean, you could, that works.

123
00:05:34.800 --> 00:05:39.786
But if you just kinda slowly drag in and
out, what you'll see is that I can make

124
00:05:39.786 --> 00:05:42.277
that long-legged star-
>> [LAUGH]

125
00:05:42.277 --> 00:05:44.372
>> That I was looking at, and likewise,

126
00:05:44.372 --> 00:05:46.120
this setting is gonna keep.

127
00:05:46.120 --> 00:05:49.642
But if I click, hold, and drag, and
then hold down my Command or CTRL key and

128
00:05:49.642 --> 00:05:52.140
drag in,
I can make something that's a lot smaller.

129
00:05:52.140 --> 00:05:56.574
That looks more like a ribbon banner.

130
00:05:56.574 --> 00:05:58.385
>> Yeah, like the little star.

131
00:05:58.385 --> 00:05:58.916
>> Like an award.

132
00:05:58.916 --> 00:06:01.028
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly, and

133
00:06:01.028 --> 00:06:05.110
you see those in a PowerPoint,
or what have you.

134
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:09.609
I think they have to call them banners or
award thingies, thingies,

135
00:06:09.609 --> 00:06:13.348
that's exactly what they called them,
but I know them.

136
00:06:13.348 --> 00:06:15.121
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, thank you, yes,

137
00:06:15.121 --> 00:06:17.179
that's exactly what I was going for,
so yeah, so

138
00:06:17.179 --> 00:06:18.800
that's another option that you have.

139
00:06:18.800 --> 00:06:22.906
So your two keyboard shortcuts, it's going
to be while you're holding down the mouse,

140
00:06:22.906 --> 00:06:23.848
that is essential.

141
00:06:23.848 --> 00:06:27.719
Using your up and
down arrow key to add points to your star,

142
00:06:27.719 --> 00:06:30.035
or using your Command or CTRL key.

143
00:06:30.035 --> 00:06:33.098
Command on a Mac, CTRL on a PC,
to extend the legs.

144
00:06:33.098 --> 00:06:38.300
Or technically the radius, if we wanna
get really technical here, of that star.

145
00:06:38.300 --> 00:06:41.987
>> And I think that you could also do like
an alt in there that does some weird thing

146
00:06:41.987 --> 00:06:43.983
to where it kinda goes inward or outward.

147
00:06:43.983 --> 00:06:48.120
But there was something that I always
would do, cuz people would go ahead.

148
00:06:48.120 --> 00:06:52.748
And they'd make a whole bunch of
points and super long-legged stars.

149
00:06:52.748 --> 00:06:58.340
And then they'd go back like,
I have no idea how to even reset it.

150
00:06:58.340 --> 00:07:01.497
So I'm like, well, if you just kinda go
back and redo what you did, they're like,

151
00:07:01.497 --> 00:07:02.257
I don't remember.

152
00:07:02.257 --> 00:07:04.770
So a little kind of key point that I know.

153
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:06.814
If you click with the star tool,

154
00:07:06.814 --> 00:07:11.837
this is kinda just like a rule of thumb to
kinda get back to as basic as you could.

155
00:07:11.837 --> 00:07:13.725
So, if you don't mind,
go ahead and click there.

156
00:07:13.725 --> 00:07:14.849
>> Yeah.
>> And just make the star and

157
00:07:14.849 --> 00:07:16.810
then bring up the dialogue
box that comes up.

158
00:07:16.810 --> 00:07:17.689
>> Yeah, just single click.
>> Yeah.

159
00:07:17.689 --> 00:07:20.546
>> Yeah.
>> In that radius one, radius two,

160
00:07:20.546 --> 00:07:23.290
you do one as a whole, one as a half.

161
00:07:23.290 --> 00:07:28.789
So if you did four, two, and five,
that's, anything to kind of,

162
00:07:28.789 --> 00:07:34.784
or two, one, and five, or one, one and
a half, five, you get the idea.

163
00:07:34.784 --> 00:07:41.680
That would take you back to the most basic
five pointed star that you can get to.

164
00:07:41.680 --> 00:07:46.208
And I think, if I remember correctly,
if you do the star tool from now on,

165
00:07:46.208 --> 00:07:48.336
it should remember that setting.

We'll see we have our rectangular
grid tool and our polar grid tool.

386
00:18:38.390 --> 00:18:41.310
I may kinda do these in tandem here.

387
00:18:41.310 --> 00:18:43.887
With our rectangular grid tool,
what we're gonna get?

388
00:18:43.887 --> 00:18:45.490
A rectangular grid.

389
00:18:45.490 --> 00:18:50.310
Hold down your Shift key if you
wanna create it a perfect grid.

390
00:18:50.310 --> 00:18:54.720
Polar grid, it's gonna be kinda of
the same thing but in a circle.

391
00:18:54.720 --> 00:18:56.900
Hold down my Shift key if
I want to make it perfect.

392
00:18:56.900 --> 00:19:00.010
Now why am I doing these at the same time?

393
00:19:00.010 --> 00:19:04.150
Well one, because they're going to use the
same keyboard shortcuts that we've done.

394
00:19:04.150 --> 00:19:09.120
So I can hold down my up and
down arrow keys to add boxes.

395
00:19:09.120 --> 00:19:12.420
Or even, this one's gonna introduce
our right and left arrow keys, so

396
00:19:12.420 --> 00:19:16.300
you can see it kind of adds more rows or
columns depending on what you're doing.

397
00:19:16.300 --> 00:19:20.101
But same method, I'm holding down my
mouse, up arrow key or right arrow key,

398
00:19:20.101 --> 00:19:22.073
left arrow key, whatever you wanna do.

399
00:19:22.073 --> 00:19:24.640
Same thing, polar grid tool.

400
00:19:24.640 --> 00:19:26.280
Gonna grab that one out.

401
00:19:26.280 --> 00:19:30.127
I'm gonna hold down my up arrow
key to add spirals, the right or

402
00:19:30.127 --> 00:19:33.700
left arrow key to add pie slices
is what I'm gonna call it.

403
00:19:33.700 --> 00:19:37.190
[LAUGH] That's the mathematical term,
right?

404
00:19:37.190 --> 00:19:38.490
So we can go ahead and add that.

405
00:19:38.490 --> 00:19:39.990
Now why am I doing these at the same time?

406
00:19:41.010 --> 00:19:43.486
They don't really look all that exciting,
right?

407
00:19:43.486 --> 00:19:46.193
So we're gonna get some spiral tools,
a star,

408
00:19:46.193 --> 00:19:49.340
you can create things that look kinda fun.

409
00:19:49.340 --> 00:19:52.916
The thing about these two is that they're
really the most helpful once you know

410
00:19:52.916 --> 00:19:54.878
some other advanced Illustrator skills.

411
00:19:54.878 --> 00:19:57.556
So we're gonna get things later,
like expanding and

412
00:19:57.556 --> 00:20:01.560
all this stuff, where you can actually
really use this to your advantage.

413
00:20:01.560 --> 00:20:03.876
You can create those pie slices and
things like that.

414
00:20:03.876 --> 00:20:08.230
But for right now, based on the skills
we have, this is the level we're at.

415
00:20:08.230 --> 00:20:09.610
Which is still great.

416
00:20:09.610 --> 00:20:13.940
I'm not saying that's bad, but
that's kinda of our basis there and

417
00:20:13.940 --> 00:20:15.340
then we'll expand on it later.

418
00:20:15.340 --> 00:20:17.349
>> Yeah, anytime I would teach these,
people were like, so

419
00:20:17.349 --> 00:20:18.297
why would you even do this?

420
00:20:18.297 --> 00:20:21.302
And it's like, well,
that comes a little later.

421
00:20:21.302 --> 00:20:25.468
If you think about if I'm
making an infograph and

422
00:20:25.468 --> 00:20:28.930
I wanted to have a pie chart or whatever.

423
00:20:28.930 --> 00:20:33.052
You could use this to kinda give you
three equal parts or four equal parts or

424
00:20:33.052 --> 00:20:36.720
you're designing something that you
need things in boxes in a sense.

425
00:20:36.720 --> 00:20:39.387
You can use these almost like a grid,
like a outline, but

426
00:20:39.387 --> 00:20:40.840
then you can use it to color it.

427
00:20:40.840 --> 00:20:45.014
There's a lot of different functionalities
that you can have with it besides right

428
00:20:45.014 --> 00:20:47.710
now, it's just kinda like okay,
that's all it is.

429
00:20:47.710 --> 00:20:49.280
>> Right, right.

430
00:20:49.280 --> 00:20:49.951
>> So just remember that for
later down the road.

431
00:20:49.951 --> 00:20:51.232
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah,

432
00:20:51.232 --> 00:20:53.232
it's just not as fun to
look at as a spiral.

433
00:20:53.232 --> 00:20:53.949
>> Yeah.

434
00:20:53.949 --> 00:20:55.378
[LAUGH]
>> So yeah, exactly,

435
00:20:55.378 --> 00:20:58.310
there are cool things that you
can do later down the road.

436
00:20:58.310 --> 00:21:02.273
But with that, I think I'm gonna leave us
there, and then when we get back later,

437
00:21:02.273 --> 00:21:05.031
we can kind of start to expand
upon some of these things and

438
00:21:05.031 --> 00:21:07.170
move into some fun stuff with Illustrator.

439
00:21:07.170 --> 00:21:07.882
So-
>> Yeah.

440
00:21:07.882 --> 00:21:08.678
>> Yeah.

441
00:21:08.678 --> 00:21:11.557
>> Yeah, well now I think we can
move on to first grade, right?

442
00:21:11.557 --> 00:21:12.952
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes, now we're ready, yeah.

443
00:21:12.952 --> 00:21:14.366
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, well I mean, and

444
00:21:14.366 --> 00:21:17.860
those tools that are in there,
like you said, they are fun.

445
00:21:17.860 --> 00:21:22.654
And there are those hidden shortcuts that
you might not know if the star tool,

446
00:21:22.654 --> 00:21:27.420
the spiral, that can lead you to
create some more very creative things.

447
00:21:27.420 --> 00:21:31.813
I've choose spiral almost like
a background kind of like a pattern and

448
00:21:31.813 --> 00:21:33.009
it's a lot of fun.

449
00:21:33.009 --> 00:21:37.030
So I hope you all are gonna have a lot of
fun with those tools too, tools too wow.

450
00:21:37.030 --> 00:21:39.615
>> [LAUGH]
>> I almost tripped up on it, yeah.

451
00:21:39.615 --> 00:21:42.692
[LAUGH] All right, well we're gonna
go ahead and wrap this one up.

452
00:21:42.692 --> 00:21:44.480
Signing off for CreativeProTV.

453
00:21:44.480 --> 00:21:45.997
I've been your host Vonne Smith.

454
00:21:45.997 --> 00:21:47.230
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

455
00:21:47.230 --> 00:21:51.093
>> And we'll see you soon.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne review basic text. They discuss the difference between area type and point type and how easy it is now to convert using the selection tool.  They demonstrate basic character and paragraph formatting and how to use the type panels
episodes.title: Basic Text
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:06.267
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.267 --> 00:00:11.208
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.208 --> 00:00:11.891
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode of CreativePro TV.

4
00:00:11.891 --> 00:00:17.430
I'm your host Vonne Smith and
this is Illustrator CC 2017,

5
00:00:17.430 --> 00:00:23.185
and in this episode, we're going
to be talking about basic text.

6
00:00:23.185 --> 00:00:28.425
Just, type type type away, so here to help
us is Miss Emily Ramsey, how is it going?

7
00:00:28.425 --> 00:00:30.810
>> Yes, I'm going to type type type away,
just like that.

8
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:32.025
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah so

9
00:00:32.025 --> 00:00:34.300
we're gonna go ahead and
actually write some stuff.

10
00:00:36.620 --> 00:00:39.745
>> I mean, because if you know
how to put in some shapes,

11
00:00:39.745 --> 00:00:42.602
you should probably know
how to put in some text.

12
00:00:42.602 --> 00:00:44.442
>> Right, yeah.
>> Because that's everything.

13
00:00:44.442 --> 00:00:46.624
Going back to that target logo you said.

14
00:00:46.624 --> 00:00:47.160
>> Yeah.

15
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:49.820
>> Two circles and some words.

16
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:50.540
>> Right, exactly.

17
00:00:50.540 --> 00:00:51.330
>> So there you go.

18
00:00:51.330 --> 00:00:54.850
>> Yeah, logos are a great example not
only of things that you would create in

19
00:00:54.850 --> 00:00:55.710
Illustrator anyway.

20
00:00:55.710 --> 00:00:57.580
I mean, logos are a good thing for that.

21
00:00:57.580 --> 00:01:00.410
But yeah, exactly, we've got little
shapes going on and we've got that.

22
00:01:00.410 --> 00:01:03.470
And now we're gonna move into the text,
of course.

23
00:01:03.470 --> 00:01:05.880
So not much more of
an introduction needed, right.

24
00:01:05.880 --> 00:01:07.070
So what we're gonna do with our text,

25
00:01:07.070 --> 00:01:08.840
we're gonna go ahead and
grab our type tool.

26
00:01:08.840 --> 00:01:11.825
Our type tool,
just the big T on our T board.

27
00:01:11.825 --> 00:01:12.832
On our T board?

28
00:01:12.832 --> 00:01:15.294
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, too much.

29
00:01:15.294 --> 00:01:18.451
On our toolbar over here [LAUGH].

30
00:01:18.451 --> 00:01:22.202
>> A cute, fancy, our T bar, you know?

31
00:01:22.202 --> 00:01:24.816
>> I'm just.
So on our toolbar, we will go ahead and

32
00:01:24.816 --> 00:01:29.800
go to that, just go to the big T and
you're going to go ahead and grab that.

33
00:01:29.800 --> 00:01:34.780
We have a lot of hidden options
underneath our type, but

34
00:01:34.780 --> 00:01:36.000
we're not gonna get into those right now.

35
00:01:36.000 --> 00:01:37.650
We're just gonna stick
with the basic text.

36
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:40.030
So I'm gonna go ahead and grab that

37
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:43.500
very similar to our shapes there are two
different methods that we can do this.

38
00:01:43.500 --> 00:01:46.040
Slightly different they're gonna
have two different names, and

39
00:01:46.040 --> 00:01:47.690
it's gonna kind of impact things later.

40
00:01:47.690 --> 00:01:52.520
But from a basic stand point what we can
do, we can either grab our type tool and

41
00:01:52.520 --> 00:01:53.870
we can single click.

42
00:01:53.870 --> 00:01:57.050
You'll see when you single click in newer
versions of Illustrator it's gonna go

43
00:01:57.050 --> 00:01:59.510
ahead and put placeholder text in there.

44
00:01:59.510 --> 00:02:00.870
>> Look at that.

45
00:02:00.870 --> 00:02:02.761
>> Yeah. You didn't know that.
>> I was like, what?

46
00:02:02.761 --> 00:02:04.492
[LAUGH]
>> What did that just do?

47
00:02:04.492 --> 00:02:05.110
>> Lorem ipsum.

48
00:02:05.110 --> 00:02:08.650
>> Yes, and I just [CROSSTALK]-
>> I'm not sure if I like that, honestly.

49
00:02:09.900 --> 00:02:10.850
>> Are you kidding?

50
00:02:10.850 --> 00:02:13.793
I love it. [LAUGH] >> I'm a little
torn right now, please continue.

51
00:02:13.793 --> 00:02:15.910
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You just take a moment to

52
00:02:15.910 --> 00:02:17.410
process that.

53
00:02:17.410 --> 00:02:17.955
>> I know.
>> Yeah.

54
00:02:17.955 --> 00:02:18.872
[LAUGH]
>> What's going on?

55
00:02:18.872 --> 00:02:19.490
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

56
00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:23.890
it's funny because it's kinda carried over
from InDesign, a different Adobe program.

57
00:02:23.890 --> 00:02:24.450
And so

58
00:02:24.450 --> 00:02:28.660
it's a little weird to used to cuz it's
definitely a newer thing in Illustrator.

59
00:02:28.660 --> 00:02:30.860
So but yes,
that is an option to either grab it and

60
00:02:30.860 --> 00:02:33.940
single click now you will see that
the Lorem ipsum is highlighted so

61
00:02:33.940 --> 00:02:36.474
you can basically just go ahead and
start typing like normal.

62
00:02:36.474 --> 00:02:38.540
So I can type in Emily
>> Okay,

63
00:02:38.540 --> 00:02:43.450
see I got a little ahead of my self
of like, I'm judging right away.

64
00:02:43.450 --> 00:02:44.420
>> Yeah.

65
00:02:44.420 --> 00:02:45.260
Just type.

66
00:02:45.260 --> 00:02:47.870
>> Right, you don't have to go through and
delete it.

67
00:02:47.870 --> 00:02:52.670
It seems weirder than it is,
but where it comes in handy is,

68
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:55.920
say I'm working on a logo I've
got some shapes or whatever.

69
00:02:55.920 --> 00:02:58.750
I don't know why for a logo you wouldn't
know the name of a company already, but

70
00:02:58.750 --> 00:03:01.620
if you didn't or you had a tagline
that you were trying to add and

71
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:03.150
you just didn't know what it was yet.

72
00:03:03.150 --> 00:03:05.800
But you needed to go ahead and
start laying it out.

73
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:07.970
That comes in handy,
you can just type in that lorem ipsum,

74
00:03:07.970 --> 00:03:08.770
that's what it's there for.

75
00:03:08.770 --> 00:03:12.540
It's just referred to as placeholder text,
so you can use that.

76
00:03:12.540 --> 00:03:14.760
So that was our first option,
was just a single click.

77
00:03:14.760 --> 00:03:17.530
Our second option was to click,
hold, and drag.

78
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:21.090
So when you click, hold, and drag, we're
going to get a lot more type in there.

79
00:03:21.090 --> 00:03:21.806
So yeah.

80
00:03:21.806 --> 00:03:24.900
[LAUGH] I see Vonne's face just like drop.

81
00:03:24.900 --> 00:03:30.020
>> See, I mean,
these are the changes that have happened

82
00:03:30.020 --> 00:03:34.630
from whatever version I
was using religiously and

83
00:03:34.630 --> 00:03:38.240
now, into this new version,
again it's those little things.

84
00:03:38.240 --> 00:03:41.580
A seasoned user like me,
it's just like, my God.

85
00:03:41.580 --> 00:03:42.130
>> RIght.
>> For

86
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:45.690
you newbies out there, you're like,
okay, this is just the new norm.

87
00:03:45.690 --> 00:03:51.480
So, just know my perspective of
going back for way too many years,

88
00:03:51.480 --> 00:03:54.430
that I even want to tell you, of how long
I've been using the product, but, yeah.

89
00:03:54.430 --> 00:03:55.660
>> Yeah.
>> These newer features,

90
00:03:55.660 --> 00:03:57.510
there are some neat little things.

91
00:03:57.510 --> 00:03:58.490
Okay.
>> I like it.

92
00:03:58.490 --> 00:03:59.860
>> You're selling on this.

93
00:03:59.860 --> 00:04:01.950
>> Okay.
Just warm up to it.

94
00:04:01.950 --> 00:04:03.060
I think you'll enjoy it.

95
00:04:03.060 --> 00:04:07.970
So, very similar to our single click
method, is that I can just go ahead, and

96
00:04:07.970 --> 00:04:11.990
go here, and type and
I can just fill up the maps.

97
00:04:11.990 --> 00:04:12.910
>> Type, type, type away.

98
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:13.780
>> Type, type, type, type away.

99
00:04:13.780 --> 00:04:17.510
Yes, exactly, so, the differences
are gonna come in our editing.

100
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:22.370
Now, technically these two methods
that we used had two different names.

101
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:25.380
So, this was point type and
this was area type.

102
00:04:25.380 --> 00:04:27.200
Point type is just when you single click.

103
00:04:27.200 --> 00:04:32.188
Area type is when you go ahead and click,
hold, and drag and create the text box.

104
00:04:32.188 --> 00:04:35.030
Area type as you can guess,
is gonna be a little bit better for

105
00:04:35.030 --> 00:04:36.200
a longer bits of text.

106
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:38.580
Things like a paragraph that
you need to put in there.

107
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:42.610
Your point type is better for just when
you need to be an example of a logo,

108
00:04:42.610 --> 00:04:44.400
just type in the name of a company.

109
00:04:44.400 --> 00:04:47.750
Now, what you'll see though is when I
click on my two different text boxes,

110
00:04:47.750 --> 00:04:49.220
I'm back in my black arrow tool.

111
00:04:49.220 --> 00:04:50.720
Always go back to black.

112
00:04:50.720 --> 00:04:54.940
When I click on my two different text
boxes, you'll see I can drag this

113
00:04:54.940 --> 00:04:59.560
area type in and out, and what's happening
is that's just going to kind of re

114
00:04:59.560 --> 00:05:03.830
thread it and re flow it as we
look at it in our text box.

115
00:05:03.830 --> 00:05:06.780
If I try and do that with my point type,
what's gonna happen is,

116
00:05:06.780 --> 00:05:08.020
you're just gonna squish it.

117
00:05:08.020 --> 00:05:10.090
Or even in that case,
I just kind of made it disappear.

118
00:05:10.090 --> 00:05:11.450
It's just gonna squish it there.

119
00:05:11.450 --> 00:05:14.410
Which is something you really want
to avoid from a design perspective

120
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:15.910
of distorting your typography.

121
00:05:15.910 --> 00:05:18.410
You never want to distort you
text from the original intention.

122
00:05:18.410 --> 00:05:23.980
So, the thing about it is, you just
kinda have to know which one you want.

123
00:05:23.980 --> 00:05:27.930
Now, you don't have
the option to do that or

124
00:05:27.930 --> 00:05:32.080
move anything around in the point
type like you do the area type, but

125
00:05:32.080 --> 00:05:34.570
what you do have the option
of is making it larger.

126
00:05:34.570 --> 00:05:38.210
So, I'm going to hold down my shift
key cuz I always wanna maintain those

127
00:05:38.210 --> 00:05:39.190
proportions.

128
00:05:39.190 --> 00:05:42.660
And then just click, hold, and
drag in the top right hand corner.

129
00:05:42.660 --> 00:05:45.910
And bam I went ahead and
increased the size of my type very easily.

130
00:05:45.910 --> 00:05:50.330
So rather then having to go through and
be like do I want 72 points, what I want.

131
00:05:50.330 --> 00:05:52.410
I can just click, hold, and
drag and make that bigger.

132
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:56.220
So not an option that I had in my area
type that's just going to change the size

133
00:05:56.220 --> 00:05:59.550
of my text, but
I do have that option in my point type.

134
00:05:59.550 --> 00:06:00.780
Now, cool thing.

135
00:06:00.780 --> 00:06:02.540
You can go back and forth between the two.

136
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:04.430
So for some reason I had this.

137
00:06:04.430 --> 00:06:07.820
And I decided, you know what,
I really want this to be point type.

138
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:10.500
I don't care if I have to
drag that around anymore.

139
00:06:10.500 --> 00:06:11.740
It's not necessary.

140
00:06:11.740 --> 00:06:15.445
What you can do, you'll notice,
if I click on either one of these.

141
00:06:15.445 --> 00:06:18.020
If I click on my point type
I have a little white circle

142
00:06:18.020 --> 00:06:19.940
coming out the right hand side of that.

143
00:06:19.940 --> 00:06:22.800
By clicking on my are type I
have a little blue circle.

144
00:06:22.800 --> 00:06:26.310
Basically you can even try to hover
over to discover if I double click

145
00:06:26.310 --> 00:06:27.540
on that circle.

146
00:06:27.540 --> 00:06:31.498
What it gonna do is to convert from
point to area or area to point.

147
00:06:31.498 --> 00:06:34.790
So, I can click, hold, and
drag this now and make this larger.

148
00:06:34.790 --> 00:06:37.450
Or likewise I could flip this one around.

149
00:06:37.450 --> 00:06:41.663
>> That was probably one of my
favorite features that they changed.

150
00:06:41.663 --> 00:06:47.250
I don't remember when, but I can
change this by just a clicking thing.

151
00:06:47.250 --> 00:06:48.220
That's amazing.

152
00:06:48.220 --> 00:06:51.280
You do stuff like cut it out,
and start a new text box and

153
00:06:51.280 --> 00:06:54.070
then drag the box to kind of go back and
forth.

154
00:06:54.070 --> 00:06:59.360
There wasn't a simple click method
to flip them back and forth so.

155
00:06:59.360 --> 00:07:03.740
Yeah, this was a while back but,
it was an amazing edition that they added.

156
00:07:03.740 --> 00:07:05.940
>> Yes
>> That I was like thank you very much.

157

It was in other programs, but it's newer.

Likewise I could also go here and

There's a whole thing about
