you can go ahead and

471
00:21:10.391 --> 00:21:12.790
share swatches which I know we're
gonna talk about in a later episode.

472
00:21:12.790 --> 00:21:14.870
We're just getting you started.

473
00:21:14.870 --> 00:21:18.900
But I wanted to just throw that out there
for you just in case you kind of go,

474
00:21:18.900 --> 00:21:19.830
what happened?

475
00:21:19.830 --> 00:21:22.250
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah in case you're thinking just open

476
00:21:22.250 --> 00:21:23.579
a new file, where did those go?

477
00:21:23.579 --> 00:21:26.100
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> Yes that was a great point I'm glad you

478
00:21:26.100 --> 00:21:26.700
mentioned that.

479
00:21:26.700 --> 00:21:30.072
>> Right well, great introduction
to where we can go ahead and

480
00:21:30.072 --> 00:21:33.770
find colors we can be efficient
[LAUGH] and our color picking.

481
00:21:33.770 --> 00:21:36.500
But that sounds like a great place
like you said to go ahead and stop and

482
00:21:36.500 --> 00:21:38.100
we'll continue on with more.

483
00:21:38.100 --> 00:21:41.750
So signing off for CreativePro.TV,
I'm your host Vonne Smith.

484
00:21:41.750 --> 00:21:42.510
>> And Emily Ramsey.

485
00:21:42.510 --> 00:21:43.312
>> And we'll see you soon.

486
00:21:43.312 --> 00:21:45.697
>> [SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily work with multiple paths.  They show different ways to select multiple paths, grouping and ungrouping objects, and shortcuts for duplicating objects. They also dive into the layers panel, showing how to arrange object stacking order, rename layers, show/hide layers, and selecting objects from the layers panel.
episodes.title: Working with Multiple Paths
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.871
[SOUND]

2

[MUSIC]

Hello, and welcome to another

I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

And in this episode, we're gonna be

And here to help us is Ms.

It's like, cool, it's not as much fun

it is really helpful.

11

[LAUGH]
>> Definitely.

12

>> Yeah.
>> And

so we're going to be doing some

so why don't we get started?

15
00:00:42.283 --> 00:00:43.901
>> All right, so what we're gonna do,

16
00:00:43.901 --> 00:00:46.575
first thing we're gonna talk
about how to duplicate a path.

17
00:00:46.575 --> 00:00:50.978
So for me, to have to create a square,
and then I want another square,

then I have to go back
to my rectangle tool.

19
00:00:53.682 --> 00:00:57.959
I don't have to do that, so,
how can we easily duplicate a path?

20
00:00:57.959 --> 00:01:02.045
And then we're gonna kind of move on from
there to talking a little about stocking

21
00:01:02.045 --> 00:01:04.162
order, layers will kind of fit in there.

22
00:01:04.162 --> 00:01:08.205
And then also grouping something, so
if I know things want to go together,

23
00:01:08.205 --> 00:01:09.881
how can I kinda work with that?

24
00:01:09.881 --> 00:01:11.775
So let's go ahead and get started, and

25
00:01:11.775 --> 00:01:14.541
we're just gonna start off
with a blank workspace here.

26
00:01:14.541 --> 00:01:18.737
And then what I'm gonna do,
I'm just gonna create a shape,

27
00:01:18.737 --> 00:01:21.713
so I wanna go ahead and
create a rectangle.

28
00:01:21.713 --> 00:01:23.483
Now, I'm gonna go back
to my black arrow tool.

29

Now, say I'm working, and I'm like,
I really think I want two rectangles here,

30
00:01:27.155 --> 00:01:28.795
I wanna go ahead and duplicate that.

31
00:01:28.795 --> 00:01:32.352
A couple of different options, the first
kind of most common method that you're

32
00:01:32.352 --> 00:01:34.412
probably thinking is a copy, paste, right?

33
00:01:34.412 --> 00:01:37.893
So what we can do, we can use that
in Illustrator, it's an option,

34
00:01:37.893 --> 00:01:41.391
I like how I phrase that,
you can tell it's not my favorite option.

35
00:01:41.391 --> 00:01:46.282
[LAUGH] What you can do, you can select
your option, or select your object, or

36
00:01:46.282 --> 00:01:47.506
your path rather.

37
00:01:47.506 --> 00:01:52.184
And go ahead and hit a Cmd or
Ctrl+ C on your keyboard, C as in copy.

38
00:01:52.184 --> 00:01:56.317
And this is a pretty standard computer
keyboard shortcut, if you will.

39
00:01:56.317 --> 00:02:01.213
And then Cmd or Ctrl+V on your keyboard
if you wanna go ahead and duplicate that.

40
00:02:01.213 --> 00:02:05.819
So that's Cmd or Ctrl+C,
Cmdon the Mac, CTRL on the PC,

41
00:02:05.819 --> 00:02:09.581
Cmd or Ctrl+V as in Vonne,
V as in Vonne, yes.

42
00:02:09.581 --> 00:02:10.306
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

43
00:02:10.306 --> 00:02:11.037
>> Yes,

44
00:02:11.037 --> 00:02:15.424
remember me when you want to paste!

45
00:02:15.424 --> 00:02:18.054
The other thing that I always tell people
to how to remember the C and the V,

46
00:02:18.054 --> 00:02:19.982
because it's not P,
because that's always print.

47
00:02:19.982 --> 00:02:22.774
>> Right.
>> Is think about glue, and

48
00:02:22.774 --> 00:02:24.983
glue comes to a point.

49
00:02:24.983 --> 00:02:25.877
Back in kindergarten,

50
00:02:25.877 --> 00:02:29.420
when you're using all of your glue,
now they use glue sticks and everything.

51
00:02:29.420 --> 00:02:30.195
>> Anyways.

52
00:02:30.195 --> 00:02:31.450
>> They're making slime, I don't know.

53
00:02:31.450 --> 00:02:32.627
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

54
00:02:32.627 --> 00:02:33.140
>> Right, so

55
00:02:33.140 --> 00:02:34.683
that's what I remember with V.

56
00:02:34.683 --> 00:02:38.252
And, of course, you always have, like,
I think you can right click, and copy and

57
00:02:38.252 --> 00:02:40.003
paste, you can also go to the Edit menu.

58
00:02:40.003 --> 00:02:42.482
Copy, and paste is, I would say,

59
00:02:42.482 --> 00:02:48.054
pretty universal thing that all people
know, but you never assume, right?

60
00:02:48.054 --> 00:02:50.372
>> Yeah, absolutely, yes, absolutely.

61
00:02:50.372 --> 00:02:53.467
And one of these things is, I didn't learn
some of these keyboard shortcuts until I

62
00:02:53.467 --> 00:02:54.851
started working with Illustrator.

63
00:02:54.851 --> 00:02:57.111
That I could do in other programs,
like Microsoft Word or something.

64
00:02:57.111 --> 00:03:00.393
But yes, to Vonne's point,
it is also available in the Edit menu,

65
00:03:00.393 --> 00:03:02.592
if the keyboard shortcut
is not your friend.

66
00:03:02.592 --> 00:03:05.812
So you can use Edit, Copy and
then Edit, Paste as well.

67
00:03:05.812 --> 00:03:09.595
Now, as I mentioned, I think that
there's an easier method, [LAUGH], and

68
00:03:09.595 --> 00:03:12.012
that's gonna be your Alt,
or your Option key.

69
00:03:12.012 --> 00:03:14.847
For some reason, this is just one of
my favorite things in Illustrator,

70
00:03:14.847 --> 00:03:17.641
I don't know why, or again,
in other Adobe programs, I just love it.

71
00:03:17.641 --> 00:03:18.603
And it's so simple,

72
00:03:18.603 --> 00:03:21.922
all I'm gonna do is I'm gonna select
this again with my black arrow tool.

73
00:03:21.922 --> 00:03:26.408
And then when I wanna duplicate it,
I'm gonna hold down my Alt or Option key,

74
00:03:26.408 --> 00:03:29.732
Alt on a Mac, or I'm sorry,
Alt on a PC, Option on a Mac.

75
00:03:29.732 --> 00:03:32.706
And then what we're gonna do,
you see when you go ahead and

76
00:03:32.706 --> 00:03:34.783
kind of hold down that Alt or Option key.

77
00:03:34.783 --> 00:03:39.460
You switch from having the one cursor
with kind of the box tail next to it but

78
00:03:39.460 --> 00:03:41.504
you have now a little triangle.

79
00:03:41.504 --> 00:03:44.480
A little black triangle, and
a little white triangle, basically,

80
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:46.234
is what we are looking at for our cursor.

81
00:03:46.234 --> 00:03:49.827
So and that's just gonna kind of
represent, hey, we're gonna go ahead and

82
00:03:49.827 --> 00:03:52.711
duplicate this, so
you see kind of the double arrows there.

83
00:03:52.711 --> 00:03:55.243
So what we're gonna do,
click, hold and drag.

84
00:03:55.243 --> 00:03:58.485
Now the only real trick to this
is holding down that Alt or

85
00:03:58.485 --> 00:04:01.185
Option key until you've
let go of your mouse.

86
00:04:01.185 --> 00:04:05.339
So what's gonna happen here, if I go, and
I Alt or Option, and I drag and drop,

87
00:04:05.339 --> 00:04:06.153
okay, great.

88
00:04:06.153 --> 00:04:09.151
But what if I go like this, and
then I let go of my Alt or Option?

89
00:04:09.151 --> 00:04:12.270
You can even see in my cursor that
I've gone back to just having

90
00:04:12.270 --> 00:04:13.293
that single arrow.

91
00:04:13.293 --> 00:04:16.135
And then I'm gonna drop there and
it's gonna be like, wait a second,

92
00:04:16.135 --> 00:04:18.028
all it did was move,
it didn't duplicate it.

93
00:04:18.028 --> 00:04:21.420
And that's just telling me that I let
go of my Alt or Option key too soon.

94
00:04:21.420 --> 00:04:26.082
I cannot tell you how many times in a day,
I use this all the time.

95
00:04:26.082 --> 00:04:27.889
Again, such a simple thing, but

96
00:04:27.889 --> 00:04:31.644
it is going to just totally transform
your workflow in Illustrator.

97
00:04:31.644 --> 00:04:34.944
So, again, that's just Alt or Option,
click, hold and drag, and let go.

98
00:04:34.944 --> 00:04:35.732
>> Yeah, and

99
00:04:35.732 --> 00:04:41.187
I think you can even do this in Photoshop
if you want to duplicate, right?

100
00:04:41.187 --> 00:04:41.855
>> Yeah.

101
00:04:41.855 --> 00:04:42.913
>> Is it layer, Alt drag?

102
00:04:42.913 --> 00:04:46.147
Alt drag is pretty,
as soon as I started saying it, I'm like,

103
00:04:46.147 --> 00:04:47.805
I actually forget what it does.

104
00:04:47.805 --> 00:04:49.687
[LAUGH]
>> But you can do it in InDesign,

105
00:04:49.687 --> 00:04:51.626
you can do it in most Adobe programs.

106
00:04:51.626 --> 00:04:56.392
>> Yes, definitely, so
I love the Alt drag, because it's amazing.

107
00:04:56.392 --> 00:04:58.239
It's so much easier than having, and

108
00:04:58.239 --> 00:05:01.084
I actually saw you try to do it
in one of the other episodes.

109
00:05:01.084 --> 00:05:01.692
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

110
00:05:01.692 --> 00:05:02.537
>> I'm like, she's going for the alt drag,

111
00:05:02.537 --> 00:05:03.156
but she hasn't taught it yet.

112
00:05:03.156 --> 00:05:04.933
[LAUGH]
>> I can't help myself.

113
00:05:04.933 --> 00:05:07.723
It's literally something that I
use that frequently, so yeah.

114
00:05:07.723 --> 00:05:08.279
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

115
00:05:08.279 --> 00:05:10.013
>> So, she totally caught me,

116
00:05:10.013 --> 00:05:13.925
she called me out on it, but so
what we're going to do from here.

117
00:05:13.925 --> 00:05:16.001
Now okay, let's go ahead and
just create a couple of shapes.

118
00:05:16.001 --> 00:05:20.302
So I've got my two squares, and then let's
throw a couple of other things in there.

119
00:05:20.302 --> 00:05:23.393
So we're gonna get really wild and
add a circle.

120
00:05:23.393 --> 00:05:27.781
And I'm gonna go ahead and start giving
these all a couple of different colors, so

121
00:05:27.781 --> 00:05:30.022
I'm gonna go back to my black arrow tool.

122
00:05:30.022 --> 00:05:33.117
By the way, we've probably
mentioned this in other videos, but

123
00:05:33.117 --> 00:05:34.704
just in case you've forgotten.

124
00:05:34.704 --> 00:05:35.449
The hot key, or

125
00:05:35.449 --> 00:05:39.539
the keyboard shortcut, to go back to your
black arrow tool is always V, as in Vonne.

126
00:05:39.539 --> 00:05:43.760
[LAUGH] So you may have seen me do that
there, I didn't actually go to my toolbar,

127
00:05:43.760 --> 00:05:45.594
I just hit the V key on my keyboard.

128
00:05:45.594 --> 00:05:47.134
To get back to that black arrow tool, so

129
00:05:47.134 --> 00:05:49.393
that's always an option that
you have available to you.

130
00:05:49.393 --> 00:05:52.072
So I'm gonna have a couple of
things that I'm working with here.

131
00:05:52.072 --> 00:05:54.749
But what you'll notice is, okay,

132
00:05:54.749 --> 00:06:00.475
everything that I've created is stacking
in the order that I created them.

133
00:06:00.475 --> 00:06:03.601
So what I'm looking at here,
especially if I go like that,

134
00:06:03.601 --> 00:06:05.803
I created the pink square first, right?

135
00:06:05.803 --> 00:06:09.889
And then I duplicated that, and
then I created what's now green and

136
00:06:09.889 --> 00:06:12.553
then the circle, the circle that was last.

137
00:06:12.553 --> 00:06:16.934
Everything by default in Illustrator will
stack in the order that you created them.

138
00:06:16.934 --> 00:06:21.109
Now, if you're new to Illustrator,
you might be going, like, shoot.

139
00:06:21.109 --> 00:06:24.206
Now I have to go back and recreate
something, first or last, or whatever,

140
00:06:24.206 --> 00:06:26.231
because that's the order
that I wanted it to go.

141
00:06:26.231 --> 00:06:29.302
And I definitely I feel like I
had that phase the very first

142
00:06:29.302 --> 00:06:32.064
time I opened Illustrator,
like how do I fix this?

143
00:06:32.064 --> 00:06:34.100
Very easy to fix, of course, obviously.

144
00:06:34.100 --> 00:06:37.864
So what we're gonna do is we're just
gonna work on our stacking order.

145
00:06:37.864 --> 00:06:41.036
So this is gonna kind of translate into
layers a little bit later, but for

146
00:06:41.036 --> 00:06:44.064
right now, we're just gonna call
it a stacking order, or Arrange.

147
00:06:44.064 --> 00:06:47.463
So what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna go
ahead and select one of these paths.

148
00:06:47.463 --> 00:06:51.383
So I'm just gonna choose the blue circle,
cuz that's what's on top, and then say,

149
00:06:51.383 --> 00:06:53.681
I wanna go ahead and
send it behind these squares.

150
00:06:53.681 --> 00:06:57.710
So what I'm gonna do, it's very simple,
I'm gonna right click on that, again,

151
00:06:57.710 --> 00:07:00.433
I selected it with my black
arrow tool then right click.

152
00:07:00.433 --> 00:07:02.785
And I'm just going to go down to Arrange,
with Arrange,

153
00:07:02.785 --> 00:07:04.212
you have four different options.

154
00:07:04.212 --> 00:07:09.313
You have Bring to Front, Bring Forward,
Send Backward, and Send to Back.

155
00:07:09.313 --> 00:07:13.039
So what's going to happen here is,
okay, obviously, this one's on top,

156
00:07:13.039 --> 00:07:13.922
you can see that.

157
00:07:13.922 --> 00:07:17.560
So if I try and do Bring Forward, or
Bring Front, or anything like that.

158
00:07:17.560 --> 00:07:20.683
Bring to Front, nothing's really going to
happen, because it's already at the front.

159
00:07:20.683 --> 00:07:25.931
But what I can do, I can right click, go
to Arrange, Send Backward or Send to Back.

160
00:07:25.931 --> 00:07:30.061
If I choose Send Backward, it's gonna go
back one path, if you will, at a time, so

161
00:07:30.061 --> 00:07:32.843
it's gonna go behind the green,
then behind the pink.

162
00:07:32.843 --> 00:07:35.530
If I send it back, it's gonna
go all the way back behind them.

163
00:07:35.530 --> 00:07:39.827
So I will go ahead and choose Send
Backward, and you'll see, there we go,

164
00:07:39.827 --> 00:07:41.614
it went back behind the green.

165
00:07:41.614 --> 00:07:45.867
Now I could do this again, right click,
Arrange, Send Backward again, and

166
00:07:45.867 --> 00:07:47.972
I could send it all the way to the back.

167
00:07:47.972 --> 00:07:52.353
Or now, because it's in the back,
I could go ahead and right-click,

168
00:07:52.353 --> 00:07:54.039
Arrange, Bring to Front.

169
00:07:54.039 --> 00:07:57.465
Now one of the important things to
note with this, and this will, again,

170
00:07:57.465 --> 00:07:59.359
kinda translate into our layers later.

171
00:07:59.359 --> 00:08:03.941
Is that, even though we're only looking at
three things right here It doesn't have to

172
00:08:03.941 --> 00:08:07.480
do specifically with the three
things that you're working with.

173
00:08:07.480 --> 00:08:12.040
So if I had other things on my art board,
for instance if I had a ton of other stuff

174
00:08:12.040 --> 00:08:16.550
going on, and I was choosing to do a range
bring forward or something like that or

175
00:08:16.550 --> 00:08:21.200
send backward It would go
forward one object at a time.

176
00:08:21.200 --> 00:08:25.590
So even if I had something you know over
here that seemed totally unaffected,

177
00:08:25.590 --> 00:08:30.270
it would still have to kind of climb
on to of that path of you will.

178
00:08:30.270 --> 00:08:32.590
>> Yeah I actually have had
people say like it's not working.

179
00:08:32.590 --> 00:08:36.150
It's not working, it keeps setting back,
setting back, or backwards.

180
00:08:36.150 --> 00:08:37.340
>> Yeah
>> Yeah,

181
00:08:37.340 --> 00:08:42.890
it's with all of the objects that
are on your paper, if you want to say,

182
00:08:42.890 --> 00:08:48.190
and throwing in another caveat,
it's also within the layer.

183
00:08:48.190 --> 00:08:52.258
If you start using layers, and we haven't
even mentioned them right now, so right

184
00:08:52.258 --> 00:08:56.577
now, think of everything on it's own layer
or same layer, [CROSSTALK] we'll say that.

185
00:08:56.577 --> 00:09:01.265
But it is within the layer of
how you're sending forward and

186
00:09:01.265 --> 00:09:05.530
sending back, so
it throws another wrench in it.

187
00:09:05.530 --> 00:09:07.500
>> It does,
cuz sometimes you're looking at it and

188
00:09:07.500 --> 00:09:09.080
you think it should be as simple as this.

189
00:09:09.080 --> 00:09:11.520
But because you have
other things going on,

190
00:09:11.520 --> 00:09:13.680
it still needs to kinda move with that.

191
00:09:13.680 --> 00:09:15.690
So that is one thing to consider.

192
00:09:15.690 --> 00:09:19.820
Now I'm gonna go ahead and take this other
little dude off to the side here away and

193
00:09:19.820 --> 00:09:22.070
what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna go ahead and select this.

194
00:09:22.070 --> 00:09:24.830
Let's just say,
I'll even add some type with it.

195
00:09:26.160 --> 00:09:32.250
We're just gonna pretend that this
is our logo, right, for a company.

196
00:09:32.250 --> 00:09:34.280
Not the fanciest thing you've seen, but

197
00:09:34.280 --> 00:09:38.803
we're gonna just pretend for
Explanation's sake, so.

198
00:09:38.803 --> 00:09:40.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's so

199
00:09:40.300 --> 00:09:44.330
crazy when you throw a couple shapes
together, you're like poof, there you go.

200
00:09:44.330 --> 00:09:46.590
>> [LAUGH] That's my logo, yes exactly.

201
00:09:46.590 --> 00:09:50.010
So we gonna pretend that
this is our logo and

202
00:09:50.010 --> 00:09:53.670
what we are looking at here now say,

00:20:33.350 --> 00:20:37.010
So, if you did not want to go into
isolation mode for whatever reason,

428
00:20:37.010 --> 00:20:39.280
we mentioned it kind of throws people off.

429
00:20:39.280 --> 00:20:41.130
I still have that option even for

430
00:20:41.130 --> 00:20:44.680
something that's grouped to
select these items individually.

431
00:20:44.680 --> 00:20:46.790
So that's kind of a handy thing.

432
00:20:46.790 --> 00:20:49.420
>> And I think if you expanded
the layer panel out more,

433
00:20:49.420 --> 00:20:51.260
you could see more like the names-
>> Yes.

434
00:20:51.260 --> 00:20:52.100
>> Next to it.

435
00:20:52.100 --> 00:20:53.190
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

436
00:20:53.190 --> 00:20:53.923
Okay.
And I've-

437
00:20:53.923 --> 00:20:54.423
>> You're so smart.

438
00:20:54.423 --> 00:20:56.036
[LAUGH]

439
00:20:56.036 --> 00:20:56.968
>> And like you said,

440
00:20:56.968 --> 00:21:00.695
we were talking before the show about
when I first start using Illustrator,

441
00:21:00.695 --> 00:21:02.320
I never want to do layers now.

442
00:21:02.320 --> 00:21:03.660
>> Yeah.
>> I never worked in it.

443
00:21:03.660 --> 00:21:06.490
I never made new ones and
I never did anything with it.

444
00:21:06.490 --> 00:21:09.730
Because it was almost like
such a freedom from Photoshop.

445
00:21:09.730 --> 00:21:12.060
>> Yeah, yeah. [LAUGH] >> Yeah,
to think about this.

446
00:21:12.060 --> 00:21:15.900
But the more I used Illustrator,
then I was like,

447
00:21:15.900 --> 00:21:21.245
I can kinda combine if you wanna say,
the Photoshopness of it into here.

448
00:21:21.245 --> 00:21:24.301
How I can work with it more to my
advantage to keep myself organized and

449
00:21:24.301 --> 00:21:26.991
everything like that, but
like right here with the group and

450
00:21:26.991 --> 00:21:28.375
then being able to isolate it.

451
00:21:28.375 --> 00:21:32.158
And then, from right here with that,

452
00:21:32.158 --> 00:21:37.016
I think with the pink
square selected right now.

453
00:21:37.016 --> 00:21:39.961
Then you could ahead and
change the fill cloud from the top and

454
00:21:39.961 --> 00:21:43.990
everything so you don't even have to get
into those other ways that we did it, so.

455
00:21:43.990 --> 00:21:44.510
>> Yeah.

456
00:21:44.510 --> 00:21:46.864
>> Multiple ways, you know,
to do things, so consider.

457
00:21:46.864 --> 00:21:47.665
>> [LAUGH] Always,

458
00:21:47.665 --> 00:21:51.509
there's always like ten different
ways to explain something, so yeah.

459
00:21:51.509 --> 00:21:54.820
[LAUGH] But one of the beautiful
things about Illustrator at the same,

460
00:21:54.820 --> 00:21:56.080
you can pick your own way of doing it.

461
00:21:56.080 --> 00:21:58.940
So, these are basically,
as we mention here,

462
00:21:58.940 --> 00:22:01.740
we're really just working
with sublayers right now.

463
00:22:01.740 --> 00:22:04.430
So, you can see, everything is
still collapsed under my layer 1.

464
00:22:04.430 --> 00:22:08.490
I could use these little eyeballs
as like to call them, kinda hide

465
00:22:08.490 --> 00:22:13.340
things all together, hide the entire layer
if I wanted to get rid of everything.

466
00:22:13.340 --> 00:22:16.540
But what I could also do is I could
also add another layer to this.

467
00:22:16.540 --> 00:22:20.810
So depending on how you wanna organize
your information, we kinda joked

468
00:22:20.810 --> 00:22:25.240
before this that neither of us really
used these when we first started out.

469
00:22:25.240 --> 00:22:29.415
But as you get going you might wanna start
to organize things a little bit better.

470
00:22:29.415 --> 00:22:31.390
Especially if you have
a lot of things going on.

471
00:22:31.390 --> 00:22:33.452
So what I can do, I'm gonna go ahead and
collapse that Layer 1.

472
00:22:33.452 --> 00:22:37.440
And I'm gonna go ahead and just click on
my post-it-note, so similar to how we've

473
00:22:37.440 --> 00:22:40.770
done it in other, you know,
like creating a new swatch, basically.

474
00:22:40.770 --> 00:22:44.590
I'm gonna click that little post-it-note
icon to create a new layer.

475
00:22:44.590 --> 00:22:47.030
Now, right now I don't have
anything on that layer but

476
00:22:47.030 --> 00:22:52.700
you'll see if I select Layer 2 and
then I go ahead and create something.

477
00:22:52.700 --> 00:22:54.654
By default, it's going to be on Layer 2.

478
00:22:54.654 --> 00:22:56.253
How do I know it's on Layer 2?

479
00:22:56.253 --> 00:23:00.197
One, because I can foresee it in
my layers panel, but then also,

480
00:23:00.197 --> 00:23:02.290
because it has a red path outline.

481
00:23:02.290 --> 00:23:08.490
So maybe I'll make this one just like tan,
so you could see it a little bit better.

482
00:23:08.490 --> 00:23:11.834
That red path outline is indicating to
me that I'm now working on Layer 2.

483
00:23:11.834 --> 00:23:16.600
If I were to create another layer,
and then make another object.

484
00:23:17.710 --> 00:23:20.930
You can see I now have that green path
outline, so that's letting me know that

485
00:23:20.930 --> 00:23:24.320
I'm working on Layer 1, Layer 2,
Layer 3 and so on and so forth.

486
00:23:24.320 --> 00:23:26.860
And kind of nice thing about this is,

487
00:23:26.860 --> 00:23:29.980
say I have something that I want to
move from one layer to the other.

488
00:23:29.980 --> 00:23:32.410
So I have this black square and

489
00:23:32.410 --> 00:23:36.340
I really want the black square
to be on Layer 3, for example.

490
00:23:36.340 --> 00:23:38.960
Cuz Layer 3 in my case
right now is on top.

491
00:23:38.960 --> 00:23:42.620
And I want this to be on top of this
other element that's on Layer 3, but

492
00:23:42.620 --> 00:23:45.410
I can't move it because I
don't have that option.

493
00:23:45.410 --> 00:23:48.055
Again, that's kinda at a range,
bring forward, send it back.

494
00:23:48.055 --> 00:23:49.221
Yeah
>> It's cool.

495
00:23:49.221 --> 00:23:52.340
>> You could go ahead and
take that black rectangle, and

496
00:23:52.340 --> 00:23:56.302
do sent to front all day long,
it's never going to go on top of that.

497
00:23:56.302 --> 00:23:57.112
Tan circles.

498
00:23:57.112 --> 00:23:58.703
>> Right.
>> There's that layer aspect, and so

499
00:23:58.703 --> 00:24:01.660
maybe you're going, okay,
now I know what you're talking about.

500
00:24:01.660 --> 00:24:04.888
>> Yeah, yeah exactly, exactly,
a range brain to front,

501
00:24:04.888 --> 00:24:09.546
tan to back is only gonna work within a
layer, it's not gonna climb other layers.

502
00:24:09.546 --> 00:24:10.602
In that case,

503
00:24:10.602 --> 00:24:15.806
I need to move this black square to
layer three when I'm looking at it.

504
00:24:15.806 --> 00:24:19.463
So a nice thing that you could do,
I have this black square selected.

505
00:24:19.463 --> 00:24:23.232
I always know when I have something
selected that it's indicated by this

506
00:24:23.232 --> 00:24:24.791
little blue square, right.

507
00:24:24.791 --> 00:24:28.023
And I can even see if I kind
of release that down that,

508
00:24:28.023 --> 00:24:30.820
that black square is selected here.

509
00:24:30.820 --> 00:24:34.170
What I can do, even with this collapsed,
I can click, hold, and

510
00:24:34.170 --> 00:24:37.610
drag that blue square to Layer 3.

511
00:24:37.610 --> 00:24:41.490
So I can click, hold, and drag this little
square right here, drag it up to Layer 3,

512
00:24:41.490 --> 00:24:44.070
and now that black square is on Layer 3.

513
00:24:44.070 --> 00:24:47.632
So I can go ahead and then move
that on top of that other object.

514
00:24:47.632 --> 00:24:52.081
So kinda nice, you can move pretty easily,
I would say between layers.

515
00:24:52.081 --> 00:24:56.161
I could also, for instance,
if I wanted to make Layer 3 in the middle,

516
00:24:56.161 --> 00:25:00.244
I could make Layer 3 Layer 2 all you
have to do is drag and drop oops!

517
00:25:00.244 --> 00:25:03.134
>> Yeah, you gotta watch the lines.

518
00:25:03.134 --> 00:25:04.748
>> Yeah, yeah, yeah, I messed my lines.

519
00:25:04.748 --> 00:25:06.223
>> So many times-
>> Drag and drop.

520
00:25:06.223 --> 00:25:11.139
>> You can basically nest layers inside
of layers, inside of layers, and so

521
00:25:11.139 --> 00:25:16.890
that first thing that you did you actually
kind of put it inside of that other layer.

522
00:25:16.890 --> 00:25:19.440
>> Right.
>> Watch those lines when you are dragging

523
00:25:19.440 --> 00:25:25.130
and dropping for the organization or
stacking order of the layers is kinda

524
00:25:25.130 --> 00:25:30.390
key and just, I always tell people to go
slow, watch the lines and then let go.

525
00:25:30.390 --> 00:25:31.794
>> Yeah, go slower than I did.

526
00:25:31.794 --> 00:25:36.169
>> [LAUGH]
>> My god, whatever, we got it, so yeah,

527
00:25:36.169 --> 00:25:38.420
so we can drag and drop.

528
00:25:38.420 --> 00:25:41.650
See I'm going from there from Layer 2,
you see that blue line there, that's

529
00:25:41.650 --> 00:25:47.090
indicating to me, okay I'm gonna drag that
between Layer 2 and Layer 3, I let go.

530
00:25:47.090 --> 00:25:49.770
Now Layer 3 is actually in between, and

531
00:25:49.770 --> 00:25:52.480
I'm trying to find something
that was on Layer 3.

532
00:25:52.480 --> 00:25:53.690
I'm like, what's where?

533
00:25:53.690 --> 00:25:55.180
You can see Layer 3,

534
00:25:55.180 --> 00:25:59.760
even though this black square is on the
top of Layer 3, it's still below Layer 2.

535
00:25:59.760 --> 00:26:02.400
Now all these numbers are kinda
sounding confusing, right?

536
00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:06.040
I'm going Layer 3, Layer 1,
they're out of order.

537
00:26:06.040 --> 00:26:07.510
What is this thing?

538
00:26:07.510 --> 00:26:09.630
You could rename these [LAUGH], okay?

539
00:26:09.630 --> 00:26:12.100
So if the numbers are just too much for
you like they are for

540
00:26:12.100 --> 00:26:17.160
me, all I have to do to rename a layer
is just double-click on the words.

541
00:26:17.160 --> 00:26:19.385
Don't try and double-click
over here on the layer itself,

542
00:26:19.385 --> 00:26:22.350
double-click on the actual name.

543
00:26:22.350 --> 00:26:24.030
And you can see I can go ahead and
rename that.

544
00:26:24.030 --> 00:26:28.850
So I'm gonna call that Tan Circle, just
thinking that there's nothing else there,

545
00:26:28.850 --> 00:26:30.960
if there is, then that won't work.

546
00:26:30.960 --> 00:26:34.120
But that works [LAUGH] there, so we'll
call that tan circle, you can go ahead and

547
00:26:34.120 --> 00:26:35.250
give this Layer 3.

548
00:26:35.250 --> 00:26:39.615
I'm just gonna double click,
I'm gonna call that the Vonne layer.

549
00:26:39.615 --> 00:26:41.025
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> You get your own layer.

550
00:26:41.025 --> 00:26:42.578
[LAUGH]
>> Well you can get your own layer too!

551
00:26:42.578 --> 00:26:43.972
>> Well, okay, yeah, I'll be Layer 1.

552
00:26:43.972 --> 00:26:44.981
>> Yeah, there you go.

553
00:26:44.981 --> 00:26:48.045
>> Double click,
we'll call that Vonne, Emily, and

554
00:26:48.045 --> 00:26:51.940
the Tan Circle,
that sounds like a band, right?

555
00:26:51.940 --> 00:26:52.530
>> Totally.

556
00:26:52.530 --> 00:26:54.380
>> Yeah, so, we can go ahead and

557
00:26:54.380 --> 00:26:58.140
give them the names,
whatever you feel like works best for you.

558
00:26:58.140 --> 00:26:59.846
Certainly, I'm somebody that I think that,

559
00:26:59.846 --> 00:27:01.563
that makes a little bit
more sense in my brain.

560
00:27:01.563 --> 00:27:08.737
>> And I will tell you, that the moving of
the dot, huge for me, I use this all time.

561
00:27:08.737 --> 00:27:13.728
Cuz talking about how like we don't really
think of layers in illustrator first, so

562
00:27:13.728 --> 00:27:18.155
I might draw something and then get it
all together and then be like, okay,

563
00:27:18.155 --> 00:27:21.132
now I want to kind of start
like organizing it out.

564
00:27:21.132 --> 00:27:25.263
So I'll put it all on one layer, then
start making my own layers on top of them,

565
00:27:25.263 --> 00:27:28.219
selecting the pieces,
then dragging that little dot.

566
00:27:28.219 --> 00:27:33.200
So maybe all my text is on one layer,
and my logos on another layer.

567
00:27:33.200 --> 00:27:38.010
And sometimes I even use layers to
whereas like do I like this look or

568
00:27:38.010 --> 00:27:39.440
do I like that look?

569
00:27:39.440 --> 00:27:41.033
And so
then I can kinda turn them on and off,

570
00:27:41.033 --> 00:27:42.900
like you were talking about the eyeballs.

571
00:27:42.900 --> 00:27:48.040
And so I can kinda get a look so I'm not
making multiple files, I'm just kinda

572
00:27:48.040 --> 00:27:53.200
using layers as like my proof one,
proof two, proof three if you wanna say.

573
00:27:53.200 --> 00:27:55.220
>> Yeah.
>> And kinda get an idea, so

574
00:27:55.220 --> 00:27:58.480
it's not deleting, it's just hiding,
it's in its own layer.

575
00:27:58.480 --> 00:28:02.120
So just a little kinda
tidbits from Vonne's little

576
00:28:02.120 --> 00:28:05.860
way of using Illustrator and all these
times I've had to do logo creations.

577
00:28:05.860 --> 00:28:07.454
>> Yes.
>> Especially if you're work with clients,

578
00:28:07.454 --> 00:28:08.860
you wanna give them different options.

579
00:28:08.860 --> 00:28:10.555
>> Yeah.
>> Just throw them in layers.

580
00:28:10.555 --> 00:28:15.530
>> Yeah, if you did this,
duplicated it, something like that.

581
00:28:15.530 --> 00:28:17.010
Put these on two different layers.

582
00:28:17.010 --> 00:28:20.620
We'll make a new one,
I totally agree with you.

583
00:28:20.620 --> 00:28:24.100
Just to be able to toggle it on and
off and look at the options that you have.

584
00:28:24.100 --> 00:28:29.260
>> Yeah, I love using that, so, and that
little dot, I think it's in InDesign too.

585
00:28:29.260 --> 00:28:32.986
It's in a couple different
places that's available.

586
00:28:32.986 --> 00:28:37.560
And I utilize it to the ninth degree,
and so just so you know,

587
00:28:37.560 --> 00:28:39.465
I love that little part.

588
00:28:39.465 --> 00:28:41.032
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Well,

589
00:28:41.032 --> 00:28:45.580
I think layers in general,
it's just really how you wanna use them.

590
00:28:45.580 --> 00:28:49.160
You don't have to use them, but

591
00:28:49.160 --> 00:28:51.900
I do think using them to your
advantage can certainly come in handy.

592
00:28:51.900 --> 00:28:54.710
Especially, I think Vonne's
mentioned a great example,

593
00:28:54.710 --> 00:28:57.620
when you're trying to kind of flip between
options and you wanna look at them

594
00:28:57.620 --> 00:29:01.330
each individually it can be a nice way
to use that with that toggle on and off.

595
00:29:01.330 --> 00:29:04.370
So I think that's really all
that I wanna mention for layers.

596
00:29:04.370 --> 00:29:06.055
That's a good introduction
of how to use them.

597
00:29:06.055 --> 00:29:08.314
As I've said a thousand
times at this point,

598
00:29:08.314 --> 00:29:10.584
it's really up to you
how you wanna use them.

599
00:29:10.584 --> 00:29:14.296
But remember working with your multiple
objects, remember that Alt drag,

600
00:29:14.296 --> 00:29:17.313
that one's gonna come in handy
in grouping and ungrouping and

601
00:29:17.313 --> 00:29:19.649
some of the other options
that you have as well.

602
00:29:19.649 --> 00:29:21.088
So I think that's it.

603
00:29:21.088 --> 00:29:25.582
>> That's awesome, yeah, all the things
that I use on a daily basis so many times.

604
00:29:25.582 --> 00:29:29.126
And hopefully now you guys will
use it on a daily basis and

605
00:29:29.126 --> 00:29:33.740
see the beautiful things that these
different things can do for you.

606
00:29:33.740 --> 00:29:35.410
Different, how many times
did we say different?

607
00:29:35.410 --> 00:29:36.385
All right, we're gonna stop.

608
00:29:36.385 --> 00:29:40.040
>> [LAUGH] So wrapping it up,
signing off for Creative Pro TV,

609
00:29:40.040 --> 00:29:41.670
I've been your host Vonne Smith.

610
00:29:41.670 --> 00:29:42.620
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

611
00:29:42.620 --> 00:29:43.443
>> And we'll see you soon.

612
00:29:43.443 --> 00:29:47.066
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to use different tools to draw paths.  They review the pencil, brush, blob brush, and smooth tool as well as discuss different options associated with each tool.
episodes.title: Freehand Drawing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.452
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.452 --> 00:00:11.205
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.205 --> 00:00:11.863
Hello, everyone.

4
00:00:11.863 --> 00:00:15.600
And welcome back to another
exciting edition of CREATIVEPRO.TV.

5
00:00:15.600 --> 00:00:17.630
I'm your host, Vonne Smith.

6
00:00:17.630 --> 00:00:20.120
And this is Illustrator CC 2017.

7
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:23.280
And in this episode we're gonna be
talking about freehand drawing.

8
00:00:23.280 --> 00:00:25.770
I'm feeling free already.

9
00:00:25.770 --> 00:00:31.435
So, here to help us unleash our inner
creativity is Ms. Emily Ramsey.

10
00:00:31.435 --> 00:00:33.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes, thank you.

11
00:00:33.960 --> 00:00:34.580
Hi, welcome to the show.

12
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:35.570
We're glad to be back.

13
00:00:35.570 --> 00:00:36.281
Why can't I talk?

14
00:00:36.281 --> 00:00:37.548
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, yes,

15
00:00:37.548 --> 00:00:41.910
so we're basically just going to liberate
ourselves from all of the rectangles and

16
00:00:41.910 --> 00:00:44.330
circles and all the crazy
stuff that you've been doing.

17
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:45.820
I'm gonna do some freehand drawing.

18
00:00:45.820 --> 00:00:49.800
The funny thing about Illustrator is,
I'm a graphic designer by day.

19
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:51.570
I do this all day long.

20
00:00:51.570 --> 00:00:54.135
I don't really feel like I free-hand draw,
very well, right?

21
00:00:54.135 --> 00:00:57.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can do a lot in Illustrator without

22
00:00:57.130 --> 00:00:59.670
having the ability to free-hand draw.

23
00:00:59.670 --> 00:01:03.800
But it is an option there that's available
to you, because Illustrator is great for

24
00:01:03.800 --> 00:01:06.690
things like cartoons or
drawings or whatever it may be.

25
00:01:06.690 --> 00:01:08.540
It has a lot of different
options available to you.

26
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:11.347
So we'll go ahead and
get into free-hand drawing.

27
00:01:11.347 --> 00:01:13.860
Now, with this pretty much, I think,

28
00:01:13.860 --> 00:01:17.518
all the tools that we're gonna mention
here, are gonna be related to open path.

29
00:01:17.518 --> 00:01:21.600
So we're gonna need to have that stroke
color applied, things like that, and

30
00:01:21.600 --> 00:01:24.730
just kind of being aware of the fact
that we are on an open path.

31
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:27.080
So with our freehand drawing,
we're gonna go ahead and

32
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:28.480
start off with paint brush tool.

33
00:01:28.480 --> 00:01:34.340
So I'm going to go ahead and grab a little
more of a fun color than just black,

34
00:01:34.340 --> 00:01:35.940
why not?

35
00:01:35.940 --> 00:01:39.234
>> And just a quick note,
could you definitely, you wanna head and

36
00:01:39.234 --> 00:01:40.550
clear the fill.

37
00:01:40.550 --> 00:01:42.585
>> Yeah, yes, good point.

38
00:01:42.585 --> 00:01:44.384
[LAUGH]

Yes.

00:01:05.814 --> 00:01:10.037
I'm like, I know cuz that's something
that would always freak me out of like,

25
00:01:10.037 --> 00:01:10.992
I drew this path.

26
00:01:10.992 --> 00:01:13.580
I always do it with
a drawing with flowers.

27
00:01:13.580 --> 00:01:16.370
We would draw the stem, and
then now you wanna draw a little leaf.

28
00:01:16.370 --> 00:01:18.554
Cuz I was something of obsessed
with when I was a kid,

29
00:01:18.554 --> 00:01:20.052
like drawing flowers everywhere.

30
00:01:20.052 --> 00:01:25.216
And so it's like, why is this leaf not
being a leaf, and the stem went away,

31
00:01:25.216 --> 00:01:29.600
and it's just kind of the nature
of that particular tool.

32
00:01:29.600 --> 00:01:31.200
And so if you're doing it,

33
00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:35.611
we wanted to go ahead and
let you know why and how to avoid it.

34
00:01:35.611 --> 00:01:36.887
>> [LAUGH] Right, right.

35
00:01:36.887 --> 00:01:40.432
You're not doing anything wrong,
it's just the way that the tool works.

36
00:01:40.432 --> 00:01:43.670
So I'm gonna go ahead and
start in the Pencil tool.

37
00:01:43.670 --> 00:01:45.050
So I have that pulled up here.

38
00:01:45.050 --> 00:01:46.780
Now, couple things we wanted to point out.

39
00:01:46.780 --> 00:01:50.230
I'm gonna attempt this fancy zoom
trick that Vonne just taught me.

40
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:51.880
If it all goes awry, I apologize.

41
00:01:51.880 --> 00:01:55.140
But, you see how with my Pencil tool,
I have that pencil and

42
00:01:55.140 --> 00:01:58.220
then I have kind of
the asterisks next to it?

43
00:01:58.220 --> 00:01:58.980
I'm gonna zoom out.

44
00:01:58.980 --> 00:02:00.590
I'm gonna attempt, that's the hard part.

45
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:02.490
Okay, there we go, we got it.

46
00:02:02.490 --> 00:02:06.400
So what we have here is that's pretty much
gonna show up any time we're creating

47
00:02:06.400 --> 00:02:08.860
a new pencil line, basically.

48
00:02:08.860 --> 00:02:11.502
So I can here and I'd just be like,
okay I'm gonna draw.

49
00:02:11.502 --> 00:02:13.300
I'm not really a flowers person.

50
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:17.000
I'm more of a squiggly lady, so
we're gonna do our squiggles.

51
00:02:17.000 --> 00:02:20.900
And we can see, okay, anytime I'm
doing a new squiggle, if you will,

52
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:23.570
that's gonna show up
with that asterisk there.

53
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:25.930
Now, what you'll see here,
I just kinda hovered over the end of it.

54
00:02:25.930 --> 00:02:28.000
I didn't even intentionally do this.

55
00:02:28.000 --> 00:02:31.110
And when I did that,
you'll see I have my asterisk.

56
00:02:31.110 --> 00:02:32.560
Oops, I moved other there.

57
00:02:32.560 --> 00:02:36.770
From the asterisk,
if I kinda go up here to

58
00:02:36.770 --> 00:02:41.960
that Pencil tool with the straight line,
the little diagonal slash there.

59
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:42.670
I'm gonna zoom out.

60
00:02:43.990 --> 00:02:46.067
It's like, give me a second here.

61
00:02:46.067 --> 00:02:47.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> Takes a while to get used to it.

62
00:02:47.570 --> 00:02:48.380
>> Yeah, yeah.

63
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:49.040
It throws you off.

64
00:02:49.040 --> 00:02:52.731
So what we can do here, now that we see
we have that line, it's like, okay,

65
00:02:52.731 --> 00:02:53.793
what does that mean?

66
00:02:53.793 --> 00:02:57.784
That basically just let's you know,
when you see that icon or

67
00:02:57.784 --> 00:03:02.890
that change to your cursor rather,
that's gonna continue on the path.

68
00:03:02.890 --> 00:03:04.230
It's not going to create a new one.

69
00:03:04.230 --> 00:03:08.890
So you kind of have to look out
anytime you are too close to a path.

70
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:12.379
If I'm trying to start a new one, but
I'm kinda too close to this old one,

71
00:03:12.379 --> 00:03:15.830
it's automatically just going to kind
of pick up and adjust that there.

72
00:03:15.830 --> 00:03:19.730
So you see, if I go back to my black
Arrow tool, that's all one path,

73
00:03:19.730 --> 00:03:21.440
it's not two separate ones.

74
00:03:21.440 --> 00:03:25.310
So that is something that you do wanna
pay attention to with your Pencil tool.

75
00:03:25.310 --> 00:03:27.260
Now, something else that you'll note.

76
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:32.020
If I go here,
rather than just kind of continuing on,

77
00:03:32.020 --> 00:03:34.810
I also have the option of kinda
picking up in the middle.

78
00:03:34.810 --> 00:03:39.515
So, I can go here,
I'm gonna draw a new squiggle, and you see

79
00:03:39.515 --> 00:03:42.965
where you have all the little points,
you see kind of the blue dots here?

80
00:03:42.965 --> 00:03:45.705
If I go and hover over the blue dot and
get nothing, and

81
00:03:45.705 --> 00:03:47.265
then it's like I have nothing.

82
00:03:47.265 --> 00:03:50.095
What does that tell me if it's just blank?

83
00:03:50.095 --> 00:03:54.755
That basically let's you know you can
kind of continue on from that point.

84
00:03:54.755 --> 00:03:57.845
So say I didn't really want
this extra stuff on the side,

85
00:03:57.845 --> 00:03:58.925
it's like I didn't mean to draw that.

86
00:03:58.925 --> 00:04:00.940
I just want to continue on from here.

87
00:04:00.940 --> 00:04:02.900
Well, when I see that,
I can just go ahead and

88
00:04:02.900 --> 00:04:07.040
just pick it up from really the middle or
any point of the path.

89
00:04:07.040 --> 00:04:08.752
So I can go ahead and do this, and

90
00:04:08.752 --> 00:04:12.400
then be like actually I think
I'll kinda wrap that down here.

91
00:04:12.400 --> 00:04:14.490
And you can go ahead and
draw that like that.

92
00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:18.340
So it's those little things
that we were mentioning that

93
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:21.040
can kind of screw you up with
the pencil or the brush or whatever.

94
00:04:21.040 --> 00:04:24.220
>> Yeah, and like, in my flower,
right, that would be the stem.

95
00:04:24.220 --> 00:04:28.403
And then I'd go to draw the leaf,
and then it would be continue, or

96
00:04:28.403 --> 00:04:32.840
picking up at wherever I had had
the pencil, and then draw it that way.

97
00:04:32.840 --> 00:04:37.050
And it took me a long
time to figure that out.

98
00:04:37.050 --> 00:04:39.400
And those little tiny icons are so cute.

99
00:04:39.400 --> 00:04:42.706
And we'll see this back when we go back
into the Pen tool or forward, back,

100
00:04:42.706 --> 00:04:44.560
whichever way we're going.

101
00:04:44.560 --> 00:04:48.920
So you'll see these slashes and
the asterisks which used to be an x.

102
00:04:48.920 --> 00:04:52.833
So if you hear me referring to it,
the pen with an x or the pencil with an x,

103
00:04:52.833 --> 00:04:55.027
it used to be an x and
now it's an asterisk.

104
00:04:55.027 --> 00:05:01.340
But again, I'm always hearing the history
lessons of Illustrator [INAUDIBLE].

105
00:05:01.340 --> 00:05:02.100
But that's something,

106
00:05:02.100 --> 00:05:06.780
like you said, that could be really
misleading if you were drawing.

107
00:05:06.780 --> 00:05:11.040
Cuz normally, if you're drawing freehand,
you're just drawing with a pencil.

108
00:05:11.040 --> 00:05:14.810
And if you want separate paths, you do
need to be conscientious about that.

109
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:15.510
>> Yeah, yeah.

110
00:05:15.510 --> 00:05:17.900
It's a minor but important thing.

111
00:05:17.900 --> 00:05:20.990
So, I'm going to go ahead and delete
all these, because I want to show you

112
00:05:20.990 --> 00:05:25.180
kind of what this looks like in
the Paintbrush tool, excuse me.

113
00:05:25.180 --> 00:05:28.690
We will notice, okay, actually
before I do that, you'll see, okay,

114
00:05:28.690 --> 00:05:33.260
when I was doing this with my Pencil tool,
you can see my Pencil tool,

115
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:36.110
as I was creating things,
it stayed selected.

116
00:05:36.110 --> 00:05:38.960
So those blue points showed up for me.

117
00:05:38.960 --> 00:05:40.569
Now, I kinda want to point that out and

118
00:05:40.569 --> 00:05:43.144
then show you how that's
different in the Paintbrush tool.

119
00:05:43.144 --> 00:05:45.963
If I go to the Paintbrush tool,
and I go like this,

120
00:05:45.963 --> 00:05:49.180
you'll see I still have my
same kind of asterisk there.

121
00:05:49.180 --> 00:05:50.830
I still have that option.

122
00:05:50.830 --> 00:05:53.130
But what happens is you don't
see those little points.

123
00:05:53.130 --> 00:05:54.435
It's not selecting it.

124
00:05:54.435 --> 00:05:57.080
Why they do that differently,
I don't know.

125
00:05:57.080 --> 00:06:00.635
But what you have to do, you still have
the options to kind of continue and

126
00:06:00.635 --> 00:06:03.804
go on like that, but you need to
go back to your black Arrow Tool.

127
00:06:03.804 --> 00:06:09.160
You need to select that Paintbrush,
or that stroke that you did.

128
00:06:09.160 --> 00:06:11.914
And then you have the option
to kind of continue on.

129
00:06:11.914 --> 00:06:14.080
And you can see that I went ahead and
did that.

130
00:06:14.080 --> 00:06:17.570
It didn't give me quite the information
that the other one did, but

131
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:18.790
I still did have that option.

132
00:06:18.790 --> 00:06:20.335
And you can see that's all one line now.

133
00:06:20.335 --> 00:06:23.110
>> Yeah, and that is so weird, okay?

134
00:06:23.110 --> 00:06:27.365
So the Pencil, you draw and
it stays selected.

135
00:06:27.365 --> 00:06:28.760
And you get those different options.

136
00:06:28.760 --> 00:06:32.830
The Brush, you draw, let go,
and then it's not selected.

137
00:06:32.830 --> 00:06:37.540
So anytime even if I was trying to draw
like the flower and stem, with the Brush,

138
00:06:37.540 --> 00:06:43.340
it would make a separate path every time,
it's always starting a new path.

139
00:06:43.340 --> 00:06:47.100
But doing the continuing select it.

140
00:06:47.100 --> 00:06:50.460
So really, really slight but
huge at the same time.

141
00:06:50.460 --> 00:06:51.832
>> Right, right.

142
00:06:51.832 --> 00:06:52.670
I totally agree.

143
00:06:52.670 --> 00:06:55.610
And so if we go back here,
we can see, okay,

144
00:06:55.610 --> 00:06:59.130
I can do that, I create a new line,
you see it's not selected.

145
00:06:59.130 --> 00:07:01.169
I need to go back to my black Arrow Tool.

146
00:07:01.169 --> 00:07:03.230
But again, I still have that option.

147
00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:05.320
I can go ahead and say, okay,
I see a little point here.

148
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:06.920
They're kind of hard to
see cuz my line is blue.

149
00:07:06.920 --> 00:07:09.500
Maybe I'll make my line orange or
something like that.

150
00:07:09.500 --> 00:07:13.270
I see that little point here, I can go,
boop, go ahead and create it from there.

151
00:07:13.270 --> 00:07:15.930
So you still have all the same options,

152
00:07:15.930 --> 00:07:20.010
just that weird having to go back to
my black Arrow Tool step between it.

153
00:07:20.010 --> 00:07:25.720
And you'll see the icons,
the cursor with your Paintbrush Tool.

154
00:07:25.720 --> 00:07:31.140
Just not quite as intuitive as
they are with the Pencil Tool.

155
00:07:31.140 --> 00:07:32.650
They don't give you as much information.

156
00:07:32.650 --> 00:07:36.560
So again, something that we really
just wanted to point out to you.

157
00:07:36.560 --> 00:07:38.350
Now, to kind of continue on,

158
00:07:38.350 --> 00:07:41.380
what I also wanna look at is
that Blob Brush Tool again.

159
00:07:41.380 --> 00:07:44.550
So the Blob Brush Tool,
it's a favorite around here.

160
00:07:44.550 --> 00:07:45.360
We love it.

161
00:07:45.360 --> 00:07:52.460
We did this and we could kinda see, okay,
all of that creates one solid grouping.

162
00:07:52.460 --> 00:07:54.420
So as soon as you're done with your blob,

163
00:07:54.420 --> 00:07:59.020
anytime I add to it,
it's gonna go ahead and create that.

164
00:07:59.020 --> 00:08:02.240
It almost turns it from a Stroke
to a Fill and creates that.

165
00:08:02.240 --> 00:08:05.560
Now, something that I specifically
wanted to point out here was that

166
00:08:05.560 --> 00:08:08.990
even if I go back, say I go off and
do something else.

167
00:08:08.990 --> 00:08:14.220
I'm totally working on something,
something very interesting over here.

168
00:08:14.220 --> 00:08:19.140
As long as I stay in that same color,
when I go back to my Blob Brush tool,

169
00:08:19.140 --> 00:08:23.400
I can always add to this,
and it's still going to

170
00:08:23.400 --> 00:08:27.740
continue on that path just
the same way that it was before.

171
00:08:27.740 --> 00:08:29.520
Now, slight difference here.

172
00:08:29.520 --> 00:08:34.510
If I change my color, so if I go to
blue or something and then try and

173
00:08:34.510 --> 00:08:37.880
blob over this,
then it's not gonna all fuse together.

174
00:08:37.880 --> 00:08:41.360
Then, it's going to be separate
in this case Fills, rather.

175
00:08:41.360 --> 00:08:43.930
So you can see, okay, that separated out.

176
00:08:43.930 --> 00:08:47.155
So, Illustrator really just looks
at color as a way of saying,

177
00:08:47.155 --> 00:08:50.290
okay, if I have orange,
she wants all that to be together.

178
00:08:50.290 --> 00:08:53.190
If I'm doing a separate color, then we're
gonna go ahead and separate it out.

179
00:08:53.190 --> 00:08:57.730
So again, just kind of a minor thing, but
something we did want to point out to you.

180
00:08:57.730 --> 00:09:02.030
>> And since we're on a whole selected
versus not selected in the Blob Brush,

181
00:09:02.030 --> 00:09:05.990
it does not have to be selected
before you start painting.

182
00:09:05.990 --> 00:09:10.270
As you had shown right there,
nothing was selected first,

183
00:09:10.270 --> 00:09:13.370
it was just the same color,
and the colors overlap.

184
00:09:13.370 --> 00:09:18.490
So it like fused together and became a
bigger blob because it was the same color.

185
00:09:18.490 --> 00:09:19.190
And that's where,

186
00:09:19.190 --> 00:09:23.230
if it was a slightly different orange,
it wouldn't add together.

187
00:09:23.230 --> 00:09:27.570
So it has to be the exact color,
and then you can go ahead and

188
00:09:27.570 --> 00:09:30.310
make your closed path as she's saying for

189
00:09:30.310 --> 00:09:34.305
the Fill versus the open path with
the Pencil and the Brush, yeah.

190
00:09:34.305 --> 00:09:37.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> I have to kind of stop and

191
00:09:37.190 --> 00:09:39.965
think which tool because they're so
different.

192
00:09:39.965 --> 00:09:40.960
It's a little weird.

193
00:09:40.960 --> 00:09:44.445
I mean, I can see, it's one of those
like why did you do that Adobe?

194
00:09:44.445 --> 00:09:46.805
But also there's a reason, well,

195
00:09:46.805 --> 00:09:50.662
maybe sometimes you don't
wanna continue on the path, so

196
00:09:50.662 --> 00:09:56.033
use the Brush tool cuz they can work very
similar than just lines and everything.

197
00:09:56.033 --> 00:09:59.098
So gives us options,
it's always good to have options.

198
00:09:59.098 --> 00:10:01.199
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes, options are good.

199
00:10:01.199 --> 00:10:03.730
And Illustrator is very good
at providing you options.

200
00:10:03.730 --> 00:10:05.775
So, I don't know how many
other ways to say it,

201
00:10:05.775 --> 00:10:08.894
but those were just a couple little
things we wanted to point out to you and

202
00:10:08.894 --> 00:10:10.650
kind of add into that freehand drawing.

203
00:10:10.650 --> 00:10:12.078
So I think that is it.

204
00:10:12.078 --> 00:10:15.350
There should be no more
information that we add in here.

205
00:10:15.350 --> 00:10:16.050
But you never know.

206
00:10:16.050 --> 00:10:17.278
So we're always coming up with stuff.

207
00:10:17.278 --> 00:10:18.683
But thank you, Vonne.

208
00:10:18.683 --> 00:10:20.464
>> Well, thank you, Emily.

209
00:10:20.464 --> 00:10:23.046
That was great information to go ahead and

210
00:10:23.046 --> 00:10:26.150
append to what we had
already talked about.

211
00:10:26.150 --> 00:10:30.000
And I think this time we
are done with this tool.

212
00:10:30.000 --> 00:10:33.530
We got very in the weeds in this one,
but it is for your benefit.

213
00:10:33.530 --> 00:10:37.095
So hopefully you won't curse our names or
like why didn't they tell us this?

214
00:10:37.095 --> 00:10:38.651
Well, we did in this part two.

215
00:10:38.651 --> 00:10:39.533
All right, good.

216
00:10:39.533 --> 00:10:40.276
So we're done.

217
00:10:40.276 --> 00:10:42.180
We are gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

218
00:10:42.180 --> 00:10:45.268
Signing off for CreativeProTV,
I've been your host Vonne Smith

219
00:10:45.268 --> 00:10:46.290
>> And I am Emily Ramsey.

220
00:10:46.290 --> 00:10:48.032
>> And we'll see you soon.

221
00:10:48.032 --> 00:10:50.260
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate and explain the importance of artboards.  They show how to use the artboard tool and the artboard panel to create new artboards and  how to modify options such as resizing, renaming, rearranging the order.
episodes.title: Artboards
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:06.659
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.659 --> 00:00:11.235
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.235 --> 00:00:15.902
Hello everyone and welcome back to another
exciting edition of Creative Pro TV,

4
00:00:15.902 --> 00:00:20.653
I'm your host Vonne Smith and we are
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:20.653 --> 00:00:24.100
In this episode, we're gonna be
talking all about art boards.

6
00:00:24.100 --> 00:00:27.140
Yes, the wonderful art board and
you're like what is that?

7
00:00:27.140 --> 00:00:28.980
Well, we're gonna tell you.

8
00:00:28.980 --> 00:00:30.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> Here to help us is Miss Elly Ramsay.

9
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:32.190
Hello again, how are you?

10
00:00:32.190 --> 00:00:33.119
>> Good, good.

11
00:00:33.119 --> 00:00:37.335
I like how you try to perk it up and make
art board sound so much more jazzy and

12
00:00:37.335 --> 00:00:38.367
exciting, yes.

13
00:00:38.367 --> 00:00:40.098
>> Jazzy.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so

14
00:00:40.098 --> 00:00:45.165
art board's not always the most
exciting sounding right.

15
00:00:45.165 --> 00:00:49.015
You're probably thinking why do I really
want to watch this when I could do more

16
00:00:49.015 --> 00:00:51.085
fun stuff like color and all that?

17
00:00:51.085 --> 00:00:53.725
The thing about it is art
boards are just gonna be so

18
00:00:53.725 --> 00:00:55.635
useful to your illustrator work flow.

19
00:00:55.635 --> 00:00:57.580
That's really where we want to use them.

20
00:00:57.580 --> 00:00:59.790
Now we've said the word art boards before.

21
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:03.860
We've kind of talked about setting up
a new file, setting up art boards.

22
00:01:03.860 --> 00:01:07.310
Your probably at this extent
thinking that it's kind of just

23
00:01:07.310 --> 00:01:10.400
pages that you would expect in
a program like Microsoft Word.

24
00:01:10.400 --> 00:01:14.140
You have an eight and a half by 11 page,
and everything is exactly the same.

25
00:01:14.140 --> 00:01:18.740
Well, art boards provide so much more
flexibility in that, which is great

26
00:01:18.740 --> 00:01:22.260
because in Illustrator often times we're

I wanna go ahead and rename these.

246
00:12:38.820 --> 00:12:41.740
I could have done this when I was creating
my art boards in my art board tool, but

247
00:12:41.740 --> 00:12:42.690
I can also do it here.

248
00:12:42.690 --> 00:12:45.530
So what I need to do is I need to
double click on the name itself.

249
00:12:45.530 --> 00:12:47.520
Don't try and
double click off to the side.

250
00:12:47.520 --> 00:12:49.870
Double click on the actual words.

251
00:12:49.870 --> 00:12:52.770
And you can see not only is it
gonna bring that one in focus.

252
00:12:52.770 --> 00:12:54.620
But it also gives you
the opportunity to name it.

253
00:12:54.620 --> 00:12:57.520
So I'll call this Original Mickey.

254
00:12:59.340 --> 00:13:03.120
And then I'll double click on Art Board 5,
again on the words.

255
00:13:03.120 --> 00:13:04.330
Call this Pink Mickey.

256
00:13:05.575 --> 00:13:09.980
And then double-click on art-board six,
and I will call that one orange Mickey.

257
00:13:09.980 --> 00:13:11.810
Now you will see that time
it did not highlight.

258
00:13:11.810 --> 00:13:13.740
I think it just had to do
with specifically where

259
00:13:13.740 --> 00:13:14.780
I clicked that first time.

260
00:13:14.780 --> 00:13:17.580
If you kind of click off to the side,
that is what is going to take you there.

261
00:13:17.580 --> 00:13:18.230
>> I think on the number.

262
00:13:18.230 --> 00:13:19.325
If you click right on the number.

263
00:13:19.325 --> 00:13:23.834
Number, I think that's the one that
selects or moves or no nevermind.

264
00:13:23.834 --> 00:13:26.325
>> [LAUGH]
>> Wrong program.

265
00:13:26.325 --> 00:13:33.245
[LAUGH] It's okay,
I've got the computer so I can test it.

266
00:13:33.245 --> 00:13:38.505
What we're looking at here is we
have that orignal pink and orange.

267
00:13:38.505 --> 00:13:40.995
I'm gonna zoom out so
we can look at these all again.

268
00:13:40.995 --> 00:13:41.680
Now.

269
00:13:41.680 --> 00:13:44.880
Why does the artboard
panel make a difference?

270
00:13:44.880 --> 00:13:46.520
So you're probably thinking, okay, great.

271
00:13:46.520 --> 00:13:48.030
I could've done that in my artboard tool.

272
00:13:48.030 --> 00:13:49.260
Whatever.

273
00:13:49.260 --> 00:13:53.550
The thing about it is with our artboard
panel you see this one, two, three?

274
00:13:53.550 --> 00:13:59.330
That's letting us know that the order how
our artboards are really going to save or

275
00:13:59.330 --> 00:13:59.880
export.

276
00:13:59.880 --> 00:14:03.660
So even if I were to go in my artboard.

277
00:14:03.660 --> 00:14:07.290
Art board tool again and
kind of rearrange these so

278
00:14:07.290 --> 00:14:09.850
that it looked like something like this.

279
00:14:09.850 --> 00:14:12.640
What you're going to see
in my art board panel,

280
00:14:12.640 --> 00:14:15.390
that original Mickey is still number one,
so even though

281
00:14:15.390 --> 00:14:18.610
you may be thinking okay this is going
to save kind of from left to right.

282
00:14:18.610 --> 00:14:23.580
How you would expect it to, original
Mickey is still going to be number one

283
00:14:23.580 --> 00:14:28.260
PDF specifically, you're gonna see
that original black Mickey first.

284
00:14:28.260 --> 00:14:30.380
Now what can I do about this?

285
00:14:30.380 --> 00:14:35.840
Obviously, you can't always just go off of
the same order that you created something,

286
00:14:35.840 --> 00:14:37.040
which is how this is being made.

287
00:14:37.040 --> 00:14:40.350
I made the orignal Mickey first,
and then the others.

288
00:14:40.350 --> 00:14:43.430
So what you can actually do is,
you can drag and drop these.

289
00:14:43.430 --> 00:14:46.840
So If I want to go in the order
that I see from left to right.

290
00:14:46.840 --> 00:14:49.920
Here pink original and then orange.

291
00:14:49.920 --> 00:14:52.480
What I can do is I can just drag and
drop this.

292
00:14:52.480 --> 00:14:54.800
Kind of like what we did with our layers.

293
00:14:54.800 --> 00:14:56.430
And you can see as I drag and

294
00:14:56.430 --> 00:15:00.290
drop that original Mickey layer
I have that blue line there.

295
00:15:00.290 --> 00:15:03.320
And that will go ahead and
let me know, okay, I kinda drop that.

296
00:15:03.320 --> 00:15:08.080
You're not gonna see any sort of change
here, but if I were go into a file

297
00:15:08.080 --> 00:15:12.550
save as and save as a PDF, you would see
that the order would be impacted there.

298
00:15:12.550 --> 00:15:15.260
So I really think that's.

299
00:15:15.260 --> 00:15:16.830
It for art boards.

300
00:15:16.830 --> 00:15:20.320
At least to get you guys to a kind
of understanding of how they work.

301
00:15:20.320 --> 00:15:23.707
You can do some things like adding
a bleed and stuff like that, but

302
00:15:23.707 --> 00:15:25.877
we'll talk about those all separately.

303
00:15:25.877 --> 00:15:29.470
So, I think that's it,
that should give you a good introduction.

304
00:15:29.470 --> 00:15:32.600
>> Yes, like you said,
not the most exciting tool,

305
00:15:32.600 --> 00:15:36.500
but when you start getting
really into design stuff and

306
00:15:36.500 --> 00:15:40.650
you have a project that you have
multiple iterations of the same thing.

307
00:15:40.650 --> 00:15:43.260
It actually becomes quite awesome to you.

308
00:15:43.260 --> 00:15:46.250
That's colorful but super useful and

309
00:15:46.250 --> 00:15:50.190
it makes your life a lot easier,
and that's always a good thing.

310
00:15:50.190 --> 00:15:53.490
So thank you so much for that, that was
awesome and we're gonna go ahead and

311
00:15:53.490 --> 00:15:56.450
wrap this episode up, so
signing off for Creative Pro TV,

312
00:15:56.450 --> 00:15:58.150
I've been your host Vonne Smith.

313
00:15:58.150 --> 00:15:59.070
>> And Emily Ramsey.

314
00:15:59.070 --> 00:16:00.851
>> And we'll see you soon.

315
00:16:00.851 --> 00:16:06.459
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily demonstrate a variety of different tools, panels, and techniques for modifying objects.  They cover the eyedropper tool, transform panel and tool, create rounded corners with the selection tool and transform panel,  and scale stroke and effects options.
episodes.title: Object Transformation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.097
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.097 --> 00:00:10.997
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10.997 --> 00:00:14.762
>> Hello everyone, and welcome to
another edition of Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:14.762 --> 00:00:20.594
I am your host Vonne Smith, and we're
continuing on with Illustrator 2017 CC.

5
00:00:20.594 --> 00:00:24.120
I think I just flipped those around, but
you know what, you know where we're at.

6
00:00:24.120 --> 00:00:25.107
We're in Illustrator.

7
00:00:25.107 --> 00:00:28.037
[LAUGH] And here to help us with
our episode that we're doing,

8
00:00:28.037 --> 00:00:29.940
and I honestly forgot we were gonna do.

9
00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:33.437
So Emily, why don't you help me
say what we're gonna do, welcome.

10
00:00:33.437 --> 00:00:34.249
>> [LAUGH] Let me tell you, yes.

11
00:00:34.249 --> 00:00:35.435
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

12
00:00:35.435 --> 00:00:37.219
>> Let me tell you all about it, Vonne.

13
00:00:37.219 --> 00:00:39.238
We are doing object transformations.

14
00:00:39.238 --> 00:00:44.064
And the reason Vonne can't remember, is
because we had a hard time titling this.

15
00:00:44.064 --> 00:00:45.799
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We did.

16
00:00:45.799 --> 00:00:46.830
>> Yeah, yeah.

17
00:00:46.830 --> 00:00:51.690
It's just kind of some things that like,
yes you can use them to transform objects.

18
00:00:51.690 --> 00:00:54.380
But they're kind of
just things that again,

19
00:00:54.380 --> 00:00:56.730
make your life a lot easier
when working with Illustrator.

20
00:00:56.730 --> 00:01:00.579
>> It was one of those we didn't really
wanna title it eyedropper transformation,

21
00:01:00.579 --> 00:01:02.511
tool end panel, and rounding corners.

22
00:01:02.511 --> 00:01:03.571
That's a really long title.

23
00:01:03.571 --> 00:01:06.620
>> Yeah.
>> So object transformation here we are.

24
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:07.343
[LAUGH]
>> Right, right.

25
00:01:07.343 --> 00:01:09.071
It's a little more succinct for you there.

26
00:01:09.071 --> 00:01:09.783
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:09.783 --> 00:01:11.780
>> Yeah, so what we are going to be doing?

28
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:14.940
We're gonna be talking about
the Eye Dropper tool, which is awesome.

29
00:01:14.940 --> 00:01:18.900
And then we're gonna get a little bit
more into the transformed panel and

30
00:01:18.900 --> 00:01:21.490
the options that you can do there,
that are a little bit different from

31
00:01:21.490 --> 00:01:24.350
just the regular transformations
that we've been doing.

32
00:01:24.350 --> 00:01:26.640
And then also kind of round some corners.

33
00:01:26.640 --> 00:01:30.530
We'll talk a little about
the transformed tool at the end as well.

34
00:01:30.530 --> 00:01:33.785
But I really wanna go ahead and
get started with the Eye Dropper tool,

35
00:01:33.785 --> 00:01:37.170
because is my favorite of all
the things that we're discussing today.

36
00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:39.716
So the Eye Dropper tool, what it does?

37
00:01:39.716 --> 00:01:45.226
It basically just gonna copy appearance
attributes from one object to the other.

38
00:01:45.226 --> 00:01:48.712
So let's say we're working on something
and I go ahead, I've pulled this up here.

39
00:01:48.712 --> 00:01:52.300
You don't need this by any means,
I just wanna use it for example's sake.

40
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:54.590
We have some texts that
I've already formatted and

41
00:01:54.590 --> 00:01:57.770
then I have just a generic shape
that I've already formatted as well.

42
00:01:57.770 --> 00:02:01.560
So let's say,
we'll start of with the example of texts.

43
00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:04.131
I am working on some texts in my document,

44
00:02:04.131 --> 00:02:08.840
wouldn't be that unusual if I was working
on a flyer or something like that?

45
00:02:08.840 --> 00:02:12.956
That if I had some other text,
like I can go ahead and call this-

46
00:02:12.956 --> 00:02:13.458
>> Other text.

47
00:02:13.458 --> 00:02:14.379
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah.

48
00:02:14.379 --> 00:02:18.491
It's like sample two,
I don't know, other text.

49
00:02:18.491 --> 00:02:19.950
I have this down here.

50
00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:25.290
What I could do, if I wanted to be,
I don't wanna take the long way.

51
00:02:25.290 --> 00:02:26.774
I could go back into my character panel.

52
00:02:26.774 --> 00:02:29.913
I could go ahead and give this the font
that I used, and I could go and

53
00:02:29.913 --> 00:02:31.386
choose the color and all that.

54
00:02:31.386 --> 00:02:33.321
I could also make my life a lot easier and

55
00:02:33.321 --> 00:02:35.450
I could do this using
the Eye Dropper tool.

56
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:38.930
So all I have to do,
I have this other text selected.

57
00:02:38.930 --> 00:02:43.600
Whatever I want to be transformed is
selected, and then I need to go ahead and

58
00:02:43.600 --> 00:02:44.718
grab my Eye Dropper tool.

59
00:02:44.718 --> 00:02:47.712
My Eye Dropper tool just looks
like the eyedropper on my toolbar,

60
00:02:47.712 --> 00:02:51.770
kind of hard to explain where this one is.

61
00:02:51.770 --> 00:02:55.470
It's kind of in the lower third,
if you will, but

62
00:02:55.470 --> 00:02:57.510
it's I think a little bit
more obvious of an icon.

63
00:02:57.510 --> 00:03:00.320
So it looks like the Eye Dropper,
and I think the hot key for

64
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:01.740
that was just the letter i.

65
00:03:01.740 --> 00:03:04.110
So if you wanna go ahead and
use that, you also can.

66
00:03:04.110 --> 00:03:06.814
So I'm gonna go ahead and
use my Eye Dropper tool, grab that.

67
00:03:06.814 --> 00:03:10.970
And then now what I'm gonna do, so
simple and stupid, you can go ahead and

68
00:03:10.970 --> 00:03:14.339
just a single click on whatever
formatting you wanna copy.

69
00:03:14.339 --> 00:03:17.486
So in my case I wanna copy this,
I'm gonna single click on that.

70
00:03:17.486 --> 00:03:21.034
And what you will notice one thing I do
wanna point out with text specifically,

71
00:03:21.034 --> 00:03:24.663
you're gonna see I got that Eye Dropper
tool, but then I also have a T next to it.

72
00:03:24.663 --> 00:03:28.185
And that just lets me know that I'm
copying the actual text formatting,

73
00:03:28.185 --> 00:03:31.592
rather than just the color which is
something that we can kinda see when

74
00:03:31.592 --> 00:03:32.820
we get into our objects.

75
00:03:32.820 --> 00:03:35.620
So I'm actually copying
the text formatting, and

76
00:03:35.620 --> 00:03:39.010
I can see that because I have
that little T letting me know.

77
00:03:39.010 --> 00:03:40.370
That's just when I'm hovering over it.

78
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:44.120
And when I single click,
all of that's done for me.

79
00:03:44.120 --> 00:03:48.980
>> This is something that,
I knew about the Eye Dropper tool.

80
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:51.332
I had no idea, honestly,
all the way up until this point,

81
00:03:51.332 --> 00:03:53.165
I had no idea that you
could do that with text.

82
00:03:53.165 --> 00:03:56.452
And it was really just before
this episode, I'm just like, no.

83
00:03:56.452 --> 00:03:58.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> Are you serious?

84
00:03:58.970 --> 00:04:03.641
It blew my mind,
because I did not that was possible.

85
00:04:03.641 --> 00:04:06.001
>> Yes.
>> So I am very happy today.

86
00:04:06.001 --> 00:04:09.781
[LAUGH]
>> I'm glad that it can just really bring

87
00:04:09.781 --> 00:04:10.393
you joy.

88
00:04:10.393 --> 00:04:10.930
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

89
00:04:10.930 --> 00:04:12.357
>> But yeah, I mean,

90
00:04:12.357 --> 00:04:17.726
that it's such a simple thing, but
it really makes a huge difference.

91
00:04:17.726 --> 00:04:20.411
And the cool thing about
the Eye Dropper tool is that,

92
00:04:20.411 --> 00:04:23.824
you're not really limited to just
one thing that you can use it for.

93
00:04:23.824 --> 00:04:26.017
So we used it for text.

94
00:04:26.017 --> 00:04:30.220
What if I wanted some shapes,
like I wanted to go ahead and

95
00:04:30.220 --> 00:04:33.732
draw a square here, or
even I can draw a circle.

96
00:04:33.732 --> 00:04:37.223
It doesn't have to be exactly
the same type of shape, but

97
00:04:37.223 --> 00:04:40.226
I still wanted to copy
that general formatting.

98
00:04:40.226 --> 00:04:44.061
Again, there's appearance attributes,
what I could do I could go ahead and

99
00:04:44.061 --> 00:04:46.545
select this thing,
be like I want that to be pink.

100
00:04:46.545 --> 00:04:50.841
But I'm too lazy to go through,
I'm more efficient than going through and

101
00:04:50.841 --> 00:04:55.154
actually choosing those colors,
changing my stroke weight and all that.

102
00:04:55.154 --> 00:04:59.792
I can select that shape that I want to be
transformed, grab my Eye Dropper tool,

103
00:04:59.792 --> 00:05:01.395
go ahead and click on this.

104
00:05:01.395 --> 00:05:03.891
And you'll see it copies
all that formatting for me.

105
00:05:03.891 --> 00:05:08.213
Vonne's shaking her head in
pure amazement over here.

106
00:05:08.213 --> 00:05:09.375
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I mean,

107
00:05:09.375 --> 00:05:12.359
this was before I knew that
the Eye Dropper tool exists for

108
00:05:12.359 --> 00:05:13.802
this particular example.

109
00:05:13.802 --> 00:05:16.676
>> It always go back to that one shape,
go up and look, and

110
00:05:16.676 --> 00:05:20.563
like remember okay it's this color,
it's this weight and everything.

111
00:05:20.563 --> 00:05:24.341
So this is so
much easier than going back and doing it.

112
00:05:24.341 --> 00:05:27.694
So it's the copy format, it's like
an Excel or any Microsoft products.

113
00:05:27.694 --> 00:05:31.312
You can paste special or
paste formatting only, so

114
00:05:31.312 --> 00:05:34.099
its kind of a copy paste and that's it.

115
00:05:34.099 --> 00:05:36.166
>> Yeah, it actually is right?

116
00:05:36.166 --> 00:05:40.539
And you are right, its so much easier than
having to remember I did 17 points here I

117
00:05:40.539 --> 00:05:42.053
need to go ahead and do that.

118
00:05:42.053 --> 00:05:45.352
So I'm just gonna do this again,
so you can see the beauty of it.

119
00:05:45.352 --> 00:05:47.152
And I'm gonna select that circle,

120
00:05:47.152 --> 00:05:50.574
it does not have to be the same type
of shape I can go ahead and do that.

121
00:05:50.574 --> 00:05:53.298
And I can select that as well.

122
00:05:53.298 --> 00:05:57.930
>> Yeah, but the biggest key is that you
have to select the object that you want to

123
00:05:57.930 --> 00:05:59.940
have the formatting applied to.

124
00:05:59.940 --> 00:06:03.374
>> Right.
>> Have that selected and then go out and

125
00:06:03.374 --> 00:06:06.006
pick the thing that is the copy.

126
00:06:06.006 --> 00:06:09.223
So that step, sometimes I think
people wanna do it backwards,

127
00:06:09.223 --> 00:06:12.088
select the thing that you
want the formatting to apply.

128
00:06:12.088 --> 00:06:13.061
Nope, the other way.

129
00:06:13.061 --> 00:06:15.109
Yeah, and this, I, yeah.

130
00:06:15.109 --> 00:06:16.326
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No,

131
00:06:16.326 --> 00:06:20.176
I have made that mistake myself, and then
I'll be mad, because then it's like you

132
00:06:20.176 --> 00:06:22.710
lose the formatting that you
actually wanted to copy.

133
00:06:22.710 --> 00:06:26.005
Of course, we all know
an Illustrator you can command or

134
00:06:26.005 --> 00:06:29.934
control Z as in zebra to undo which
is actually what I just did here,

135
00:06:29.934 --> 00:06:34.092
to save your life, but yes,
it definitely can cause some confusion.

136
00:06:34.092 --> 00:06:37.900
Now there are some other things that
I wanna point out, what if I wanted,

137
00:06:37.900 --> 00:06:41.781
I had this square here, but then I wanted
to copy just the pink of the text.

138
00:06:41.781 --> 00:06:45.249
Say, you had that some sort of specialty
color and you didn't have the swatch for

139
00:06:45.249 --> 00:06:48.209
that whatever, I could go ahead in
here and I could do the same thing.

140
00:06:48.209 --> 00:06:50.030
But I'm only gonna copy the color.

141
00:06:50.030 --> 00:06:53.810
So don't think that you're
limited from just text to text or

142
00:06:53.810 --> 00:06:56.410
object to object,
you can do it kinda cross.

143
00:06:56.410 --> 00:07:00.840
>> And I did notice on the square now,
it doesn't have the same stroke.

144
00:07:00.840 --> 00:07:03.580
It copied the fill and
the stroke of the text,

145
00:07:03.580 --> 00:07:06.189
cuz of course you can
have stroke on a text.

146
00:07:06.189 --> 00:07:11.347
So it's not like,
I wanna keep the orange stroke,

147
00:07:11.347 --> 00:07:14.451
but now change the fill of that.

148
00:07:14.451 --> 00:07:17.580
I can't remember if there's options for
it, is there-

149
00:07:17.580 --> 00:07:19.415
>> I think that you can hold down-

150
00:07:19.415 --> 00:07:21.463
>> Yes, as soon as I started talking,

151
00:07:21.463 --> 00:07:26.261
I'm like, wait, I know there's some key or
modifier that I could hold to do that.

152
00:07:26.261 --> 00:07:26.956
>> Yes, yes, so.

153
00:07:26.956 --> 00:07:27.989
>> Okay, thank you for reminding me.
[LAUGH]

154
00:07:27.989 --> 00:07:30.133
>> You are actually bringing me to my next

155
00:07:30.133 --> 00:07:33.014
point, where you can start

what it will do is it will naturally
adjust the scale of your strokes.

380
00:18:46.370 --> 00:18:50.035
So you'll see in this case, it took it
down to a 2.481, something like that.

381
00:18:50.035 --> 00:18:53.995
>> Yeah, it keeps the proportions
constrained, if you wanna say,

382
00:18:53.995 --> 00:18:58.459
with the what it looks like here when
you applied it, you make it smaller or

383
00:18:58.459 --> 00:19:01.560
bigger, we're gonna go ahead and
change as well.

384
00:19:01.560 --> 00:19:05.960
This is a huge one for me,
whether you want it on or

385
00:19:05.960 --> 00:19:10.230
off, I have reasons why
it needs to be on and

386
00:19:10.230 --> 00:19:14.610
it needs to be off,
because it's like 2.1.4, you know?

387
00:19:14.610 --> 00:19:19.510
That gets a little strange sometimes,
but I want the visual consistency,

388
00:19:19.510 --> 00:19:22.852
or the visual proportions to stay,
keep it on, and

389
00:19:22.852 --> 00:19:26.375
it is one of those things,
that it's kind of hidden.

390
00:19:26.375 --> 00:19:27.160
>> Yeah.

391
00:19:27.160 --> 00:19:30.565
>> It's in this menu, it's also in
the preferences and stuff like that.

392
00:19:30.565 --> 00:19:31.552
>> Yeah.
>> So it is nice to

393
00:19:31.552 --> 00:19:35.590
keep it on the transform panel here
on the bottom to know where it's at.

394
00:19:35.590 --> 00:19:40.310
But the more you'll use this, you'll
realize how important it is to know where

395
00:19:40.310 --> 00:19:44.199
that checkbox is, and when to turn it on,
and when to turn it off.

396
00:19:44.199 --> 00:19:45.166
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Well, and exactly,

397
00:19:45.166 --> 00:19:46.093
I think you mentioned a great point.

398
00:19:46.093 --> 00:19:48.691
There are times when you'll wanna
use it and time when you don't.

399
00:19:48.691 --> 00:19:52.262
So it's nice to have an idea of, or
have that option to go ahead and flip it,

400
00:19:52.262 --> 00:19:56.236
illustrator doesn't just pick one for
you, and you'll notice this has a scales,

401
00:19:56.236 --> 00:19:57.470
strokes, and effects.

402
00:19:57.470 --> 00:20:00.374
So we haven't necessarily

403
00:20:00.374 --> 00:20:02.456
if you're watching this in order, but

404
00:20:02.456 --> 00:20:06.617
just to know that if I had something like
a drop shadow applied to this, the same
