00:20:06.617 --> 00:20:11.062
concept would apply to any sort of effect,
it would also kind of scale that as well.

406
00:20:11.062 --> 00:20:13.150
Now there's one thing that I
wanted to point out with this.

00:20:13.150 --> 00:20:15.353
So we're seeing kind of
a rounded corners here.

408
00:20:15.353 --> 00:20:18.560
Illustrator has another kind
of rounded corner option.

00:20:18.560 --> 00:20:20.898
So, it's kind of confusing, but

410
00:20:20.898 --> 00:20:26.151
basically the rounded corners there is
really just impacting your corners.

411
00:20:26.151 --> 00:20:31.097
If you want something that impacts

412
00:20:31.097 --> 00:20:35.190
what you wanna do to round your
corners is choose this method.

413
00:20:35.190 --> 00:20:37.710
So, what you'll notice,
if I draw a square, and

00:20:37.710 --> 00:20:43.265
then go back to my black arrow tool,
well we can move that up.

415
00:20:43.265 --> 00:20:44.982
We'll just jut it over here.

416
00:20:44.982 --> 00:20:48.730
So what we're looking at, okay,
we have a perfectly shaped rectangle.

417
00:20:48.730 --> 00:20:50.170
We have those hard edges.

418
00:20:50.170 --> 00:20:54.070
You do have a rounded rectangle tool
in Illustrator, but I feel like they're

00:20:54.070 --> 00:20:57.610
almost phasing that out,
because now they've added in this option,

420
00:20:57.610 --> 00:21:00.013
which has to do with these
little circles here.

421
00:21:00.013 --> 00:21:03.360
So these little circles in the top, or
I shouldn't say the top, but all four

422
00:21:03.360 --> 00:21:06.836
corners of your shape, and even it shows
up if you've been using the pen tool.

423
00:21:06.836 --> 00:21:08.435
It'll show up in other shapes.

424
00:21:08.435 --> 00:21:11.932
It's not specific just to a square, or
a rectangle, or something like that.

425
00:21:11.932 --> 00:21:15.450
But what you can do is you can
select these little circles.

426
00:21:15.450 --> 00:21:16.063
Don't try and

427
00:21:16.063 --> 00:21:19.950
select the point like you typically would
where you get their double pointed arrows.

428
00:21:19.950 --> 00:21:25.290
But if you select those circles
specifically and then drag in you're gonna

429
00:21:25.290 --> 00:21:30.350
get, not quite the same type of rounded
corner that you saw with the corner

430
00:21:30.350 --> 00:21:33.360
options with our transform panel, but
it's something that's gonna impact and

431
00:21:33.360 --> 00:21:37.100
really change the entire dimension
of your shape a lot differently,

432
00:21:37.100 --> 00:21:42.130
I would say, and the other option that we
have with this, is just to adjust one.

433
00:21:42.130 --> 00:21:46.737
Now this one, in order to just change one
corner, I feel like it's kind of tricky.

434
00:21:46.737 --> 00:21:50.240
Vonne and
I were actually discussing this here.

00:21:50.240 --> 00:21:54.433
What you have to do, you have to
single-click to select something, and

00:21:54.433 --> 00:21:59.522
then kinda single-click on it again, it's
not really necessarily a double-click,

00:21:59.522 --> 00:22:02.342
although I think even
that sometimes will work,

438
00:22:02.342 --> 00:22:05.192
if you just double-click
on a specific corner.

439
00:22:05.192 --> 00:22:08.743
But say for whatever reason you
only wanted to round one corner,

440
00:22:08.743 --> 00:22:13.149
what I could do, kind of single-click
to select it, single-click again, or

441
00:22:13.149 --> 00:22:16.870
even if you wanna go crazy and
double-click, I do think it works.

442
00:22:16.870 --> 00:22:19.968
But sometimes I think there's a little
bit of distinction between kinda

443
00:22:19.968 --> 00:22:23.371
single-clicking and then single-clicking
again, if that makes sense, and

444
00:22:23.371 --> 00:22:26.060
that's an option as well to just
go ahead and round one corner,

445
00:22:26.060 --> 00:22:27.913
which sometimes I think looks kinda cool.

446
00:22:27.913 --> 00:22:29.459
If you want that kind of effect.

447
00:22:29.459 --> 00:22:33.610
>> Yeah, and I like how you really
kind of drove it home, I wanna say,

448
00:22:33.610 --> 00:22:38.980
with the thing in the transform panel of
rounding the corners, it's still a square.

449
00:22:38.980 --> 00:22:42.772
It's still straight points, when we
get into what type of points you have.

450
00:22:42.772 --> 00:22:46.391
This is like you're actually
modifying the path itself.

451
00:22:46.391 --> 00:22:50.026
So people are like, well,
it's the same thing.

452
00:22:50.026 --> 00:22:52.901
[SOUND] It's the same,
but different [LAUGH].

453
00:22:52.901 --> 00:22:53.423
My favorite saying.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

454
00:22:53.423 --> 00:22:57.358
>> So just kind of keep that in mind when
you're, especially when you get into like

455
00:22:57.358 --> 00:23:00.840
what the white arrow will do to select
points and how you can modify it.

456
00:23:00.840 --> 00:23:02.740
That will make a big difference here.

457
00:23:02.740 --> 00:23:06.287
>> Yeah, and actually I think you lead us
nicely with that white arrow thing into

458
00:23:06.287 --> 00:23:09.945
our next point, which is talking about
some of the transform tools that you have

00:23:09.945 --> 00:23:11.280
available to you.

460
00:23:11.280 --> 00:23:15.075
>> Again, this is another thing that we
were kinda discussing before the episode.

461
00:23:15.075 --> 00:23:17.776
These are just things that I
don't personally use a lot,

00:23:17.776 --> 00:23:21.039
because I would typically, personally,
use the wide arrow tool for

463
00:23:21.039 --> 00:23:23.363
some of these things
that we're gonna discuss.

464
00:23:23.363 --> 00:23:27.271
So you do have options for
a free transform tool.

465
00:23:27.271 --> 00:23:32.050
You also have a scale tool, and if I click
and hold that you also have a shear tool.

00:23:32.050 --> 00:23:36.282
Shear was kind of that thing we did in our
transform panel where it sheared it there.

467
00:23:36.282 --> 00:23:38.934
But if I go ahead and
grab my free transform tool,

468
00:23:38.934 --> 00:23:41.860
just to give you guys kind of
an idea of how this works.

469
00:23:41.860 --> 00:23:45.490
Now, like I said this just really isn't
something I use all that often, but

470
00:23:45.490 --> 00:23:48.171
I have a general idea that I
can kind of discuss with you.

471
00:23:48.171 --> 00:23:50.380
You have these kind of
options that appear.

472
00:23:50.380 --> 00:23:53.008
It's almost like that
toolbar tearoff that comes

00:23:53.008 --> 00:23:55.143
up in the top left-hand corner for you.

474
00:23:55.143 --> 00:23:57.113
One, this first option
is gonna be constrained.

00:23:57.113 --> 00:24:01.842
That's gonna kinda be the proportions that
we mentioned very similar to the links

00:24:01.842 --> 00:24:03.564

477
00:24:03.564 --> 00:24:06.944
We also have this free transform option.

We have perspective distort and
free distort, and

00:24:09.257 --> 00:24:12.180
this is almost one that you just
kinda have to play around with.

480
00:24:12.180 --> 00:24:13.950
So, I'm gonna go around and
grab this new c.

481
00:24:13.950 --> 00:24:16.175
I can kinda grab each
one of the corners and

00:24:16.175 --> 00:24:20.130
this is pretty similar to what we're
looking at here if I grab the corner.

483
00:24:20.130 --> 00:24:24.080
But then if I can kinda go over here,
I have the option to like drag it in,

00:24:24.080 --> 00:24:27.270
and I think you can, yeah,
you can kinda shear it like that.

485
00:24:27.270 --> 00:24:30.560
So you have the option to
kind of just freely distort.

486
00:24:30.560 --> 00:24:34.660
The key with this always trying to click
the on those little white circles and

00:24:34.660 --> 00:24:37.620
that's really gonna be kinda
your distortion point.

488
00:24:37.620 --> 00:24:39.536
So, if you will, so you can go ahead and

489
00:24:39.536 --> 00:24:41.990
kinda try it out with each
of the different tools.

490
00:24:41.990 --> 00:24:47.080
You see the perspective distort kind of,
again, kind of add to that shear.

491
00:24:47.080 --> 00:24:51.270
You can see how the, I think this
one's the free distort option,

492
00:24:51.270 --> 00:24:52.690
you know how that one is gonna work.

493
00:24:52.690 --> 00:24:56.980
I can kinda drag these two in,
which can be really nice tools.

494
00:24:56.980 --> 00:25:00.328
I do think you'll find once you

00:25:00.328 --> 00:25:04.071
some of those other options,
that's probably gonna be your go-to.

496
00:25:04.071 --> 00:25:05.700
But you do have the availability here.

497
00:25:05.700 --> 00:25:08.260
>> And right now,
we're just changing a square,

00:25:08.260 --> 00:25:13.100
it's almost like you don't

00:25:13.100 --> 00:25:15.520
When you're distorting or

00:25:15.520 --> 00:25:18.320
it's like you're kind of shifting it.

00:25:18.320 --> 00:25:21.310
So if you think of,

00:25:21.310 --> 00:25:24.360
Or something that had text on it,

00:25:24.360 --> 00:25:29.400
that's where you can really see the

504
00:25:29.400 --> 00:25:30.670
So if you had, say,

00:25:30.670 --> 00:25:34.680
some text that you wanted to kind of look

00:25:34.680 --> 00:25:38.010
something, you might wanna go ahead and

00:25:38.010 --> 00:25:39.510
You might have to convert

508
00:25:39.510 --> 00:25:40.180
>> Yeah.

509
00:25:40.180 --> 00:25:40.764
>> Getting a little ahead.

510
00:25:40.764 --> 00:25:42.330
>> Perspective grid tool, yeah.

511
00:25:42.330 --> 00:25:43.140
[CROSSTALK] All of that.

00:25:43.140 --> 00:25:46.157
[LAUGH]
>> It may kind of all blend together

00:25:46.157 --> 00:25:50.509

I don't see the whole perspective

00:25:50.509 --> 00:25:55.210
distort going on in this particular
example, but the tools are there.

515
00:25:55.210 --> 00:25:59.890
Like you said,
I don't use these all that frequently, but

00:25:59.890 --> 00:26:01.810
it is one of those to each its own.

517
00:26:01.810 --> 00:26:03.810
I want to let you know where it's at,

518
00:26:03.810 --> 00:26:08.809
so you can be able to modify it cuz
there's always 15 ways [LAUGH].

519
00:26:08.809 --> 00:26:09.830
>> [LAUGH] Every time.

520
00:26:09.830 --> 00:26:10.540
>> To do things.

521
00:26:10.540 --> 00:26:11.430
>> Yeah, yeah.

522
00:26:11.430 --> 00:26:15.230
I think it is nice to know if you're just
getting comfortable with illustrator and

00:26:15.230 --> 00:26:17.530
you're getting comfortable

524
00:26:17.530 --> 00:26:20.790
And kinda start discussing that,
that might be kind of a good introduction

525
00:26:20.790 --> 00:26:23.290
is just to use those free
transform tools for what you do.

526
00:26:23.290 --> 00:26:28.190
Now, I think that's it,
as far as our object transformations,

527
00:26:28.190 --> 00:26:29.080
however you wanna call it.

528
00:26:29.080 --> 00:26:32.710
Talking about our eyedropper tools,
transform panel, and

529
00:26:32.710 --> 00:26:34.280
some of the transform tools.

530
00:26:34.280 --> 00:26:36.260
Don't forget that scales,
strokes, and effects in there too,

531
00:26:36.260 --> 00:26:37.510
that was a really important one.

532
00:26:37.510 --> 00:26:39.780
So, I think that's it for today.

533
00:26:39.780 --> 00:26:41.240
>> All right.
>> So you can wrap it up and.

534
00:26:41.240 --> 00:26:44.860
>> Wonderful, all right, yeah, good
introduction to object transformation,

535
00:26:46.030 --> 00:26:48.136
whatever we decided to name this [LAUGH].

536
00:26:48.136 --> 00:26:50.025
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm mixing all of these different

537
00:26:50.025 --> 00:26:52.235
tools that you can do to your objects.

538
00:26:52.235 --> 00:26:53.605
So I think we're good.

539
00:26:53.605 --> 00:26:55.865
I'm gonna stop, because I'm gonna

00:26:55.865 --> 00:26:56.455
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right.

541
00:26:56.455 --> 00:26:57.995
Let's go ahead and wrap this one up.

Signing off for CREATIVEPRO.TV,

episodes.description: A picture says a thousand words.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to add an image to an Illustrator file.  They review the difference between linked and embedded images as well as how raster images behave in a vector file format.
episodes.title: Images
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:03.419
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.419 --> 00:00:11.188
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.188 --> 00:00:15.330
Hello everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting edition of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:15.330 --> 00:00:20.790
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:20.790 --> 00:00:24.169
We're at the stage where we're going
to do images, yehey, pictures.

6
00:00:24.169 --> 00:00:26.814
[LAUGH] So
here to help us along is Ms Emily Ramsey.

7
00:00:26.814 --> 00:00:28.350
How are we doing today?

8
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:29.762
>> I'm great, thank you.

9
00:00:29.762 --> 00:00:33.103
And yeah, images, so kind of
an interesting thing in Illustrator.

10
00:00:33.103 --> 00:00:35.824
I think it's nice to
kind of distinguish here,

11
00:00:35.824 --> 00:00:39.443
we're not actually talking about
creating images right now.

12
00:00:39.443 --> 00:00:43.640
What we're talking about is working with
images inside your Illustrator documents.

13
00:00:43.640 --> 00:00:45.870
So kind of just a little bit of
a distinction for you there.

14
00:00:45.870 --> 00:00:48.213
So what we're gonna be talking about is,
of course,

15
00:00:48.213 --> 00:00:50.513
how to get an image into
your Illustrator document.

16
00:00:50.513 --> 00:00:55.125
And then, also kind of a couple of little
things that you should know when you

17
00:00:55.125 --> 00:00:57.665

18
00:00:57.665 --> 00:01:00.385
And some little tips and
tricks that go along with that.

19
00:01:00.385 --> 00:01:03.960
So, what I would recommend to you now,
go ahead and find an image.

20
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:07.881
If you wanna pause me, go ahead and
Google search something.

21
00:01:07.881 --> 00:01:11.870
Whatever you think you looks cool and

22
00:01:11.870 --> 00:01:16.806
You got a picture of your kids,
your cats, whatever.

23
00:01:16.806 --> 00:01:17.348
[LAUGH]
>> Kids, cats.

24
00:01:17.348 --> 00:01:19.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yep, that's the list.

25
00:01:19.840 --> 00:01:21.961
[LAUGH]
>> That's where my list runs out.

26
00:01:21.961 --> 00:01:26.970
I think other people probably you could
throw a dog in there I guess whatever.

27
00:01:26.970 --> 00:01:28.960
Whatever kind of picture you have,
just go ahead and

00:01:28.960 --> 00:01:30.732
find it,
doesn't matter what it looks like.

29
00:01:30.732 --> 00:01:32.570
We're gonna be working with

so I'm sorry if you are not a cat lover,

31
00:01:35.730 --> 00:01:39.170
So one thing that I wanna go ahead and
get started with and we can go ahead and

32
00:01:39.170 --> 00:01:43.460
look at my Illustrator workspace
here Images in Illustrator

are inserted [LAUGH] through

And I almost hesitated to say the word

Again, like
a Microsoft Office-based program,

00:01:56.387 --> 00:02:00.614
you're probably gonna be looking for like
a edit, insert or insert something and

00:02:00.614 --> 00:02:03.560
that's what you're gonna
be kinda thinking.

39

In Illustrator,
you have to look for place.

So what we're gonna be doing,
we're gonna go to file and then place, and

Now, you could also use

It's a little bit of a long one here but

as in place,

45
00:02:21.290 --> 00:02:23.990
I thin if you just use Cmd+ P,
which is always what I wanna do,

46
00:02:23.990 --> 00:02:25.580
that's just for printing.

47
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:28.200
So command,
shift+P is gonna be your option.

48
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:32.520
But we can just go to File > Place, and
it's just gonna be right down there.

49
00:02:32.520 --> 00:02:37.560
Now, what this is gonna do is it's
just gonna pull up your computer,

50
00:02:37.560 --> 00:02:39.600

typically think it would.

51
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:41.440
So we can go to File > Place.

52
00:02:41.440 --> 00:02:44.883
We can just ignore all the cool
stuff I have on my desktop here.

53
00:02:44.883 --> 00:02:48.025
And what you're gonna see, I've got

00:14:08.450 --> 00:14:12.730
this is not what it's designed to do,
so that's kind of important distinction.

278
00:14:12.730 --> 00:14:15.460
>> Yeah, and
as I keep rattling off these things,

279
00:14:15.460 --> 00:14:19.900
the linking versus embedding,
that's where I've had issues with that.

280
00:14:19.900 --> 00:14:24.168
I send somebody my Illustrative file that,
I forgot I had all of these linked images,

281
00:14:24.168 --> 00:14:28.178
and then it pops up on their screen, it's
like, It's missing all these pictures.

282
00:14:28.178 --> 00:14:29.667
>> Yes.
>> Well, okay, so

283
00:14:29.667 --> 00:14:35.550
I would either need to embed the file or
but, of course, that makes it larger.

284
00:14:35.550 --> 00:14:38.770
They do have a package functioning here,
don't they?

285
00:14:38.770 --> 00:14:39.386
>> Yeah.
>> In Illustrator?

286
00:14:39.386 --> 00:14:40.480
>> Yes, yeah.

287
00:14:40.480 --> 00:14:42.140
>> We don't have to talk
about this right now, but

288
00:14:42.140 --> 00:14:47.390
if you guys are familiar within design and
the whole concept of what packaging means,

289
00:14:47.390 --> 00:14:49.730
think about, okay,
I have my Illustrative file.

290
00:14:49.730 --> 00:14:52.550
All these linked images to it,
if you package it,

291
00:14:52.550 --> 00:14:55.970
it makes it into a nice package,
in a folder.

292
00:14:55.970 --> 00:15:00.450
You send them that whole
folder with the AI and

293
00:15:00.450 --> 00:15:05.970
all the images, and then they'll have
it all in one nice self-contained unit.

294
00:15:05.970 --> 00:15:08.070
So just thinking ahead,

295
00:15:08.070 --> 00:15:11.420
if you're going to use images,
having those different options.

296
00:15:11.420 --> 00:15:14.736
Keep it linked but package it, or
just embed it and make your file larger.

297
00:15:14.736 --> 00:15:18.387
>> Yeah, I think that's a great point,
cuz I think we discussed the downside of

298
00:15:18.387 --> 00:15:22.152
embedding but we didn't really necessarily
get into the downside of linking,

299
00:15:22.152 --> 00:15:25.270
and that would be when your
sending your file to someone.

300
00:15:25.270 --> 00:15:27.737
And they don't have this picture
of my cat on their desktop.

301
00:15:27.737 --> 00:15:28.750
[LAUGH]
>> One more thing,

302
00:15:28.750 --> 00:15:31.790
because I've done this,
I'll move the picture.

303
00:15:31.790 --> 00:15:34.740
I'll go ahead and
take it off my desktop and put, okay,

304
00:15:34.740 --> 00:15:37.030
I need to get everything off my desktop,
cuz I'm one of those.

305
00:15:37.030 --> 00:15:39.616
I clutter it up and
then I file away later.

306
00:15:39.616 --> 00:15:43.140
And then I open the Illustrator
files like wait, what?

307
00:15:43.140 --> 00:15:46.920
Oops, [LAUGH] I put Ollie in his
own folder, try to reorganize and

308
00:15:46.920 --> 00:15:47.837
then I forget.

309
00:15:47.837 --> 00:15:50.420
And so you can always go back and
relink it.

310
00:15:50.420 --> 00:15:51.190
>> Right.

311
00:15:51.190 --> 00:15:53.434
>> This is linked properly.

312
00:15:53.434 --> 00:15:56.785
But don't you think right on
the linked file up at the top?

313
00:15:56.785 --> 00:16:00.656
>> Yeah, I think it should give you
an option when you open up an Illustrator

314
00:16:00.656 --> 00:16:05.145
document, I think you can double-click-
>> Think its the little chain thing

315
00:16:05.145 --> 00:16:05.836
>> Yeah.

316
00:16:05.836 --> 00:16:06.714
>> Right there.

317
00:16:06.714 --> 00:16:09.280
>> Relink
>> So yeah,

318
00:16:09.280 --> 00:16:13.210
if you were also to open up an Illustrator
document and say for this instance,

319
00:16:13.210 --> 00:16:17.320
I had moved Ollie, it would kind
of give you that warning there,

320
00:16:17.320 --> 00:16:20.170
and then it will prompt you
to go ahead and relink that.

321
00:16:20.170 --> 00:16:22.633
So that's also an option there,
it'll kind of let you know, so yeah.

322
00:16:22.633 --> 00:16:23.195
>> That's all.

323
00:16:23.195 --> 00:16:26.088
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just want to throw all those things

324
00:16:26.088 --> 00:16:30.879
up because everything that I've run into
when working with images in Illustrator,

325
00:16:30.879 --> 00:16:33.370
some just putting it out there for
you all.

326
00:16:33.370 --> 00:16:36.590
In case you all are thinking about being
designers, and you're trying to do

327
00:16:36.590 --> 00:16:40.115
things like that, and then you run into
those problems, so we're here to help.

328
00:16:40.115 --> 00:16:41.800
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yes, exactly.

329
00:16:41.800 --> 00:16:43.190
It makes me feel like a superhero.

330
00:16:43.190 --> 00:16:44.659
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But yeah,

331
00:16:44.659 --> 00:16:46.436
I think that wrapped it up nicely,

332
00:16:46.436 --> 00:16:50.682
I'm glad you kind of added those points
there at the end cuz it's very important.

333
00:16:50.682 --> 00:16:51.827
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I'm just

334
00:16:51.827 --> 00:16:53.872
playing around with a picture of my cat.

335
00:16:53.872 --> 00:16:55.303
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] He's famous.

336
00:16:55.303 --> 00:16:57.293
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, well, I mean,

337
00:16:57.293 --> 00:17:01.309
if y'all have been watching some of
my other shows you know that I do use

338
00:17:01.309 --> 00:17:06.000
Fuego and Bishop, the two spokespersons
for Christmas Cats Incorporated.

339
00:17:06.000 --> 00:17:12.275
That's the company we've made and
we sell Christmas cat ornaments.

340
00:17:12.275 --> 00:17:15.180
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah yeah I'll buy what you're selling.

341
00:17:15.180 --> 00:17:16.557
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Awesome,

342
00:17:16.557 --> 00:17:19.714
well I think we've been done a nice
introduction to images right here.

343
00:17:19.714 --> 00:17:24.421
So we're gonna go ahead and wrap this one
up for today in a nice little package.

344
00:17:24.421 --> 00:17:26.909
>> [LAUGH]
>> Signing off for CreativeProTV,

345
00:17:26.909 --> 00:17:29.820
I've been your host, Vonne Smith
>> And Emily Ramsey.

346
00:17:29.820 --> 00:17:30.740
>> And we'll see you soon.

347
00:17:30.740 --> 00:17:36.550
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how different ways to create a gradient using the gradient panel and gradient tool. They also demonstrate how to save gradient swatches, use gradients from the swatch libraries, and how to apply gradients on strokes.
episodes.title: Gradients
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:06.425
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.425 --> 00:00:10.751
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10.751 --> 00:00:12.076
Hello, everyone, and

4
00:00:12.076 --> 00:00:15.671
welcome back to another exciting
edition of CreativePro.TV.

5
00:00:15.671 --> 00:00:20.114
I am Vonne Smith and we are continuing
on with Illustrator CC 2017.

6
00:00:20.114 --> 00:00:22.910
And today we're talking about gradients.

7
00:00:22.910 --> 00:00:24.320
I love me a gradient.

8
00:00:24.320 --> 00:00:27.767
So here to share the love is Ms.
Emily Ramsay, hello.

9
00:00:27.767 --> 00:00:29.093
>> Hello, you're so excited.

10
00:00:29.093 --> 00:00:29.815
>> I know.

11
00:00:29.815 --> 00:00:30.698
>> Vonne's like, yes.

12
00:00:30.698 --> 00:00:31.861
>> Well, gradients.

13
00:00:31.861 --> 00:00:32.860
[LAUGH]
>> Yes,

14
00:00:32.860 --> 00:00:35.180
it's finally we feel like we're
getting to a point where it's like,

15
00:00:35.180 --> 00:00:36.135
this is actually exciting.

16
00:00:36.135 --> 00:00:36.666
>> Yeah.

17
00:00:36.666 --> 00:00:38.606
[LAUGH]
>> I think everything is exciting

18
00:00:38.606 --> 00:00:39.190
in Illustrator.

19
00:00:39.190 --> 00:00:42.190
Don't get me wrong, but gradients,
you just make pretty things.

20
00:00:42.190 --> 00:00:45.670
>> I know, just all the colors,
and blending them all together.

21
00:00:45.670 --> 00:00:49.406
It's just like rainbows galore, because
that's always what I end up making,

22
00:00:49.406 --> 00:00:50.084
is rainbows.

23
00:00:50.084 --> 00:00:52.149
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, you do, yeah, I like that.

24
00:00:52.149 --> 00:00:57.340
I tend to go a little more subtle,
maybe I'll go rainbow today.

25
00:00:57.340 --> 00:00:59.800
So gradients, essentially,
if you aren't aware,

26
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:03.390
are just any time that really one
color fades into another color.

27
00:01:03.390 --> 00:01:05.020
And it doesn't even really
have to be just two.

28
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:05.890
We'll kind of get into that.

29
00:01:05.890 --> 00:01:08.790
You can fade many different
colors into one another.

30
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:12.110
And so it's just kind of a fun thing
that you can do, and a nice effect.

31
00:01:12.110 --> 00:01:14.770
If you don't really want
just kind of a solid color,

32
00:01:14.770 --> 00:01:18.600
if you wanna add a little more oomph to
it, gradients are a great way to do that.

33
00:01:18.600 --> 00:01:20.520
So we'll go ahead and look at that.

34
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:23.610
What I'm gonna do here is,
I'm just gonna create a rectangle.

35
00:01:23.610 --> 00:01:26.700
I know you guys are probably tired
of seeing me create a rectangle, but

36
00:01:26.700 --> 00:01:29.180
it's just a great way to
show off an example here.

37
00:01:29.180 --> 00:01:31.860
You can see, I'm just doing my swatches or
my control bar.

38
00:01:31.860 --> 00:01:35.970
I went ahead and applied a color, so
I just have a regular black there.

39
00:01:35.970 --> 00:01:38.270
You do have some Gradient Swatch options.

40
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:39.414
We don't really need to get into those.

41
00:01:39.414 --> 00:01:43.569
But you do for some reason, you just wanna
go with something that's pre-made for you,

42
00:01:43.569 --> 00:01:44.460
you can do that.

43
00:01:44.460 --> 00:01:47.646
But what we're gonna do is, we're
actually gonna create our own gradients.

44
00:01:47.646 --> 00:01:52.658
So you have with your gradients, you have
a Gradient Panel and a Gradient Tool.

45
00:01:52.658 --> 00:01:56.618
And my advice, I would always say,
start with the Gradient Panel, and

46
00:01:56.618 --> 00:01:58.930
then use the Gradient Tool to kinda edit.

47
00:01:58.930 --> 00:02:00.370
At least, that's how I do it.

48
00:02:00.370 --> 00:02:01.531
Vonne is like, no, I don't know.

49
00:02:01.531 --> 00:02:05.175
>> [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> Really, you're going that way?

50
00:02:05.175 --> 00:02:10.106
Do tell,
because I would go the other way, yeah.

51
00:02:10.106 --> 00:02:11.562
>> Really, okay, so everybody has their
own different ways for doing things.

52
00:02:11.562 --> 00:02:15.100
We're just gonna do it the way I do it,
so sorry, Vonne.

53
00:02:15.100 --> 00:02:17.592
>> Brosie.

54
00:02:17.592 --> 00:02:20.060
>> Okay, [LAUGH] so what I'm gonna
do is I'm gonna go ahead and

55
00:02:20.060 --> 00:02:21.900
start in my Gradient panel.

56
00:02:21.900 --> 00:02:25.385
As you know, if you don't have your
Gradient Panel, go to Window and

57
00:02:25.385 --> 00:02:26.885
then I think this one is just on its own.

58
00:02:26.885 --> 00:02:28.615
Yes, just down there as Gradient.

59
00:02:28.615 --> 00:02:30.287
So you can go ahead and grab that.

60
00:02:30.287 --> 00:02:33.705
I'm gonna pull mine out, so we can just
kind of isolate that a little bit better.

61
00:02:33.705 --> 00:02:35.935
And we're kind of be looking
at a couple of things here.

62
00:02:35.935 --> 00:02:38.672
So we can see okay,
gradient type, all that.

63
00:02:38.672 --> 00:02:40.852
What I mainly want you
to focus on right here,

64
00:02:40.852 --> 00:02:44.512
is just this, what's known as
the gradient ramp, I believe.

65
00:02:44.512 --> 00:02:48.232
So it's just basically looking at
white kinda fading into black.

66
00:02:48.232 --> 00:02:52.060
So what I'm gonna do to go ahead and
just kind of apply a gradient to my shape.

67
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:54.370
Now you'll notice I have
the shape selected.

68
00:02:54.370 --> 00:02:56.790
I would go ahead and
select the shape that you're working with.

69
00:02:56.790 --> 00:02:58.700
Again, just with your Black Arrow Tool or
whatever,

70
00:02:58.700 --> 00:03:00.910
so you can kind of have that ready to go.

71
00:03:00.910 --> 00:03:03.170
So that way,
when you click on your gradient slider.

72
00:03:03.170 --> 00:03:05.185
I'm sorry,
it's called gradient slider, not ramp.

73
00:03:05.185 --> 00:03:06.860
>> I always-
>> You can call it,

74
00:03:06.860 --> 00:03:08.280
I've always called it the ramp.

75
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:10.003
So that's probably why
you're calling it a ramp.

76
00:03:10.003 --> 00:03:10.727
>> Yeah.

77
00:03:10.727 --> 00:03:12.550
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so she's lying to you.

78
00:03:12.550 --> 00:03:13.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what she's saying.

79
00:03:13.630 --> 00:03:14.220
>> She's lying.

80
00:03:14.220 --> 00:03:15.294
It's actually the gradient slider.

81
00:03:15.294 --> 00:03:18.035
[LAUGH] So yes, when we go out and
click on the slider ramp,

82
00:03:18.035 --> 00:03:21.880
whatever you wanna call it, you'll see
that you'll actually get a gradient.

83
00:03:21.880 --> 00:03:24.010
So hey, you've already done step one.

84
00:03:24.010 --> 00:03:26.610
You have created
a gradient in Illustrator.

85
00:03:26.610 --> 00:03:28.680
But we're kinda looking at
a couple of different things here.

86
00:03:28.680 --> 00:03:30.820
So I'm gonna kinda go from the top now.

87
00:03:30.820 --> 00:03:34.020
So we see, we have,
by default, typeset as linear.

88
00:03:34.020 --> 00:03:36.660
If I was going to be using a circle,
for instance,

89
00:03:36.660 --> 00:03:40.830
say if I had a, grab my Ellipse Tool,
something like this.

90
00:03:40.830 --> 00:03:43.300
Maybe I don't wanna change
that type to radial, so

91
00:03:43.300 --> 00:03:45.750
that way you can kinda
see that effect there.

92
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:48.970
Certainly, just depends on what you're
doing, it doesn't really matter.

93
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:52.190
We can also see, you can kinda
flip these reverse gradients, so

94
00:03:52.190 --> 00:03:55.260
I can reverse and
I've kinda just moved down here

95
00:03:55.260 --> 00:03:59.520
to this option right underneath where
you see the fill and the stroke kinda.

96
00:03:59.520 --> 00:04:03.820
You can see how I can flip those two
gradients, so that is an option.

97
00:04:03.820 --> 00:04:07.788
And you can also adjust the angle, okay?

98
00:04:07.788 --> 00:04:08.952
That was the word I was looking.

99
00:04:08.952 --> 00:04:11.550
I wanna say skew,
the angle of the gradient.

100
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:15.470
So what we need to focus on here, though,
and particularly what I use the gradient

101
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:19.880
slider for, are these little
houses that you see at the bottom.

102
00:04:19.880 --> 00:04:21.910
Houses is a term I borrowed from Vonne.

103
00:04:21.910 --> 00:04:24.770
They're technically
referred to as color stops.

104
00:04:24.770 --> 00:04:28.330
You see this black color stop,
and this white color stop.

105
00:04:28.330 --> 00:04:31.795
Those color stops are the actual
color swatches that we have

106
00:04:31.795 --> 00:04:36.635
applied that kind of just blend together
to make the all the colors in between.

107
00:04:36.635 --> 00:04:39.864
So really, all we're working with
right now is just two colors, and

108
00:04:39.864 --> 00:04:42.495
Illustrator is doing all of
the magic in between for us.

109
00:04:42.495 --> 00:04:45.175
So we can go ahead and change those.

110
00:04:45.175 --> 00:04:48.573
So if you want something a little more
exciting than a white and a black,

111
00:04:48.573 --> 00:04:50.624
what I can do just double-click on those.

112
00:04:50.624 --> 00:04:54.833
If I double-click on each color swatch, so
I'm actually clicking on the little house

113
00:04:54.833 --> 00:04:58.351
itself, you'll see they'll either
take you into your Color Panel, or

114
00:04:58.351 --> 00:05:00.500
it would take you into
your Swatches Panel.

115
00:05:00.500 --> 00:05:03.180
So if you wanna create a color on its own,

116
00:05:03.180 --> 00:05:06.370
not a swatch that you already are working
with, you do have that option for you.

117
00:05:06.370 --> 00:05:11.930
You could use the CMI case sliders there,
or RGB, whatever color mode you're in.

118
00:05:11.930 --> 00:05:13.400
I'm just gonna use my swatches.

119
00:05:13.400 --> 00:05:17.470
So maybe I'll go choose just
kind of a random blue there.

120
00:05:17.470 --> 00:05:21.150
Now let's say I wanna go ahead and
adjust the white one.

121
00:05:21.150 --> 00:05:24.300
So I'm gonna double-click
on that color stop, and

122
00:05:24.300 --> 00:05:27.250
I can go ahead and
make that green, for instance.

123
00:05:27.250 --> 00:05:30.310
Now a couple things that you can do with
this, and I kinda pointed this out with

124
00:05:30.310 --> 00:05:32.495
the black and white, but
it's just more fun to look at colors.

125
00:05:32.495 --> 00:05:36.240
So what I can see here is I
can adjust this slider, and

126
00:05:36.240 --> 00:05:39.165
I may even make this kind of more
distinct colors just so you can see it.

127
00:05:39.165 --> 00:05:44.440
If I change that to pink, if I slide these
around, you see that they actually move.

128
00:05:44.440 --> 00:05:47.550
That's gonna impact
the appearance of my gradients.

129
00:05:47.550 --> 00:05:50.450
If I want more pink, slide over more pink.

130
00:05:50.450 --> 00:05:53.460
If I want more blue, slide over more blue.

131
00:05:53.460 --> 00:05:56.240
Likewise, you can use this
little diamond at the top, and

132
00:05:56.240 --> 00:06:00.760
that's also gonna impact
the appearance of the color, rather.

133
00:06:00.760 --> 00:06:02.900
So that's another option that
you have available to you.

134
00:06:02.900 --> 00:06:05.033
Now we mentioned you're
not just stuck with two.

135
00:06:05.033 --> 00:06:09.630
You could have 25 colors in
a gradient if you wanted to.

136
00:06:09.630 --> 00:06:11.200
How are you gonna go ahead and add those?

137
00:06:11.200 --> 00:06:15.780
Well, you'll notice, even right now just
hovered between the two color stops,

138
00:06:15.780 --> 00:06:18.680
I've a little plus sign on my cursor.

139
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:21.764
So you see, I have that white cursor
with a little plus sign next to it.

140
00:06:21.764 --> 00:06:25.210
Any time you hover between the two color
stops, the two houses, whatever you wanna

141
00:06:25.210 --> 00:06:29.340
call them, you can go ahead and just kind
of single-click anywhere in that space.

142
00:06:29.340 --> 00:06:33.570
You're not clicking on the ramp itself or
the slider itself, but just below it, and

143
00:06:33.570 --> 00:06:35.216
you can go ahead and add a color stop.

144
00:06:35.216 --> 00:06:35.995
Now by default,

145
00:06:35.995 --> 00:06:40.385
the color it's gonna add is just kind
of whatever was blending right there.

146
00:06:40.385 --> 00:06:42.335
So I got a kind of a weird pinkish blue,
so

147
00:06:42.335 --> 00:06:44.045
you don't really see anything different.

148
00:06:44.045 --> 00:06:45.855
But again, I can change this color.

149
00:06:45.855 --> 00:06:49.965
So I can double-click, and
I can go ahead and add an orange in there.

150
00:06:49.965 --> 00:06:52.795
And you can kind of see how
that all starts to fade and

151
00:06:52.795 --> 00:06:54.945
where some of the moving comes in.

152
00:06:54.945 --> 00:06:59.580
Now I have two diamonds at the top that I

>> So yeah, you can [INAUDIBLE] more.

381
00:17:49.451 --> 00:17:52.767
>> Yeah, there is some and I like because
it gives me like a base to start with,

382
00:17:52.767 --> 00:17:54.557
like ooh, I really like this sunset, or

383
00:17:54.557 --> 00:17:56.839
whatever this one that we
have selected right now.

384
00:17:56.839 --> 00:17:59.469
But I kinda want to
change that one purple.

385
00:17:59.469 --> 00:18:03.368
Then you go into the gradient, or
I would grab the Gradient Tool, and

386
00:18:03.368 --> 00:18:06.203
then change the houses,
or the stops from there.

387
00:18:06.203 --> 00:18:08.081
And so
you can do some modifications from it.

388
00:18:08.081 --> 00:18:09.631
So it's a nice starting point.

389
00:18:09.631 --> 00:18:12.227
They've got so
many that you can choose from.

390
00:18:12.227 --> 00:18:17.336
And then one other note on this one,
if you pull up the swatch, you can see it

391
00:18:17.336 --> 00:18:22.808
automatically adds the swatches from
the libraries into your Swatches Panel.

392
00:18:22.808 --> 00:18:25.390
And we talked about in
the swatches episodes,

393
00:18:25.390 --> 00:18:28.630
that is that swatches are file specific.

394
00:18:28.630 --> 00:18:30.000
And the other ones with the libraries,

395
00:18:30.000 --> 00:18:34.500
we had to click on the folder to force
it to be added into our swatches.

396
00:18:34.500 --> 00:18:37.940
The gradients from the library
goes automatically into it.

397
00:18:37.940 --> 00:18:40.720
So I just wanted to point that out.

398
00:18:40.720 --> 00:18:43.762
Cuz I really, really love this
swatch libraries of gradient and

399
00:18:43.762 --> 00:18:45.513
I like the names, fruits and vegetables.

400
00:18:45.513 --> 00:18:46.114
>> Yeah.

401
00:18:46.114 --> 00:18:48.136
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I know I was just thinking.

402
00:18:48.136 --> 00:18:49.126
I was like, foliage.

403
00:18:49.126 --> 00:18:51.675
[LAUGH] It's fall, I love it.

404
00:18:51.675 --> 00:18:52.582
>> Yes.

405
00:18:52.582 --> 00:18:53.620
>> So yeah, no, that's great.

406
00:18:53.620 --> 00:18:58.050
And I'm glad you mentioned that cuz
I had forgotten about the gradient

407
00:18:58.050 --> 00:18:59.880
swatch libraries and all that.

408
00:18:59.880 --> 00:19:00.870
So yeah, I think that's it.

409
00:19:00.870 --> 00:19:01.790
I think that's a good,

410
00:19:01.790 --> 00:19:05.540
again, introduction into how to actually
create a gradient and start editing one.

411
00:19:05.540 --> 00:19:08.777
So have fun, enjoy it,
make some rainbows if you want to.

412
00:19:08.777 --> 00:19:13.760
Do all kinds of crazy stuff,
whatever you wanna do, so it's exciting.

413
00:19:13.760 --> 00:19:15.160
>> Yay, well, thank you so much.

414
00:19:15.160 --> 00:19:16.700
Like I said, I love me a gradient.

415
00:19:16.700 --> 00:19:20.160
I'm feeling very, very fluffy right now,
very colorful and everything.

416
00:19:20.160 --> 00:19:23.668
And so we're gonna go ahead, and
that's probably a good place for us to,

417
00:19:23.668 --> 00:19:26.510
if Vonne's getting colorful,
we need to wrap this one up.

418
00:19:26.510 --> 00:19:28.094
So we're gonna go ahead and do that.

419
00:19:28.094 --> 00:19:32.850
Signing off for CreativePro.TV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

420
00:19:32.850 --> 00:19:33.720
And I'm Emily Ramsey.

421
00:19:33.720 --> 00:19:39.819
>> And we'll see you soon.
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne demonstrate different text effects, covering the type on a path tool , touch  type tool, and create outlines from text.
episodes.title: Text Effects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:06.430 --> 00:00:11.428
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.428 --> 00:00:15.173
Hello everyone, and welcome to
another addition of CreativeProTV.

3
00:00:15.173 --> 00:00:20.098
I'm your host Vonne Smith, and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017.

4
00:00:20.098 --> 00:00:23.626
And in this episode we're gonna
be talking about text effects,

5
00:00:23.626 --> 00:00:26.185
not just regular text but
the effects of text.

6
00:00:26.185 --> 00:00:28.389
Wow, I said that and
didn't trip up and that's pretty good.

7
00:00:28.389 --> 00:00:32.027
So here to help us is Ms.
Emily Ramsey, hello how are you?

8
00:00:32.027 --> 00:00:34.421
>> Hello, good,
I like how you phrased that.

9
00:00:34.421 --> 00:00:39.371
>> Yes, yes I was more thinking along
the lines of okay, how am I gonna explain

10
00:00:39.371 --> 00:00:44.179
this, this is kind of like object
transformation, but with your text?

11
00:00:44.179 --> 00:00:45.521
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, right.

12
00:00:45.521 --> 00:00:48.552
We're gonna fancy up our text,
just not in a straight line.

13
00:00:48.552 --> 00:00:51.109
We're gonna go crazy,
we're gonna go circular.

14
00:00:51.109 --> 00:00:52.556
>> Wow.
>> [LAUGH]

15
00:00:52.556 --> 00:00:53.824
>> Check it out, yes.

16
00:00:53.824 --> 00:00:55.872
[LAUGH] I know you're excited now, right?

17
00:00:55.872 --> 00:00:59.859
So yes, basically what we're gonna do
is we're gonna be looking at some of

18
00:00:59.859 --> 00:01:01.824
the various, different effects for

19
00:01:01.824 --> 00:01:05.267
lack of a better word that we can
place specifically on our text.

20
00:01:05.267 --> 00:01:07.699
Now sometimes you can take things
that you would typically do for

21
00:01:07.699 --> 00:01:09.239
an object and also apply it to your text.

22
00:01:09.239 --> 00:01:12.376
But these are gonna be things
that are really type specific.

23
00:01:12.376 --> 00:01:16.074
So what we're gonna look at, we're
gonna look at the type on a path tool,

24
00:01:16.074 --> 00:01:17.936
which is pretty fun and pretty neat.

25
00:01:17.936 --> 00:01:22.301
And then we're also gonna look at
the touch type tool which are one of

26
00:01:22.301 --> 00:01:25.070
the fairly newer options in Illustrator.

27
00:01:25.070 --> 00:01:28.144
And then also talk about outlining out
text and really kind of what that means,

28
00:01:28.144 --> 00:01:29.229
and what you can do with it.

29
00:01:29.229 --> 00:01:32.501
So we'll go ahead and
get started with the type on a path.

30
00:01:32.501 --> 00:01:36.598
So let's go ahead and jump into my
computer, and the first thing that we need

31
00:01:36.598 --> 00:01:39.493
to do is actually create a path for
our type to type on.

32
00:01:39.493 --> 00:01:43.460
So the first thing I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna actually show the example of

33
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:44.054
a circle.

34
00:01:44.054 --> 00:01:46.373
Rather than using a perfect circle though,

35
00:01:46.373 --> 00:01:50.209
I'm probably gonna do something that's
a little bit more like an oval.

36
00:01:50.209 --> 00:01:53.896
Cuz what it's gonna do for us is it's
gonna allow our text to have kind

37
00:01:53.896 --> 00:01:57.156
of more of a place to go, so
more of a place to rest if you will.

38
00:01:57.156 --> 00:02:00.657
So I'm gonna go and
grab my ellipse tool, and

39
00:02:00.657 --> 00:02:05.182
then once I get that I'm gonna
go ahead and make that oval.

40
00:02:05.182 --> 00:02:08.219
And then you can go ahead and
just go back to your black arrow tool,

41
00:02:08.219 --> 00:02:09.775
kinda go back into your neutral.

42
00:02:09.775 --> 00:02:13.996
Now, something that Vaughn and I were
talking about a second ago is I'm gonna go

43
00:02:13.996 --> 00:02:16.267
ahead here and change this fill to yellow.

44
00:02:16.267 --> 00:02:18.728
So that way you can see the path
outlined a little bit better.

45
00:02:18.728 --> 00:02:21.124
And I think that that's gonna
make a distinction for you.

46
00:02:21.124 --> 00:02:24.205
So once of the things that can
kinda trip you up with this is kind

47
00:02:24.205 --> 00:02:27.183
of being able to see the path and
it trips me up, it just did.

48
00:02:27.183 --> 00:02:30.993
So it happens to everybody, but
from here once we have our path

49
00:02:30.993 --> 00:02:35.779
actually created we need to go ahead of
course grab out our type on a path tool.

50
00:02:35.779 --> 00:02:38.500
So I'm gonna go back to
that type tool the T.

51
00:02:38.500 --> 00:02:41.011
And then when you click and
hold on it you'll see okay,

52
00:02:41.011 --> 00:02:42.659
I've got my hidden options there.

53
00:02:42.659 --> 00:02:45.542
The type tool has a lot of
hidden options underneath it.

54
00:02:45.542 --> 00:02:48.909
We're just gonna go straight
into that type on a path option.

55
00:02:48.909 --> 00:02:51.105
So once you get that you see
you have your little cursor,

56
00:02:51.105 --> 00:02:53.131
kinda looks like an I with
a little wave through it.

57
00:02:53.131 --> 00:02:57.566
So it's the typical, type cursor, but then
you have that wave through that's kind of

58
00:02:57.566 --> 00:03:00.267
indicating okay,
you can kind of do a fun path here.

59
00:03:00.267 --> 00:03:06.154
Now, here's kind of the part that trips me
up, is knowing exactly where that path is.

60
00:03:06.154 --> 00:03:07.862
So what you'll see if you try and

61
00:03:07.862 --> 00:03:10.910
click over here,
you're gonna get this error message.

62
00:03:10.910 --> 00:03:14.536
You must click on a non path comp,
cmpound non-masking path, blah blah blah.

63
00:03:14.536 --> 00:03:18.188
And you're probably thinking, what does
that even mean, like I have no idea.

64
00:03:18.188 --> 00:03:20.514
Likewise, if I try and
click just slightly off,

65
00:03:20.514 --> 00:03:24.279
which seems to be the issue that I tend
to have, I'm gonna get that same thing.

66
00:03:24.279 --> 00:03:27.870
You need to make sure that you're clicking
exactly on the outside of that path, and

67
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:29.321
it's a very subtle difference.

68
00:03:29.321 --> 00:03:33.240
You'll see, we were talking either,
I think it used to have a little bit

69
00:03:33.240 --> 00:03:35.822
more of a-
>> I thought there was some visual

70
00:03:35.822 --> 00:03:39.655
indication with the mouse
cursor icon to let you know,

71
00:03:39.655 --> 00:03:41.888
I found the path to attach myself.

72
00:03:41.888 --> 00:03:43.162
I mean it makes sense.

73
00:03:43.162 --> 00:03:43.763
>> Mm-hm.

74
00:03:43.763 --> 00:03:47.184
>> But I really felt like there
was another visual indication.

75
00:03:47.184 --> 00:03:49.455
I might also be crossing
streams with InDesign.

76
00:03:49.455 --> 00:03:51.432
>> Yeah.
>> To where I kept doing this,

77
00:03:51.432 --> 00:03:53.953
I'd put parentheses around it or
something.

78
00:03:53.953 --> 00:03:57.153
I don't know, but yeah,
now it's just saying, okay,

79
00:03:57.153 --> 00:04:00.568
it's kinda highlighting it and
it's saying the word path.

80
00:04:00.568 --> 00:04:01.093
>> Right.

81
00:04:01.093 --> 00:04:03.834
>> Which are hovered over the stroke or
outside.

82
00:04:03.834 --> 00:04:05.603
It's not the inside, cuz it can't go in.

83
00:04:05.603 --> 00:04:11.187
It's gotta be right on the outline if
you wanna say of whatever path you have.

84
00:04:11.187 --> 00:04:13.134
>> Yeah.
>> So it's a little weird, so.

85
00:04:13.134 --> 00:04:15.278
>> It's a little weird, I agree.

86
00:04:15.278 --> 00:04:19.083
Thankfully, that's one of the more
difficult things that we're gonna have to

87
00:04:19.083 --> 00:04:21.026
deal here, the rest is just kind of fun.

88
00:04:21.026 --> 00:04:22.973
So we're gonna go ahead and click, and

89
00:04:22.973 --> 00:04:26.823
then once you do that actually on the path
again look for that pink path there.

90
00:04:26.823 --> 00:04:29.607
You can see just like our regular
text is gonna go ahead and

91
00:04:29.607 --> 00:04:31.177
fill it in without lorem ipsum.

92
00:04:31.177 --> 00:04:33.906
Which I know is probably funny
to you if you're not accustom

93
00:04:33.906 --> 00:04:36.207
to using this in recent
versions of illustrator.

94
00:04:36.207 --> 00:04:38.322
And then from there, of course you
just go ahead and start typing.

95
00:04:38.322 --> 00:04:40.776
And just as you normally
would with your regular type.

96
00:04:40.776 --> 00:04:44.499
So, I can go ahead and say,
Hello my name is Emily,

97
00:04:44.499 --> 00:04:48.846
and you'll see how that will
kind of wrap around our shape.

98
00:04:48.846 --> 00:04:51.283
You can see maybe why I used an oval,

99
00:04:51.283 --> 00:04:55.191
because I wanted to give more
of a platform for that text.

100
00:04:55.191 --> 00:04:58.968
And you'll also see what happened here
is after I typed that, I was like, okay,

101
00:04:58.968 --> 00:05:02.428
I should have probably started a little
farther over to the left, right.

102
00:05:02.428 --> 00:05:05.135
So that way I could have
had all of that over.

103
00:05:05.135 --> 00:05:07.929
That is fixable, it's not something
that you have to go back and

104
00:05:07.929 --> 00:05:09.830
say, no, I have to start over.

105
00:05:09.830 --> 00:05:11.840
What we're gonna do from here is
actually everything's gonna be

106
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:13.080
done in our black air tool.

107
00:05:13.080 --> 00:05:18.456
Once you get your type set the way you
want it, like if I wanna go ahead here and

108
00:05:18.456 --> 00:05:22.328
change my font size or
font type or whatever I wanna do.

109
00:05:22.328 --> 00:05:26.339
If I wanna do something kind of crazy,
this is where I get into the weeds and

110
00:05:26.339 --> 00:05:29.530
I start getting really into fonts and
trying to pick them.

111
00:05:29.530 --> 00:05:31.895
So I'm pretty much just
gonna leave that as is.

112
00:05:31.895 --> 00:05:33.038
We'll stick with Myriad Pro.

113
00:05:33.038 --> 00:05:36.552
But know that that's an option that you
can otherwise it'll take me ten years to

114
00:05:36.552 --> 00:05:37.242
choose a font.

115
00:05:37.242 --> 00:05:41.086
So, from here, once you have that set,
you change the color, all that.

116
00:05:41.086 --> 00:05:43.083
Now I can go back into
my black arrow tool, and

117
00:05:43.083 --> 00:05:44.722
this is where the fun really begins.

118
00:05:44.722 --> 00:05:49.237
So, what you're gonna see, if you can
kinda take a look at this for me and

119
00:05:49.237 --> 00:05:53.825
I'll kinda try and use my fancy like
zoom tricks that Vonne has taught me,

120
00:05:53.825 --> 00:05:55.327
to look at these lines.

121
00:05:55.327 --> 00:05:58.026
That's where we're gonna go ahead and
get started here.

122
00:05:58.026 --> 00:06:01.123
Now, I wish I had a better
way of describing this.

123
00:06:01.123 --> 00:06:04.615
But basically what we're gonna be looking
looking at, is we're gonna be looking at

124
00:06:04.615 --> 00:06:07.777
the lines with the boxes on them versus
the straight line with nothing on it.

125
00:06:07.777 --> 00:06:11.578
Vonne may be able to tell me if there's
like a better name for that but

126
00:06:11.578 --> 00:06:15.663
that's what I go with for this, so
the lines with the boxes around them.

127
00:06:15.663 --> 00:06:18.893
One thing to point out, I'm saying
the lines with the boxes around them so

128
00:06:18.893 --> 00:06:22.241
that I can distinguish it, you don't
wanna click on the boxes themselves.

129
00:06:22.241 --> 00:06:23.584
That's gonna do something
a little bit different.

130
00:06:23.584 --> 00:06:25.392
You wanna make sure to click on that line.

131
00:06:25.392 --> 00:06:27.871
But when you do, what it's gonna do for

132
00:06:27.871 --> 00:06:31.417
you is it's gonna allow you
to rotate that text around.

133
00:06:31.417 --> 00:06:36.022
Now, the kind of funny thing with this is
that you have keep the text within those

134
00:06:36.022 --> 00:06:36.723
two lines.

135
00:06:36.723 --> 00:06:38.465
See how when I'm going over that?

136
00:06:38.465 --> 00:06:42.369
That starts to give me that little red
plus sign that's letting me know that I

137
00:06:42.369 --> 00:06:43.409
have overset text.

138
00:06:43.409 --> 00:06:46.299
We haven't, I don't think really think
about over that text at this point if

139
00:06:46.299 --> 00:06:47.553
you're watching this in order.

140
00:06:47.553 --> 00:06:50.014
But it is something that
you've had to be aware off.

141
00:06:50.014 --> 00:06:54.089
>> This is where I would say it's like
pushing the train down the track.

142
00:06:54.089 --> 00:06:55.608
>> Yeah.
>> It's like this is the chu-chu train and

143
00:06:55.608 --> 00:06:56.218
here's the track.

144
00:06:56.218 --> 00:07:01.314
So we're gonna push the train down but
once you get to that end it's

145
00:07:01.314 --> 00:07:06.246
like you are track and
it's going in a tunnel I literally use it.

146
00:07:06.246 --> 00:07:08.104
>> Yes.
>> Yeah, we're going in the tunnel, but

147
00:07:08.104 --> 00:07:10.508
you don't want that to be in the times,
and you can't see, so

148
00:07:10.508 --> 00:07:11.769
you got back the train back out.

149
00:07:11.769 --> 00:07:13.784
And where the track starts, and

150
00:07:13.784 --> 00:07:17.299
ends, that's what I call
those little guys out there.

151
00:07:17.299 --> 00:07:20.668
>> I loved that, yes, exactly,
okay, yes, so like a train,

152
00:07:20.668 --> 00:07:23.192
think about like that in a tunnel,
I love it.

153
00:07:23.192 --> 00:07:27.185
But what you maybe thinking okay, I need
to move this further over to the left.

154
00:07:27.185 --> 00:07:28.967
What does it really do for me here?

155
00:07:28.967 --> 00:07:34.277
And so what you have to do this other
y here it's flexible, it can move.

156
00:07:34.277 --> 00:07:38.329
So what we can do, we just have to move
that over further over to the left.

157
00:07:38.329 --> 00:07:41.194
So that way I can move this
one further over to the left.

158
00:07:41.194 --> 00:07:45.017
And then now we have the option okay,
that looks a little bit more centered,

159
00:07:45.017 --> 00:07:48.266
you can kinda just fidget with it
until you get where it likes it.

160
00:07:48.266 --> 00:07:51.093
Now, part of the reason why I
used the example of a circle.

161
00:07:51.093 --> 00:07:54.399
Say for example, I've got this and
it looks good but

162
00:07:54.399 --> 00:07:57.571
what if I wanted it to be
on the bottom of my circle?

163
00:07:57.571 --> 00:08:00.143
What if I wanted it to be down here,
right?

164
00:08:00.143 --> 00:08:04.861
Well, you can rotate your text
all the way around to the bottom.

165
00:08:04.861 --> 00:08:07.105
And that's fine, that's great.

166
00:08:07.105 --> 00:08:10.561
But the issue is, unless you can read
upside-down, unless you're a bat,

167
00:08:10.561 --> 00:08:13.680
basically [LAUGH] it's going
to give you some problems.

168
00:08:13.680 --> 00:08:15.504
So what does that mean for us?

169
00:08:15.504 --> 00:08:18.251
And whoops, I'm getting a little
wonky over here with my mouse and

170
00:08:18.251 --> 00:08:20.080
dragging this all around.

171
00:08:20.080 --> 00:08:24.932
That is where that other little
mysterious plane line is gonna come in.

172
00:08:24.932 --> 00:08:28.134
So we kind of move around to your
heart's content with those two,

173
00:08:28.134 --> 00:08:30.440
the lines with the boxes around them.

174
00:08:30.440 --> 00:08:33.850
And then now this is the only
other thing that trips people up,

175
00:08:33.850 --> 00:08:38.220
with this is this kind of moving in and
out and that's what's gonna be done here.

176
00:08:38.220 --> 00:08:43.850
So for this one, what you wanna do,
it's a very subtle small movement.

177
00:08:43.850 --> 00:08:49.770
You want to select this line and
then subtly drag it into the inside.

178
00:08:49.770 --> 00:08:53.688
So I'm just going to very small movement
drag that to the inside of my circle.

179
00:08:53.688 --> 00:08:56.572
And you'll see that it will now flip

00:19:46.580 --> 00:19:49.480
you need to also,
you need to outline your text.

404
00:19:49.480 --> 00:19:52.475
So that way, when they open it up in
Illustrator they are not getting all these

405
00:19:52.475 --> 00:19:57.790
warning messages like, hey, use this weird
font, Cubano, and I don't have that.

406
00:19:57.790 --> 00:20:00.530
So that's the reason why we wanna do it.

407
00:20:00.530 --> 00:20:03.390
But because it's not
gonna be editable later,

408
00:20:03.390 --> 00:20:06.060
I need to save myself a version
where this is editable.

409
00:20:06.060 --> 00:20:09.480
So I will either kind of
duplicate this off to the side,

410
00:20:09.480 --> 00:20:11.730
off of my art board before I do it.

411
00:20:11.730 --> 00:20:14.550
Or what I'll do is I'll just
save a version of my file,

412
00:20:14.550 --> 00:20:19.480
call it file and
then I'll have a file dash outline.

413
00:20:19.480 --> 00:20:22.780
So I'll have two different versions of
my file just depending on what I need.

414
00:20:22.780 --> 00:20:25.820
So once we do this, you're stuck.

415
00:20:25.820 --> 00:20:28.110
Now that I've warned you about that app.

416
00:20:28.110 --> 00:20:31.670
So it's very simple to do,
to actually outline your text.

417
00:20:31.670 --> 00:20:34.820
All you're gonna do is you're going
to take your font, or take your type,

418
00:20:34.820 --> 00:20:40.090
rather, right-click, and
then you're gonna choose create outlines.

419
00:20:40.090 --> 00:20:45.930
I thought there was a command or control,
>> No, it's in the Type menu.

420
00:20:45.930 --> 00:20:48.840
>> In the type menu, yeah, I thought
there was a keyboard shortcut for it.

421
00:20:48.840 --> 00:20:49.355
>> Yeah, there it is.

422
00:20:49.355 --> 00:20:53.390
>> Shift+Ctrl+O is the keyboard shortcut,
or you can go to your Type menu as well.

423
00:20:53.390 --> 00:20:55.820
So right-click, Create Outlines.

424
00:20:55.820 --> 00:20:57.290
And then now,
what you're gonna see, okay, so

425
00:20:57.290 --> 00:20:59.250
they're grouped, so
you don't see a lot of difference.

426
00:20:59.250 --> 00:21:03.710
But if I kinda double-click, go into
isolation mode, you're gonna start to see

427
00:21:03.710 --> 00:21:09.120
all those points, and you're gonna be able
to when we get into our layer tool and

428
00:21:09.120 --> 00:21:13.100
pen tool and all that you're gonna
be able to really edit this more.

429
00:21:13.100 --> 00:21:15.150
>> Yeah, this is now a shape.

430
00:21:15.150 --> 00:21:18.077
This is a group of shapes
that come together.

431
00:21:18.077 --> 00:21:22.986
And that's where it's, and I've actually
had where I'm sending something

432
00:21:22.986 --> 00:21:27.593
to the printers, like the print
specifications, they'll say, okay,

433
00:21:27.593 --> 00:21:32.300
I need it, CMYK, 300 ppi, and
all text must be converted to outlines.

434
00:21:32.300 --> 00:21:37.060
Even if it's paragraph text,
maybe paragraphs of information,

435
00:21:37.060 --> 00:21:40.830
you still convert that to outlines
because that commercial printer

436
00:21:40.830 --> 00:21:44.720
doesn't wanna have to do
anything with your font files.

437
00:21:44.720 --> 00:21:47.640
And especially with a little
bit more in back in the day,

438
00:21:47.640 --> 00:21:48.910
like the Mac versus PC fonts.

439
00:21:48.910 --> 00:21:53.840
And there's so many fonts out there,
they're like just give it to us in like

440
00:21:53.840 --> 00:21:58.160
the straight vector information, and we'll
be good to go, we won't have to worry

441
00:21:58.160 --> 00:22:03.660
about that whole kind of extra
layer of issues that can arise.

442
00:22:03.660 --> 00:22:04.650
>> Yeah, absolutely.

443
00:22:04.650 --> 00:22:07.730
So I was trying to show, while you were
talking, I was trying to show the example

444
00:22:07.730 --> 00:22:10.690
of a paragraph, just to try to kind
of reiterate what you had said.

445
00:22:10.690 --> 00:22:13.540
Yes, if you are working on a flyer or
something in Illustrator,

446
00:22:13.540 --> 00:22:14.680
you definitely wanna do same thing.

447
00:22:14.680 --> 00:22:16.930
I'm gonna duplicate this over,
or save it somewhere else.

448
00:22:16.930 --> 00:22:18.390
So that you have it if your client or

449
00:22:18.390 --> 00:22:21.706
your boss needs to you edit something
real quick, you're not in trouble later.

450
00:22:21.706 --> 00:22:23.625
And then right-click and Create Outlines.

451
00:22:23.625 --> 00:22:26.795
And I definitely have
the same issue before we're,

452
00:22:26.795 --> 00:22:28.885
even on accident I just forgot to
outline something one time, and

453
00:22:28.885 --> 00:22:31.395
the printer came back to me like we can't
do this, you didn't outline your text.

454
00:22:31.395 --> 00:22:35.663
So I have to go back and redo, or
not redo it, but outline text.

455
00:22:35.663 --> 00:22:40.195
>> Yeah, one thing that I have done,
I usually save either multiple files or

456
00:22:40.195 --> 00:22:41.875
sometimes I'll put like
a totally different layer and

457
00:22:41.875 --> 00:22:45.375
then hide the layer of it as text,
text, text.

458
00:22:45.375 --> 00:22:47.730
But then sometimes I'll go back and

459
00:22:47.730 --> 00:22:50.740
I forgot what font I used
in the outlined version.

460
00:22:50.740 --> 00:22:53.990
So I've gotten in a habit
of anytime I do it,

461
00:22:53.990 --> 00:22:57.810
type the name of the font off to the side,
even if I create,

462
00:22:57.810 --> 00:23:02.260
cuz sometimes I do a ctrl+a, Select All,
and everything goes to an outline.

463
00:23:02.260 --> 00:23:06.730
But since I wrote down the name
of the font that I used,

464
00:23:06.730 --> 00:23:10.120
that's off to the side, even if it's
outlined, I know which one it was.

465
00:23:10.120 --> 00:23:13.900
And that's where I, it was tripping me up
quite a few times, and now it's my new

466
00:23:13.900 --> 00:23:18.460
habit of anything I do, write the name of
the font that you used off to the side.

467
00:23:18.460 --> 00:23:24.050
>> Yeah, that is a smart and handy tip
cuz I've also had the moment before,

468
00:23:24.050 --> 00:23:26.523
where it's like, well,
this kind of looks like Open Sans, but

469
00:23:26.523 --> 00:23:27.230
[LAUGH]-
>> [LAUGH]

470
00:23:27.230 --> 00:23:28.080
>> I don't know.

471
00:23:28.080 --> 00:23:32.600
So, yeah, you always want to save
that duplicate, write yourself notes.

472
00:23:32.600 --> 00:23:34.040
I think layers are a great example.

473
00:23:34.040 --> 00:23:36.690
And that's a great time to use layers.

474
00:23:36.690 --> 00:23:40.410
As we mentioned, I'm not always
the best about using layers.

475
00:23:40.410 --> 00:23:41.580
I could be a little more organized.

476
00:23:41.580 --> 00:23:44.950
But if you are,
that's a great time to be organized.

477
00:23:44.950 --> 00:23:49.480
One other thing that I wanted to
mention with our text outlines.

478
00:23:49.480 --> 00:23:52.930
Because it often comes up, especially
as we're talking about gradients.

479
00:23:52.930 --> 00:23:55.950
Hey, can I apply a gradient on my type?

480
00:23:55.950 --> 00:23:58.240
In other programs, yes, you can.

481
00:23:58.240 --> 00:24:01.655
But you'll see, if I go ahead here,
this was my non-outlined version.

482
00:24:01.655 --> 00:24:04.321
If I go to my swatches panel and
try to apply a gradient there,

483
00:24:04.321 --> 00:24:05.587
nothing is going to happen.

484
00:24:05.587 --> 00:24:07.080
With you do that,

485
00:24:07.080 --> 00:24:13.167
you have to convert your type To a shape
in order to apply a gradient on it.

486
00:24:13.167 --> 00:24:16.712
So I can go ahead there and
I can now apply a gradient to that.

487
00:24:16.712 --> 00:24:18.152
So that's the key thing.

488
00:24:18.152 --> 00:24:21.776
You always have to do that outline mode or
create a shape out of it.

489
00:24:21.776 --> 00:24:25.221
>> Yeah, and now, that it's a group you
can see that the gradient was applied to

490
00:24:25.221 --> 00:24:26.769
every single individual letter.

491
00:24:26.769 --> 00:24:30.995
If you take the gradient tool now as it's
still a group and just click, hold, and

492
00:24:30.995 --> 00:24:31.750
drag across.

493
00:24:31.750 --> 00:24:36.716
Now, you can go ahead and have a gradient
go all the way through the word and

494
00:24:36.716 --> 00:24:37.368
it goes.

495
00:24:37.368 --> 00:24:39.609
I always got that big question.

496
00:24:39.609 --> 00:24:42.151
I was like,
I can't do gradients with text.

497
00:24:42.151 --> 00:24:45.193
Well, you can, it's just not text anymore.

498
00:24:45.193 --> 00:24:45.890
>> Right, yeah.

499
00:24:45.890 --> 00:24:48.862
>> So, make sure you're done with
typing and that's what you need.

500
00:24:48.862 --> 00:24:49.988
And always have a backup.

501
00:24:49.988 --> 00:24:52.101
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, yeah, exactly.

502
00:24:52.101 --> 00:24:55.445
But yes, you can still get
the same kind of appearance.

503
00:24:55.445 --> 00:24:56.991
And just for example's sake,

504
00:24:56.991 --> 00:25:00.148
because we did talk a lot about
the Touch Type tool versus this.

505
00:25:00.148 --> 00:25:04.436
So, in the past, before the Touch Type
tool existed, what you would have to do,

506
00:25:04.436 --> 00:25:07.022
is you would either have
to kind of ungroup this or

507
00:25:07.022 --> 00:25:11.212
just double-click to go in isolation mode,
which is what I'm gonna do here.

508
00:25:11.212 --> 00:25:12.837
I did a Cmd or Ctrl+Z.

509
00:25:12.837 --> 00:25:19.335
And then I would have to kind of shift
things around, okay, I'm gonna rotate.

510
00:25:19.335 --> 00:25:22.167
Try and adjust it that way.

511
00:25:22.167 --> 00:25:26.729
You would have to adjust it as
a shape rather than as a character.

512
00:25:26.729 --> 00:25:29.116
And again,
you later can't go back and edit it.

513
00:25:29.116 --> 00:25:32.842
So that's when we say the Touch Type tool
is nice because you used to have to do it

514
00:25:32.842 --> 00:25:33.354
this way.

515
00:25:33.354 --> 00:25:36.394
>> Yeah, because at this point, if you
had misspelled my name by any means,

516
00:25:36.394 --> 00:25:38.170
that is the correct spelling, by the way.

517
00:25:38.170 --> 00:25:41.115
You could go in and
take out an N or take out the E or

518
00:25:41.115 --> 00:25:43.940
just V-O-N, which everybody wants to do.

519
00:25:43.940 --> 00:25:45.635
It's like, no, it's V-O-N-N-E.

520
00:25:45.635 --> 00:25:46.320
>> Yeah, there you go.

521
00:25:46.320 --> 00:25:47.714
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's text this.

522
00:25:47.714 --> 00:25:50.060
And then you could go double N's and
all that kind of,

523
00:25:50.060 --> 00:25:51.951
I guess I already have
a double N in my name.

524
00:25:51.951 --> 00:25:52.636
There you go.

525
00:25:52.636 --> 00:25:54.552
>> [LAUGH] VONNNNE.

526
00:25:54.552 --> 00:25:57.671
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So you can go back and do that

527
00:25:57.671 --> 00:26:02.168
editing as text, which again, I hope
that's driving home the point of why we

528
00:26:02.168 --> 00:26:06.826
keep saying that and why it's so cool to
be able to have it as the Touch Type tool.

529
00:26:06.826 --> 00:26:09.112
>> Yeah.
>> And I also made one other observation.

530
00:26:09.112 --> 00:26:09.693
>> Yes.

531
00:26:09.693 --> 00:26:13.131
>> That font that you just chose,
I'm like, why does this look so familiar.

532
00:26:13.131 --> 00:26:15.813
It's like the little letters that
you put on the refrigerator.

533
00:26:15.813 --> 00:26:16.393
>> Yeah.

534
00:26:16.393 --> 00:26:18.123
[LAUGH]
>> It kinda reminds me of that.

535
00:26:18.123 --> 00:26:19.644
[LAUGH]
>> I know.

536
00:26:19.644 --> 00:26:22.628
It's always my go to for
some reason in an example like this.

537
00:26:22.628 --> 00:26:23.812
I'm like, this looks kinda fun.

538
00:26:23.812 --> 00:26:24.868
>> I love it, yeah.

539
00:26:24.868 --> 00:26:27.817
I mean, it's obviously, yes,
those are the refrigerator letters.

540
00:26:27.817 --> 00:26:28.815
They look just like it.

541
00:26:28.815 --> 00:26:30.443
At least to me it does, so.

542
00:26:30.443 --> 00:26:31.916
>> Yeah.
No, it's perfect, just perfect.

543
00:26:31.916 --> 00:26:34.223
I got it for a client once and
they didn't like it, so I was like, well,

544
00:26:34.223 --> 00:26:35.120
I'll just use it for this.

545
00:26:35.120 --> 00:26:35.781
>> Yeah.

546
00:26:35.781 --> 00:26:37.013
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

547
00:26:37.013 --> 00:26:38.257
>> It goes along with our whole like

548
00:26:38.257 --> 00:26:41.265
kindergarten of references that we've
been making in some other episodes.

549
00:26:41.265 --> 00:26:44.620
So I'm just like, this is just
like kindergarten all over again.

550
00:26:44.620 --> 00:26:45.305
Yay.

551
00:26:45.305 --> 00:26:45.979
>> Exactly.

552
00:26:45.979 --> 00:26:48.071
>> [LAUGH]
>> So yes, it was a perfect example for

553
00:26:48.071 --> 00:26:48.951
affecting our text.

554
00:26:48.951 --> 00:26:51.089
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think we're done.

555
00:26:51.089 --> 00:26:55.663
Yeah, that was it for affecting our text
or at least kind of getting us started.

556
00:26:55.663 --> 00:26:59.247
I'm sure in some other episodes we'll
mention, I can already think of like

557
00:26:59.247 --> 00:27:02.159
an envelope distort or
something that we'll talk about, and

558
00:27:02.159 --> 00:27:06.079
again, in a separate episode, where we can
kinda go a little fancy on our text, but

559
00:27:06.079 --> 00:27:07.769
that was a great start, I think so.

560
00:27:07.769 --> 00:27:09.488
>> Ooh,
dropping the envelope at the store.

561
00:27:09.488 --> 00:27:10.486
>> No.
>> I see.

562
00:27:10.486 --> 00:27:11.728
>> I'm dropping that bomb, yeah.

563
00:27:11.728 --> 00:27:15.249
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, I can't wait to get there, but

564
00:27:15.249 --> 00:27:18.868
for right now, I think that was a great
introduction to different things

565
00:27:18.868 --> 00:27:22.504
that can do to affect our text and
make it just a little cooler there, so.

566
00:27:22.504 --> 00:27:25.150
We're gonna go ahead and
wrap up this episode.

567
00:27:25.150 --> 00:27:28.296
Signing off for CreativeProTV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

568
00:27:28.296 --> 00:27:29.445
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

569
00:27:29.445 --> 00:27:30.791
>> And we'll see you soon.

570
00:27:30.791 --> 00:27:31.291
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to combine shapes in different ways using the pathfinder panel. They define and demonstrate what is a compound path and how to work with them.
episodes.title: Pathfinder and Compound Path
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:02.948
[SOUND]

2
00:00:02.948 --> 00:00:11.306
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.306 --> 00:00:13.963
Hello, and welcome to another
edition of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:13.963 --> 00:00:15.393
I'm your host, Vonne Smith,

5
00:00:15.393 --> 00:00:18.477
and we are continuing on with
our Illustrator CC 2017 series.

6
00:00:18.477 --> 00:00:23.217
And in this episode, we're gonna be
talking about the pathfinder and

7
00:00:23.217 --> 00:00:25.330
the compound path.

8
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:28.590
Sounds like a lot of words that you're
like, I have no idea what this means.

9
00:00:28.590 --> 00:00:32.760
But luckily we have the one and only Miss
Emily Ramsey to help guide us through.

10
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:35.080
>> I'm going to explain
what those words mean.

11
00:00:35.080 --> 00:00:38.240
No, it's kind of funny cuz they
sound like dull words I think.

12
00:00:38.240 --> 00:00:43.350
But the pathfinder and the compound path,
they do actually some pretty cool things.

13
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:44.930
>> And we were talking about this,

14
00:00:44.930 --> 00:00:50.740
they are kind of core concepts
in Illustrator, and at first,

15
00:00:50.740 --> 00:00:54.290
and I remember when I first learned this
on my whatever, whatever that thing is.

16
00:00:54.290 --> 00:00:57.420
And also because I really
didn't understand it.

17
00:00:57.420 --> 00:01:00.190
It's almost too simple,
and you're thinking,

18
00:01:00.190 --> 00:01:02.450
I'm not going to see this that much.

19
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:08.100
It's amazing how much I see and
use both the pathfinder panel and

20
00:01:08.100 --> 00:01:13.930
the concept of what is a compound path
in the things that I do in Illustrator.

21
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:15.240
>> Yeah.
>> Not to scare you,

22
00:01:15.240 --> 00:01:18.560
maybe you might not get
it at first either.

23
00:01:18.560 --> 00:01:19.580
That's okay,

24
00:01:19.580 --> 00:01:23.780
I'm just trying to tell you my perspective
of how I've been using illustrator.

25
00:01:23.780 --> 00:01:27.950
And it is, you're going to see
it come up more than you think.

26
00:01:27.950 --> 00:01:29.980
>> Yeah, I totally agree.

27
00:01:29.980 --> 00:01:31.520
I think part of the reason for

28
00:01:31.520 --> 00:01:36.610
that is why it comes up is because I tend
to think with people in Illustrator,

29
00:01:36.610 --> 00:01:39.580
you tend to automatically go to
the hard route for something.

30
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:43.240
So, we always talk about the pen tool,
maybe you haven't gotten there yet

31
00:01:43.240 --> 00:01:47.170
in the episodes, but that's kind of
the hard route of doing something.

32
00:01:47.170 --> 00:01:51.250
What the pathfinder panel, which is kind
of where we'll kind of start out, does for

33
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:54.740
you, it basically makes it look
like you can draw when you can't.

34
00:01:54.740 --> 00:01:56.830
[LAUGH] That's the way I phrase it.

35
00:01:56.830 --> 00:01:58.568
>> And
that's probably why I've loved it so much.

36
00:01:58.568 --> 00:02:00.017
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> All my years as well,

37
00:02:00.017 --> 00:02:03.437
because it's like, I'm like if I
just kind of put these together and

38
00:02:03.437 --> 00:02:05.950
I'm a little bit more of a puzzle person.

39
00:02:05.950 --> 00:02:06.508
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, and

40
00:02:06.508 --> 00:02:10.740
how the pieces fit together and if I just
take that out, there you go, perfect!

41
00:02:10.740 --> 00:02:12.720
That's what I wanted to do.

42
00:02:12.720 --> 00:02:14.450
>> I can see the puzzle example for sure.

43
00:02:14.450 --> 00:02:18.530
Okay, we are gonna take your puzzle and
we are gonna start with Mickey Mouse.

44
00:02:18.530 --> 00:02:20.640
I'm all about the mouse.

45
00:02:20.640 --> 00:02:22.970
So what we're gonna do here,
I'm actually gonna give two examples.

46
00:02:22.970 --> 00:02:27.360
I'm gonna one, just draw a Mickey Mouse,
go with me here, okay.

47
00:02:27.360 --> 00:02:32.246
If you don't love the mouse, I'm sorry,
terrible childhood memories, I don't know.

48
00:02:32.246 --> 00:02:34.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> But go ahead and just draw something,

49
00:02:34.250 --> 00:02:37.390
even if it's not exactly like this,
something that's just close to it.

50
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:41.020
I'm gonna just draw those three circles
and then make this a little bit larger,

51
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:42.930
just so
it's a little bit bigger on my art board.

52
00:02:42.930 --> 00:02:46.420
And then right next to that,
I'm gonna take two yellow circles,

53
00:02:46.420 --> 00:02:48.090
just kind of overlapping each other.

54
00:02:49.940 --> 00:02:53.750
Kind of like a Venn diagram,
do you remember that back from?

55
00:02:55.090 --> 00:02:55.670
English?

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily introduce the basics of editing paths using the direct selection tool.  They define and introduce Bezier paths, covering the how to add, subtract, and convert points using the different pen tools.
episodes.title: Path Editing Tools
