one when I selected it,

442
00:21:47.270 --> 00:21:49.108
and it turned to a darker shade of blue?

443
00:21:49.108 --> 00:21:52.600
That just lets me know, okay, I have
that one chosen, and I can go ahead and

444
00:21:52.600 --> 00:21:54.056
delete that off of my artboard.

445
00:21:54.056 --> 00:21:56.250
I'm just using my Delete
key off of my keyboard,

446
00:21:56.250 --> 00:21:58.830
same way that you would if you
were deleting anything else.

447
00:21:58.830 --> 00:22:01.720
So guides are definitely something
again that I think are helpful,

448
00:22:01.720 --> 00:22:03.670
and I liked Vonne's
examples of the margins.

449
00:22:03.670 --> 00:22:07.821
>> Yeah, and just a few other little tips
that I've learned through all the years.

450
00:22:07.821 --> 00:22:12.089
When I'm using things like margins or
guides that are for my setup and

451
00:22:12.089 --> 00:22:14.527
layout of whatever I'm working with?

452
00:22:14.527 --> 00:22:18.684
I, personally,
I put them all on its own layer, too.

453
00:22:18.684 --> 00:22:21.692
Yeah, cuz they kind of
get mixed up sometimes.

454
00:22:21.692 --> 00:22:24.764
Cuz if I am working in layers,
and I'm in two and three and

455
00:22:24.764 --> 00:22:28.168
four, then I have a guide in layer
four and a guide in layer two?

456
00:22:28.168 --> 00:22:32.338
It's like, I don't really want them
kind of all in with the stuff.

457
00:22:32.338 --> 00:22:36.710
So I'll make my own layer, go ahead and
put all the guides in there,

458
00:22:36.710 --> 00:22:40.419
and then I can use that layer
sometimes to turn on and off.

459
00:22:40.419 --> 00:22:43.945
I always use the Hide Guides,
that Cmd+Colon,

460
00:22:43.945 --> 00:22:46.680
it's programmed in my brain-
>> All day long.

461
00:22:46.680 --> 00:22:49.560
>> Of how, right, cuz sometimes you
don't want to see the guides but

462
00:22:49.560 --> 00:22:51.884
you want to see the artwork and
everything like that.

463
00:22:51.884 --> 00:22:53.847
So that's something that I suggest.

464
00:22:53.847 --> 00:22:57.830
One other suggestion that I have with
guides is, once you unlock them and

465
00:22:57.830 --> 00:23:00.150
select them, and you have it selected.

466
00:23:00.150 --> 00:23:02.500
You can find either in
the Transform panel,

467
00:23:02.500 --> 00:23:06.590
I think it's Transform panel,
where you can find like the x-coordinate.

468
00:23:06.590 --> 00:23:10.830
I need it to be exactly at
half-inch from the left, so

469
00:23:10.830 --> 00:23:14.789
I will change that x-value
to whatever it is, and

470
00:23:14.789 --> 00:23:16.664
now that one on the-
>> Yeah,

471
00:23:16.664 --> 00:23:18.759
that one on the right-hand
side might be a little tricky,

472
00:23:18.759 --> 00:23:21.002
on the left-hand side it's
probably a little easier [LAUGH].

473
00:23:21.002 --> 00:23:23.116
>> Yeah, you gotta start doing math and
things like that.

474
00:23:23.116 --> 00:23:25.739
So it's like, I have an 8.5 and 11 minus-
>> It's too early to do math.

475
00:23:25.739 --> 00:23:28.904
[LAUGH]
>> Right, but I do use those x and

476
00:23:28.904 --> 00:23:33.023
y-coordinates when setting guides,
either this way or this way,

477
00:23:33.023 --> 00:23:35.563
depending on, I'm like, where am I at?

478
00:23:35.563 --> 00:23:37.074
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, which one?

479
00:23:37.074 --> 00:23:39.856
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's kind of perfect of where we're at,

480
00:23:39.856 --> 00:23:43.028
right here of, I need to know
exactly this amount for my guide.

481
00:23:43.028 --> 00:23:49.168
So just another little tip and
trick from me to you about that.

482
00:23:49.168 --> 00:23:51.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that's a great idea, actually,

483
00:23:51.820 --> 00:23:55.705
to use your Transform panel, that's one
of the good uses for that, so absolutely.

484
00:23:55.705 --> 00:23:59.525
So I now made these exactly half
an inch from the left and the top.

485
00:23:59.525 --> 00:24:01.556
I wasn't getting into
the math on the other side-

486
00:24:01.556 --> 00:24:02.347
>> [LAUGH]

487
00:24:02.347 --> 00:24:04.076
>> But you could, if you wanted to.

488
00:24:04.076 --> 00:24:07.942
So, with guides, one thing I want to point
out real quick before we move onto grids.

489
00:24:07.942 --> 00:24:11.983
Is make sure that now, okay, I've
unlocked these, make sure you go back and

490
00:24:11.983 --> 00:24:15.396
lock them, so if you want to-
>> Gosh, yeah, my god, I'm so

491
00:24:15.396 --> 00:24:16.803
glad you just added that.

492
00:24:16.803 --> 00:24:20.124
Because there is so many times where
I'll do just that, click, hold, and

493
00:24:20.124 --> 00:24:21.794
drag cuz I'm selecting my objects.

494
00:24:21.794 --> 00:24:25.670
And I'm grabbing the guides and I'm
moving them, and I didn't realize, oops,

495
00:24:25.670 --> 00:24:28.060
gotta lock them,
gotta go back and lock them.

496
00:24:28.060 --> 00:24:32.861
So it can be slightly frustrating,
and even to me, cuz I keep forgetting.

497
00:24:32.861 --> 00:24:35.431
And then you have to click off
of everything to make sure you

498
00:24:35.431 --> 00:24:38.956
can right-click, cuz if you right-click
something it'll select it, ugh.

499
00:24:38.956 --> 00:24:41.023
>> Ugh, right, trying to do that,
it's like, ugh!

500
00:24:41.023 --> 00:24:41.661
>> Yeah, yeah.

501
00:24:41.661 --> 00:24:44.261
>> Well, actually that did show up, but-
>> [LAUGH]

502
00:24:44.261 --> 00:24:45.550
>> Bad example, so okay,

503
00:24:45.550 --> 00:24:47.424
I hadn't selected it all the way.

504
00:24:47.424 --> 00:24:50.347
So yeah, I'm gonna go ahead and
make sure I have nothing selected, and

505
00:24:50.347 --> 00:24:52.413
I'm gonna go back to Lock Guides,
Cmd or Ctrl.

506
00:24:52.413 --> 00:24:55.640
No, I'm sorry, Cmd or Ctrl+Semicolon
turns them on and off, but yeah.

507
00:24:55.640 --> 00:24:59.030
>> And you could do all this at the View
menu as well, in you wanted to unlock or

508
00:24:59.030 --> 00:24:59.720
lock the guides.

509
00:24:59.720 --> 00:25:02.610
I think it's all in the Guides,
yeah, there you go.

510
00:25:02.610 --> 00:25:04.668
The Clear Guides, I forgot,
that's a good one too.

511
00:25:04.668 --> 00:25:06.976
>> Yeah, yeah, actually,
I'm glad that we went there.

512
00:25:06.976 --> 00:25:08.374
So yeah, View > Guides, and then if for

513
00:25:08.374 --> 00:25:11.020
some reason you want to get rid of all
of them, go ahead and hit Clear Guides.

514
00:25:11.020 --> 00:25:13.811
And that's gonna go ahead and
put everything away.

515
00:25:13.811 --> 00:25:16.767
>> Yeah, I've used that,
I'm glad we went through it too.

516
00:25:16.767 --> 00:25:17.641
>> I know, we're cool.

517
00:25:17.641 --> 00:25:20.938
>> [LAUGH] But I know you have more about-
>> I do.

518
00:25:20.938 --> 00:25:25.898
>> Yes, I know we have some grids and
some snaps and everything like that,

519
00:25:25.898 --> 00:25:28.969
and I would like to give
that their due time.

520
00:25:28.969 --> 00:25:33.354
So, I'm making us, I'm guiding you here,
so maybe we'll come back for

521
00:25:33.354 --> 00:25:37.130
a part two so we can kind of get
all the other things that we know.

522
00:25:37.130 --> 00:25:39.615
Cuz there is quite a bit more to cover,
right?

523
00:25:39.615 --> 00:25:40.498
>> Yeah, I agree.

524
00:25:40.498 --> 00:25:41.995
>> I'm like, yeah, right?

525
00:25:41.995 --> 00:25:43.888
>> I was thinking about it,
I said yeah, it's been a little long.

526
00:25:43.888 --> 00:25:46.071
>> [LAUGH]
>> Who's riding who here, so yeah.

527
00:25:46.071 --> 00:25:48.101
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, well,

528
00:25:48.101 --> 00:25:52.213
we will guide you back in another
episode in just a little bit, [SOUND].

529
00:25:52.213 --> 00:25:56.718
But for now, I got it, we're going to
ahead and sign off for CreativeProTV.

530
00:25:56.718 --> 00:25:57.972
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

531
00:25:57.972 --> 00:25:58.831
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

532
00:25:58.831 --> 00:25:59.979
>> And we'll see you soon.

533
00:25:59.979 --> 00:26:03.312
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue with aligning objects, specifically covering make guides from a selection, snap to grid and point, view grids, the measure tool, and outline view.
episodes.title: Aligning Objects Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.376 --> 00:00:06.217
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.217 --> 00:00:10.993
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10.993 --> 00:00:14.661
Hello and welcome back to another
episode of Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:14.661 --> 00:00:19.557
I'm your host Vonne Smith, and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017,

5
00:00:19.557 --> 00:00:22.146
I've got it right, yes, I am in alignment.

6
00:00:22.146 --> 00:00:25.483
And yes, this is a part two
of our aligning objects, and

7
00:00:25.483 --> 00:00:28.331
here back to help us again is Ms.
Emily Ramsey.

8
00:00:28.331 --> 00:00:28.884
[CROSSTALK]
>> I'm so-

9
00:00:28.884 --> 00:00:29.733
>> I'm so glad you're here.

10
00:00:29.733 --> 00:00:31.951
[LAUGH]
>> I know, I'm so glad to be here.

11
00:00:31.951 --> 00:00:34.799
And actually,
I'm glad we took that little pause and

12
00:00:34.799 --> 00:00:37.648
did a part two because we
thought about something, or

13
00:00:37.648 --> 00:00:41.466
Taylor our director reminded us of
something that we didn't mention.

14
00:00:41.466 --> 00:00:44.046
So now we have a new cool tricks to
talk about that we didn't even have

15
00:00:44.046 --> 00:00:44.556
on the list.

16
00:00:44.556 --> 00:00:45.558
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

17
00:00:45.558 --> 00:00:48.499
we are gonna continue with our
guides as we were discussing,

18
00:00:48.499 --> 00:00:51.623
just one quick little tip that
again we remembered on our break.

19
00:00:51.623 --> 00:00:56.773
And then also carry in to grids, and then
some outline mode, and that measure tool.

20
00:00:56.773 --> 00:00:59.630
I'm gonna get back to measuring those
things that I mentioned earlier.

21
00:00:59.630 --> 00:01:02.172
So let's go ahead and
jump right back into illustrator.

22
00:01:02.172 --> 00:01:07.034
Now again, while we were on that break,
our director Taylor said you know what,

23
00:01:07.034 --> 00:01:09.270
can I make a guide that's diagonal?

24
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:12.950
And it just kind of, our brains were like,
yes, you can actually.

25
00:01:12.950 --> 00:01:14.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we forgot to mention that.

26
00:01:14.840 --> 00:01:16.516
So something that you wanna do,

27
00:01:16.516 --> 00:01:20.128
say notice everything was perfectly
horizontal or vertical there.

28
00:01:20.128 --> 00:01:25.002
But I want something a little fancier than
that, I want to create a diagonal guide.

29
00:01:25.002 --> 00:01:28.610
What I can do, I'm gonna go ahead and
grab my line segment tool.

30
00:01:28.610 --> 00:01:32.100
I'm just gonna draw a diagonal
line across my art board here.

31
00:01:33.410 --> 00:01:38.010
And really cool trick that you can use, I
can keep this selected, don't go back and

32
00:01:38.010 --> 00:01:40.456
click over here, make sure it is selected.

33
00:01:40.456 --> 00:01:44.382
You see mine has no fill or no stroke
color that doesn't necessarily matter, but

34
00:01:44.382 --> 00:01:46.995
I just don't feel like
applying any color right now.

35
00:01:46.995 --> 00:01:50.207
So what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna go to my View menu,

36
00:01:50.207 --> 00:01:54.530
then I'm gonna go down the Guides,
and I'm gonna choose Make Guide.

37
00:01:54.530 --> 00:01:56.728
So when I pick that, Make Guide,

38
00:01:56.728 --> 00:02:00.981
you'll see that converted that to a guide,
which is just cool.

39
00:02:00.981 --> 00:02:02.704
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean, right?

40
00:02:02.704 --> 00:02:06.598
>> And it was one of those things where
he asked and we were both, my gosh, yeah,

41
00:02:06.598 --> 00:02:08.245
I'm actually done this before.

42
00:02:08.245 --> 00:02:10.648
Because on that talking
about those margins, and

43
00:02:10.648 --> 00:02:13.650
this is just a line that I would
actually make a rectangle.

44
00:02:13.650 --> 00:02:17.130
Make sure the dimensions are exactly
what that inner space needs to be,

45
00:02:17.130 --> 00:02:20.032
align it right in the center,
and then choose make guides.

46
00:02:20.032 --> 00:02:21.469
I'm like, yes, I've done this before.

47
00:02:21.469 --> 00:02:22.053
>> Yes.

48
00:02:22.053 --> 00:02:24.940
>> This is so cool, yeah,
we both forgot about how you could do it.

49
00:02:24.940 --> 00:02:25.579
>> Yeah.

50
00:02:25.579 --> 00:02:30.351
>> And then yeah, you can totally make
a diagonal, I almost said horizontal,

51
00:02:30.351 --> 00:02:31.554
a diagonal guide.

52
00:02:31.554 --> 00:02:33.652
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, but like you said,

53
00:02:33.652 --> 00:02:35.104
you can use anything, I think-
>> Mm-hm.

54
00:02:35.104 --> 00:02:38.728
>> You can use a rectangle, I'm gonna
go ahead and delete this one just so

55
00:02:38.728 --> 00:02:40.024
it's not in the middle.

56
00:02:40.024 --> 00:02:43.567
But yeah, she was saying go ahead and
do something like that,

57
00:02:43.567 --> 00:02:46.852
use your own line panel,
kinda align this to the center.

58
00:02:46.852 --> 00:02:49.820
I'm not really perfecting this but
you can kinda see what I would do.

59
00:02:49.820 --> 00:02:52.877
View, Guides, Make Guides,
and its gonna go ahead and

60
00:02:52.877 --> 00:02:54.709
convert that into a guide for me.

61
00:02:54.709 --> 00:02:56.400
So you can kinda use that as your margins.

62
00:02:56.400 --> 00:02:58.642
I'm basically just repeating
everything she just said.

63
00:02:58.642 --> 00:02:59.579
But I wanted to go ahead and do it so

64
00:02:59.579 --> 00:03:01.064
you could kinda see what
that look like right there.

65
00:03:01.064 --> 00:03:02.952
>> Yeah,
it's nice that we have a visual reference.

66
00:03:02.952 --> 00:03:03.596
>> yeah.

67
00:03:03.596 --> 00:03:05.094
>> This is how you can actually do it,
so yeah.

68
00:03:05.094 --> 00:03:08.830
And the center center thing, I'm always
aligning center centers for some reason,

69
00:03:08.830 --> 00:03:12.156
overlapping circles and squares,
the target logo we keep talking about.

70
00:03:12.156 --> 00:03:12.734
>> Yeah.

71
00:03:12.734 --> 00:03:13.808
[LAUGH]
>> Just go ahead and

72
00:03:13.808 --> 00:03:17.261
make sure they're right center center,
and you're good to go, so yay.

73
00:03:17.261 --> 00:03:17.903
>> I love it.

74
00:03:17.903 --> 00:03:18.723
>> Thank you, Taylor.

75
00:03:18.723 --> 00:03:19.615
[LAUGH]
>> Taylor,

76
00:03:19.615 --> 00:03:20.761
you get a little shout-out there.

77
00:03:20.761 --> 00:03:24.821
So I'm gonna go ahead, I'm gonna either,
maybe I'll go ahead, oop, that was,

78
00:03:24.821 --> 00:03:27.020
I just locked it,
I was trying to unlock it.

79
00:03:27.020 --> 00:03:30.677
So go ahead and get rid of that just so
we can see our grids a little bit better.

80
00:03:30.677 --> 00:03:35.180
So grids are kinda like the cousin
to guides basically, if you will.

81
00:03:35.180 --> 00:03:38.810
What we can do, I'm gonna go ahead and
turn on my grids, cuz I think the best way

82
00:03:38.810 --> 00:03:41.512
to show you what that is,
is to go ahead and just turn it on.

83
00:03:41.512 --> 00:03:45.253
So, again either way you can
go to your View menu and

84
00:03:45.253 --> 00:03:50.930
go down to Show Grid, or I'm going
to right click and choose Show Grid.

85
00:03:50.930 --> 00:03:54.247
That's usually kind of my go to is
the right click method but you do you,

86
00:03:54.247 --> 00:03:55.365
whatever you wanna do.

87
00:03:55.365 --> 00:03:57.620
And I can go ahead and turn on this grid.

88
00:03:57.620 --> 00:04:01.427
So this grid is basically just like
a lot of guides to help you go ahead and

89
00:04:01.427 --> 00:04:02.258
align things.

90
00:04:02.258 --> 00:04:03.637
So oftentimes in design,

91
00:04:03.637 --> 00:04:06.907
you wanna make sure that things
are kinda perfectly aligned.

92
00:04:06.907 --> 00:04:11.104
Now, when I say the word perfect, I really
wanna kinda be careful there because

93
00:04:11.104 --> 00:04:14.500
I think that tends to naturally
flow people into Pixel Perfect.

94
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:18.980
This is not a pixel preview, this is not
necessarily what you're looking at here,

95
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:21.357
it's just guides to help you align things.

96
00:04:21.357 --> 00:04:22.510
There are options for

97
00:04:22.510 --> 00:04:26.040
making sure everything's perfectly
aligned to the pixel grid.

98
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:29.673
And certainly we're gonna get to that
when we do our kinda saving for web and

99
00:04:29.673 --> 00:04:30.605
things like that.

100
00:04:30.605 --> 00:04:36.200
But for right now this is really just,
okay, basic alignment.

101
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:38.925
And it's nice, you can use this,
I'm gonna kind of zoom in here.

102
00:04:38.925 --> 00:04:42.260
I can go ahead and be like okay,
I wanna draw something, and

103
00:04:42.260 --> 00:04:45.350
I wanna make sure that it's
kind of perfectly in line.

104
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:47.606
And it just helps you when
you're working to make sure,

105
00:04:47.606 --> 00:04:50.582
especially if you're doing something
maybe a little bit more detailed,

106
00:04:50.582 --> 00:04:52.176
to ensure that everything is lined up.

107
00:04:52.176 --> 00:04:57.580
Now, kind of a handy thing that goes along
with this is this snap to guides option.

108
00:04:57.580 --> 00:04:59.640
So if I go back into my View menu.

109
00:04:59.640 --> 00:05:00.553
>> Or Snap to Grid.

110
00:05:00.553 --> 00:05:01.677
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

111
00:05:01.677 --> 00:05:02.301
>> Snap.

112
00:05:02.301 --> 00:05:03.132
[LAUGH]
>> It's guides, you know.

113
00:05:03.132 --> 00:05:04.881
>> G, I dunno.

114
00:05:04.881 --> 00:05:08.586
[LAUGH] So I'm gonna go ahead and
turn on this Snap to Grid, so View and

115
00:05:08.586 --> 00:05:12.050
then almost all the way down at
the bottom you have Snap to Grid.

116
00:05:12.050 --> 00:05:15.336
And what that's gonna do for
us is just make this a little bit easier.

117
00:05:15.336 --> 00:05:19.078
So you'll see, and it's almost even
kind of hard to see as I'm doing it, but

118
00:05:19.078 --> 00:05:23.510
it's definitely something you feel
as you're working in Illustrator.

119
00:05:23.510 --> 00:05:28.069
As I'm moving it is trying to snap
to each of these guide points.

120
00:05:28.069 --> 00:05:32.192
So if you are using your guides,
I would definitely recommend turning on,

121
00:05:32.192 --> 00:05:34.080
I'm sorry, using your guides.

122
00:05:34.080 --> 00:05:37.364
If you're using your grids,
I would definitely recommended

123
00:05:37.364 --> 00:05:40.719
turning on that Snap to Grid,
I'm not gonna say guide, grid.

124
00:05:40.719 --> 00:05:45.490
[LAUGH] And use that Snap to Grid as
a way of just kinda making it a little

125
00:05:45.490 --> 00:05:47.510
bit more intuitive for you.

126
00:05:47.510 --> 00:05:49.046
If you're gonna use your grids anyway,

127
00:05:49.046 --> 00:05:51.224
I kinda feel like you may as
well turn on your Snap to Grid.

128
00:05:51.224 --> 00:05:53.378
Now, the thing that can get
a little bit tricky about this, and

129
00:05:53.378 --> 00:05:55.190
we were kinda discussing this earlier.

130
00:05:55.190 --> 00:06:00.428
Say I go ahead and hide my grid and I just
kinda forget that I have that on, right?

131
00:06:00.428 --> 00:06:03.910
And I forget that I was even
using the grid at one point,

132
00:06:03.910 --> 00:06:08.930
just cuz I'm hiding my grid doesn't
necessarily mean the Snap to Grid is off.

133
00:06:08.930 --> 00:06:12.504
So this is still snapping,
whether or not you can see the grid,

134
00:06:12.504 --> 00:06:14.538
it's still snapping to that grid.

135
00:06:14.538 --> 00:06:18.961
So if that something that you want,
great, if you don't want it, go ahead and

136
00:06:18.961 --> 00:06:20.910
turn to your View menu again.

137
00:06:20.910 --> 00:06:24.385
Oops, and
make sure to turn off that Snap to Grid.

138
00:06:24.385 --> 00:06:27.631
So I'm gonna go ahead and unselect that.

139
00:06:27.631 --> 00:06:32.548
>> I use the grid a lot, and I also use
the Snap to Grid, but like you're saying,

140
00:06:32.548 --> 00:06:37.392
I toggle back and forth of hiding and
showing the grid, and then snapping and

141
00:06:37.392 --> 00:06:39.080
not snapping to the grid.

142
00:06:39.080 --> 00:06:42.010
So those keyboard shortcuts that
are to the right of each one

143
00:06:42.010 --> 00:06:45.657
of those commands in that View menu,
those are committed to memory to me.

144
00:06:45.657 --> 00:06:46.331
>> Yeah.

145
00:06:46.331 --> 00:06:49.246
>> I mean, it's been a while so
I probably have to remind myself.

146
00:06:49.246 --> 00:06:53.123
But when I'm deep in projects like this,
I'm all the time on and off,

147
00:06:53.123 --> 00:06:57.780
using the grids, hiding the grids,
turning on the guides, hiding the guides.

148
00:06:57.780 --> 00:07:02.679
All that kind of stuff, and going back and
forth between all of them to make

149
00:07:02.679 --> 00:07:07.836
sure that it is as accurate as I need it
to be, and I didn't wanna say perfect.

150
00:07:07.836 --> 00:07:08.967
[CROSSTALK]
>> Right, right.

151
00:07:08.967 --> 00:07:11.307
>> How can I not say,
it's perfectly aligned?

152
00:07:11.307 --> 00:07:12.804
[LAUGH]
>> Right, yeah.

153
00:07:12.804 --> 00:07:14.554
[LAUGH] It's tough actually.

154
00:07:14.554 --> 00:07:15.085
>> Right?

155
00:07:15.085 --> 00:07:18.263
>> Yeah, [LAUGH], apparently I
don't have a lot of descriptions.

156
00:07:18.263 --> 00:07:20.278
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so

157
00:07:20.278 --> 00:07:22.676
one other thing I wanted to point out,
or actually,

158
00:07:22.676 --> 00:07:25.710
really two other things that I
wanted to point out with our grids.

159
00:07:25.710 --> 00:07:29.592
One, this isn't necessarily
directly related to our grids, but

160
00:07:29.592 --> 00:07:32.585
I think it kind of comes up
with that snap to option.

161
00:07:32.585 --> 00:07:35.270
I'm gonna go ahead and
create a second object here.

162
00:07:36.960 --> 00:07:39.106
They don't necessarily have to be
different colors, but just for

163
00:07:39.106 --> 00:07:41.078
fun's sake we'll go ahead and
make them different colors.

164
00:07:41.078 --> 00:07:42.870
And then I'm gonna go
back to that View menu.

165
00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:45.134
You also may have noticed that there
were several different options.

166
00:07:45.134 --> 00:07:47.988
Snap to Pixel,
we'll kind of talk about that, again,

167
00:07:47.988 --> 00:07:51.340
when we get into our more saving for
web, things like that.

168
00:07:51.340 --> 00:07:53.373
But then there's also a Snap to Point.

169
00:07:53.373 --> 00:07:58.220
Now, Snap to Point versus Snap to Grid,
it's kind of a subtle difference,

170
00:07:58.220 --> 00:07:59.490
I would say.

171
00:07:59.490 --> 00:08:01.219
But the Snap to Point, basically,

172
00:08:01.219 --> 00:08:03.764
it's gonna help you kinda
align objects together.

173
00:08:03.764 --> 00:08:08.186
So, for instance if I wanna kinda
align this corners together it's

174
00:08:08.186 --> 00:08:12.698
basically just gonna snap the two
points of those objects together.

175
00:08:12.698 --> 00:08:16.986
So really just depends on your own
personal preference, I would say.

176
00:08:16.986 --> 00:08:18.061
>> And I think this is on by default.

177
00:08:18.061 --> 00:08:18.791
>> Yeah.

178
00:08:18.791 --> 00:08:23.683
>> The Snap to Point, and you might
have noticed as you've been going along,

179
00:08:23.683 --> 00:08:26.324
the two squares will kind of magnetize or

180
00:08:26.324 --> 00:08:30.454
magnetically snap together when
they get close to each other.

181
00:08:30.454 --> 00:08:34.563
Or even with using the smart guides
where it kind of, it snaps in,

182
00:08:34.563 --> 00:08:36.073
that's on by default.

183
00:08:36.073 --> 00:08:41.299
So if you didn't want any of that, I've
turned that off every once in a while.

184
00:08:41.299 --> 00:08:42.489
>> Right.

185
00:08:42.489 --> 00:08:48.040
>> But it is different to the objects
to each other, if you wanna say,

186
00:08:48.040 --> 00:08:53.811
not to a grid or a guide, it's all
the objects as their own entities.

187
00:08:53.811 --> 00:08:55.683
>> Yes, yes, and I like them magnetized.

188
00:08:55.683 --> 00:08:56.885
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean,

189
00:08:56.885 --> 00:08:59.975
that's basically what it's doing,
it's kinda just pulling the two together.

190
00:08:59.975 --> 00:09:03.431
And you kinda like she said,
I very rarely turn this off,

191
00:09:03.431 --> 00:09:07.031
I just kind of leave it there,
cuz I do find it to be helpful.

192
00:09:07.031 --> 00:09:09.718
But occasionally,
you have something that keeps snapping and

193
00:09:09.718 --> 00:09:12.670
your like please stop snapping,
it's driving me crazy.

194
00:09:12.670 --> 00:09:16.272
And you can go ahead and just go to your
View menu, and go ahead and unselect that.

195
00:09:16.272 --> 00:09:19.466
Now with that grid, there was one
other thing that I pointed out,

196
00:09:19.466 --> 00:09:23.380
cuz we just kind of naturally
wanna get in to pixels with this.

197
00:09:23.380 --> 00:09:26.369
If you do wanna see kind of
a pixel grid or a pixel preview,

198
00:09:26.369 --> 00:09:29.935
what you're gonna do is,
you're gonna need to zoom in really far.

199
00:09:29.935 --> 00:09:32.878
So you're gonna need to zoom in past 600%,

200
00:09:32.878 --> 00:09:36.350
and that's what's gonna show
you your pixel preview.

201
00:09:36.350 --> 00:09:40.163
Again, I think that's another thing you
can adjust in your preferences if you

202
00:09:40.163 --> 00:09:42.260
wanna see it earlier or
later in your zoom.

203
00:09:42.260 --> 00:09:46.050
But I can go here,
just using your typically zooming method.

204
00:09:46.050 --> 00:09:49.596
So I'm just gonna use a Cmd or
Ctrl+, and zoom in really far.

205
00:09:49.596 --> 00:09:53.500
Maybe I'll space over here so
you can actually start to see it.

206
00:09:53.500 --> 00:09:57.888
May not be coming up with the resolution
of my screen I think, but it is something

207
00:09:57.888 --> 00:10:02.491
that you would typically see, you would
start to pull up, past 600%, a grid.

208
00:10:02.491 --> 00:10:05.391
Apparently, I'm just not giving you
a very good example of that, but

209
00:10:05.391 --> 00:10:07.960
[LAUGH] probably something that
you are seeing on your screen.

210
00:10:07.960 --> 00:10:10.132
So, I did wanna mention that with that.

211
00:10:10.132 --> 00:10:15.420
Now, I said earlier we were going
to go back to these little guys.

212
00:10:15.420 --> 00:10:19.086
So if you watch the aligning
objects part one episode,

213
00:10:19.086 --> 00:10:21.647
I was gonna test Illustrator on this.

214
00:10:21.647 --> 00:10:26.081
So we said, okay, in our aligning objects,
using that distribute option,

215
00:10:26.081 --> 00:10:30.330
we said that we wanted this to be exactly
half an inch away from each other.

216
00:10:30.330 --> 00:10:34.133
Now, how can I actually measure
something in Illustrator and

217
00:10:34.133 --> 00:10:38.608
make sure that this is gonna be exactly
half an inch away from each other?

218
00:10:38.608 --> 00:10:43.281
Notice I used the word measure,
we're going to hop into our Measure tool,

219
00:10:43.281 --> 00:10:47.940
so our Measure tool is hidden
underneath that Eye-Dropper tool.

220
00:10:47.940 --> 00:10:50.268
So I'm gonna click and
hold on the Eye-Dropper, and

221
00:10:50.268 --> 00:10:51.571
I'm gonna grab the Measure.

222
00:10:51.571 --> 00:10:55.350
It looks like a little ruler,
which is kinda cute.

223
00:10:55.350 --> 00:10:58.301
And what I can do to measure
the distance between points,

224
00:10:58.301 --> 00:11:01.018
I'm just gonna click hold and
drag between the two.

225
00:11:01.018 --> 00:11:04.340
So something you may wanna do is hold
down your Shift key to make sure you have

226
00:11:04.340 --> 00:11:05.607
a perfectly straight line,

227
00:11:05.607 --> 00:11:08.780
cuz otherwise that can kinda
start to impact your measure.

228
00:11:08.780 --> 00:11:12.609
So I'm gonna hold down my Shift key,
click, hold, and drag.

229
00:11:12.609 --> 00:11:14.225
And what that's gonna pull up for

230
00:11:14.225 --> 00:11:16.890
me is it's automatically
gonna pull up my info panel.

231
00:11:16.890 --> 00:11:19.176
Now I've let go of my mouse, so
you don't have to keep holding.

232
00:11:19.176 --> 00:11:22.557
And what you'll see,
the width of that line was half an inch,

233
00:11:22.557 --> 00:11:25.230
which is exactly what I
told Illustrator to do.

234
00:11:25.230 --> 00:11:27.366
So unless they're lying to me twice,

235
00:11:27.366 --> 00:11:29.983
I know that this is exactly
half an inch apart.

236
00:11:29.983 --> 00:11:33.158
Again, this all will natively
pull up your Info panel so

237
00:11:33.158 --> 00:11:36.215
you can see kind of some
other information with that.

238
00:11:36.215 --> 00:11:40.567
But you can too, any time you need to see
the distance between two objects, like

239
00:11:40.567 --> 00:11:45.190
that's 5.841, but it's probably because
I just dragged my line a little too far.

240
00:11:45.190 --> 00:11:47.739
It's probably close enough,
and with that just-

241
00:11:47.739 --> 00:11:48.371
>> No.

242
00:11:48.371 --> 00:11:49.325
>> You go ahead, yeah.

243
00:11:49.325 --> 00:11:52.720
>> I raised my hand over here
because it was just a natural,

244
00:11:52.720 --> 00:11:54.246
hey, I have a question.

245
00:11:54.246 --> 00:11:57.788
Does it automatically snap
to that edge of screen?

246
00:11:57.788 --> 00:11:58.510
It doesn't, does it?

247
00:11:58.510 --> 00:11:59.158
>> No, it does not.

248
00:11:59.158 --> 00:12:02.342
Which is what the issue was that I had
with the one being slightly larger.

249
00:12:02.342 --> 00:12:03.219
I'm glad that you pointed that out, yeah.

250
00:12:03.219 --> 00:12:07.668
>> Yeah, and that's where this tool,
I've used it before but

251
00:12:07.668 --> 00:12:13.091
I can't get that pin point accuracy,
am I right on the edge of the square.

252
00:12:13.091 --> 00:12:20.809
And so I was asking if they actually did
that in this iteration of the CC product.

253
00:12:20.809 --> 00:12:21.795
They haven't done that?

254
00:12:21.795 --> 00:12:26.837
Okay, well then I'll use it, but
it's really more of, a am I close enough?

255
00:12:26.837 --> 00:12:28.184
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah.

256
00:12:28.184 --> 00:12:29.733
>> To half of an inch.

257
00:12:29.733 --> 00:12:32.635
>> Yeah, that's kind of basically,
I mean, honestly,

258
00:12:32.635 --> 00:12:35.782
I don't even really use it that often,
but if it's, okay,

259
00:12:35.782 --> 00:12:39.520
that's probably actually it and
I just drew a little bit too far.

260
00:12:39.520 --> 00:12:42.080
And I also just wanted to point out,
just for fun's sake,

261
00:12:42.080 --> 00:12:44.182
it kinda pulls up your
Navigator panel as well.

262
00:12:44.182 --> 00:12:49.010
Your Navigator panel, just natively for
me, always comes up with my Illustrator,

263
00:12:49.010 --> 00:12:50.360
my Info panel.

264
00:12:50.360 --> 00:12:53.804
And that just kinda lets you know where
everything is in your work space,

265
00:12:53.804 --> 00:12:56.582
where all of your objects are,
if you're losing things.

266
00:12:56.582 --> 00:13:00.810
>> Yeah, and this is one of those things
if you read any of the tutorial guides, or

267
00:13:00.810 --> 00:13:05.638
classroom in a book, or anything, they're
always talking about the Navigator Panel.

268
00:13:05.638 --> 00:13:09.849
There's some cute little things about it,
personally I never use this panel.

269
00:13:09.849 --> 00:13:10.878
>> [LAUGH]
>> Never.

270
00:13:10.878 --> 00:13:11.401
>> Yeah.

271
00:13:11.401 --> 00:13:14.047
>> [LAUGH]
>> I always use all of our zooms,

272
00:13:14.047 --> 00:13:16.989
all of our shortcuts and
everything like that.

273
00:13:16.989 --> 00:13:21.166
To me this is more steps
needed to get me around-

274
00:13:21.166 --> 00:13:21.778
>> Mm-hm.

275
00:13:21.778 --> 00:13:26.820
>> Than mastering all of my zooms,
and the toggles of the hand tool and

276
00:13:26.820 --> 00:13:29.894
everything like that, so it's there.

277
00:13:29.894 --> 00:13:31.014
I don't use it, I just wanted to ask you.

278
00:13:31.014 --> 00:13:31.971
>> Yeah.
>> You don't use it either?

279
00:13:31.971 --> 00:13:32.952
>> No.
>> Okay, good.

280
00:13:32.952 --> 00:13:34.973
>> [LAUGH]
>> Never, the only reason I mentioned it,

281
00:13:34.973 --> 00:13:36.747
I was sitting here and
I was like, well, it's there.

282
00:13:36.747 --> 00:13:37.269
>> Yeah, right.

283
00:13:37.269 --> 00:13:39.308
>> [LAUGH]
>> Throw it out there.

284
00:13:39.308 --> 00:13:40.290
>> You're like, what does that do?

285
00:13:40.290 --> 00:13:40.975
>> Right, right.

286
00:13:40.975 --> 00:13:41.698
>> I'll tell ya.

287
00:13:41.698 --> 00:13:44.330
>> In case anybody was pulling it up and
they saw, like me,

288
00:13:44.330 --> 00:13:46.180
it always comes up with the Info panel.

289
00:13:46.180 --> 00:13:49.149
In case you just wanted to know,
that's basically what it's there for.

290
00:13:49.149 --> 00:13:52.950
So we'll go ahead and
move on into Outline.

291
00:13:52.950 --> 00:13:59.504
So now that we know how to measure,
outline mode or viewing outlines rather.

292
00:13:59.504 --> 00:14:01.788
This is one of those things that I think,
again,

293
00:14:01.788 --> 00:14:05.190
you may not necessarily realize
the value of straight away.

294
00:14:05.190 --> 00:14:09.791
But where it comes in handy, so let's say
I'm working on a bunch of objects, or

295
00:14:09.791 --> 00:14:12.691
a couple objects that
are really close together.

296
00:14:12.691 --> 00:14:15.469
And I'm having a hard time
kind of aligning things and

297
00:14:15.469 --> 00:14:17.950
just really seeing where things start and
end.

298
00:14:17.950 --> 00:14:20.444
I know this seems like a very basic
example and you're like, Emily,

299
00:14:20.444 --> 00:14:23.328
can you really not see where those things
start and end, it's pretty obvious.

300
00:14:23.328 --> 00:14:26.694
But when you start, especially if
you're drawing something with a pen,

301
00:14:26.694 --> 00:14:29.310
you've got some more
intricate details in there.

302
00:14:29.310 --> 00:14:32.253
Sometimes it can be really hard to see,
okay, where does one path start and

303
00:14:32.253 --> 00:14:33.435
where does another path end?

304
00:14:33.435 --> 00:14:34.668
Especially you can say, okay,

305
00:14:34.668 --> 00:14:37.480
if they were the same color or
something like that, right?

306
00:14:37.480 --> 00:14:41.681
So what sometimes comes in handy for
that is viewing something in Outline mode.

307
00:14:41.681 --> 00:14:45.990
Outline mode is just gonna let you
see exactly where the paths are.

308
00:14:45.990 --> 00:14:47.921
Now, it's probably gonna
kinda freak you out at first.

309
00:14:47.921 --> 00:14:53.690
So what we're gonna do, we're gonna go to
View, and then Outline, Cmd or Ctrl+Y.

310
00:14:53.690 --> 00:14:57.342
And it's basically just gonna be,
what just happened to my Work Space?

311
00:14:57.342 --> 00:15:01.978
Everything just kind of goes
into this very basic just

312
00:15:01.978 --> 00:15:05.696
outlines of exactly where your paths are.

313
00:15:05.696 --> 00:15:07.378
>> It's like a wire mesh,
if you wanna say.

314
00:15:07.378 --> 00:15:08.103
>> Yeah.

315
00:15:08.103 --> 00:15:09.836
>> Of where everything is.

316
00:15:09.836 --> 00:15:12.925
And it's funny when you're like,
where did I go?

317
00:15:12.925 --> 00:15:15.441
And then people go and select,
cuz you can still select a square.

318
00:15:15.441 --> 00:15:16.915
>> You can still move, yeah.

319
00:15:16.915 --> 00:15:21.667
>> And then you go up and do a fill,
why is it not filling in green, or

320
00:15:21.667 --> 00:15:25.808
what have you, and
it's you're in Outline mode.

321
00:15:25.808 --> 00:15:29.127
And a lot of people get here by mistake.

322
00:15:29.127 --> 00:15:33.099
Because if you notice
the shortcut is Cmd or Ctrl+Y.

323
00:15:33.099 --> 00:15:36.657
>> Mm-hm.
>> Which is, in a Microsoft product,

324
00:15:36.657 --> 00:15:39.727
Ctrl+Z is undo, Ctrl+Y is redo.

325
00:15:39.727 --> 00:15:41.758
So if you have that-
>> Yeah,

326
00:15:41.758 --> 00:15:46.720
if you have that mapped in your head
that redo is Ctrl+Y you get into here,

327
00:15:46.720 --> 00:15:49.700
and then you Ctrl+Z and you can't get out.

328
00:15:49.700 --> 00:15:50.716
>> And then you're like, what's happening?

329
00:15:50.716 --> 00:15:54.591
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, cuz you're in a different mode,

330
00:15:54.591 --> 00:16:00.389
and then I've had people calling me
in a panic, I don't know what to do.

331
00:16:00.389 --> 00:16:02.194
And I'm, check your Outline mode,
and they're like, that?

332
00:16:02.194 --> 00:16:04.739
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so

333
00:16:04.739 --> 00:16:06.793
be a little careful of the shortcuts.

334
00:16:06.793 --> 00:16:09.889
And redo in here is the Ctrl+ Shift+Z.

335
00:16:09.889 --> 00:16:10.612
Am I right?

336
00:16:10.612 --> 00:16:11.295
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes.

337
00:16:11.295 --> 00:16:16.631
And also another handy tip that I
use all the time, Ctrl+ Shift+Z.

338
00:16:16.631 --> 00:16:19.334
Yeah, it's one of those
things that a lot of times,

339
00:16:19.334 --> 00:16:23.030
maybe not quite the frantic calls
at midnight like she's describing.

340
00:16:23.030 --> 00:16:25.824
I'll definitely have students come to me,
and be like,

341
00:16:25.824 --> 00:16:27.990
I can't select a color, what's going on?

342
00:16:27.990 --> 00:16:29.530
And it's just cuz you're in Outline mode.

343
00:16:29.530 --> 00:16:33.664
So, does come in handy, again,
just depending on the situation,

344
00:16:33.664 --> 00:16:35.411
got a lot of things going on.

345
00:16:35.411 --> 00:16:39.074
Sometimes it's helpful just to be, you
know what, I need to take a step back and

346
00:16:39.074 --> 00:16:40.287
just look at those paths.

347
00:16:40.287 --> 00:16:43.688
So certainly, I think falls
into the category of aligning.

348
00:16:43.688 --> 00:16:47.675
To kind of wrap things up here, so
we kinda had all of those align tools,

349
00:16:47.675 --> 00:16:50.346
and then I think all of the grids and
the guides.

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne add some pizazz to objects by using effects.  They discuss the difference between Photoshop and Illustrator effects in the effects menu as well as 3D effects. They also cover the appearance panel, showing how to edit, add, remove, and rearrange effects  and formatting on fills and strokes of objects
episodes.title: Working with Effects

me that effect to it.

426
00:21:06.130 --> 00:21:09.480
It's gonna be much more of
a photo realistic style thing.

427
00:21:09.480 --> 00:21:11.110
So that's kind of why I look at it.

428
00:21:11.110 --> 00:21:12.570
And there's a lot that you can do with it.

429
00:21:12.570 --> 00:21:15.962
You can change the position
here in your drop down menu,

430
00:21:15.962 --> 00:21:21.130
you kinda just change the position on your
own or even typing in some things here.

431
00:21:21.130 --> 00:21:23.100
You can adjust the extrude depth.

432
00:21:23.100 --> 00:21:26.280
So if I want that to kind of
go out a little bit farther,

433
00:21:26.280 --> 00:21:30.128
I may go back to the set,
not that front, but the off axis front.

434
00:21:30.128 --> 00:21:31.742
I'm just gonna stick with that one there.

435
00:21:31.742 --> 00:21:35.935
With the extrude depth, I can go ahead and
say, okay, I want that to be a lot fatter,

436
00:21:35.935 --> 00:21:38.020
basically, as what you're looking at.

437
00:21:38.020 --> 00:21:39.883
You can adjust the cap as well,

438
00:21:39.883 --> 00:21:44.200
that's gonna kinda make it hollow
is an option that you have.

439
00:21:44.200 --> 00:21:48.120
So there's all kinds of just again,
just playing around with it.

440
00:21:48.120 --> 00:21:50.302
It's not even necessarily me
sitting here and telling you,

441
00:21:50.302 --> 00:21:51.600
okay this is exactly what you need.

442
00:21:51.600 --> 00:21:55.580
But just looking and saying, okay, these
are the options that I get with my bevel.

443
00:21:55.580 --> 00:21:57.490
Look how you can change that.

444
00:21:57.490 --> 00:21:59.690
That is something that you can impact.

445
00:21:59.690 --> 00:22:02.207
Like woah, that jaggedy,
it looks like an accordion, right?

446
00:22:02.207 --> 00:22:03.950
You can do that.

447
00:22:03.950 --> 00:22:06.130
So you can also adjust the surface,
things like that.

448
00:22:06.130 --> 00:22:10.423
Now one thing I want to point out here
that you may not necessarily have

449
00:22:10.423 --> 00:22:12.570
noticed is that Map Art option.

450
00:22:12.570 --> 00:22:16.546
So if I click on Map Art, what that's
gonna do, okay, you're gonna see, okay,

451
00:22:16.546 --> 00:22:17.597
no difference here.

452
00:22:17.597 --> 00:22:20.849
See where it says symbol at the top?

453
00:22:20.849 --> 00:22:22.565
Right now, it's set at none.

454
00:22:22.565 --> 00:22:28.453
Now, symbols are gonna be something we
discuss in a totally different episode but

455
00:22:28.453 --> 00:22:32.462
basically this is gonna be
some artwork that we can apply

456
00:22:32.462 --> 00:22:35.210
specifically on to this object here.

457
00:22:35.210 --> 00:22:38.901
So I can just pick one from the drop-down
menu, it has to be a symbol,

458
00:22:38.901 --> 00:22:42.540
will talk about how to create
symbols in the different episode.

459
00:22:42.540 --> 00:22:47.662
But this are kinda the defaults here,
and what you can do is you can say, okay

460
00:22:47.662 --> 00:22:53.289
I want that to go ahead and apply to this
specific surface, in this specific place.

461
00:22:53.289 --> 00:22:54.670
And you can see what it does.

462
00:22:54.670 --> 00:22:55.508
It kind of gives it that perspective.

463
00:22:55.508 --> 00:23:00.158
If I try to take this symbol or try to
take some art without being in this and

464
00:23:00.158 --> 00:23:05.111
try to place it on there, it wouldn't
give it that kind of sidewayness to it,

465
00:23:05.111 --> 00:23:06.510
that perspective.

466
00:23:06.510 --> 00:23:08.081
It would try and just be flat and

467
00:23:08.081 --> 00:23:11.111
it wouldn't appear as if it
was actually on our 3D effect.

468
00:23:11.111 --> 00:23:13.720
Now, you can also change the surface.

469
00:23:13.720 --> 00:23:17.610
So you don't have to just use this one
in particular front facing surface.

470
00:23:17.610 --> 00:23:20.550
You see how that red
outline is there around it?

471
00:23:20.550 --> 00:23:22.385
That's letting us know which
surface we have chosen.

472
00:23:22.385 --> 00:23:23.900
But I can filter it through.

473
00:23:23.900 --> 00:23:25.275
>> Yeah, and
there's this 42 of them right now.

474
00:23:25.275 --> 00:23:26.081
>> Yeah, yeah.

475
00:23:26.081 --> 00:23:28.100
>> Like why is there 42?

476
00:23:28.100 --> 00:23:30.343
Well that's because of the-
>> The jagged.

477
00:23:30.343 --> 00:23:34.568
>> The jaggedness that you had and
so if we click either OK, or Cancel,

478
00:23:34.568 --> 00:23:35.690
change that-
>> We'll do another one.

479
00:23:35.690 --> 00:23:37.037
>> Yeah, go back.

480
00:23:37.037 --> 00:23:41.375
That makes it a little easier cuz now
there's only six, cuz if you think about

481
00:23:41.375 --> 00:23:43.111
an actual cube or like a dice-
>> Yeah!

482
00:23:43.111 --> 00:23:45.056
>> There's six sides of a dice.

483
00:23:45.056 --> 00:23:49.677
And so if I wanted to map artwork
on different sides of that dice or

484
00:23:49.677 --> 00:23:54.469
cube, you just have to kind of cycle
through and watching those red

485
00:23:54.469 --> 00:23:59.433
lines that are kind of highlighting
which side of this particular 3D

486
00:23:59.433 --> 00:24:04.506
cube that we have That's gonna make
a difference of cycling through.

487
00:24:04.506 --> 00:24:05.517
>> Uh-hum/
>> Yeah.

488
00:24:05.517 --> 00:24:09.862
And if you want to go ahead and map all
42 sides of that jagged bevel thing.

489
00:24:09.862 --> 00:24:10.589
>> You got it.
>> That's fine.

490
00:24:10.589 --> 00:24:13.725
But showing it on
a regular cube-like face,

491
00:24:13.725 --> 00:24:18.980
I think makes it a little bit easier and
like I said it is a symbol.

492
00:24:18.980 --> 00:24:20.950
But it's, I love this.

493
00:24:20.950 --> 00:24:24.170
I always love to show the 3D in bevel and
the map artwork.

494
00:24:24.170 --> 00:24:28.266
This is one of those, like ooh, how many
times have you used this in real life?

495
00:24:28.266 --> 00:24:29.528
>> Yeah.
>> Besides just having fun?

496
00:24:29.528 --> 00:24:33.170
Yeah, it depends.

497
00:24:33.170 --> 00:24:37.980
But I mean if you think, okay, think about
if you were having to do a product design

498
00:24:37.980 --> 00:24:42.120
of this is what the box of cereal is
gonna look like with your logo on it.

499
00:24:42.120 --> 00:24:44.271
>> Right.
>> Just to give that appearance of that

500
00:24:44.271 --> 00:24:45.961
type of marketing collateral.

501
00:24:45.961 --> 00:24:46.486
>> Right.

502
00:24:46.486 --> 00:24:47.747
>> I just came up with
that in my head right now.

503
00:24:47.747 --> 00:24:49.162
[LAUGH]
>> That's a genius example.

504
00:24:49.162 --> 00:24:51.573
Yeah, I was thinking like a bar graph,
like sometimes,

505
00:24:51.573 --> 00:24:54.800
which you have a graph tool and
it'll show your, but you know, whatever.

506
00:24:54.800 --> 00:24:55.302
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

507
00:24:55.302 --> 00:24:57.395
[LAUGH] >> I just thought of that and
I'm like, yeah,

508
00:24:57.395 --> 00:24:59.190
cuz if you're doing a style guide or like.

509
00:24:59.190 --> 00:24:59.729
>> Uh-hum.
>> This

510
00:24:59.729 --> 00:25:02.868
is what your logo will look in
all these different things.

511
00:25:02.868 --> 00:25:06.476
>> Yeah.
>> This could be one that could be kind of

512
00:25:06.476 --> 00:25:07.540
cool to do.

513
00:25:07.540 --> 00:25:08.190
>> I'm so impressed.

514
00:25:08.190 --> 00:25:09.095
>> Well thank you.

515
00:25:09.095 --> 00:25:10.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'll pat myself on the back on

516
00:25:10.480 --> 00:25:11.261
that one [LAUGH]
>> No.

517
00:25:11.261 --> 00:25:12.987
>> I think that's a great example.

518
00:25:12.987 --> 00:25:16.005
And again I kinda hate to keep saying
this, but just kinda play around a bit,

519
00:25:16.005 --> 00:25:16.720
see what you get.

520
00:25:16.720 --> 00:25:20.680
See what different kind of styles
are really working for you.

521
00:25:20.680 --> 00:25:22.330
>> Yeah, and
right here in this particular scheme,

522
00:25:22.330 --> 00:25:28.250
once you're done mapping the artwork,
then you can go back and change the key.

523
00:25:28.250 --> 00:25:31.250
I was like, she'll catch it.

524
00:25:31.250 --> 00:25:33.630
>> [LAUGH] I didn't even
necessarily mean to.

525
00:25:33.630 --> 00:25:34.155
But yes.

526
00:25:34.155 --> 00:25:36.868
[LAUGH]
>> And you can move the cube around and

527
00:25:36.868 --> 00:25:40.589
like change the face of like which one
you want to do in that kind of like

528
00:25:40.589 --> 00:25:41.900
rotatory thing.

529
00:25:41.900 --> 00:25:44.140
That's right in there, yeah that guide.

530
00:25:44.140 --> 00:25:45.460
>> So the rotator?

531
00:25:45.460 --> 00:25:47.781
>> The rotator guide, yeah [LAUGH].

532
00:25:47.781 --> 00:25:50.970
And if you have specific measurements,
you can go ahead and type in.

533
00:25:50.970 --> 00:25:52.919
I was just to kind of drag it around.

534
00:25:52.919 --> 00:25:55.590
>> Yeah, well because you can, right?

535
00:25:55.590 --> 00:25:56.480
It's just fun.

536
00:25:56.480 --> 00:25:58.635
>> It is [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So you definitely,

537
00:25:58.635 --> 00:26:02.220
you have all kinds of different
options that you can do.

538
00:26:02.220 --> 00:26:05.480
And again, without to sound
like I'm beating a dead horse.

539
00:26:05.480 --> 00:26:07.400
Just kinda keep playing around
until you see what you got.

540
00:26:07.400 --> 00:26:12.230
But I think that should be a great way
to kinda get introduced to effects and

541
00:26:12.230 --> 00:26:13.130
get excited about it.

542
00:26:13.130 --> 00:26:13.700
>> Yeah.

543
00:26:13.700 --> 00:26:16.690
And like you said, we're not gonna
go through every single one of them.

544
00:26:16.690 --> 00:26:19.578
And in those Photoshop effects,
you bring up that screen,

545
00:26:19.578 --> 00:26:22.890
there's all those little like slider
you got all over to the right.

546
00:26:22.890 --> 00:26:26.646
>> Where you can kinda control how much
colored pencil and how much glowing edges,

547
00:26:26.646 --> 00:26:27.945
it's my favorite to show.

548
00:26:27.945 --> 00:26:28.550
>> Yeah.

549
00:26:28.550 --> 00:26:31.617
>> And then you can go ahead and
mess with that but

550
00:26:31.617 --> 00:26:35.250
just to make sure you remember
the appearance panel,

551
00:26:35.250 --> 00:26:40.590
the importance of it, and being able
to go back there to edit the effects.

552
00:26:40.590 --> 00:26:44.220
Change that stacking order,
add effects to different parts of it.

553
00:26:44.220 --> 00:26:46.350
The more you use Illustrator,

554
00:26:46.350 --> 00:26:50.440
the more you're gonna probably stay
in that appearance panel a lot.

555
00:26:50.440 --> 00:26:53.220
Just kinda have it over to the side,
just seeing what's going on.

556
00:26:53.220 --> 00:26:55.031
>> Yeah.
>> So, lot's of fun stuff.

557
00:26:55.031 --> 00:26:58.673
Lots of new tools for you guys to
go ahead and play around with and

558
00:26:58.673 --> 00:27:01.170
spend hours [LAUGH] just tinkering around.

559
00:27:01.170 --> 00:27:04.866
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up, we're gonna sign off for

560
00:27:04.866 --> 00:27:07.230
Creative Pro TV I've been your host,
Vonne Smith

561
00:27:07.230 --> 00:27:08.000
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey

562
00:27:08.000 --> 00:27:09.444
>> And we'll see you soon.

563
00:27:09.444 --> 00:27:14.635
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to work with the graphic styles panel.  They demonstrate how to find styles in the libraries, break link to style to create custom styles, and create your own graphic style.
episodes.title: Graphic Styles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:06.686
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.686 --> 00:00:11.291
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.291 --> 00:00:14.889
Hello, welcome back to another
exciting edition of CREATIVE Pro.TV.

4
00:00:14.889 --> 00:00:19.556
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and
this is Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:19.556 --> 00:00:23.041
And we are going to be working with
graphics styles in this episode.

6
00:00:23.041 --> 00:00:25.800
I love graphic styles.

7
00:00:25.800 --> 00:00:28.676
There's actually not much in
Illustrator that I don't love.

8
00:00:28.676 --> 00:00:29.776
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

9
00:00:29.776 --> 00:00:30.780
>> And I love

10
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:33.460
that Emily Ramsey is back yet
again to help us.

11
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:34.004
>> Hello.

12
00:00:34.004 --> 00:00:34.815
>> Yay.

13
00:00:34.815 --> 00:00:36.316
>> I know, Vonne's so excited,
she can't contain herself.

14
00:00:36.316 --> 00:00:39.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> All about the graphic styles, and

15
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:40.343
really I can understand why.

16
00:00:40.343 --> 00:00:45.590
I mean they are just not only cool but
also just kind of useful,

17
00:00:45.590 --> 00:00:48.640
so that kind of a nice thing to
about is if you do it right,

18
00:00:48.640 --> 00:00:51.490
which we were kindly joking before,
I often don't.

19
00:00:51.490 --> 00:00:53.050
Not on purpose but, just you know,

20
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:56.015
I kind of forget that I have it
available to me when I'm working.

21
00:00:56.015 --> 00:01:02.140
But it really can, again, make your life
much easier if you are doing it properly.

22
00:01:02.140 --> 00:01:03.820
Aside from just the fun aspect of it.

23
00:01:03.820 --> 00:01:07.250
So what we're gonna do, I'm gonna go ahead
and hop into my Illustrator art board, and

24
00:01:07.250 --> 00:01:09.720
you'll see I just have
a blank black square.

25
00:01:09.720 --> 00:01:11.970
So kinda drab, right.

26
00:01:11.970 --> 00:01:14.360
And then I also have my
graphic styles panel open.

27
00:01:14.360 --> 00:01:16.460
So of course if you don't have
your graphic styles panel open,

28
00:01:16.460 --> 00:01:20.060
go to Window, go to Graphic Styles,
and go ahead and grab that down.

29
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:23.240
So what are graphic styles do?

30
00:01:23.240 --> 00:01:27.480
They are a set of reusable
appearance attributes.

31
00:01:27.480 --> 00:01:33.470
So you can basically take any shape and
then copy the appearance of something,

32
00:01:33.470 --> 00:01:35.050
kind of like going back
to our appearance panel.

33
00:01:35.050 --> 00:01:36.720
We're going to hop back in there.

34
00:01:36.720 --> 00:01:40.120
You can copy those appearance
attributes over onto another shape.

35
00:01:40.120 --> 00:01:43.690
So if you say, you get something you
really like or, we're gonna start with

36
00:01:43.690 --> 00:01:47.320
kinda the preexisting ones,
the library of graphic styles.

37
00:01:47.320 --> 00:01:49.211
Say if I like that effect
I can go ahead and

38
00:01:49.211 --> 00:01:51.336
just apply it to multiple
different shapes.

39
00:01:51.336 --> 00:01:52.774
So really kind of nice for that.

40
00:01:52.774 --> 00:01:55.150
So I'm gonna go and
pull up my graphic styles.

41
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:58.570
I'm gonna start with the,
I won't say the boring ones, but

42
00:01:58.570 --> 00:02:01.120
I'm gonna start with all
the white ones here.

43
00:02:01.120 --> 00:02:03.080
What we have here,
we have that first option.

44
00:02:03.080 --> 00:02:06.080
That's just gonna be our
default style in Illustrator.

45
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:08.530
If for some reason you wanna go
back to that, that white fill and

46
00:02:08.530 --> 00:02:11.950
that black stroke with the one point,
that's gonna be our default style.

47
00:02:11.950 --> 00:02:15.790
Now I'm gonna Cmd or Ctrl+Z just so
we can get to that black square.

48
00:02:15.790 --> 00:02:20.400
Now these ones with the Alt,
I gave away my trick,

49
00:02:20.400 --> 00:02:25.260
with the red slash through it in the
bottom left hand corner of the preview.

50
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:29.040
That's letting you know that that's
something that only, it does not apply

51
00:02:29.040 --> 00:02:32.330
a fill or a stroke to something, it only
does something kind of outside of it.

52
00:02:32.330 --> 00:02:36.290
So what I need to do, basically,
this one's an example of a drop shadow,

53
00:02:36.290 --> 00:02:39.300
I need to Alt or Option click on it.

54
00:02:40.750 --> 00:02:44.148
And then you can see from there it's gonna
go ahead and apply just a drop shadow.

55
00:02:44.148 --> 00:02:46.745
And even maybe I'll go back here and
I'll change that to blue or

56
00:02:46.745 --> 00:02:49.350
something like that so
you can maybe see it a little bit better.

57
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:50.105
It's pretty subtle.

58
00:02:50.105 --> 00:02:51.797
[CROSSTALK]
>> Okay, yeah, cuz I'm like,

59
00:02:51.797 --> 00:02:52.674
what did it do?

60
00:02:52.674 --> 00:02:56.569
It's a very, very small drop
shadow that's being applied there.

61
00:02:56.569 --> 00:02:59.565
>> Exactly, but what we can do,
we can go to our appearance panel.

62
00:02:59.565 --> 00:03:02.629
>> Mm-hm.
>> So I'm gonna go Window Appearance and

63
00:03:02.629 --> 00:03:06.867
you can see, okay yes,
I do indeed have a drop shadow there.

64
00:03:06.867 --> 00:03:11.071
>> Okay, and that, just to clarify, the
Alt that you did, that was where if you

65
00:03:11.071 --> 00:03:14.649
had not held your Alt key down it
would take out the fill in stroke.

66
00:03:14.649 --> 00:03:16.060
Is that correct?

67
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:18.280
>> I believe just yeah,
nothing happens, or

68
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:20.870
basically it just removes all
the formatting that you have there, yeah.

69
00:03:20.870 --> 00:03:25.680
>> Okay, and the Alt was like, okay, I
only want you to apply just whatever's in

70
00:03:25.680 --> 00:03:30.350
the effect, which would be the drop
shadow, and keep my fill and or stroke or

71
00:03:30.350 --> 00:03:32.750
whatever else I have on it.

72
00:03:32.750 --> 00:03:33.612
>> Right, thank you for
the clarification, yes.

73
00:03:33.612 --> 00:03:38.457
>> And I'm not sure if I knew that,
so that's why I was like, okay.

74
00:03:38.457 --> 00:03:41.395
There was just another light
bulb that came off of like,

75
00:03:41.395 --> 00:03:43.092
I don't think I've done that.

76
00:03:43.092 --> 00:03:44.188
So thank you [LAUGH].

77
00:03:44.188 --> 00:03:45.706
>> Pat on the back again.

78
00:03:45.706 --> 00:03:47.200
No, I'm just kidding.

79
00:03:47.200 --> 00:03:49.240
All right, so what we can do here,
you can kinda go through them.

80
00:03:49.240 --> 00:03:52.630
You can see this one,
it kinda looks like that first one we did.

81
00:03:52.630 --> 00:03:56.460
But what's actually happening is it's
rounding the corners a little bit.

82
00:03:56.460 --> 00:04:00.750
So you can see just, again,
a very subtle corner round on that one.

83
00:04:00.750 --> 00:04:02.110
So I'm gonna go ahead and go back.

84
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:03.700
We'll just kinda keep filtering through.

85
00:04:03.700 --> 00:04:06.390
Maybe I'll Command+Z or
whatever a couple of times.

86
00:04:06.390 --> 00:04:10.460
And then we'll end with this,
one of the less exciting options.

87
00:04:10.460 --> 00:04:13.920
And then we'll go ahead and Alt click
again, cuz I see that red slash and

88
00:04:13.920 --> 00:04:17.470
basically what this is gonna do
is it's gonna mirror for us.
