00:15:12.600 --> 00:15:16.485
or Alt or Option key held down,
replace that graphic style in which you're

315
00:15:16.485 --> 00:15:21.375
gonna see is it's not gonna change
that specific, I cannot say that word,

316
00:15:21.375 --> 00:15:25.115
specific one because I have
broken that link there.

317
00:15:25.115 --> 00:15:26.905
So that's something else that
I would suggest that you pay

318
00:15:26.905 --> 00:15:28.655
attention to with your
graphic styles as well.

319
00:15:30.040 --> 00:15:35.210
Wow, [LAUGH] I can feel the,
i'ts coming back to me to say something.

320
00:15:35.210 --> 00:15:38.620
I'm just like amazed and

321
00:15:38.620 --> 00:15:42.585
I really am speechless of all the things
I thought I knew about this and I didn't.

322
00:15:42.585 --> 00:15:44.090
[LAUGH]
>> Please.

323
00:15:44.090 --> 00:15:47.726
And the funny thing is, again, we were
kinda joking at the beginning like graphic

324
00:15:47.726 --> 00:15:51.840
styles I think are something you use
all the time, something that I teach.

325
00:15:51.840 --> 00:15:54.430
But professionally forget to use and

326
00:15:54.430 --> 00:15:57.490
realize just how much of
a time saver this would be.

327
00:15:57.490 --> 00:15:59.750
If there's something you mentioned,
as simple as a drop shadow,

328
00:15:59.750 --> 00:16:02.850
that I just know that I'm going to
want to apply to different shapes,

329
00:16:02.850 --> 00:16:06.310
I can just create it once and
then apply it to other different things.

330
00:16:06.310 --> 00:16:08.520
So it can save you so much time.

331
00:16:08.520 --> 00:16:09.780
And it's just kind of fun.

332
00:16:09.780 --> 00:16:12.330
>> Wow, yeah, and
I guess one more thing I can add.

333
00:16:12.330 --> 00:16:12.840
>> Yes.

334
00:16:12.840 --> 00:16:14.880
>> Now I'm like questioning,
do I know this for real?

335
00:16:14.880 --> 00:16:15.400
>> Please.
[LAUGH]

336
00:16:15.400 --> 00:16:18.280
>> That styles are file specific, right.

337
00:16:18.280 --> 00:16:19.853
>> Yes.
>> So if I went ahead and

338
00:16:19.853 --> 00:16:24.667
did all this fancy stuff and then open
up a new file or created a new file,

339
00:16:24.667 --> 00:16:29.020
then my graphic styles panel is
going right back to the default.

340
00:16:29.020 --> 00:16:29.719
>> Right.

341
00:16:29.719 --> 00:16:33.731
>> And then it's like well we'll
show you how you can save them.

342
00:16:33.731 --> 00:16:37.280
This is actually I think the same for
brushes.

343
00:16:37.280 --> 00:16:37.890
>> Right.

344
00:16:37.890 --> 00:16:38.530
Swatches.

345
00:16:38.530 --> 00:16:41.970
>> Swatches, styles,
and symbols I believe.

346
00:16:41.970 --> 00:16:42.630
>> Yes.

347
00:16:42.630 --> 00:16:44.590
>> But once we show you how to share one,

348
00:16:44.590 --> 00:16:46.830
I think we're gonna do share
swatches eventually, right?

349
00:16:46.830 --> 00:16:47.550
>> Yes.

350
00:16:47.550 --> 00:16:48.780
In that-
>> CC libraries.

351
00:16:48.780 --> 00:16:49.780
>> Yeah, yeah.

352
00:16:49.780 --> 00:16:54.250
When we do that, just know that you
can apply that same thought process,

353
00:16:54.250 --> 00:16:57.370
if you want to say, or
technique of sharing out swatches.

354
00:16:57.370 --> 00:17:01.590
You can share out the brushes, and the
styles, and the symbols the same way and

355
00:17:01.590 --> 00:17:05.060
be able to kind of load them
up into your other new files.

356
00:17:05.060 --> 00:17:08.775
So if you're getting super happy
about all this and want to move on,

357
00:17:08.775 --> 00:17:10.090
just keep that in mind.

358
00:17:11.390 --> 00:17:12.910
Good, I added something.

359
00:17:12.910 --> 00:17:14.845
>> No.
>> I know about styles in this episode

360
00:17:14.845 --> 00:17:18.194
because you've taught me so
much that I could go ahead and apply, and

361
00:17:18.194 --> 00:17:20.178
I'm definitely going to be doing that.

362
00:17:20.178 --> 00:17:21.091
So thank you.

363
00:17:21.091 --> 00:17:21.763
Cool.

364
00:17:21.763 --> 00:17:23.288
>> Can't thank you enough.

365
00:17:23.288 --> 00:17:25.378
>> [LAUGH]
>> Thank you guys for tuning in.

366
00:17:25.378 --> 00:17:27.742
I hope you guys are gonna go have
fun with your styles as well.

367
00:17:27.742 --> 00:17:32.382
But for now, signing off for CREATIVE
Pro.TV, I've been your host Vonne Smith.

368
00:17:32.382 --> 00:17:33.122
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

369
00:17:33.122 --> 00:17:34.423
>> And we will see you soon.

370
00:17:34.423 --> 00:17:40.199
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to work with clipping masks and opacity masks in Illustrator to create different effects on objects.
episodes.title: Working with Masks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:07.427
[NOISE]

2
00:00:07.427 --> 00:00:11.044
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.044 --> 00:00:15.370
Hello, welcome back to another
exciting edition of Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:15.370 --> 00:00:19.740
I'm your host Vonne Smith and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017,

5
00:00:19.740 --> 00:00:23.570
and we're gonna be
talking all about masks.

6
00:00:23.570 --> 00:00:24.900
Ooh, it feels very Heidi-like.

7
00:00:24.900 --> 00:00:25.905
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

8
00:00:25.905 --> 00:00:28.815
>> [LAUGH] Heidi-like,
is that what we're gonna do?

9
00:00:28.815 --> 00:00:32.910
[LAUGH] Yeah, well here to help us is Miss
Emily Ramsey talk about our Heidi-ness.

10
00:00:32.910 --> 00:00:33.865
>> Yes, our Heidi-ness.

11
00:00:33.865 --> 00:00:34.477
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sure [LAUGH].

12
00:00:34.477 --> 00:00:35.986
>> I don't know.

13
00:00:35.986 --> 00:00:38.253
>> I can see where you're going with that.

14
00:00:38.253 --> 00:00:39.631
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's like Phantom of the Opera.

15
00:00:39.631 --> 00:00:40.239
>> Yes.

16
00:00:40.239 --> 00:00:41.094
>> Sure that sounds very dramatic.

17
00:00:41.094 --> 00:00:43.043
>> I wanna start singing,
but I'd better not.

18
00:00:43.043 --> 00:00:44.183
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

19
00:00:44.183 --> 00:00:44.683
>> Okay, stop.

20
00:00:44.683 --> 00:00:45.494
[LAUGH]

21
00:00:45.494 --> 00:00:47.130
>> Yeah, maybe not.

22
00:00:47.130 --> 00:00:51.720
So what we're gonna get into, we are going
to be talking about working with masks.

23
00:00:51.720 --> 00:00:53.772
It sounds so mysterious.

24
00:00:53.772 --> 00:00:57.452
We're gonna kind of use a couple of
different examples of how these can apply

25
00:00:57.452 --> 00:00:59.131
and why you would want to use them.

26
00:00:59.131 --> 00:01:03.751
But I think is gonna best work when we're
talking about our opacity masks, and

27
00:01:03.751 --> 00:01:07.750
our clipping masks, is if we start
out with the concept of an image.

28
00:01:07.750 --> 00:01:11.774
So we're gonna go ahead and
grab here, my cat is back.

29
00:01:11.774 --> 00:01:15.340
And we are going to start
off with our clipping mask.

30
00:01:15.340 --> 00:01:17.990
So clipping masks are kinda cool.

31
00:01:17.990 --> 00:01:20.550
It's kind of funny,
they basically back in the day,

32
00:01:20.550 --> 00:01:24.550
before cropping existed which
only happened pretty recently.

33
00:01:24.550 --> 00:01:27.820
They were basically your way of
cropping an image in Illustrator.

34
00:01:27.820 --> 00:01:30.010
So what we can do here through,

35
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:33.300
since we no longer need to crop
an image using an clipping mask.

36
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:37.270
I can say okay, I've got that crop option,
it's not obsolete.

37
00:01:37.270 --> 00:01:39.760
But we are just gonna use it
in a slightly different way.

38
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:41.400
So I am gonna take my image.

39
00:01:41.400 --> 00:01:44.450
Now, this does not have
to be done on an image.

40
00:01:44.450 --> 00:01:47.370
You can apply it to vectors and we'll
kind of show you some examples of that.

41
00:01:47.370 --> 00:01:49.357
I am just using the example
of an image here.

42
00:01:49.357 --> 00:01:52.267
What if I wanted to make
this image a circle?

43
00:01:52.267 --> 00:01:55.493
I can crop something, but
i can't crop an image into a circle.

44
00:01:55.493 --> 00:01:56.940
So what I am gonna do?

45
00:01:56.940 --> 00:01:59.014
I am gonna go ahead and
grab my ellipse tool.

46
00:02:00.320 --> 00:02:03.790
And then I'm just gonna drag it
right over my little guy's face.

47
00:02:03.790 --> 00:02:07.950
I'm gonna take that gradient away,
that'll come into play in a minute.

48
00:02:07.950 --> 00:02:09.490
But what I'm gonna do,
I'm just gonna say, okay,

49
00:02:09.490 --> 00:02:12.520
I want that to be kind
of right about there.

50
00:02:12.520 --> 00:02:15.883
Poor little guy's little belly is sticking
out, I'm just cutting the fat here.

51
00:02:15.883 --> 00:02:21.959
[LAUGH] So what we're gonna say now,
now I have a vector on top of a raster.

52
00:02:21.959 --> 00:02:25.709
The only key part of that Is that
only the vector can actually

53
00:02:25.709 --> 00:02:27.290
create a clipping mask.

54
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:29.540
So I could not flip this
is what I'm saying.

55
00:02:29.540 --> 00:02:32.250
I couldn't have a circle
with a picture on top of it.

56
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:35.080
And then to create our clipping mask,
what I'm gonna do I'm gonna select

57
00:02:35.080 --> 00:02:38.020
both of those objects,
however you wanna select both of them.

58
00:02:38.020 --> 00:02:39.889
And then it's actually
just a right-click option.

59
00:02:39.889 --> 00:02:42.530
So I'm gonna right-click and
then Make Clipping Mask.

60
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:45.930
I think this one's also available
under your Object menu.

61
00:02:45.930 --> 00:02:49.800
Somewhere down there you have
Object > Clipping Mask > Make.

62
00:02:49.800 --> 00:02:53.540
So we can go ahead and choose that,
whatever method you want to use.

63
00:02:53.540 --> 00:02:57.540
Make Clipping Mask and now it's gonna
convert my image into a circle.

64
00:02:57.540 --> 00:03:01.646
So basically whatever's
underneath the topmost vector,

65
00:03:01.646 --> 00:03:03.786
in my case I had a circle on top.

66
00:03:03.786 --> 00:03:08.051
Anything that's underneath it is gonna
take the shape of that object that

67
00:03:08.051 --> 00:03:08.757
was on top.

68
00:03:08.757 --> 00:03:11.846
And again that object on
top can only be a vector.

69
00:03:11.846 --> 00:03:15.471
But you can have multiple things
underneath it and fun stuff.

70
00:03:15.471 --> 00:03:17.418
>> Yeah and
I like the idea of a mask right?

71
00:03:17.418 --> 00:03:21.212
When you put a mask on your face,
whatever,

72
00:03:21.212 --> 00:03:24.402
the circular cut outs for your eyes.

73
00:03:24.402 --> 00:03:29.990
Your eyes show through that area,
and it hides everything else.

74
00:03:29.990 --> 00:03:35.410
So it's not that we've removed any
of the information of Mr. Ollie.

75
00:03:35.410 --> 00:03:37.018
It's just that we're hiding it.

76
00:03:37.018 --> 00:03:39.639
This is the area that's
going to show through.

77
00:03:39.639 --> 00:03:42.548
Everything else is going to be hidden, so

78
00:03:42.548 --> 00:03:47.545
that show-hide aspect of a mask is,
well, the whole concept of mask.

79
00:03:47.545 --> 00:03:49.443
>> Right, right, and
I think that's a great point.

80
00:03:49.443 --> 00:03:51.558
That's why it's referred to as a mask and
you can even see it.

81
00:03:51.558 --> 00:03:54.322
If I hover over this, you still
see the dimensions of that image.

82
00:03:54.322 --> 00:03:56.435
So we have not taken the image away.

83
00:03:56.435 --> 00:03:58.465
In fact, I can go ahead and
kind of edit this.

84
00:03:58.465 --> 00:04:01.797
So if I wanna double-click,
go into Isolation mode, and I'm like,

85
00:04:01.797 --> 00:04:04.402
you know what,
I don't want to see exactly that part.

86
00:04:04.402 --> 00:04:07.735
Maybe I wanna move them
slightly over here,

87
00:04:07.735 --> 00:04:12.360
I can even not only edit
what's being masked, my image.

88
00:04:12.360 --> 00:04:13.980
I can actually edit the mask itself.

89
00:04:13.980 --> 00:04:17.017
So just depending on what you click,
if I wanna select that mask,

90
00:04:17.017 --> 00:04:18.794
I can make that smaller for instance.

91
00:04:18.794 --> 00:04:22.730
So if I wanna make it a smaller circle,
that is an option that I have.

92
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:25.896
Now, let's say I am gonna double-click
to get out of isolation mode, so

93
00:04:25.896 --> 00:04:27.490
just double-click off to the side.

94
00:04:27.490 --> 00:04:32.163
Now let's say I'm working on this, and
I really just don't want the mask anymore.

95
00:04:32.163 --> 00:04:35.900
I kinda wanna get rid of it,
I wanna see the whole cat, okay?

96
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:38.070
So what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna right-click, and

97
00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:41.390
just in the same way that you can make
a clipping mask, you can release it.

98
00:04:41.390 --> 00:04:46.520
Just as Vonne was saying, it has not gone
away, it's just being hidden right now.

99
00:04:46.520 --> 00:04:49.100
So if I could choose that release
clipping mask, what you're gonna see,

100
00:04:49.100 --> 00:04:51.360
I still have that circle on top.

101
00:04:51.360 --> 00:04:54.696
Basically, anything that you
had on top to create your mask,

102
00:04:54.696 --> 00:04:57.337
it's gonna convert to no fill,
and no strokes.

103
00:04:57.337 --> 00:04:59.351
So do you wanna use that later?

104
00:04:59.351 --> 00:05:02.996
You can, if I want to go ahead and say,
okay, I'm gonna put that over here, or

105
00:05:02.996 --> 00:05:05.780
if you just wanted to get rid of it,
that's also an option.

106
00:05:05.780 --> 00:05:10.058
Now, just to show you,
you can use this for other vectors, or

107
00:05:10.058 --> 00:05:12.792
again, multiple different objects.

108
00:05:12.792 --> 00:05:17.534
So typically, if I have something going
on, maybe there's like a lot going on in

109
00:05:17.534 --> 00:05:21.180
my artboard and I just kinda wanna
trim things up a little bit.

110
00:05:21.180 --> 00:05:25.350
Sometimes I'll have like images hanging
off to the side, or maybe I'll create,

111
00:05:25.350 --> 00:05:29.110
I'll use the example of a star.

112
00:05:29.110 --> 00:05:33.930
Maybe I have a star, but I want it to only
appear on my artboard as if just that one

113
00:05:33.930 --> 00:05:38.500
little portion, or a circle,
or something like this.

114
00:05:38.500 --> 00:05:41.510
So I have all these things
kinda hanging off my artboard.

115
00:05:41.510 --> 00:05:44.590
Sometimes what I'll do when I'm
kinda finalizing my file, just so

116
00:05:44.590 --> 00:05:46.871
I can give myself an idea
of what it will look like.

117
00:05:46.871 --> 00:05:48.991
I'll just create a clipping
mask over the entire thing.

118
00:05:48.991 --> 00:05:51.690
So I can go here, grab my Rectangle tool.

119
00:05:51.690 --> 00:05:56.500
I'm gonna drag and drop that so
that it's about the size of my artboard.

120
00:05:56.500 --> 00:05:58.720
I'm not worrying about
perfection right here.

121
00:05:58.720 --> 00:06:00.260
And I'm just gonna
Make Clipping Mask again.

122
00:06:00.260 --> 00:06:04.910
So I'm gonna select all these objects,
right-click, Make Clipping Mask.

123
00:06:04.910 --> 00:06:06.185
And then now I can say, okay,

124
00:06:06.185 --> 00:06:09.513
that's gonna give me more of an idea of
what this is actually gonna look like.

125
00:06:09.513 --> 00:06:12.580
When I go and save my file as a PDF,
or whatever output I need.

126
00:06:12.580 --> 00:06:15.507
And I can say you know what,
I don't really like that star.

127
00:06:15.507 --> 00:06:19.565
I'm gonna double-click, Edit, maybe I,
oops, didn't mean to do that like that.

128
00:06:19.565 --> 00:06:22.326
I meant to rotate,
maybe I wanna do something like that.

129
00:06:22.326 --> 00:06:25.419
And I can go ahead and say okay,
that looks a little bit better.

130
00:06:25.419 --> 00:06:26.637
And it gives me again,

131
00:06:26.637 --> 00:06:30.621
just an idea of what's something's
gonna look like in the final output.

132
00:06:30.621 --> 00:06:34.047
>> Yeah, I'm over here just
smiling away because I'm like,

133
00:06:34.047 --> 00:06:36.738
yeah this is the example
I show a lot of people.

134
00:06:36.738 --> 00:06:37.306
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

135
00:06:37.306 --> 00:06:38.370
[LAUGH]
>> And

136
00:06:38.370 --> 00:06:43.232
one step further that I do on this method,
just to avoid having

137
00:06:43.232 --> 00:06:47.930
to go into isolation mode is
I'll make in its own layer too.

138
00:06:47.930 --> 00:06:51.829
And that way I can kind of lock or
hide that layer when needed.

139
00:06:51.829 --> 00:06:54.418
Because sometimes I need to see
everything like hanging off the artboard.

140
00:06:54.418 --> 00:06:57.683
And it's almost like a final preview,
if you wanna say, so

141
00:06:57.683 --> 00:06:59.700
you turn that layer back off.

142
00:06:59.700 --> 00:07:02.870
I'll make a really big rectangle, and

143
00:07:02.870 --> 00:07:06.900
then the rectangle that's
the size of the artboard.

144
00:07:06.900 --> 00:07:09.923
And so that way, super,
super big, way off the artboard.

145
00:07:09.923 --> 00:07:15.500
Another small one, use that of the two
rectangles being the clipping mask.

146
00:07:15.500 --> 00:07:19.994
And then, that's its own layer to be
able to kinda turn off and on, there-

147
00:07:19.994 --> 00:07:21.170
>> So something like this.

148
00:07:21.170 --> 00:07:23.211
>> Yep.
>> I actually remember you doing this.

149
00:07:23.211 --> 00:07:23.997
>> Yeah?
>> Back in the day.

150
00:07:23.997 --> 00:07:25.901
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, you go like this,

151
00:07:25.901 --> 00:07:27.203
you Make Clipping Mask.

152
00:07:27.203 --> 00:07:29.496
And then what she's saying is,
she goes ahead and

153
00:07:29.496 --> 00:07:31.413
just kinda creates that on its own layer.

154
00:07:31.413 --> 00:07:31.913
>> Yep.
>> Yeah.

155
00:07:31.913 --> 00:07:34.487
>> Yeah, and that way, I can go ahead and

156
00:07:34.487 --> 00:07:37.599
or flip it, however, I would do it.
>> Some way.

157
00:07:37.599 --> 00:07:38.267
>> Yeah, yeah. [LAUGH] >> [LAUGH]

158
00:07:38.267 --> 00:07:39.381
>> How did I do that?

159
00:07:39.381 --> 00:07:39.923
Yeah, okay,

160
00:07:39.923 --> 00:07:41.269
something like that.
[LAUGH]

161
00:07:41.269 --> 00:07:42.138
>> Yeah, it will work.

162
00:07:42.138 --> 00:07:42.863
>> Or flip and it-

163
00:07:42.863 --> 00:07:43.920
>> You can make it compound,

164
00:07:43.920 --> 00:07:47.006
but if you wanna do something similar
to that you could make a compound path.

165
00:07:47.006 --> 00:07:47.559
>> A compound path.

166
00:07:47.559 --> 00:07:48.755
>> And it will knock the hole,

167
00:07:48.755 --> 00:07:49.956
if I made this.

168
00:07:49.956 --> 00:07:52.065
>> You can use your eyedropper tool and
make that.

169
00:07:52.065 --> 00:07:54.116
I know we're going off
on a total tangent but

170
00:07:54.116 --> 00:07:55.815
it is something you could also-
>> And

171
00:07:55.815 --> 00:08:00.260
I just blended two concepts into one and
so you know what, it's a compound path.

172
00:08:00.260 --> 00:08:03.950
It's not a clipping mask, but
they can be kinda confusing in that sense.

173
00:08:03.950 --> 00:08:06.821
But a compound path knocks the hole out,
but

174
00:08:06.821 --> 00:08:10.246
the clipping mask is what
you want to see through it.

175
00:08:10.246 --> 00:08:11.107
>> Exactly.

176
00:08:11.107 --> 00:08:13.200
>> Okay, I'm getting myself confused.

177
00:08:13.200 --> 00:08:14.226
I don't wanna confuse you either.

178
00:08:14.226 --> 00:08:15.875
So I'm gonna stop unless you keep going.

179
00:08:15.875 --> 00:08:18.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's all right.

180
00:08:18.810 --> 00:08:21.962
It's all good but I think actually,
you kinda learn good something from that.

181
00:08:21.962 --> 00:08:24.601
>> So even if you're like,
what just happened?

182
00:08:24.601 --> 00:08:25.724
>> [LAUGH]
>> Compound path,

183
00:08:25.724 --> 00:08:29.326
if you wanna create something where you
can kinda do basically the same effect.

184
00:08:29.326 --> 00:08:32.366
I can have my star going
off to the side here, and

185
00:08:32.366 --> 00:08:34.953
I won't keep us on too much of a tangent.

186
00:08:34.953 --> 00:08:39.310
But I can kinda see okay what
that would look like, so yeah.

187
00:08:39.310 --> 00:08:40.213
>> Carry on.
>> [LAUGH]

188
00:08:40.213 --> 00:08:41.890
>> That is what she was trying to say.

189
00:08:41.890 --> 00:08:44.490
So we will take our clipping mask.

190
00:08:44.490 --> 00:08:47.180
And our clipping mask again is just
going to be any time I want something

191
00:08:47.180 --> 00:08:49.885
below it to take the shape
of what is on top.

192
00:08:49.885 --> 00:08:53.381
Now, we will move onto something
similar called opacity mask.

193
00:08:53.381 --> 00:08:55.368
So in order to get my opacity mask,

194
00:08:55.368 --> 00:08:58.321
I think at some point I
deleted my picture of my cat.

195
00:08:58.321 --> 00:09:03.100
He'd be so offended, if I go ahead and
I'm just gonna Cmd or Ctrl+Z so

196
00:09:03.100 --> 00:09:07.320
I can get that back, there he is,
to show you an opacity mask.

197
00:09:07.320 --> 00:09:11.720
So with an opacity mask I'm gonna
do kind of a similar setup here.

198
00:09:11.720 --> 00:09:14.670
I'm gonna go ahead and
I'm gonna grab the Ellipse Tool.

199
00:09:16.977 --> 00:09:22.790
And then this time, and you'll even see it
created automatically for me last time.

200
00:09:22.790 --> 00:09:24.770
I need to go ahead and
put a gradient on it.

201
00:09:24.770 --> 00:09:26.660
So this is where it gets kinda fancy.

202
00:09:26.660 --> 00:09:28.580
I'm gonna go ahead and
grab my Gradient panel, and

203
00:09:28.580 --> 00:09:30.070
then all I need is that default.

204
00:09:30.070 --> 00:09:31.770
I just need black and white.

205
00:09:31.770 --> 00:09:36.700
When we work on our opacity masks,
we're gonna have black equals hide and

206
00:09:36.700 --> 00:09:38.350
white equals show.

207
00:09:38.350 --> 00:09:43.119
So that may not make sense right now, but
what we can look at here if I take this.

208
00:09:43.119 --> 00:09:45.053
And I'm gonna grab both objects,

209
00:09:45.053 --> 00:09:48.528
again very similar to how we're
setting up our opacity mask.

210
00:09:48.528 --> 00:09:52.224
Now I wanna go next door
to that Transparency panel.

211
00:09:52.224 --> 00:09:54.434
So grab your Transparency panel,
however you find it.

212
00:09:54.434 --> 00:09:57.624
Window, go to Transparency,
you can also find it,

213
00:09:57.624 --> 00:10:00.680
it's kind of the two circles
on top of each other.

214
00:10:00.680 --> 00:10:04.216
I keep meaning to drag these out, so
you can actually read the labels there,

215
00:10:04.216 --> 00:10:04.890
there you go.

216
00:10:04.890 --> 00:10:09.350
And what we see when I have both options,
I'm gonna go ahead and select Make Mask.

217
00:10:09.350 --> 00:10:13.520
Now, not only did this
actually clip my shape, but

218
00:10:13.520 --> 00:10:18.450
it also added some effects
of transparency there to it.

219
00:10:18.450 --> 00:10:19.940
So it went ahead and kinda faded out.

220
00:10:19.940 --> 00:10:22.880
And remember that part
that was black before?

221
00:10:22.880 --> 00:10:27.042
We had that white gradient over here,
the black color stopped over here.

222
00:10:27.042 --> 00:10:29.703
That part has now faded into transparency.

223
00:10:29.703 --> 00:10:32.320
So what I can do,
I can take this over here.

224
00:10:32.320 --> 00:10:35.890
And you see it's not white,
it's actually fading into nothing.

225
00:10:35.890 --> 00:10:39.396
I could put something green behind this,
for example, and

226
00:10:39.396 --> 00:10:42.140
it would look like it
was fading into nothing.

227
00:10:42.140 --> 00:10:48.000
So that's the option that you have
with this Opacity mask, so grab that.

228
00:10:48.000 --> 00:10:50.020
I'm gonna go into
the Transparency panel again,

229
00:10:50.020 --> 00:10:52.830
just to show you a couple a couple
of things in terms of editing.

230
00:10:52.830 --> 00:10:55.180
So one, you have the option,
you see here it's set at Normal.

231
00:10:55.180 --> 00:10:57.210
That's just gonna affect
the blending mode.

232
00:10:57.210 --> 00:11:00.530
Again, this is one of those that's just
totally gonna depend on what you're doing.

233
00:11:00.530 --> 00:11:03.350
And I would say it's not worth
the time for me to go through and

234
00:11:03.350 --> 00:11:07.190
say, here's what each one of them does,
just kind of play around with it.

235
00:11:07.190 --> 00:11:09.260
You can adjust the Opacity there,
of course.

236
00:11:09.260 --> 00:11:13.590
Now one thing I wanted to mention too,
is that you can clip this, or not clip it.

237
00:11:13.590 --> 00:11:16.760
So right now, you see that it
took away the rest of my image,

238
00:11:16.760 --> 00:11:19.970
basically, or not took away,
it masked the rest of my image.

239
00:11:19.970 --> 00:11:21.770
All right, turn off that Clip option.

240
00:11:21.770 --> 00:11:24.699
You're gonna be able to go ahead and
see the rest of your image there.

241
00:11:24.699 --> 00:11:27.661
You're still gonna have
that kind of transparency.

242
00:11:27.661 --> 00:11:30.540
It's just all looking a little
bit different, basically.

243
00:11:30.540 --> 00:11:33.442
So depending on what you want to do,
you can turn that clip on and off.

244
00:11:33.442 --> 00:11:35.240
You can also Invert Mask.

245
00:11:35.240 --> 00:11:39.290
If I wanna flip the part that is white,
or the part this is shown

246
00:11:39.290 --> 00:11:42.120
versus the part that is hidden,
that's also an option to do.

247
00:11:42.120 --> 00:11:46.070
Now what do I say if I actually want
to just adjust that mask entirely?

248
00:11:46.070 --> 00:11:48.970
Now this is the one part that gets
a little bit tricky because you

249
00:11:48.970 --> 00:11:51.400
have to be aware of where
you are selecting things.

250
00:11:51.400 --> 00:11:55.310
So right now I've been doing all of this

251
00:11:55.310 --> 00:11:57.660
with actually this part on
the left-hand side that I've selected.

252
00:11:57.660 --> 00:12:02.580
This kind of preview of my cat
basically is what I have selected, so

253
00:12:02.580 --> 00:12:03.500
I have that there.

254
00:12:03.500 --> 00:12:05.090
Now, its a very subtle change,

255
00:12:05.090 --> 00:12:07.470
I don't feel like they really
point it out to you enough.

256
00:12:07.470 --> 00:12:12.090
But if you go ahead and select over here,
okay, now I'm actually adjusting the mask.

257
00:12:12.090 --> 00:12:15.500
And that's going to come into play later
when you forget that you have the mask

258
00:12:15.500 --> 00:12:16.140
selected.

259
00:12:16.140 --> 00:12:20.069
So I can go here, maybe make that
a little bit larger or do whatever.

260
00:12:20.069 --> 00:12:25.693
Or I could also just maybe use my Gradient
tool to adjust how I want that to appear,

261
00:12:25.693 --> 00:12:29.210
maybe I wanted it to be top to bottom.

262
00:12:29.210 --> 00:12:32.440
However you wanna adjust it, radial,
something like that, you can change.

263
00:12:32.440 --> 00:12:34.350
Now, where do people get tripped up?

264
00:12:34.350 --> 00:12:37.462
They forget that they
have that mask selected.

265
00:12:37.462 --> 00:12:39.870
So you try and go and
do something else, and you're like,

266
00:12:39.870 --> 00:12:41.640
why does that keep moving?

267
00:12:41.640 --> 00:12:45.015
Or even, I think, if you try and
create other shapes, it's just,

268
00:12:45.015 --> 00:12:47.043
see how I just tried to draw a rectangle?

269
00:12:47.043 --> 00:12:49.517
And it went ahead and
kinda masked over there?

270
00:12:49.517 --> 00:12:53.063
And it becomes very frustrating if
you don't know what's going on.

271
00:12:53.063 --> 00:12:58.193
And all the issue is, is that you
have that actual mask selected,

272
00:12:58.193 --> 00:13:02.870
you don't have the actual image,
if you will, selected.

273
00:13:02.870 --> 00:13:04.640
I forget what they actually call it.

274
00:13:04.640 --> 00:13:08.368
But this is the mask, that's gonna
be kind of your image on its own.

275
00:13:08.368 --> 00:13:12.132
And now, I can go here and
draw a rectangle or something like that.

276
00:13:12.132 --> 00:13:13.390
It's gonna be unaffected.

277
00:13:13.390 --> 00:13:16.380
So Opacity masks
are definitely kind of fun.

278
00:13:16.380 --> 00:13:20.453
Again, we're using the example of an image
here because I do think that an Opacity

279
00:13:20.453 --> 00:13:22.840
mask is probably gonna be
more effective on an image.

280
00:13:22.840 --> 00:13:25.340
But if you go back to things
like our clipping mask,

281
00:13:25.340 --> 00:13:28.370
just remember that you can
apply them on anything.

282
00:13:28.370 --> 00:13:31.030
Images are a great example of
a time when you may use them.

283
00:13:31.030 --> 00:13:33.576
But we also talked about some
other ideas that you wanna use.

284
00:13:33.576 --> 00:13:38.253
So I would say, enjoy your masking,
enjoy the mystery with that, and

285
00:13:38.253 --> 00:13:39.770
have some fun with it.

286
00:13:39.770 --> 00:13:43.472
>> Yeah, and hopefully I didn't cause too
much mystery of throwing in the compound

287
00:13:43.472 --> 00:13:45.659
path and like, yeah, that's what I did.

288
00:13:45.659 --> 00:13:51.190
Yeah, but it did kind of, it harkened
that in me to say, I used to do that.

289
00:13:51.190 --> 00:13:53.360
And go ahead and put that layer and
everything like that.

290
00:13:53.360 --> 00:13:58.853
But it's okay, I'm glad that you're
here to help us get on the path and

291
00:13:58.853 --> 00:14:00.330
stay on that path.

292
00:14:00.330 --> 00:14:03.100
And master very cool, and
be able to show and hide.

293
00:14:03.100 --> 00:14:07.482
The biggest thing on the opacity thing
that I always need to remember black hide,

294
00:14:07.482 --> 00:14:10.680
white show, and
which way I'm dragging the gradient.

295
00:14:10.680 --> 00:14:15.680
I repeat that to myself as I'm drawing

296
00:14:15.680 --> 00:14:19.375
the gradient to remember what I want
to show and what I want to hide.

297
00:14:19.375 --> 00:14:22.507
So thank you so much for
that great introduction to everything.

298
00:14:22.507 --> 00:14:25.167
We're gonna go ahead and wrap this one up.

299
00:14:25.167 --> 00:14:28.620
Signing off for CreativePro.TV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

300
00:14:28.620 --> 00:14:29.459
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

301
00:14:29.459 --> 00:14:30.853
>> We'll see you soon.

302
00:14:30.853 --> 00:14:35.999
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to use the mesh tool to create realistic shading.  They also cover the recolor artwork command and make a new color group of solid color swatches from a gradient.
episodes.title: Mesh and Recolor
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:07.192
[NOISE]

2

[MUSIC]

3

Hello everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting edition of CreativeProTV.

00:00:15.373 --> 00:00:17.053
I'm your host Vonne Smith and

we're continuing on with our
Illustrator CC 2017 series.

And we're gonna talk about a mesh and

00:00:23.188 --> 00:00:26.748
recolor Am I thinking I

But that's okay, Emily is gonna tell us.

00:00:28.961 --> 00:00:29.950
>> [LAUGH]

00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:30.723
>> That's right.
>> Emily Ramsey,

I can't even get your name right now.

00:00:31.703 --> 00:00:32.512
>> I'm not Crimps.

00:00:32.512 --> 00:00:33.244
I don't need a last name.

14
00:00:33.244 --> 00:00:34.821
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Just Emily.

15
00:00:34.821 --> 00:00:38.714
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's all, and no.

16
00:00:38.714 --> 00:00:43.175
Mesh and recolor, so
much more exciting than it sounds, right?

So, this is gonna be something,

18

So what we're seeing,

The tool actually also used to

And then at some point along the way

But we're gonna use it to mix colors and
use it to make some new and

00:01:06.170 --> 00:01:07.230

25
00:01:07.230 --> 00:01:09.959
So let's go ahead and get started.

26
00:01:09.959 --> 00:01:13.327
What I wanna do here, I wanna use
the example of a circle, you do you,

whatever you want, I just like the example

28
00:01:17.470 --> 00:01:20.722
And then go ahead and give it some

29
00:01:20.722 --> 00:01:24.780
So if you're kind of thinking, okay,

30
00:01:24.780 --> 00:01:27.676
There's gonna be some kind of
like dominate color, right?

So in my case, I'm gonna go with kind of
what I want to be like Background color,

32
00:01:32.303 --> 00:01:33.074

33
00:01:33.074 --> 00:01:37.504
This is all adjustable later, yadda
yadda yadda, but I'm gonna go here and

34
00:01:37.504 --> 00:01:41.120
I'm gonna say okay,
I want something that's gonna be blue.

35
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:43.068
I'm gonna get really
creative on my colors here.

36
00:01:43.068 --> 00:01:47.304
One of these days I'll pick something
other that pink, or blue, or orange.

37
00:01:47.304 --> 00:01:48.981
So we're gonna go with that here.

38
00:01:48.981 --> 00:01:52.124
And from there we need

39
00:01:52.124 --> 00:01:53.302
Now our mesh tool, well,

40
00:01:53.302 --> 00:01:56.794
first of all make sure you have the

00:01:56.794 --> 00:01:59.287
I think maybe I clicked off it there.

42
00:01:59.287 --> 00:02:03.246
So I have it selected with my block arrow
tool then I'm grabbing my mesh tool.

43
00:02:03.246 --> 00:02:05.055
Now my mesh tool is kind of a funny one.

44
00:02:05.055 --> 00:02:10.228
It almost acts like your white arrow tool
in that you're going to be adding points.

45
00:02:10.228 --> 00:02:11.998
Now you're not necessarily adding points.

46
00:02:11.998 --> 00:02:17.292
In the same way that you would with add
anchor point, or anything like that.

47
00:02:17.292 --> 00:02:19.444
You're actually adding mesh points.

48
00:02:19.444 --> 00:02:23.496
And we're gonna use these mesh

49
00:02:23.496 --> 00:02:27.009
Now you're gonna see those
Bezier handles again.

50
00:02:27.009 --> 00:02:28.337
So don't let me lose you.

51
00:02:28.337 --> 00:02:31.500
Don't get scared cuz you
see a Bezier handle.

It's actually gonna be pretty cool.

53

Now, with this you wanna
be careful how many you do.

54
00:02:36.425 --> 00:02:39.925
When you create one, it's kinda
gonna create another one for you.

55
00:02:39.925 --> 00:02:44.437
So it's like a, I don't know if the word
I'm going for here, but it's like a-

56
00:02:44.437 --> 00:02:45.430
>> Well it creates a grid.

57
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:46.857
>> [CROSSTALK] Yin Yang.

58
00:02:46.857 --> 00:02:47.753
Yeah, it creates a grid.
Thank you.

59
00:02:47.753 --> 00:02:50.904
>> You create one, then it's going
to create an x and a Yy basically.

60
00:02:50.904 --> 00:02:52.606
So one across, one going down.

61
00:02:52.606 --> 00:02:54.293
And that's where the point is.

62
00:02:54.293 --> 00:02:56.015
>> And so it kind of-
>> A mesh.

63
00:02:56.015 --> 00:02:56.550
>> Yeah.

64
00:02:56.550 --> 00:02:57.375
>> Yeah.

65
00:02:57.375 --> 00:02:59.673
>> Just like a,
I'm thinking like chicken wire.

66
00:02:59.673 --> 00:03:00.782
Like a mesh wire.

67
00:03:00.782 --> 00:03:04.118
That's what we're going to be creating.

68
00:03:04.118 --> 00:03:04.693
>> Yeah.

69
00:03:04.693 --> 00:03:06.995
>> And then we're going, and
then I'll stop right there-

70
00:03:06.995 --> 00:03:07.575
>> No, no, no.

71
00:03:07.575 --> 00:03:09.776
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No, I was like keep going,

72
00:03:09.776 --> 00:03:10.633
I love it, yeah.

73
00:03:10.633 --> 00:03:13.228
Made a lot more sense than my Ying and
Yang example.

74
00:03:13.228 --> 00:03:14.793
I was going down a bad path.

75
00:03:14.793 --> 00:03:18.258
But yeah, we're creating a mesh,
as the name implies.

76
00:03:18.258 --> 00:03:21.855
So yeah, you have to kind of think about
it like that, so what I'm gonna do, and

77
00:03:21.855 --> 00:03:23.359
you can do whatever you want, but

78
00:03:23.359 --> 00:03:26.140
I would suggest just kinda
follow my lead on this one.

79
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:28.720
I'm gonna make a single click
in the top left hand corner and

80
00:03:28.720 --> 00:03:30.985
a single click in the bottom
right hand corner.

81
00:03:30.985 --> 00:03:34.240
Cuz I'm gonna make that grid,
I don't need to make all four points.

82
00:03:34.240 --> 00:03:36.546
Or I could make more than that,
but I don't want to.

83
00:03:36.546 --> 00:03:40.482
What I'm gonna do, just single-click,
not necessarily on my path.

84
00:03:40.482 --> 00:03:41.872
I'm not clicking on that.

85
00:03:41.872 --> 00:03:46.030
I'm just gonna go somewhere generally
in the top left-hand corner, so

86
00:03:46.030 --> 00:03:47.403
somewhere about here.

87
00:03:47.403 --> 00:03:52.402
And then somewhere generally in the bottom
right-hand corner, so somewhere like that.

88
00:03:52.402 --> 00:03:56.745
Now you'll see, it made that grid for
me, and you can see here,

89
00:03:56.745 --> 00:03:59.006
I have kind of those Mesh points.

90
00:03:59.006 --> 00:04:02.670
It kinda looks like our points that we
used with the white arrow tool, right?

91
00:04:02.670 --> 00:04:05.660
And not to get too far ahead of ourselves,
but this is actually something I can

92
00:04:05.660 --> 00:04:08.820
change with my white arrow tool,
but we'll get to that in a second.

it will make the solid colors of the stuff
that they used along that gradient rim.

320
00:15:21.610 --> 00:15:25.824
And then, you can go ahead and have
those to match up with different things.

321
00:15:25.824 --> 00:15:29.363
I love this feature,
especially with the pre-made ones or

322
00:15:29.363 --> 00:15:32.748
getting artwork from somebody
else It has gradients.

323
00:15:32.748 --> 00:15:36.241
I love all these colors and we pull them
out, just click the folder icon, and

324
00:15:36.241 --> 00:15:37.778
there you got them, wonderful.

325
00:15:37.778 --> 00:15:38.911
>> [LAUGH] It's fantastic, right?

326
00:15:38.911 --> 00:15:40.850
>> [LAUGH] It is.

327
00:15:40.850 --> 00:15:43.425
>> One of the many beautiful
things about Illustrator, so

328
00:15:43.425 --> 00:15:45.408
I think we're just gonna leave it at that.

329
00:15:45.408 --> 00:15:48.771
Again, just remember that New Color Group,
the Recolor Artwork,

330
00:15:48.771 --> 00:15:52.070
their New Color Group from gradient,
the Recolor Artwork.

331
00:15:52.070 --> 00:15:55.000
Those are not limited to just
the use of the mesh tool.

332
00:15:55.000 --> 00:15:58.730
We just both kind of agree,
it goes along really with the mesh tool.

333
00:15:58.730 --> 00:16:00.130
So I hope you can enjoy it.

334
00:16:00.130 --> 00:16:02.713
I hope you have fun playing with your
mesh, creating all kinds of crazy things.

335
00:16:02.713 --> 00:16:06.275
And yeah, this was fun.

336
00:16:06.275 --> 00:16:08.851
[LAUGH]
>> We just opened Pandora's box for you.

337
00:16:08.851 --> 00:16:13.184
Look at all these things you can do
with re-coloring and the mesh and

338
00:16:13.184 --> 00:16:15.195
make marbles and everything.

339
00:16:15.195 --> 00:16:17.611
>> [LAUGH]
>> Marble to your heart's content.

340
00:16:17.611 --> 00:16:18.401
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, there you go!

341
00:16:18.401 --> 00:16:21.960
All right, well that was super fun,
and lots of coloring.

342
00:16:21.960 --> 00:16:24.903
But we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

343
00:16:24.903 --> 00:16:28.044
Signing off for CreativeProTV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

344
00:16:28.044 --> 00:16:29.182
>> And I'm Emily Ramsay.

345
00:16:29.182 --> 00:16:30.924
>> We'll see you soon.

346
00:16:30.924 --> 00:16:35.719
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily take a deeper dive into swatches, specifically covering process versus spot swatches and global swatches. They explain best practices for using these types of swatches for commercial print and formatting artwork in general.
episodes.title: Advanced Swatches
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:07.088
[SOUND]

2
00:00:07.088 --> 00:00:11.275
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.275 --> 00:00:15.900
Hello everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting edition of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:15.900 --> 00:00:20.122
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and
this is Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:20.122 --> 00:00:24.498
And we're continuing on with something
that Emily is gonna tell us what we're

6
00:00:24.498 --> 00:00:27.560
doing, because I forgot what
the title of episode is.

7
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:30.069
So thank you, Emily, for
being here, welcome back.

8
00:00:30.069 --> 00:00:31.471
[LAUGH]
>> That's why I'm here,

9
00:00:31.471 --> 00:00:33.615
just to tell you the title of the episode.

10
00:00:33.615 --> 00:00:36.890
So today we are talking
about advanced swatches.

11
00:00:36.890 --> 00:00:40.161
Which I feel like it's kind of like
a broad name that can encompass many

12
00:00:40.161 --> 00:00:41.110
different things.

13
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:44.425
But in a lot of ways, what we're talking
about has to do with, or at least what

14
00:00:44.425 --> 00:00:47.980
we're going to start with, I should say,
has to do with commercial printing.

15
00:00:47.980 --> 00:00:52.623
And how you wanna kind of frame your
swatches for commercial printing and

16
00:00:52.623 --> 00:00:53.540
kind of set them up.

17
00:00:53.540 --> 00:00:55.310
And a couple of different
things that you wanna look at.

18
00:00:55.310 --> 00:00:59.070
Now, we'll mention some other cool things
at the end like the logo swatches.

19
00:00:59.070 --> 00:01:02.794
We'll certainly be getting into
our swatch libraries again, and

20
00:01:02.794 --> 00:01:06.061
we may even get a little crazy and
get into the color panel.

21
00:01:06.061 --> 00:01:07.996
So let's go ahead and get started.

22
00:01:07.996 --> 00:01:11.940
Now, funny thing about this is, I'm gonna
start with a little lesson here, and

23
00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:14.380
I'm actually gonna be using my type tool.

24
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:16.930
You don't have to follow along, but
what I wanna do here is just to,

25
00:01:16.930 --> 00:01:20.660
I'm a visual person, so
I just wanna write this out for you.

26
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:26.060
So when we are working with our swatches,
particularly in commercial printing,

27
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:29.000
you have two different types of
swatches that you're wanna work with,

28
00:01:29.000 --> 00:01:32.970
either process or spot.

29
00:01:32.970 --> 00:01:35.550
So process colors are really
the colors that we've

30
00:01:35.550 --> 00:01:37.270
been working with up until this point.

31
00:01:37.270 --> 00:01:41.184
So it´s those CMYK colors, again,
I´m referring to commercial printing,

32
00:01:41.184 --> 00:01:42.880
so I´m just sticking with CMYK.

33
00:01:42.880 --> 00:01:47.769
So process, we´re gonna say, equals CMYK.

34
00:01:47.769 --> 00:01:50.110
Now, why is process CMYK?

35
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:55.100
CMYK, cyan, magenta, yellow, and
black are those four different

36
00:01:55.100 --> 00:01:58.800
inks that a printer is using when
it actually prints something.

37
00:01:58.800 --> 00:02:02.030
So if you have something
set up in a CMYK mode and

38
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:06.150
you send it to a commercial printer,
the printer is actually printing

39
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:08.610
percentages of cyan,
magenta, yellow, and black.

40
00:02:08.610 --> 00:02:12.760
You guys can remember that from when we
created swatches, and you had the sliders.

41
00:02:12.760 --> 00:02:16.129
Remember, you had that cyan slider,
magenta, yellow and black, and

42
00:02:16.129 --> 00:02:18.277
you had kind of combinations
of all of those.

43
00:02:18.277 --> 00:02:22.079
So that CMYK,
that equals four inks, right?

44
00:02:22.079 --> 00:02:26.610
Spot color, spot colors are also
kind of known as Pantone colors.

45
00:02:26.610 --> 00:02:29.660
Have you ever heard the term
Pantone thrown around?

46
00:02:29.660 --> 00:02:34.200
Pantone is kind of just the color
authority, at least where we are.

47
00:02:34.200 --> 00:02:37.490
They do all kinds of crazy things
where they kind of establish

48
00:02:37.490 --> 00:02:38.513
a color of the year.

49
00:02:38.513 --> 00:02:42.643
And they're tied into fashion and
all of these other different industries,

50
00:02:42.643 --> 00:02:46.021
where they kind of set the standard for
color in this industry.

51
00:02:46.021 --> 00:02:49.437
>> I don't know if we even meant to do
this on purpose, but didn't Target have

52
00:02:49.437 --> 00:02:53.034
something a couple of years ago, where
they had like the Pantone Collection?

53
00:02:53.034 --> 00:02:53.615
>> Yes.

54
00:02:53.615 --> 00:02:57.760
>> And everything was like Pantone 185 or
whatever, right?

55
00:02:57.760 --> 00:03:01.440
>> Yeah, mugs and things like that, where
they would have the top of it be white and

56
00:03:01.440 --> 00:03:04.570
then the bottom half is Pantone this.

57
00:03:04.570 --> 00:03:10.150
So it's fairly common,
you may not have heard of it.

58
00:03:10.150 --> 00:03:13.017
It's quite possible that you wouldn't have
heard of it, but it's also pretty common.

59
00:03:13.017 --> 00:03:17.364
>> And it's things like,
I've noticed it because I'm like, my gosh,

60
00:03:17.364 --> 00:03:20.410
they're doing a whole thing
on Pantones at Target.

61
00:03:20.410 --> 00:03:24.146
Where it's like, you had the purples,
and I had all the spreads,

62
00:03:24.146 --> 00:03:26.766
the what are those things
that goes on the bed?

63
00:03:26.766 --> 00:03:27.397
>> A bedspread?

64
00:03:27.397 --> 00:03:27.954
>> Yeah.

65
00:03:27.954 --> 00:03:30.114
[LAUGH]
>> You had spread,

66
00:03:30.114 --> 00:03:33.380
I was like [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

67
00:03:33.380 --> 00:03:36.251
>> Wow, yes, that's why you're here,

68
00:03:36.251 --> 00:03:37.906
to help me think, so.

69
00:03:37.906 --> 00:03:39.685
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's it, yeah.

70
00:03:39.685 --> 00:03:43.645
But yeah, you're right, so you probably,
we noticed it cuz we're aware.

71
00:03:43.645 --> 00:03:46.841
And depending on how aware you are before,
you might not have noticed it.

72
00:03:46.841 --> 00:03:50.190
So that spot, that equals a Pantone color.

73
00:03:50.190 --> 00:03:54.210
Now, what's kind of the difference
here mainly between a process versus

74
00:03:54.210 --> 00:03:55.510
a spot color?

75
00:03:55.510 --> 00:04:00.510
A process color is four inks,
a spot color is one ink.

76
00:04:00.510 --> 00:04:04.950
So when you send something to the printer,
they only have to print one specific ink.

77
00:04:04.950 --> 00:04:05.735
Now, how's it work?

78
00:04:05.735 --> 00:04:08.409
It's typically, and
Vonne knows all about this, so

79
00:04:08.409 --> 00:04:10.320
she can correct me if I'm wrong here.

80
00:04:10.320 --> 00:04:13.550
But it's an ink that's gonna be
mixed outside of the printer, and

81
00:04:13.550 --> 00:04:16.580
then it's actually something that you're
gonna go ahead and insert in there.

82
00:04:16.580 --> 00:04:20.610
So it's not something like our CMYK,
where it's as it's happening,

83
00:04:20.610 --> 00:04:22.230
those four inks are combining.

84
00:04:22.230 --> 00:04:23.530
It's something mixed outside the printer.

85
00:04:23.530 --> 00:04:26.030
>> Yeah, cuz we were talking
about commercial print,

86
00:04:26.030 --> 00:04:30.040
normally what are known as offset
printing, not digital printing.

87
00:04:30.040 --> 00:04:34.060
Cuz digital printing goes back to just
your regular desktop printer, where you

88
00:04:34.060 --> 00:04:37.550
have the cartridges, and it just goes
ahead and spits out the paper at the end.

89
00:04:37.550 --> 00:04:42.100
Digital printing, and that says just be
a really, really big version of that.

90
00:04:42.100 --> 00:04:45.630
When you have offset printing,
you have a commercial press.

91
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:49.750
And the press have what are known as
plates, and the plates is where it takes

92
00:04:49.750 --> 00:04:55.070
and breaks up your artwork, or whatever
you have, into those individual inks.

93
00:04:55.070 --> 00:04:56.940
The cyan, magenta, yellow and
black, and they go ahead and

94
00:04:56.940 --> 00:04:58.668
put the ink on the well on the top.

95
00:04:58.668 --> 00:05:02.700
And then it rolls up, kind of like
a stamp, rolls up into the ink, and

96
00:05:02.700 --> 00:05:04.230
then rolls down into your paper.

97
00:05:04.230 --> 00:05:09.370
And that's where those inks process
together on the paper to go ahead and

98
00:05:09.370 --> 00:05:13.350
make your greens and your oranges and
your purples and things like that.

99
00:05:13.350 --> 00:05:17.980
So if you have something that I need
to have a two color process, or

100
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:20.490
two color artwork, or
even one color artwork,

101
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:24.500
then that means it's only
one plate on that press.

102
00:05:24.500 --> 00:05:28.590
And then all of the ink is that one color,
goes down onto the paper, and

103
00:05:28.590 --> 00:05:30.620
then that's only one plate.

104
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:34.600
Like I just said, biggest difference here,
sometimes with cost.

105
00:05:34.600 --> 00:05:36.940
Think about four inks, more money.

106
00:05:36.940 --> 00:05:42.630
One ink or two inks, less money in theory,
when you get into those types of things.

107
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:45.570
>> Yeah, yeah, that was actually
gonna be my next point to you.

108
00:05:45.570 --> 00:05:47.490
Is I think that they're cheaper.

109
00:05:47.490 --> 00:05:50.241
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> Certainly I never
want to be the one to tell somebody,

110
00:05:50.241 --> 00:05:54.144
yes absolutely, that's certainly something
you wanna talk to your printer about, but

111
00:05:54.144 --> 00:05:55.499
[CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah, and again,

112
00:05:55.499 --> 00:05:59.329
throwing out that whole digital versus
offset printing, depending on your job and

113
00:05:59.329 --> 00:06:01.845
how much you're going to be doing,
and everything.

114
00:06:01.845 --> 00:06:05.580
Quantity-wise and depending on your job,
it's like well we'll just go ahead and

115
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:08.950
run that digitally rather
than on the press.

116
00:06:08.950 --> 00:06:13.580
Because we'll actually save you money
on the digital versus the offset and

117
00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:15.920
then like the amount of
inks doesn't really matter.

118
00:06:15.920 --> 00:06:19.241
But I'm getting into the weeds,
cuz I do love to talk about this stuff.

119
00:06:19.241 --> 00:06:21.220
>> Yes. [LAUGH] >> And
I can talk about it for hours.

120
00:06:21.220 --> 00:06:25.220
So we're gonna just kinda go ahead and
consult your print company,

121
00:06:25.220 --> 00:06:26.030
your commercial printer.

122
00:06:26.030 --> 00:06:29.974
Talk to them, honestly sometimes
before you even start a job.

123
00:06:29.974 --> 00:06:31.950
To kinda get your mind around,

124
00:06:31.950 --> 00:06:35.225
what do I need to even think
about in terms of money?

125
00:06:35.225 --> 00:06:39.200
Cuz you don't wanna design this amazing
artwork with four process colors,

126
00:06:39.200 --> 00:06:42.480
three spots, because that's what
you had to have, that's seven.

127
00:06:42.480 --> 00:06:43.793
That's gonna be a lot of money, so.

128
00:06:43.793 --> 00:06:46.056
[LAUGH]
>> Right, right, and then you client or

129
00:06:46.056 --> 00:06:49.512
whoever loves it, and then you have to be
the one to back to them going well, sorry.

130
00:06:49.512 --> 00:06:50.054
>> Yeah.

131
00:06:50.054 --> 00:06:51.201
[LAUGH]
>> So always,

132
00:06:51.201 --> 00:06:54.633
always my advice is talk to your printer
if it is something that you're gonna be

133
00:06:54.633 --> 00:06:55.570
working on in print.

134
00:06:55.570 --> 00:07:00.170
Now, how do I actually like
find these Pantone colors?

135
00:07:00.170 --> 00:07:02.860
I mentioned it's something
that's kind of premixed outside.

136
00:07:02.860 --> 00:07:03.845
So in other words,

137
00:07:03.845 --> 00:07:07.330
they're actually something that
are already created basically for you.

138
00:07:07.330 --> 00:07:10.825
So what we're going to be working
with here are really just a set

139
00:07:10.825 --> 00:07:14.935
of Pantone swatches, I mentioned
Pantone's kind of the color authority.

140
00:07:14.935 --> 00:07:15.765
And even say,

141
00:07:15.765 --> 00:07:20.385
I would go online, go to their website,
they have color books available for you.

142
00:07:20.385 --> 00:07:22.285
It's almost like going to Lowe's or
Home Depot, and

143
00:07:22.285 --> 00:07:23.885
you pull out the paint swatches.

144
00:07:23.885 --> 00:07:29.555
That's what Pantone has for colors
that we can use in terms of designing.

145
00:07:29.555 --> 00:07:31.865
So I'm gonna go into my Swatches panel.

146
00:07:33.330 --> 00:07:37.139
And then what we're gonna do, we're
gonna go into our color libraries, so

147
00:07:37.139 --> 00:07:38.576
the Swatch Libraries menu.

148
00:07:38.576 --> 00:07:42.500
And then you can go down
into your Color Books.

149
00:07:42.500 --> 00:07:46.479
Now we have several different options
here, and we're gonna skip and

150
00:07:46.479 --> 00:07:48.238
focus mainly on the CMYK ones.

151
00:07:48.238 --> 00:07:51.407
But you'll notice that there
are all kinds of different things,

152
00:07:51.407 --> 00:07:54.413
you can choose from metallics,
pastels, things like that.

153
00:07:54.413 --> 00:07:59.285
>> Yeah, and that also kinda throws
a whole other element of what The ink

154
00:07:59.285 --> 00:08:02.738
that is being mixed and
like what basis they use.

155
00:08:02.738 --> 00:08:05.074
Whether it has a metallic, or that neon.

156
00:08:05.074 --> 00:08:08.230
And also, you can see down there like,
coded versus uncoded.

157
00:08:08.230 --> 00:08:09.915
That's talking about like the paper stock.

158
00:08:09.915 --> 00:08:10.484
>> Right.

159
00:08:10.484 --> 00:08:14.111
Like what you're actually printing on,
because that kind affect how

160
00:08:14.111 --> 00:08:18.270
the ink is going to actually kind of
blend into the paper, if you wanna say.

161
00:08:18.270 --> 00:08:21.736
And it's nice that you call them books,
because if you were doing that drop down

162
00:08:21.736 --> 00:08:24.644
and looking for Pantone,
in this main menu, if you wanna call it.

163
00:08:24.644 --> 00:08:29.172
You're like, Pantone doesn't exist, no,
it's off the color books, which is weird.

164
00:08:29.172 --> 00:08:31.450
Just throwing out a couple more things.

165
00:08:31.450 --> 00:08:34.820
Pantone is the one that everybody
normally goes with, but

166
00:08:34.820 --> 00:08:38.710
you can see there's that HKS and
some other ones in there.

167
00:08:38.710 --> 00:08:43.660
They are not the only ones out there but,
Pantones were, like the Toyo Ink and

168
00:08:43.660 --> 00:08:44.860
everything.

169
00:08:44.860 --> 00:08:48.920
But again, I think its pretty safe to say
that Pantone is gonna be the one that's

170
00:08:48.920 --> 00:08:50.600
gonna win out in the long run.

171
00:08:50.600 --> 00:08:52.980
>> Yeah,
its typically the one that I would choose,

172
00:08:52.980 --> 00:08:55.700
now to her point you know you
can't pick these other options.

173
00:08:55.700 --> 00:08:58.730
But, as you've probably heard me
calling on the color authority,

174
00:08:58.730 --> 00:09:02.790
you can see which way I kinda lean
in that, so what we're gonna do,

175
00:09:02.790 --> 00:09:06.010
I typically would go with
a Pantone solid coated.

176
00:09:06.010 --> 00:09:09.846
Now you're free, of course,
to pick out the Pantone pastels and

177
00:09:09.846 --> 00:09:12.582
neons just to see what
some of those look like.

178
00:09:12.582 --> 00:09:16.388
But just kinda from a basic standpoint,
I always go to color books and

179
00:09:16.388 --> 00:09:21.002
then go to Pantone solid coated, because
that's gonna be kind of what I would use.

180
00:09:21.002 --> 00:09:24.310
We're thinking about, again,
that coated versus un-coated.

181
00:09:24.310 --> 00:09:27.420
Has to do with the actual paper stock,
but if I'm printing something for

182
00:09:27.420 --> 00:09:30.200
client, it's probably gonna be in
a little bit nicer of a stock.

183
00:09:30.200 --> 00:09:33.840
That uncoated is more just like printer
paper, is kinda the way I look at it.

184
00:09:33.840 --> 00:09:36.438
So, Pantone Solid Coated,
I'm gonna go ahead and grab that.

185
00:09:36.438 --> 00:09:40.590
Now you see you'll have all of these
different colors to choose from.

186
00:09:40.590 --> 00:09:42.130
All of these different options.

187
00:09:42.130 --> 00:09:44.820
Now, something else that you will probably
notice with all of these different

188
00:09:44.820 --> 00:09:47.720
options, they all have a little
eyeball attached to them, right.

189
00:09:47.720 --> 00:09:51.060
So, what we are seeing with
all of these spot colors, and

190
00:09:51.060 --> 00:09:52.885
you can even see as I
start to click around.

191
00:09:52.885 --> 00:09:55.760
Everytime I click on one,
it adds to my swatches panel,

192
00:09:55.760 --> 00:09:57.540
you see that happening, right there?

193
00:09:57.540 --> 00:10:01.430
In my swatches panel, you can see
the distinction between a process versus

194
00:10:01.430 --> 00:10:03.940
a spot color based on that little dot.

195
00:10:03.940 --> 00:10:06.690
So It'll have that white corner,
and then, you have a dot on it and

196
00:10:06.690 --> 00:10:11.140
you can think process spot,
the spot colors have a spot there.

197
00:10:11.140 --> 00:10:14.660
And what you can do, you can kind of just
filter through and see what works for you.

198
00:10:14.660 --> 00:10:17.493
Now, this is where having a color
book will come in handy, so

199
00:10:17.493 --> 00:10:19.895
if you were actually to
purchase one from Pantone.

200
00:10:19.895 --> 00:10:24.787
I say purchase, they're not necessarily
always the most inexpensive things

201
00:10:24.787 --> 00:10:29.247
that you can buy, but they do have
some higher and lower-end options.

202
00:10:29.247 --> 00:10:31.287
You can kind of look through and

203
00:10:31.287 --> 00:10:35.850
you can see exactly what it's going
to look like when it's printed.

204
00:10:35.850 --> 00:10:39.970
So in my case solid coated,
they would have this particular, what am I

205
00:10:39.970 --> 00:10:44.560
hovering over, Pantone 587c, they would
have it printed on a coded stock, so

206
00:10:44.560 --> 00:10:46.550
I can see exactly what
that's going to look like.

207
00:10:46.550 --> 00:10:49.796
And, that's really one of the benefits
of Pantone or a spot color, in general.

208
00:10:49.796 --> 00:10:52.540
Is that, you have more of a clear idea
of what it is going to look like.

209
00:10:52.540 --> 00:10:57.014
>> And a lot of your major corporations
and major companies that have

210
00:10:57.014 --> 00:11:01.830
been branded, they'll have guides
that say, what is my CMYK value?

211
00:11:01.830 --> 00:11:04.180
What is my spot value?

212
00:11:04.180 --> 00:11:05.667
What is my RGB value?
They have all of them,

213
00:11:05.667 --> 00:11:09.178
kind of designated because, if you're
supposed to use the company colors and

214
00:11:09.178 --> 00:11:10.860
that's what we're doing.

215
00:11:10.860 --> 00:11:16.020
Going back to, if we're only going to
do University of Florida, for example.

216
00:11:16.020 --> 00:11:17.570
They have orange and blue.

217
00:11:17.570 --> 00:11:20.205
Well, that orange is 172C.

218
00:11:20.205 --> 00:11:21.700
Why?

219
00:11:21.700 --> 00:11:24.389
Because we've done a lot of work for
UF and we know that [LAUGH].

220
00:11:24.389 --> 00:11:28.830
So that is Gator orange
in the Pantone value.

221
00:11:28.830 --> 00:11:32.732
And if I was gonna look up,
yep, Gator blue, 287.

222
00:11:32.732 --> 00:11:33.259
>> Yes.

223
00:11:33.259 --> 00:11:37.600
There's my Gator blue, and that's going
to designate that in that Pantone.

224
00:11:37.600 --> 00:11:41.300
If you're thinking about if we were making
a flyer, or any type of little thing that

225
00:11:41.300 --> 00:11:45.720
only needed Get a orange and get a blue,
I would designate that as a spot,

226
00:11:45.720 --> 00:11:48.720
because that's two inks plus money,
all that kind of stuff.

227
00:11:48.720 --> 00:11:53.497
And there's even some things that like you
can only achieve a certain color with that

228
00:11:53.497 --> 00:11:57.130
Pantone like there's no
actually like relate to that,

229
00:11:57.130 --> 00:11:59.030
that's going a little extreme.

230
00:11:59.030 --> 00:11:59.610
>> Yeah.

231
00:11:59.610 --> 00:12:03.822
Probably wouldn't want a company branded
like that, where you only had spot inks,

232
00:12:03.822 --> 00:12:06.213
because that could get
a little too expensive.

233
00:12:06.213 --> 00:12:07.816
[LAUGH]
>> It's a little limiting.

234
00:12:07.816 --> 00:12:08.354
>> Yeah.

235
00:12:08.354 --> 00:12:08.906
>> So, question for you.

236
00:12:08.906 --> 00:12:12.620
So now, when we say this, we're saying
okay two inks and things like that.

237
00:12:12.620 --> 00:12:14.949
But that's not including black and
white and shades of grey.

238
00:12:14.949 --> 00:12:15.609
>> Yes.

239
00:12:15.609 --> 00:12:16.650
>> Right?

240
00:12:16.650 --> 00:12:17.200
>> Yeah.

241
00:12:17.200 --> 00:12:18.070
>> Yes.

242
00:12:18.070 --> 00:12:22.570
That would be an ink in itself,
so if you had black, orange and

243
00:12:22.570 --> 00:12:26.270
blue that's three inks and everything and
we're getting more into like varying

244
00:12:26.270 --> 00:12:29.261
print specific stuff because
we do a lot of print work.

245
00:12:29.261 --> 00:12:29.885
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

246
00:12:29.885 --> 00:12:33.070
>> But it is nice to know that
that's what it's going to do, and

247
00:12:33.070 --> 00:12:35.250
just really knowing the nature of.

248
00:12:35.250 --> 00:12:38.010
Hey, you have to at the artwork level,

249
00:12:38.010 --> 00:12:43.550
you have to designate what the color
information is going to be.

250
00:12:43.550 --> 00:12:45.980
Is it a process blue,
or is it a spot blue?

251
00:12:45.980 --> 00:12:49.620
Because, how you design it here,
makes a huge difference,

252
00:12:49.620 --> 00:12:53.580
or it really is everything of how the
printer is going to get your files, and

253
00:12:53.580 --> 00:12:56.950
be able to translate what that
information's going to be in.

254
00:12:56.950 --> 00:12:59.800
>> Right.
So, but what you see as you're working,

255
00:12:59.800 --> 00:13:03.970
besides from noticing those spots in my
swatches panel, I'm not really gonna see

256
00:13:03.970 --> 00:13:07.030
a whole lot of difference when I'm
actually working on something.

257
00:13:07.030 --> 00:13:08.480
So I can go ahead here, and

258
00:13:08.480 --> 00:13:12.370
I can just apply this just in the same
way that I would a typical swatch.

259
00:13:12.370 --> 00:13:15.260
Now, what tends to kind
of confuse people here.

260
00:13:15.260 --> 00:13:20.240
Okay, we have that option with
the little slash and the dot through it.

261
00:13:20.240 --> 00:13:23.600
There's another option we can
create in our swatches panel,

262
00:13:23.600 --> 00:13:25.930
that's gonna have kind
of a similar look to it.

263
00:13:27.160 --> 00:13:30.270
That might kinda throw you off,
and that's called a global swatch.

264
00:13:30.270 --> 00:13:33.873
So what I'm gonna do here, I'm gonna
go ahead and create a couple pieces.

265
00:13:33.873 --> 00:13:36.220
Well, actually no, I take that back.

266
00:13:36.220 --> 00:13:39.270
I'm just gonna stick with this,
as I'm thinking it through.

267
00:13:39.270 --> 00:13:41.610
And then,
I'm gonna create a new swatch here.

268
00:13:41.610 --> 00:13:45.110
So I'm gonna create a new swatch, and you
can go ahead and you can change the color.

269
00:13:45.110 --> 00:13:48.020
We talked about those sliders,
those CMYK sliders.

270
00:13:48.020 --> 00:13:50.290
Another option, actually,
as I'm pointing this out.

271
00:13:50.290 --> 00:13:54.570
I could go to my color panel,
use the sliders there, and

272
00:13:54.570 --> 00:13:56.930
kinda just do the same thing
until I find something.

273
00:13:56.930 --> 00:14:00.300
Yay, yeah I kinda like that purply gray.

274
00:14:00.300 --> 00:14:04.650
And then go into my swatches panel, I'm
gonna X out of those Pantones real quick.

275
00:14:04.650 --> 00:14:08.040
Create a new swatch, and
now here's the thing I wanna point out.

276
00:14:08.040 --> 00:14:10.300
So I have this color I like,
but, you know,

277
00:14:10.300 --> 00:14:14.100
it's variety of different reasons
why you might wanna do this.

278
00:14:14.100 --> 00:14:18.970
But, say that I like it but
I'm not positive about it, okay.

279
00:14:18.970 --> 00:14:21.880
I'm thinking, it's good but
I may wanna change it later.

280
00:14:21.880 --> 00:14:25.290
So what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna go
ahead and apply a global swatch.

281
00:14:25.290 --> 00:14:28.900
Now again, different reasons why you might
want to do this, but the example I'm going

282
00:14:28.900 --> 00:14:32.640
with is that, I'm just a little
unsure about this purpley color.

283
00:14:32.640 --> 00:14:34.260
So I'm gonna go ahead and hit OK.

284
00:14:34.260 --> 00:14:35.390
I'm gonna create a global swatch.

285
00:14:35.390 --> 00:14:37.270
Now, why did I say that was confusing?

286
00:14:37.270 --> 00:14:39.860
Because if you look at this,
you see how those spot colors,

287
00:14:39.860 --> 00:14:42.600
they have a spot on there?

288
00:14:42.600 --> 00:14:45.830
My global swatch has
a very similar look to it.

289
00:14:45.830 --> 00:14:48.580
It has that kind of white
flag in the corner.

290
00:14:48.580 --> 00:14:52.940
But, it's not a spot color,
this is a processed color.

291
00:14:52.940 --> 00:14:55.400
Can you see I just mixed
it with my CMYK values?

292
00:14:55.400 --> 00:14:57.810
You know, I went ahead and
mixed in my color panel.

293
00:14:57.810 --> 00:14:58.428
It is not a Pantone.
And

294
00:14:58.428 --> 00:15:02.320
this is generally something that
threw me off for the longest time.

295
00:15:02.320 --> 00:15:04.871
I would look at something with that
little white flag and I'll be like, yeah,

296
00:15:04.871 --> 00:15:05.770
that's a Pantone color.

297
00:15:05.770 --> 00:15:06.400
You know, I don't know.

298
00:15:07.630 --> 00:15:09.447
Because you just forget.
It makes perfect sense right now,

299
00:15:09.447 --> 00:15:10.211
spot is the spot.

300
00:15:10.211 --> 00:15:14.460
But six months down the road
you might not remember.

301
00:15:14.460 --> 00:15:18.030
So, there is a key difference
there between that spot and

302
00:15:18.030 --> 00:15:19.090
then just the white flag.

303
00:15:19.090 --> 00:15:21.750
Now, what is the global swatch do for us?

304
00:15:21.750 --> 00:15:27.639
Well say that I go here, and
I'm gonna just start creating

305
00:15:27.639 --> 00:15:33.539
a bunch of things with that
specific global swatch apply.

306
00:15:33.539 --> 00:15:35.673
So, I got a couple of
different things going on.

307
00:15:35.673 --> 00:15:39.240
Now, I've said it before I wasn't
really quite sure about this purple

308
00:15:39.240 --> 00:15:42.910
that I had going on,
I thought maybe I'd wanna change it later.

309
00:15:42.910 --> 00:15:47.199
Let me go back into my swatches panel and
I'm going to double click on this.

310
00:15:47.199 --> 00:15:50.139
And I am going to adjust my color, so

311
00:15:50.139 --> 00:15:53.578
maybe I decide I want
that to be more blue.

312
00:15:53.578 --> 00:15:55.381
Go ahead, and hit OK.

313
00:15:55.381 --> 00:15:59.861
Everything that was using that
global swatch will then change.

314
00:15:59.861 --> 00:16:05.002
So super handy, again, I almost say, like,
a lot of time I just create my swatches

315
00:16:05.002 --> 00:16:10.020
globally as I'm working, you know, just so
that I can more easily change them.

316
00:16:10.020 --> 00:16:11.520
>> I've gotten in the habit of,

317
00:16:11.520 --> 00:16:16.160
anytime I'm mixing colors,
I always change it to a global swatch.

318
00:16:16.160 --> 00:16:20.320
Just for that idea, I might want to go and
change that one thing later.

319
00:16:20.320 --> 00:16:23.560
Now we did talk about read color artwork,
in another episode,

320
00:16:23.560 --> 00:16:26.900
so you can think, well I'll just
go ahead and do the recolor.

321
00:16:26.900 --> 00:16:28.790
It's just another way to
get to the same place.

322
00:16:28.790 --> 00:16:35.650
And that kind of link, the linking of the
color apply to your object, to the swatch.

323
00:16:35.650 --> 00:16:37.480
The only way you can get
that is with global.

324
00:16:37.480 --> 00:16:41.720
Cuz you could go to any one of
these swatches that are not global.

325
00:16:41.720 --> 00:16:46.440
Like the regular CMYK process or
an RGB, double-click it, go into and

326
00:16:46.440 --> 00:16:52.440
start changing its values, but if you had
already applied that multiple places and

327
00:16:52.440 --> 00:16:55.510
then you go and change the base,
if you want to say.

328
00:16:55.510 --> 00:16:58.890
It´s not connected,
there´s no connection back to it.

329
00:16:58.890 --> 00:17:03.280
It has to be global for
it to do what we just demonstrated,

330
00:17:03.280 --> 00:17:08.230
tying it all together So that's why
I've just got in the habit of click that

331
00:17:08.230 --> 00:17:13.080
box at the bottom, make it a global swatch
just in case later I need to modify it.

332
00:17:13.080 --> 00:17:13.630
>> Right, exactly.

333
00:17:13.630 --> 00:17:16.470
I'm kinda glad you brought it
back to the recolor artwork, too.

334
00:17:16.470 --> 00:17:17.540
Cuz it is kind of just a different

335
00:17:17.540 --> 00:17:19.310
a different way of getting
to the same thing.

336
00:17:19.310 --> 00:17:23.080
Now, there's one other thing that I want
to mention with our global swatches.

337
00:17:23.080 --> 00:17:26.160
Just because I know it tends to come
up in some of the things that I do.

338
00:17:26.160 --> 00:17:30.920
I'm going to hop back into the color
panel, I'm still using this global swatch.

339
00:17:30.920 --> 00:17:32.700
This may be getting to
into the weeds here, but

340
00:17:32.700 --> 00:17:35.590
I'm going to bring up a concept
called tint Swatches.

341
00:17:35.590 --> 00:17:39.130
So, in color you have things
called shades and tints.

342
00:17:39.130 --> 00:17:41.420
You've probably heard of
a shade of a certain color.

343
00:17:42.810 --> 00:17:45.480
Technically speaking, again I don't want
to get too much into the weeds here.

344
00:17:45.480 --> 00:17:48.970
Technically speaking, a shade is
when you add black to a color and

345
00:17:48.970 --> 00:17:51.770
a tint is when you add white to a color.

346
00:17:51.770 --> 00:17:56.598
When you have a global swatch
in illustrator you can actually,

347
00:17:56.598 --> 00:17:58.704
very easily create a tint.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily discuss how to use and create pattern swatches.  They demonstrate how to create custom pattern swatches, edit existing pattern swatches, find pattern swatches in the swatch libraries, scaling swatches, and modify pattern to repeat on all sides.
episodes.title: Pattern Swatches
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.485
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.485 --> 00:00:10.882
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10.882 --> 00:00:12.020
Hello everyone, and

4
00:00:12.020 --> 00:00:15.382
welcome back to another exciting
addition of CreativeProTV.

5
00:00:15.382 --> 00:00:20.820
I'm your host Vonne Smith, and we're
continuing on with Illustrator CC 2017.

6
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:23.832
And we're gonna be talking
all about patterns.

7
00:00:23.832 --> 00:00:25.421
Yes, I had to sing it.

8
00:00:25.421 --> 00:00:28.467
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And here to help us is Ms.

9
00:00:28.467 --> 00:00:29.538
Emily Ramsey.

10
00:00:29.538 --> 00:00:30.305
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

11
00:00:30.305 --> 00:00:32.620
I feel like patterns are one of
those that you have to sing.

12
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:33.757
>> [LAUGH]
>> Every once in a while,

13
00:00:33.757 --> 00:00:35.423
you come across something in Illustrator.

14
00:00:35.423 --> 00:00:38.213
You're like,
I'm just that excited about it, right?

15
00:00:38.213 --> 00:00:42.366
>> Yeah, we haven't been excited
about anything in this whole show.

16
00:00:42.366 --> 00:00:44.418
>> [LAUGH] No, no,
Illustrator is so boring.

17
00:00:44.418 --> 00:00:45.351
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

18
00:00:45.351 --> 00:00:46.488
>> No, so I'm excited.

19
00:00:46.488 --> 00:00:50.445
We're gonna actually get in to
making some patterns in Illustrator.

20
00:00:50.445 --> 00:00:54.602
So you may have looked at or we may have
mentioned before some patterns swatches

21
00:00:54.602 --> 00:00:57.520
that are already
preexisting in Illustrator.

22
00:00:57.520 --> 00:01:00.920
And that's great, but won't it be more
fun if we could kind of create our own?

23
00:01:00.920 --> 00:01:03.210
So that's what we're getting into here.

24
00:01:03.210 --> 00:01:05.371
Now what I'm gonna start off with here.

25
00:01:05.371 --> 00:01:08.963
We're basically gonna go through
two different types of patterns.

26
00:01:08.963 --> 00:01:13.042
I'm gonna do one, but
I like to call my more organic pattern,

27
00:01:13.042 --> 00:01:15.562
which is just kind of free form shape.

28
00:01:15.562 --> 00:01:19.610
And then I'm gonna do another one,
where everything is kind of repeated and

29
00:01:19.610 --> 00:01:20.760
perfectly matched.

30
00:01:20.760 --> 00:01:23.349
So we're gonna start
with our organic pattern,

31
00:01:23.349 --> 00:01:26.220
because that's gonna be
a little bit easier.

32
00:01:26.220 --> 00:01:30.435
And so, when I say organic,
I'm not saying healthy.

33
00:01:30.435 --> 00:01:34.254
So I'm actually going to use
the example of creating sprinkles.

34
00:01:34.254 --> 00:01:36.720
You do not have to create sprinkles, okay?

35
00:01:36.720 --> 00:01:40.294
If that's not what you're feeling,
if you're on a diet, make something else.

36
00:01:40.294 --> 00:01:43.650
But I'm gonna go ahead and
use the example of sprinkles here.

37
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:46.400
So I'm gonna go ahead and
grab my rectangle tool.

38
00:01:46.400 --> 00:01:48.440
In case, you're wondering how
I'm gonna make a sprinkle.

39
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:51.350
I'm basically just gonna make
a couple rounded rectangles with some

40
00:01:51.350 --> 00:01:52.505
fancy colors on them.

41
00:01:52.505 --> 00:01:55.805
So I'm using the word sprinkles loosely.

42
00:01:55.805 --> 00:01:58.475
But what I can do here,
I'm gonna go in, I'm gonna zoom in.

43
00:01:58.475 --> 00:02:01.765
I could have used my Rounded Rectangle
Tool, but what I'm actually gonna do for

44
00:02:01.765 --> 00:02:06.295
no real apparent reason is just use
these little circles to drag in.

45
00:02:06.295 --> 00:02:08.235
You could have used your
Rounded Rectangle Tool.

46
00:02:08.235 --> 00:02:09.637
I just kind of like that better.

47
00:02:09.637 --> 00:02:12.448
And then I'm gonna go ahead and
just duplicate this over again.

48
00:02:12.448 --> 00:02:17.345
So rather than having to go through
the effort of actually re-drawing

49
00:02:17.345 --> 00:02:21.750
that sprinkle, I'm just gonna alt drag,
duplicate that up.

50
00:02:21.750 --> 00:02:25.010
And then I'm gonna start kinda
moving these little guys around.

51
00:02:25.010 --> 00:02:30.840
So maybe I'll have something that looks
like that, and drag another one over here.

52
00:02:30.840 --> 00:02:33.508
I mean, it kind of get them where I
like and then we can go through and

53
00:02:33.508 --> 00:02:34.662
change some colors as well.

54
00:02:34.662 --> 00:02:38.892
So don't think that, we're only
gonna have the yellow sprinkles.

55
00:02:38.892 --> 00:02:41.730
If you haven't been here by now,
you probably figured out we are making

56
00:02:41.730 --> 00:02:44.496
rainbows sprinkles, [LAUGH]
>> Rainbows, yay.

57
00:02:44.496 --> 00:02:48.830
>> [LAUGH] So yes, we're going
with the rainbow sprinkles here.

58
00:02:48.830 --> 00:02:50.759
I'm just gonna do something like this,

59
00:02:50.759 --> 00:02:53.551
I mean, I'm really not gonna
worry about perfecting it.

60
00:02:53.551 --> 00:02:59.090
I'm just gonna do Some random
sprinkly things, right?

61
00:03:00.130 --> 00:03:01.750
Sprinkly that's a word.

62
00:03:01.750 --> 00:03:06.130
So we'll do something that looks like
that, that may or may not end up

63
00:03:06.130 --> 00:03:09.680
looking so good, but we can always fix
it later, that's always an option.

64
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:14.340
So I'm gonna just call those sprinkles,
go here.

65
00:03:15.740 --> 00:03:18.710
Start adding some color on.

66
00:03:18.710 --> 00:03:23.730
So add some, I don't know what color that

episodes.description: Sharing is caring.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily discuss how to share swatches using the Creative Cloud libraries panel.  They also show other ways to share swatches, brushes, styles, and symbols across documents using user defined libraries.

And what you see here is, you want to

00:15:31.810 --> 00:15:33.155

[LAUGH]

[LAUGH] So we will take that.

00:15:41.910 --> 00:15:44.710
And you're going to see how it's going

00:15:44.710 --> 00:15:48.340
it's going to separate out your colors,
it's going to separate out your graphics.

00:15:48.340 --> 00:15:51.000
And then now, if I want to apply those,
I can go ahead and

00:15:53.240 --> 00:15:56.240
Likewise, I can drag and

So, that is just a fantastic

I'm not pulling out a vector graphic and

So that it is something that you

Nola it'll kind of let you know

>> Yeah, so

Again, I want to be able

it does translate it to-

because you can do a lot of same

things in In Design so if I had some

>> All right.

You could copy paste.

So yeah but I'd
>> Still definitely think you know my CC

Having to choose color swatches over and

I was telling her the example I have

Especially bouncing back and

So, I really think that it's something

CC libraries have continued to evolve.

it's something that will probably continue

00:17:33.660 --> 00:17:38.190
So maybe even that vectorizing thing will

363
00:17:38.190 --> 00:17:41.142

00:17:41.142 --> 00:17:41.680
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

[LAUGH] You know it's

And I also think that I'm

>> Yes.

376

Well, I think we're going to go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne demonstrate how to blend paths using the blend command.  They show how to use the blend tool, modify objects and paths in the blend, explore the blend options, and expand into individual paths.
episodes.title: Blend Tool
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:05.329
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.329 --> 00:00:11.434
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.434 --> 00:00:15.580
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting edition of CreativeProTV.

00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:16.820
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

00:00:16.820 --> 00:00:21.450

yes, Illustrator CC 2017.

6

And here to help us talk what

8

>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, right?

9

>> Yeah, yeah.
>> Okay, yeah.

10

11

>> If it's not, it is now.

12
00:00:29.148 --> 00:00:32.531
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:32.531 --> 00:00:34.495

18

So, basically, what the blend

So, I feel like the best way to actually

24

25

And I'm gonna grab them

26

So what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna go

27

28
00:01:19.785 --> 00:01:20.514
>> I know.
>> [LAUGH]

29

>> You saw me bypass that rectangle.

I thought about it, I kinda hovered,

we're doing stars, so.

32
00:01:26.495 --> 00:01:29.822
[LAUGH]
>> If you're not watching in order you're
