00:01:29.822 --> 00:01:30.595
like, okay.

34
00:01:30.595 --> 00:01:31.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

35
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:35.190
this is a huge departure

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

37

I pretty much stick with the rectangles.

38
00:01:38.536 --> 00:01:40.071
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

39
00:01:40.071 --> 00:01:41.254
>> So, while we're getting,

we're gonna jump into the star.

I'm gonna duplicate that over,

I've got my star and my star.

Now, what I wanna do is I wanna

Now, there are multiple different

00:03:50.840 --> 00:03:55.087

00:03:55.087 --> 00:03:57.153

But you could use the white too, I think,

you just have to watch that I

95
00:04:25.403 --> 00:04:28.188
>> Okay, yeah,
never would have thought about that.

Everybody has their own

But in some ways, I actually think

So we both like each other's methods here.

100

>> [LAUGH]
>> So yeah,

you can choose whatever

00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:04.380

And blend options are something you can

116
00:05:33.420 --> 00:05:34.450
It doesn't matter.

Cuz I had ten steps specified last time,

00:05:55.740 --> 00:06:01.250
So I'm constantly turning on my Blend

00:06:01.250 --> 00:06:02.675

00:06:02.675 --> 00:06:06.210
So I tend to use this

00:06:06.210 --> 00:06:07.830

00:06:08.890 --> 00:06:09.750

00:06:12.820 --> 00:06:15.590

00:06:20.240 --> 00:06:20.960

00:06:20.960 --> 00:06:26.900
I can go back into my blend option,

00:06:32.630 --> 00:06:34.548

138
00:06:34.548 --> 00:06:36.070
I'm gonna go ahead and set that to 10.

139
00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:37.850
And you can start to see here,

Something that I use

00:07:05.810 --> 00:07:07.810
These just here tend to get

00:07:07.810 --> 00:07:12.720
But if I did have some cool options

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne take a deeper look into character and paragraph formatting.  They cover kerning, tracking, leading, indents, space before and after, character and paragraph styles, and other typography elements.  They also cover more about area type with how to control overset text, thread text boxes, and create columns.
episodes.title: Advanced Text

episodes.description: Creating bullets in Illustrator is not as easy as clicking a button.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to create bullets using glyphs, indents, and tabs
episodes.title: Bullets and Numbering
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:05.399
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.399 --> 00:00:11.147
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.147 --> 00:00:14.506
Hello and welcome back to another
exciting edition of CreativePro.TV.

4
00:00:14.506 --> 00:00:19.643
I'm your host Vonne Smith and
this is our Illustrator cc 2017 series.

5
00:00:19.643 --> 00:00:25.430
And in this episode it's kind of a part
two, but it's not labeled as a part two.

6
00:00:25.430 --> 00:00:26.630
This is bullets and

7
00:00:26.630 --> 00:00:30.740
numbering cuz we're continuing on
from our advanced text episode.

8
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:33.590
Yeah, cuz bullets and
numbering they are weird little things.

9
00:00:33.590 --> 00:00:36.952
And here to help us talk about all
the weirdness is Ms. Emily Ramsey.

10
00:00:36.952 --> 00:00:37.637
Thank you so much.

11
00:00:37.637 --> 00:00:39.709
>> Yes, it shouldn't be that weird, right?

12
00:00:39.709 --> 00:00:40.297
>> Right?

13
00:00:40.297 --> 00:00:44.719
>> This one's kind of funny, because we
basically have an entire episode dedicated

14
00:00:44.719 --> 00:00:48.382
to the fact that Illustrator doesn't
have this natively built in.

15
00:00:48.382 --> 00:00:51.076
>> No, and it's like,
wer were talking about it.

16
00:00:51.076 --> 00:00:53.920
They gave us the crop tool in images.

17
00:00:53.920 --> 00:00:55.172
We can crop an image.

18
00:00:55.172 --> 00:00:56.778
I was like, yes, and this one's like,

19
00:00:56.778 --> 00:00:59.291
can't you just make a bullet
button where it's like, click.

20
00:00:59.291 --> 00:01:00.398
I want a bullet button.

21
00:01:00.398 --> 00:01:02.259
No, it's not that easy.

22
00:01:02.259 --> 00:01:05.100
It's way harder than it should be.

23
00:01:05.100 --> 00:01:07.517
>> Yes, yes, it's not hard.

24
00:01:07.517 --> 00:01:09.970
It's just way harder than it should be.

25
00:01:09.970 --> 00:01:11.051
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

26
00:01:11.051 --> 00:01:11.575
>> Yeah, so.

27
00:01:11.575 --> 00:01:12.123
>> Exactly.

28
00:01:12.123 --> 00:01:13.695
>> So let's talk about
what that looks like here.

29
00:01:13.695 --> 00:01:19.670
Bullets and numbering, not something that
natively exists in Illustrator, why?

30
00:01:19.670 --> 00:01:20.189
I don't know.

31
00:01:20.189 --> 00:01:23.804
You have that bullet button in many
other programs, or just numbering, and

32
00:01:23.804 --> 00:01:27.720
you can go ahead and click that and
everything will work out beautifully.

33
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:31.160
We're still gonna have a beautiful
end result here in Illustrator,

34
00:01:31.160 --> 00:01:34.020
we're just gonna have to kinda go about
it in a little bit funny of a way.

35
00:01:34.020 --> 00:01:36.090
So what I have here,
if you wanna go ahead and

36
00:01:36.090 --> 00:01:38.770
look at this,
I've basically built my grocery list.

37
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:42.940
So I really love me some fruit
basically is what I'm saying.

38
00:01:42.940 --> 00:01:46.100
So I've got a list here, and
you can basically, just go ahead and

39
00:01:46.100 --> 00:01:46.760
type something out.

40
00:01:46.760 --> 00:01:48.737
Anything that you would typically bullet,
right?

41
00:01:48.737 --> 00:01:51.183
Now, you'll see, okay,
I'm looking at my Character panel.

42
00:01:51.183 --> 00:01:53.532
I'm looking in Paragraph panel.

43
00:01:53.532 --> 00:01:55.325
[SOUND] I don't see any bullets.

44
00:01:55.325 --> 00:01:59.292
I don't see an option for that, not
an option that you have in Illustrator.

45
00:01:59.292 --> 00:02:01.110
So we have to kinda fake it.

46
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:03.034
Couple different ways
that you can do this.

47
00:02:03.034 --> 00:02:07.874
My personal favorite is just to use
the keyboard shortcut Alt or Option and

48
00:02:07.874 --> 00:02:10.850
the letter,
the letter [LAUGH] the number 8.

49
00:02:10.850 --> 00:02:17.110
So if I hit Alt+8 that's gonna go ahead
and add a bullet in there for me.

50
00:02:17.110 --> 00:02:17.910
So that's one option.

51
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:21.117
Second option, and I'll go ahead and
do that a couple times, Alt+8.

52
00:02:21.117 --> 00:02:23.896
>> And you're adding just
a single space after that?

53
00:02:23.896 --> 00:02:25.026
>> That's right, yes, yes.

54
00:02:25.026 --> 00:02:29.730
>> Okay, so if you wanted more space
between it, you could fake it and

55
00:02:29.730 --> 00:02:31.500
do a couple more spaces.

56
00:02:31.500 --> 00:02:35.468
Because we talked about this before the
episode, we're not gonna get in tabs, and

57
00:02:35.468 --> 00:02:36.728
tab software [CROSSTALK].

58
00:02:36.728 --> 00:02:40.386
So if you want more space just do
the thing we tell you not to do, space,

59
00:02:40.386 --> 00:02:42.133
space, space, space, space.

60
00:02:42.133 --> 00:02:43.403
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes,

61
00:02:43.403 --> 00:02:46.150
of course in our advanced text episode we
were like don't add additional spaces when

62
00:02:46.150 --> 00:02:48.174
you don't need to,
well here we're breaking our own rules.

63
00:02:48.174 --> 00:02:51.016
So I'm doing Alt+8, and
then I'm just adding a space.

64
00:02:51.016 --> 00:02:52.600
So we;ll do that kind of for
our first three.

65
00:02:52.600 --> 00:02:56.330
Now, our second option here
is to go into our glyphs.

66
00:02:56.330 --> 00:03:00.650
Now glyphs sound really crazy and
fancy, and they kind of are.

67
00:03:00.650 --> 00:03:02.590
So glyphs are gonna be basically a way for

68
00:03:02.590 --> 00:03:06.350
you to see kind of all the characters
that you have within a font.

69
00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:09.360
So I'm gonna go ahead and
pull up my Type menu.

70
00:03:09.360 --> 00:03:12.491
And then from there,
I'm gonna go to Glyphs.

71
00:03:12.491 --> 00:03:15.396
Now when you see, I pull this up.

72
00:03:15.396 --> 00:03:18.468
I'm searching the entire font.

73
00:03:18.468 --> 00:03:19.519
And I can see, okay,

74
00:03:19.519 --> 00:03:22.806
whoa I have all the special little
characters that I have in there.

75
00:03:22.806 --> 00:03:24.941
And you kinda look,
you see some crazy stuff.

76
00:03:24.941 --> 00:03:28.607
There's accent marks and
all that, that's great.

77
00:03:28.607 --> 00:03:31.044
If you ever need to know
how to add an accent mark.

78
00:03:31.044 --> 00:03:34.651
If you're doing something in French,
add all that.

79
00:03:34.651 --> 00:03:36.105
>> Or the umlauts.

80
00:03:36.105 --> 00:03:37.761
I love saying that.

81
00:03:37.761 --> 00:03:40.096
Umlaut, the two dots over the o or
the u's or whatever.

82
00:03:40.096 --> 00:03:44.831
Not to go too crazy off to, on the rails,
off the rails, on the rails,

83
00:03:44.831 --> 00:03:49.806
this is all part of the open type font and
every font is either an open type or

84
00:03:49.806 --> 00:03:54.493
two type and how many characters it
has within that particular font.

85
00:03:54.493 --> 00:03:57.798
The 65,536 characters that
are available for you.

86
00:03:57.798 --> 00:03:58.685
Yes, that it is true.

87
00:03:58.685 --> 00:04:05.632
And it allows for
all of these extra letters and things.

88
00:04:05.632 --> 00:04:08.970
So if you're picking a font, you go to
here it's like I don't see all this.

89
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:11.730
It's the nature of the font itself,

90
00:04:11.730 --> 00:04:16.115
if it allows for extended character
sets or anything to that effect.

91
00:04:16.115 --> 00:04:18.950
So just keep that in mind in
case you don't see anything, but

92
00:04:18.950 --> 00:04:22.500
I think we're gonna be going to
a different font anyway, as it may be.

93
00:04:22.500 --> 00:04:24.011
Like with the Webdings and the wink.

94
00:04:24.011 --> 00:04:27.051
[LAUGH] I'm not gonna go to the Wingdings,
but

95
00:04:27.051 --> 00:04:30.098
you can Wingding all day long,
I mean we can.

96
00:04:30.098 --> 00:04:32.762
[LAUGH]
>> Cuz the bullet doesn't have to be

97
00:04:32.762 --> 00:04:35.330
the same character as the font
that you're choosing.

98
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:37.126
>> Yes.
>> And that's why I want kitty cats for

99
00:04:37.126 --> 00:04:37.755
my bullets.

100
00:04:37.755 --> 00:04:42.396
Then you're gonna need to go into
the Webding or the Wingding font.

101
00:04:42.396 --> 00:04:43.034
>> Yes.

102
00:04:43.034 --> 00:04:46.572
>> That has those funny little
things like the kitty cats.

103
00:04:46.572 --> 00:04:47.654
[LAUGH]
>> You know I heard

104
00:04:47.654 --> 00:04:50.132
you say something about kitty cats
before this episode and I was like,

105
00:04:50.132 --> 00:04:51.607
I don't know what she's talking about.

106
00:04:51.607 --> 00:04:54.832
But yes, you could go into your
Wingdings and you could grab,

107
00:04:54.832 --> 00:04:56.890
I could have a peace sign for my bullet.

108
00:04:56.890 --> 00:04:58.659
[LAUGH]
>> I pick that one too a lot.

109
00:04:58.659 --> 00:04:59.636
The yin yang, yeah.

110
00:04:59.636 --> 00:05:01.754
>> Why not?

111
00:05:01.754 --> 00:05:03.068
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's like we're the same brain.

112
00:05:03.068 --> 00:05:06.917
>> See,
I was just gonna go into my Open Sans and

113
00:05:06.917 --> 00:05:09.588
pick this little guy-
>> [LAUGH]

114
00:05:09.588 --> 00:05:10.906
>> That looks like a bullet but

115
00:05:10.906 --> 00:05:12.173
I like the peace sign too.

116
00:05:12.173 --> 00:05:13.529
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's pretty cool.

117
00:05:13.529 --> 00:05:16.634
Once you find it, peace sign,
kitty cat, plain old bullet,

118
00:05:16.634 --> 00:05:20.530
whatever you want to use just double-click
to go ahead and add that in there.

119
00:05:20.530 --> 00:05:24.733
>> Just to notice where we found the
Wingdings, it's on the bottom like that's

120
00:05:24.733 --> 00:05:26.390
the font picker down-
>> Yes.

121
00:05:26.390 --> 00:05:28.240
>> At the bottom where it says Open Sans.

122
00:05:28.240 --> 00:05:31.610
You could change that to any font really.

123
00:05:31.610 --> 00:05:34.516
And then be able to use
their character sets or

124
00:05:34.516 --> 00:05:37.122
the different glyphs that live in here.

125
00:05:37.122 --> 00:05:40.840
So if you wanted a diamond, you know,
that's not as crazy as a kitty cat.

126
00:05:40.840 --> 00:05:41.675
We could use a diamond.

127
00:05:41.675 --> 00:05:46.225
[LAUGH] And so you can go into those
different fonts that might have a little

128
00:05:46.225 --> 00:05:47.948
bit of funness added to it.

129
00:05:47.948 --> 00:05:49.013
Yep, I said funness.

130
00:05:49.013 --> 00:05:50.987
[LAUGH]
>> You did.

131
00:05:50.987 --> 00:05:52.675
>> So just,
that's how I usually go with it.

132
00:05:52.675 --> 00:05:53.185
>> You went there.

133
00:05:53.185 --> 00:05:53.732
>> I did.

134
00:05:53.732 --> 00:05:55.019
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

135
00:05:55.019 --> 00:05:58.600
you can go with whatever you
find that you wanna work with.

136
00:05:58.600 --> 00:06:02.119
And this is actually kinda helpful too
cuz you can see it comes with registered

137
00:06:02.119 --> 00:06:04.393
copyright symbols,
things that you need to add,

138
00:06:04.393 --> 00:06:06.740
we get little extra fun
facts in here with this one.

139
00:06:06.740 --> 00:06:09.294
So I'm gonna go ahead and
double-click and add another.

140
00:06:09.294 --> 00:06:13.941
>> You do that out to me because that
in Word is Insert Special Character and

141
00:06:13.941 --> 00:06:17.819
that's where you can get the trademark and
the copyright.

142
00:06:17.819 --> 00:06:20.639
If you were looking for that,
like I need to put in a copyright.

143
00:06:20.639 --> 00:06:24.883
Because you're a part of the company
that this is what it is,

144
00:06:24.883 --> 00:06:29.225
you go to the Glyphs panel to be
able to type that character in.

145
00:06:29.225 --> 00:06:31.385
So I'm glad you threw that out and

146
00:06:31.385 --> 00:06:34.483
just keeping on with my
little comments [LAUGH].

147
00:06:34.483 --> 00:06:37.270
>> Just dropping down some extra
knowledge in this episode, right.

148
00:06:37.270 --> 00:06:41.775
So you have these options, one thing I
noticed, it's kinda weird with the glyphs.

149
00:06:41.775 --> 00:06:45.592
I'm just doing a single space here and
it almost looks like a tab.

150
00:06:45.592 --> 00:06:48.638
Yeah, so that can get you a little.

151
00:06:48.638 --> 00:06:52.380
>> Yeah, and I'm sure usually you're gonna
have your bullets be consistent across

152
00:06:52.380 --> 00:06:53.745
the paragraphs or whatever.

153
00:06:53.745 --> 00:07:00.256
But the Webdings and Wingdings do
give you these weird massive spaces.

154
00:07:00.256 --> 00:07:03.424
I think it's because of-
>> It's the tracking.

155
00:07:03.424 --> 00:07:07.465
>> Yeah, or where the character
actually occupies that space?

156
00:07:07.465 --> 00:07:09.046
Maybe it's a mono space font.

157
00:07:09.046 --> 00:07:11.092
I'm actually going deeper into
things that I don't know.

158
00:07:11.092 --> 00:07:11.674
>> I think it is.

159
00:07:11.674 --> 00:07:13.641
I was gonnago in there.

160
00:07:13.641 --> 00:07:17.198
I think it's a mono space font which
means there's a lot of space between each

161
00:07:17.198 --> 00:07:17.806
character.

162
00:07:17.806 --> 00:07:22.116
So our Wingdings get a little funny,
basically is what I'm saying.

163
00:07:22.116 --> 00:07:24.110
But, you know, whatever.

164
00:07:24.110 --> 00:07:26.267
If you wanted to you could adjust
the kerning or something like that.

165
00:07:26.267 --> 00:07:28.220
You wanna kinda get back into that.

166
00:07:28.220 --> 00:07:29.950
Now one thing I did
also want to point out.

167
00:07:29.950 --> 00:07:35.190
You'll notice there's a slight difference
between that Alt+8 option I chose and

168
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:39.010
the glyphs option,
these are a little bit smaller bullets, so

169
00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:40.800
maybe it's just something
you wanna look at.

170
00:07:40.800 --> 00:07:42.340
It kinda depends on what you wanna use.

171
00:07:42.340 --> 00:07:46.940
But one thing I do like that Alt+8 option
for is that you can use it anywhere.

172
00:07:46.940 --> 00:07:49.000
So sometimes I'll use it
in the middle of type.

173
00:07:49.000 --> 00:07:50.920
I know I'm getting on
a little bit of a tangent.

174
00:07:50.920 --> 00:07:57.070
But I'll go here and
I'll say Bananas, Alt+8, Apples.

175
00:07:57.070 --> 00:07:59.400
So sometimes if you wanna kinda
separate things out that way,

176
00:07:59.400 --> 00:08:01.380
it makes it a little bit easier for you.

177
00:08:01.380 --> 00:08:05.230
So just an extra, again,
just dropping all kinds of knowledge here.

178
00:08:05.230 --> 00:08:08.460
So that's basically gonna
be our way to fake this,

179
00:08:08.460 --> 00:08:12.010
now one thing that I wanted to point
out in terms of kind of spacing.

180
00:08:12.010 --> 00:08:13.380
So I know and

181
00:08:13.380 --> 00:08:16.370
Vonne knows where I'm going with this cuz
it's probably a pet peeve for both of us.

182
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:19.220
What if you have a bullet
that falls onto two lines?

183
00:08:19.220 --> 00:08:25.243
So I'm gonna say grapes are my favorite
fruit, and see what happens here?

184
00:08:25.243 --> 00:08:28.362
Ignore the hyphenations, we can turn
that off, that's pretty easy to fix.

185
00:08:28.362 --> 00:08:29.794
>> [LAUGH] Sorry.

186
00:08:29.794 --> 00:08:31.969
>> Are you laughing at grapes
being my favorite fruit?

187
00:08:31.969 --> 00:08:35.424
>> Well, it says grapes my
are favorite fruit [LAUGH].

188
00:08:35.424 --> 00:08:37.229
>> [LAUGH] Whatever.

189
00:08:37.229 --> 00:08:39.553
>> I come out here like,
>> [LAUGH]

190
00:08:39.553 --> 00:08:41.024
>> She'll catch it, okay, no,

191
00:08:41.024 --> 00:08:41.822
I'll tell her.

192
00:08:41.822 --> 00:08:43.372
>> No, no, she's not catching it.

193
00:08:43.372 --> 00:08:44.477
She's just going with it.

194
00:08:44.477 --> 00:08:47.188
Again, we see where my strengths lie.

195
00:08:47.188 --> 00:08:51.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> Grapes are my favorite fruit.

196
00:08:51.040 --> 00:08:54.520
And now, when I look at this, that text,

197
00:08:54.520 --> 00:08:57.660
that word favorite,
is falling below the bullet.

198
00:08:57.660 --> 00:09:02.100
That's something that typography
really just a big no no.

199
00:09:02.100 --> 00:09:05.010
You always wanna try and
keep that clean line as best you can.

200
00:09:05.010 --> 00:09:08.077
You want all your text to line up, and
you want all your bullets to line up.

201
00:09:08.077 --> 00:09:10.536
You don't want this one kinda
getting in the way of things.

202
00:09:10.536 --> 00:09:13.692
So how are we gonna kind
of fake that spacing?

203
00:09:13.692 --> 00:09:16.564
What we have to do is,
we have to go into our Paragraph panel.

204
00:09:16.564 --> 00:09:18.017
However you wanna do it,
I'm clicking up here.

205
00:09:18.017 --> 00:09:19.562
I also have my Paragraph panel open.

206
00:09:19.562 --> 00:09:26.843
And what you can do I believe, okay,
positive first line indent, negative, yes.

207
00:09:26.843 --> 00:09:31.243
So positive left indent rather,
negative first line indent.

208
00:09:31.243 --> 00:09:32.652
It's weird, I know.

209
00:09:32.652 --> 00:09:34.840
We said this was gonna be weird,
and it is.

210
00:09:34.840 --> 00:09:40.500
>> Well it moves everything in,
so it indents into the left.

211
00:09:40.500 --> 00:09:43.470
And then you want that
first line to come out.

212
00:09:43.470 --> 00:09:45.285
And what you do is you
just play around with it.

213
00:09:45.285 --> 00:09:49.301
There's no actual exact numberings
of if it’s a positive nine,

214
00:09:49.301 --> 00:09:50.768
it’s a negative nine.

215
00:09:50.768 --> 00:09:55.935
No, you just kinda line it up visually
of where does that word grape start and

216
00:09:55.935 --> 00:09:58.923
then the next line which
would be favorite,

217
00:09:58.923 --> 00:10:02.417
how does that line up enough
visually to look good?

218
00:10:02.417 --> 00:10:03.984
And then that's where you go.

219
00:10:03.984 --> 00:10:07.255
Just keep on going left and
keep on going negative first and

220
00:10:07.255 --> 00:10:09.204
you'll line them up eventually.

221
00:10:09.204 --> 00:10:09.809
>> You will get there.

222
00:10:09.809 --> 00:10:13.269
Yeah, I'm sorry, while you were
talking I had to get rid of the-

223
00:10:13.269 --> 00:10:14.470
>> Okay.

224
00:10:14.470 --> 00:10:15.841
>> It was kinda the line.

225
00:10:15.841 --> 00:10:18.541
>> [LAUGH]
>> Gotta stay consistent.

226
00:10:18.541 --> 00:10:20.044
>> Yeah, yeah, I can't do it.

227
00:10:20.044 --> 00:10:21.893
[LAUGH] I can't do it anymore.

228
00:10:21.893 --> 00:10:26.741
So what you'll see here is that that kind
of gives the illusion that all these

229
00:10:26.741 --> 00:10:28.950
are in a perfectly straight line.

230
00:10:28.950 --> 00:10:33.170
So basically we are giving the illusion
that we had a bullet button and

231
00:10:33.170 --> 00:10:36.190
doing something that you know another
program would have done for us.

232
00:10:36.190 --> 00:10:39.880
So again, if you want to do that you're
gonna wanna make sure that you go into

233
00:10:39.880 --> 00:10:41.260
your Paragraph panel.

234
00:10:41.260 --> 00:10:44.900
You wanna go to a positive left indent
which is just that first option and

235
00:10:44.900 --> 00:10:47.070
then some sort of negative first line and

236
00:10:47.070 --> 00:10:50.340
exactly what Vonne said,
there's no real set option.

237
00:10:50.340 --> 00:10:54.423
I can't tell you that it's always gonna
be positive five, negative seven.

238
00:10:54.423 --> 00:10:57.353
It's gonna change
depending on what you need.

239
00:10:57.353 --> 00:10:59.458
>> And the font size and all that stuff.

240
00:10:59.458 --> 00:11:05.121
And another big point to note is if you
enter off of your bullet like in a regular

241
00:11:05.121 --> 00:11:10.105
word or whatever program that's like,
the bullet button is on.

242
00:11:10.105 --> 00:11:12.505
Cuz it is a paragraph level formatting.

243
00:11:12.505 --> 00:11:16.100
You would enter and it keeps on bulleting,
keeps on numbering.

244
00:11:16.100 --> 00:11:19.050
You'd go back and delete one and
you change the other number and

245
00:11:19.050 --> 00:11:21.080
it just keeps on continuing.

246
00:11:21.080 --> 00:11:22.470
That doesn't happen here.

247
00:11:22.470 --> 00:11:25.970
You have to manually copy

248
00:11:25.970 --> 00:11:30.030
the paragraph with the bullet character,
with your spacing.

249
00:11:30.030 --> 00:11:31.840
Then go ahead and change out the text.

250
00:11:31.840 --> 00:11:33.981
It doesn't work,
yeah your numbering right here.

251
00:11:33.981 --> 00:11:35.612
She's manually typing.

252
00:11:35.612 --> 00:11:39.571
>> I'm manually typing in the number
three, and I'm gonna go here,

253
00:11:39.571 --> 00:11:43.176
manually type in, or just skip it,
manually type in kiwi and

254
00:11:43.176 --> 00:11:46.447
now let's say I wanna go ahead and
add something here.

255
00:11:46.447 --> 00:11:48.987
I'm basically just visually
doing what Vonne was saying.

256
00:11:48.987 --> 00:11:50.932
If I wanna go ahead and
add something here,

257
00:11:50.932 --> 00:11:52.669
note it's not adding a number for me.

258
00:11:52.669 --> 00:11:54.796
I have to go in here and say find three.

259
00:11:54.796 --> 00:11:57.830
I need grapes to be the third one.

260
00:11:57.830 --> 00:11:59.976
Then I have to go in here and
change the number.

261
00:11:59.976 --> 00:12:02.630
So there's just nothing auto about it.

262
00:12:02.630 --> 00:12:05.951
>> Yeah, and we put the title of
the episode as Bullets and Numbering and

263
00:12:05.951 --> 00:12:10.199
we were talking like there is no numbering
it's just another alpha numeric character.

264
00:12:10.199 --> 00:12:13.536
It's a manual thing, so you don't
have to go to the Glyphs panel or

265
00:12:13.536 --> 00:12:17.348
anything fancy with that just know you
can do your spacing in the first line,

266
00:12:17.348 --> 00:12:18.793
positive and the negative.

267
00:12:18.793 --> 00:12:23.145
Wait no, positive left negative
first to do all your spacing for

268
00:12:23.145 --> 00:12:26.060
multiple lines, but it is full on manual.

269
00:12:26.060 --> 00:12:27.739
There is no tricks there.

270
00:12:27.739 --> 00:12:30.023
You gotta do it all by yourself.

271
00:12:30.023 --> 00:12:30.685
>> Yeah.

272
00:12:30.685 --> 00:12:33.983
>> Not so much fun, but it happens, so.

273
00:12:33.983 --> 00:12:35.833
[LAUGH]
>> We don't often tell you you have to do

274
00:12:35.833 --> 00:12:36.780
things the old fashioned way.

275
00:12:36.780 --> 00:12:38.262
>> [LAUGH]
>> So this is kind of like the one time in

276
00:12:38.262 --> 00:12:40.385
Illustrator you have to do
something the old fashioned way.

277
00:12:40.385 --> 00:12:42.994
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah definitely, and it is one of those

278
00:12:42.994 --> 00:12:46.426
things where it does trip people up
of why can't I do a bolded list?

279
00:12:46.426 --> 00:12:48.158
Cuz they don't have it.

280
00:12:48.158 --> 00:12:49.008
>> All right.

281
00:12:49.008 --> 00:12:51.814
>> I think that covers pretty
much everything, right?

282
00:12:51.814 --> 00:12:52.537
>> Yes, yes.

283
00:12:52.537 --> 00:12:56.724
>> We got the glyphs and we did the
spacing and we totally skipped over tabs,

284
00:12:56.724 --> 00:12:58.103
which was a good thing.

285
00:12:58.103 --> 00:13:03.108
I love me some tab stops, but I think it's
a little out of the scope of this one.

286
00:13:03.108 --> 00:13:05.463
And you'll actually probably thank us, so.

287
00:13:05.463 --> 00:13:07.595
>> [LAUGH]
>> You don't wanna know.

288
00:13:07.595 --> 00:13:08.141
>> Yeah.

289
00:13:08.141 --> 00:13:10.580
[LAUGH]
>> All right, well I think that's good for

290
00:13:10.580 --> 00:13:11.296
this episode.

291
00:13:11.296 --> 00:13:12.631
And now you know how to do it.

292
00:13:12.631 --> 00:13:14.529
And we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

293
00:13:14.529 --> 00:13:17.182
Signing off for CreativePro TV.

294
00:13:17.182 --> 00:13:18.009
I'm your host Vonne Smith.

295
00:13:18.009 --> 00:13:19.114
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

296
00:13:19.114 --> 00:13:20.057
>> An we'll see you soon.

297
00:13:20.057 --> 00:13:27.959
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne show how to use some lesser known tools for editing paths, specifically the eraser, knife, and scissors tool. They explain best practices for when and how to use these tools and some other techniques to manipulate closed and open paths.
episodes.title: Knife Eraser Sissors
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.688
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.688 --> 00:00:11.176
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.176 --> 00:00:15.330
Hello everyone and welcome to another
exciting edition of CREATIVE ProTV.

4
00:00:15.330 --> 00:00:19.650
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and
this is Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:19.650 --> 00:00:23.530
And in this episode we're doing knife,
eraser, scissors.

6
00:00:23.530 --> 00:00:25.625
Yes, we had too much fun with this title.

7
00:00:25.625 --> 00:00:30.500
[LAUGH] And here to help us cover those
exact things is Ms. Emily Ramsey.

8
00:00:30.500 --> 00:00:31.110
>> Hello.

9
00:00:31.110 --> 00:00:34.430
All right,
do we need to start with like, yeah.

10
00:00:34.430 --> 00:00:35.173
Hollywood job.

11
00:00:35.173 --> 00:00:37.251
[LAUGH]
>> I know, of course.

12
00:00:37.251 --> 00:00:39.818
[LAUGH] Yeah,
before the show we were just like,

13
00:00:39.818 --> 00:00:43.741
cuz those are the tools that we're
going to be covering in this episode.

14
00:00:43.741 --> 00:00:46.530
And we're like, so
what should we name this cutting?

15
00:00:46.530 --> 00:00:49.530
That sounds like, no,
cuz we are cutting paths.

16
00:00:49.530 --> 00:00:51.400
We didn't know what to say and

17
00:00:51.400 --> 00:00:56.500
then we just had way too much fun
coming up with knife, eraser, scissors.

18
00:00:56.500 --> 00:00:58.815
>> There will be a tournament at the end.

19
00:00:58.815 --> 00:01:01.030
[LAUGH] All right so
what are we doing here?

20
00:01:01.030 --> 00:01:03.910
Basically we're finding
different ways to cut paths.

21
00:01:03.910 --> 00:01:09.300
So if you want to, no pun intended,
cut out using the ad anchor point tool or

22
00:01:09.300 --> 00:01:11.390
delete anchor point tool or
any of those things,

23
00:01:11.390 --> 00:01:14.545
there are also some other options
available to you in Illustrator.

24
00:01:14.545 --> 00:01:16.630
So, such as our eraser scissors knife.

25
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:18.860
So what we're gonna do,
I'm gonna go ahead and hop in here.

26
00:01:18.860 --> 00:01:20.800
I have a couple shapes already created.

27
00:01:20.800 --> 00:01:23.790
I through these out here especially for
Vonne cuz she makes fun of me,

28
00:01:23.790 --> 00:01:25.110
I always go to the rectangle tool.

29
00:01:25.110 --> 00:01:28.110
So we're doing a polygon and a star.

30
00:01:28.110 --> 00:01:29.132
>> Whoa, polygon.

31
00:01:29.132 --> 00:01:29.945
>> I know, I know.

32
00:01:29.945 --> 00:01:31.710
[LAUGH]
>> Crazy.

33
00:01:31.710 --> 00:01:33.990
>> I'm really mixing it up guys, okay.

34
00:01:33.990 --> 00:01:37.030
So what we're going to do,
we're going to start off with this, and

35
00:01:37.030 --> 00:01:40.390
I'm going to go ahead and
grab my eraser tool first.

36
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:43.862
I'm going in opposite order of our knife,
whatever we said.

37
00:01:43.862 --> 00:01:44.843
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

38
00:01:44.843 --> 00:01:47.849
what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna go
ahead with my eraser tool first.

39
00:01:48.875 --> 00:01:52.650
Eraser tool one, again, you know, you've
kind of seen this in some other things but

40
00:01:52.650 --> 00:01:53.690
I can use my right and

41
00:01:53.690 --> 00:01:56.750
left bracket keys on my keyboard
to make this larger or smaller.

42
00:01:56.750 --> 00:02:00.360
So you can kind of see that preview
of the diameter there with that.

43
00:02:00.360 --> 00:02:02.835
I'm gonna go ahead and
use my right arrow key to make, or

44
00:02:02.835 --> 00:02:05.785
right bracket key rather,
to make that a little bit larger,

45
00:02:05.785 --> 00:02:07.355
left bracket key to make
it a little bit smaller.

46
00:02:07.355 --> 00:02:10.605
And what we do with our eraser tool,
you can kinda just imagine

47
00:02:10.605 --> 00:02:14.910
erasing something with a pencil,
you can kinda just swipe through that.

48
00:02:14.910 --> 00:02:16.050
You can go ahead and erase it.

49
00:02:16.050 --> 00:02:18.270
Now you'll notice that
I put a stroke on this.

50
00:02:18.270 --> 00:02:21.590
I put a stroke on this for a reason,
so that you can see when I

51
00:02:21.590 --> 00:02:26.520
use the eraser tool, it's gonna maintain
the characteristics of my shape.

52
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:29.900
That's gonna come into play a little
bit later, cuz you'll see how

53
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:33.190
something like your scissors tool
might work a little bit differently.

54
00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:35.840
And basically here you can go ahead and
just keep swiping.

55
00:02:35.840 --> 00:02:39.021
Now also note how it's adding points for
us.

56
00:02:39.021 --> 00:02:43.117
So you'll see here I have all of these
additional points added that I could go

57
00:02:43.117 --> 00:02:47.149
with my white arrow tool, and maybe
I'll adjust the stroke color on this so

58
00:02:47.149 --> 00:02:49.500
you guys can see it a little better.

59
00:02:49.500 --> 00:02:51.180
I can go here and

60
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:55.310
I can adjust all of those additional
points that are now added for me.

61
00:02:55.310 --> 00:02:59.450
So that's kind of a nice thing
that the eraser tool does for us.

62
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:02.470
>> And those are now individual shapes,
right?

63
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:05.500
If we went to the black arrow tool and
moved that, yeah, that's separate,

64
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:09.820
that's separate cuz you basically
erased all the way through, in a sense.

65
00:03:09.820 --> 00:03:12.700
Yeah, we got that extra little-
>> [INAUDIBLE] that

66
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:13.695
disappeared, I'm sorry.

67
00:03:13.695 --> 00:03:16.600
>> [LAUGH] It's those kinda gremlins,
I call it,

68
00:03:16.600 --> 00:03:18.592
they kinda leave little tidbits here.

69
00:03:18.592 --> 00:03:21.830
>> Yeah [LAUGH].
>> But those are individual paths, or

70
00:03:21.830 --> 00:03:27.850
closed paths, shapes now that you can edit
individually that go, yeah, that way.

71
00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:31.350
So just making sure you know it's not
a group, it's not a compound path or

72
00:03:31.350 --> 00:03:35.370
anything else that we've kind of gone
through in the sequence of these episodes.

73
00:03:35.370 --> 00:03:38.740
They're individual shapes, and
I've used this eraser to do just that.

74
00:03:38.740 --> 00:03:40.620
>> Yeah.
>> Kind of free form cut out,

75
00:03:40.620 --> 00:03:47.155
if you want to say, individual shapes from
one starting, what was that thing called?

76
00:03:47.155 --> 00:03:47.927
A polygon, right?

77
00:03:47.927 --> 00:03:48.915
>> Oh,yeah.
[LAUGH]

78
00:03:48.915 --> 00:03:50.005
>> That shaped thing [LAUGH].

79
00:03:50.005 --> 00:03:51.820
>> This is a quiz, what is she asking?

80
00:03:51.820 --> 00:03:53.259
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, but no, exactly.

81
00:03:53.259 --> 00:03:57.147
So when I went ahead and I changed
the stroke color, I selected all of them,

82
00:03:57.147 --> 00:03:58.710
I didn't just selected one.

83
00:03:58.710 --> 00:04:00.480
It wasn't a group or anything like that.

84
00:04:00.480 --> 00:04:03.710
These are all now individually shapes
with their own individual points.

85
00:04:03.710 --> 00:04:07.790
And again, note how it maintains
the characteristics of my original shape.

86
00:04:07.790 --> 00:04:11.080
So it kept that stroke color,
basically was what I'm saying, and

87
00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:13.200
added a stroke to all of our new shapes.

88
00:04:13.200 --> 00:04:15.610
So that's one thing with the eraser tool.

89
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:19.760
Now, I think I may kind of either
start with a new shape or,

90
00:04:19.760 --> 00:04:22.730
this one's too far gone I feel like for
me to use again.

91
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:27.040
So let me go ahead and make a new polygon,
and I may even use this star here for

92
00:04:27.040 --> 00:04:28.390
this next example.

93
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:30.600
I want to go into our path eraser tool.

94
00:04:30.600 --> 00:04:34.464
Now are path eraser tool is not
necessarily in the same category as our

95
00:04:34.464 --> 00:04:36.140
eraser, scissors, knife.

96
00:04:36.140 --> 00:04:39.272
So you see if you hover over, or
click and hold rather, on your eraser

97
00:04:39.272 --> 00:04:43.390
tool you get the scissors and the knife
and it's all neatly packaged together.

98
00:04:43.390 --> 00:04:46.630
But I wanna bring up the path eraser
tool now just because it has the word

99
00:04:46.630 --> 00:04:47.600
eraser in it.

100
00:04:47.600 --> 00:04:52.490
I feel like it's something that could be
kind of misleading, not misleading, but

101
00:04:52.490 --> 00:04:54.500
I feel like it just kind
of ties together basically.

102
00:04:54.500 --> 00:04:57.360
So what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna
go ahead and grab that star here.

103
00:04:57.360 --> 00:04:59.540
I want to use this as an example.

104
00:04:59.540 --> 00:05:02.770
Our path eraser tool is actually
hidden underneath our shaper tool.

105
00:05:02.770 --> 00:05:05.550
So I'm gonna click and
hold on my shaper tool.

106
00:05:05.550 --> 00:05:09.260
Remember way way back to that
pencil smooth, things like that?

107
00:05:09.260 --> 00:05:11.610
I'm gonna go ahead and
grab this path eraser.

108
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:15.240
It basically actually just looks like
a pencil kinda upside down there.

109
00:05:15.240 --> 00:05:16.620
So I'm gonna grab that path eraser.

110
00:05:16.620 --> 00:05:20.560
Now your path eraser just erases paths.

111
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:23.650
So what we're gonna do,
if I go ahead and slide right here, and

112
00:05:23.650 --> 00:05:25.530
you'll see I actually need to go back and
select that.

113
00:05:25.530 --> 00:05:27.580
At some point, it came unselected.

114
00:05:27.580 --> 00:05:30.480
It's just going to erase where my path is.

115
00:05:30.480 --> 00:05:33.290
So if I kinda glide that around here,
it doesn't have to be perfect.

116
00:05:33.290 --> 00:05:36.060
You see how that blue
path outline went away?

117
00:05:36.060 --> 00:05:40.150
It may not really look that different now,
but look if I go ahead and

118
00:05:40.150 --> 00:05:42.350
I just convert this to a stroke.

119
00:05:42.350 --> 00:05:45.090
I'll even make this a little bit darker so
you can see it.

120
00:05:45.090 --> 00:05:47.240
I'm missing that path.

121
00:05:47.240 --> 00:05:49.200
So it kinda just takes it away.

122
00:05:49.200 --> 00:05:53.200
Again, just gonna depend on what you
need or what you you're trying to do.

123
00:05:53.200 --> 00:05:55.956
And certainly as I go through and
erase more paths,

124
00:05:55.956 --> 00:05:59.750
I'll maybe make that fill again, you're
gonna start to see some wonky things.

125
00:05:59.750 --> 00:06:03.060
So it's gonna take my star,
and kinda go like that.

126
00:06:03.060 --> 00:06:05.705
It's something that you can use
any time you just need to be like,

127
00:06:05.705 --> 00:06:09.820
you just need to get rid of that one
path a little bit individually there.

128
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:13.320
I don't need to go full
the way into my eraser tool,

129
00:06:13.320 --> 00:06:15.860
I just need to get rid of
that one little piece.

130
00:06:15.860 --> 00:06:20.080
So you can kinda keep working with it and
see how it adjusts as you go.

131
00:06:20.080 --> 00:06:23.310
>> Well, when we first started this
episode she's like, the path eraser tool.

132
00:06:23.310 --> 00:06:24.410
I'm like, wait, what?

133
00:06:24.410 --> 00:06:26.330
I forgot about this, yeah.

134
00:06:26.330 --> 00:06:31.490
But just to remind myself,
it's erasing from point to point.

135
00:06:31.490 --> 00:06:35.000
On that star,
could you erase half of that?

136
00:06:35.000 --> 00:06:35.840
>> Yes.
>> You can, okay.

137
00:06:35.840 --> 00:06:40.440
I thought it's very much like
a regular eraser on your pencil, but

138
00:06:40.440 --> 00:06:45.000
you're saying just different than
the eraser that went though the cloud.

139
00:06:45.000 --> 00:06:49.550
But for lack of a better terms,
this is just the stroke, just the path.

140
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:54.117
It doesn't have anything really to do
with the fill, it's the path itself.

141
00:06:54.117 --> 00:06:56.035
>> Right.
>> It erases fully, not make,

142
00:06:56.035 --> 00:06:59.647
the other one almost made another
path where the eraser kind of went

143
00:06:59.647 --> 00:07:01.055
through everything.

144
00:07:01.055 --> 00:07:03.445
>> Exactly, exactly,
this is just taking apart a path.

145
00:07:03.445 --> 00:07:04.945
And I think that was a great point to add,

146
00:07:04.945 --> 00:07:09.040
that it will only erase the part
of the path that you want to.

147
00:07:09.040 --> 00:07:11.360
You don't have to go fully
from point to point.

148
00:07:11.360 --> 00:07:14.830
I can have something here where I just
kind of went in between like that.

149
00:07:14.830 --> 00:07:15.846
>> Point to add.

150
00:07:15.846 --> 00:07:17.953
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sorry, sorry,

151
00:07:17.953 --> 00:07:22.137
I'm over here laughing at
myself like that's so funny.

152
00:07:22.137 --> 00:07:23.088
>> She's got jokes.

153
00:07:23.088 --> 00:07:25.122
>> We're erasing and she said point.

154
00:07:25.122 --> 00:07:26.406
[LAUGH] Sorry.

155
00:07:26.406 --> 00:07:31.291
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, moving on.

156
00:07:31.291 --> 00:07:32.203
No, I'm just kidding.

157
00:07:32.203 --> 00:07:36.631
All right, so you can see here,
I feel like I've just made a logo for

158
00:07:36.631 --> 00:07:39.690
a rock band with my cool star,
so we have that.

159
00:07:39.690 --> 00:07:43.296
I'm making fun of Vonne for her jokes and
then I'm like, I just make something for

160
00:07:43.296 --> 00:07:44.195
a rock band, yeah.

161
00:07:44.195 --> 00:07:45.736
>> I'm like,
that's totally what it looks like.

162
00:07:45.736 --> 00:07:49.650
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so yeah,

163
00:07:49.650 --> 00:07:51.120
we're pretty cool.

164
00:07:51.120 --> 00:07:52.590
>> Professional faces.

165
00:07:52.590 --> 00:07:53.865
Professional faces now.

166
00:07:53.865 --> 00:07:57.430
>> [LAUGH] We'll go ahead but
we'll reign it back in.

167
00:07:57.430 --> 00:08:00.040
And I want to talk about
our scissors tool.

168
00:08:00.040 --> 00:08:02.440
You know what, maybe I am going to
keep the star up in case I decide to

169
00:08:02.440 --> 00:08:02.960
use it later.

170
00:08:02.960 --> 00:08:06.150
So our scissors tool is gonna
be a little bit different.

171
00:08:06.150 --> 00:08:09.580
I feel that out of these,
the erase, scissors, knife,

172
00:08:09.580 --> 00:08:14.780
the scissors are the most
easily messed up, if you will.

173
00:08:14.780 --> 00:08:16.180
I'm not gonna say complicated.

174
00:08:16.180 --> 00:08:17.810
But the way the scissors

175
00:08:19.050 --> 00:08:23.140
tool works is you basically have to
select one point and select another.

176
00:08:23.140 --> 00:08:26.110
So if you think about
actually using scissors,

177
00:08:26.110 --> 00:08:30.150
you can kind of just pick your
start point and your end point.

178
00:08:30.150 --> 00:08:36.950
So if I wanna cut from here to here,
I'm gonna single click on each point.

179
00:08:36.950 --> 00:08:40.480
That start where I'm kind of cutting in,
and then the end where I'm cutting out.

180
00:08:40.480 --> 00:08:43.177
Now it looks like nothing happened,
hopefully something did.

181
00:08:43.177 --> 00:08:46.300
[LAUGH] It's always like,
she did it right, she did it right.

182
00:08:46.300 --> 00:08:50.140
And you see what happens is that will
go ahead and separate that shape out.

183
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:54.380
You'll also notice that this is not
maintaining the characteristics of

184
00:08:54.380 --> 00:08:55.190
the original shape.

185
00:08:55.190 --> 00:08:59.560
So it's not kind of adding in that
additional path like our eraser did, so

186
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:03.470
you can see how my stroke
became separated out.

187
00:09:03.470 --> 00:09:06.880
>> It's almost the eraser,
if you went all the way through,

188
00:09:06.880 --> 00:09:09.990
it could create a closed path,
this is staying open.

189
00:09:09.990 --> 00:09:13.040
But again, you could take the eraser and
not go all the way through.

190
00:09:13.040 --> 00:09:16.050
So I don't want you to think it's
always gonna create a closed path.

191
00:09:16.050 --> 00:09:19.130
But yeah, keeping the characteristics
of the whole stroke and

192
00:09:19.130 --> 00:09:20.900
shape, stroke and shape?

193
00:09:20.900 --> 00:09:21.400
>> Yeah.

194
00:09:21.400 --> 00:09:23.400
>> This is open, fully open.

195
00:09:23.400 --> 00:09:25.230
Yeah, it doesn't connect across.

196
00:09:25.230 --> 00:09:29.560
Cuz the eraser would've made
a connecting line, in a sense.

197
00:09:29.560 --> 00:09:31.540
Close that path off.

198
00:09:31.540 --> 00:09:36.031
Here you don't see any closed path, yeah.

199
00:09:36.031 --> 00:09:37.990
>> Mm-hm.
>> So that's what we're trying to do.

200
00:09:37.990 --> 00:09:40.280
I don't want to confuse you
with all of these terms, but

201
00:09:40.280 --> 00:09:42.960
just throwing out different
ways of explaining it, so.

202
00:09:42.960 --> 00:09:47.300
And the other thing that I always talked
about with the scissors, it's like,

203
00:09:47.300 --> 00:09:48.250
as opposed to the knife.

204
00:09:48.250 --> 00:09:52.950
I always think of it like if you had a
piece of string or a piece of hair, you're

205
00:09:52.950 --> 00:09:56.410
not gonna want to use a knife for that,
you'll want to use a scissors to just cut.

206
00:09:56.410 --> 00:09:57.280
And you cut one place,

207
00:09:57.280 --> 00:10:00.920
you gotta cut the other cuz you want
that little piece of string to stay.

208
00:10:00.920 --> 00:10:04.220
So that was just another
little metaphor that I use.

209
00:10:04.220 --> 00:10:05.630
>> It's a good metaphor.

210
00:10:05.630 --> 00:10:06.550
I like it, I like it.

211
00:10:06.550 --> 00:10:09.212
And I think the funny
thing with these scissor

212
00:10:09.212 --> 00:10:12.730
tool is I believe you also always need
to make sure that you hit on a path.

213
00:10:12.730 --> 00:10:15.329
So see right here,
even though it broke up,

214
00:10:15.329 --> 00:10:19.424
it looks like there's a path there
cuz there's a fill applied to it.

215
00:10:19.424 --> 00:10:23.048
But you see there's not actual path,
so it's telling me no, no, no, no,

216
00:10:23.048 --> 00:10:24.760
no I need it to actually be on a path.

217
00:10:24.760 --> 00:10:27.290
So it can get a little bit wonky but

218
00:10:27.290 --> 00:10:28.710
I feel like that's where
that starts to come in.

219
00:10:28.710 --> 00:10:31.470
>> And you just remind me of why I would
always say that cuz you had to cut

220
00:10:31.470 --> 00:10:33.610
on the string,
you couldn't cut in the middle of the air,

221
00:10:33.610 --> 00:10:37.270
you had to cut on the string or
a piece of hair or something like that.

222
00:10:37.270 --> 00:10:38.040
Yay, okay good.

223
00:10:38.040 --> 00:10:41.760
>> And we all just brought it all back in,
tied it all together.

224
00:10:41.760 --> 00:10:46.350
So yes, scissors tool, it's all just
dependent on what you're doing and

225
00:10:46.350 --> 00:10:47.600
what you feel like you need to cut.

226
00:10:47.600 --> 00:10:49.630
I think Vonne had a great example.

227
00:10:49.630 --> 00:10:54.229
If I need to cut a piece of hair, a piece
of string, I want to go ahead and do that,

228
00:10:54.229 --> 00:10:56.865
so I can go ahead and
click here, click here.

229
00:10:56.865 --> 00:10:59.885
And you'll start to see it's like, whoa
it's starting to get a little bit wonky,

230
00:10:59.885 --> 00:11:01.190
especially as I've divided that.

231
00:11:01.190 --> 00:11:04.000
But now I can see that,
that's in three different pieces.

232
00:11:04.000 --> 00:11:06.870
So, just keep going with it.

233
00:11:06.870 --> 00:11:09.492
Make sure you're always
cutting along that path.

234
00:11:09.492 --> 00:11:13.210
Now I'll go ahead and
kinda shift this little guy over.

235
00:11:13.210 --> 00:11:16.860
We'll draw a new polygon
to talk about our knife.

236
00:11:16.860 --> 00:11:20.050
So our knife tool, rather than having
our start and our end points, or

237
00:11:20.050 --> 00:11:23.730
the string as Vonne mentioned, you're
actually going to slice something with

238
00:11:23.730 --> 00:11:26.590
the knife, which sounds way more dramatic.

239
00:11:26.590 --> 00:11:30.270
[LAUGH] So what we're going to do, we're
gonna go ahead and grab our knife tool.

240
00:11:30.270 --> 00:11:34.410
Now our knife tool by default, you're
gonna kind of want to work in a curve.

241
00:11:34.410 --> 00:11:36.960
So the funny thing with the knife tool
that kind of throws people off in

242
00:11:36.960 --> 00:11:39.520
the beginning is that it feels
like it gets really wonky.

243
00:11:39.520 --> 00:11:44.120
If I just go down here, you'll see
how I have kind of a crooked line.

244
00:11:44.120 --> 00:11:49.884
Still works, I'm just gonna have kind
of a crooked appearance by default.

245
00:11:49.884 --> 00:11:53.976
But you will see that it maintained the
characteristics of my original shapes, so

246
00:11:53.976 --> 00:11:55.740
it kinda filled in for us.

247
00:11:55.740 --> 00:11:59.040
So what I say is make sure
you're kinda working in a curve.

248
00:11:59.040 --> 00:12:01.880
So if I kinda click, hold,
and drag up from here,

249
00:12:01.880 --> 00:12:05.150
if I kinda work in a curve,
I can go ahead and get that effect.

250
00:12:05.150 --> 00:12:07.960
Now there is a way to make it straight and
we'll talk about that in a second.

251
00:12:07.960 --> 00:12:11.800
But again, I just wanna point out,
note how the difference between this and

252
00:12:11.800 --> 00:12:14.930
our scissors where their scissors
did not kind of fill in that path.

253
00:12:14.930 --> 00:12:16.340
It didn't enclose it in.

254
00:12:16.340 --> 00:12:20.470
This is closing our path and therefore
maintaining the characteristics of our

255
00:12:20.470 --> 00:12:22.370
original shape because it
can add that stroke back in.

256
00:12:22.370 --> 00:12:25.094
>> And maybe one thing you are like,
that's like what the eraser did.

257
00:12:25.094 --> 00:12:30.616
But the eraser had a diameter that it
kind of made a swath through, [LAUGH] and

258
00:12:30.616 --> 00:12:36.770
a knife, there's not space if you want
to say, in between where you're cutting.

259
00:12:36.770 --> 00:12:40.020
And I always said if you take a knife and
cut through a loaf of bread and

260
00:12:40.020 --> 00:12:41.780
you gotta cut all the way down
through the loaf of bread.

261
00:12:41.780 --> 00:12:47.060
You don't cut halfway through or
it doesn't become it's own piece.

262
00:12:47.060 --> 00:12:50.120
>> Yeah, you didn't kind of lose anything
in there in the middle with that diameter.

263
00:12:50.120 --> 00:12:53.222
You've got it all perfectly sliced,
if you will.

264
00:12:53.222 --> 00:12:58.020
So now what if you do want to cut
something in a straight line, okay?

265
00:12:58.020 --> 00:13:00.810
This one always throws me, I'll be honest.

266
00:13:00.810 --> 00:13:04.750
So with the knife tool, in order to cut
something in a straight line you actually

267
00:13:04.750 --> 00:13:06.880
to hold down your Alt or Option key.

268
00:13:06.880 --> 00:13:07.930
Why does that throw me?

269
00:13:07.930 --> 00:13:11.730
Because in everything else you
have to hold down your Shift key.

270
00:13:11.730 --> 00:13:15.550
So pretty much everything else,
if you're drawing straight square,

271
00:13:15.550 --> 00:13:16.860
straight line, things like that.

272
00:13:16.860 --> 00:13:19.420
So if I grab my knife tool and
then I hold down my Alt or Option key,

273
00:13:19.420 --> 00:13:22.000
you'll actually see I didn't
hold it down quick enough.

274
00:13:22.000 --> 00:13:23.000
If I hold down the Alt or

275
00:13:23.000 --> 00:13:26.878
Option key, it's gonna make sure
that I have a straight line.

276
00:13:26.878 --> 00:13:32.180
So it's not necessarily saying straight
in 90 degree, but it's a straight line.

277
00:13:32.180 --> 00:13:33.588
So I can go ahead and use that.

278
00:13:33.588 --> 00:13:38.005
Now, what if I want a straight line and
I do wanna make sure that it's 90 degrees?

279
00:13:38.005 --> 00:13:39.755
That's when your Shift key comes in handy.

280
00:13:39.755 --> 00:13:42.535
Why is this backwards
from everything else?

281
00:13:42.535 --> 00:13:43.756
I don't know.

282
00:13:43.756 --> 00:13:46.358
But [LAUGH] I'm gonna hold down my Alt or
Option key and

283
00:13:46.358 --> 00:13:48.444
I'm gonna hold down my Shift key as well.

284
00:13:48.444 --> 00:13:50.775
And I'm trying to move my
mouse from side to side,

285
00:13:50.775 --> 00:13:53.657
it's basically just doing I
think 45 degree increments.

286
00:13:53.657 --> 00:13:56.570
Not 90 degrees, 45 degree increments.

287
00:13:56.570 --> 00:14:01.713
And I can ensure that that's a straight
line and then also 45 degrees, yeah.

288
00:14:01.713 --> 00:14:03.433
[LAUGH]
>> I don't think I ever knew that.

289
00:14:03.433 --> 00:14:05.159
I never knew the Alt.

290
00:14:05.159 --> 00:14:09.000
I would always do different ways
of cutting with straight lines.

291
00:14:09.000 --> 00:14:10.670
I won't tell you how.

292
00:14:10.670 --> 00:14:13.920
I did not know about the Alt.

293
00:14:13.920 --> 00:14:17.170
And to make it go to a whole other piece,
just to remind myself,

294
00:14:17.170 --> 00:14:20.940
you do have to go all
the way through the path.

295
00:14:20.940 --> 00:14:26.910
If you go halfway, it'll still do that but
it doesn't make a separate piece.

296
00:14:26.910 --> 00:14:31.927
It just made a weird compound path thing,
all right, yeah.

297
00:14:31.927 --> 00:14:36.030
That was another, going back to my
had to cut through a loaf of bread.

298
00:14:36.030 --> 00:14:39.460
You had to cut all the way down
through to get the slice off.

299
00:14:39.460 --> 00:14:42.350
You've gotta go all the way through
it to make it come off, so.

300
00:14:43.600 --> 00:14:44.772
>> I think that's the next little thing.

301
00:14:44.772 --> 00:14:46.490
Thank you.

302
00:14:46.490 --> 00:14:49.730
And excellent, Vonne's always good for
the metaphors I feel like.

303
00:14:49.730 --> 00:14:50.980
It's excellent, so yeah.

304
00:14:50.980 --> 00:14:54.342
I'd definitely say,
just kinda keep swiping.

305
00:14:54.342 --> 00:14:56.630
Keep cutting if you will.

306
00:14:56.630 --> 00:15:00.500
But remember kind of the slight variations
between that eraser, scissors, knives.

307
00:15:00.500 --> 00:15:04.470
For our eraser, it's gonna have that kind
of diameter, it's gonna pull through,

308
00:15:04.470 --> 00:15:07.650
it's gonna add those extra points
in to close our paths off.

309
00:15:07.650 --> 00:15:10.330
Are scissors, not going to close the path.

310
00:15:10.330 --> 00:15:12.808
Path eraser, just erasing our path.

311
00:15:12.808 --> 00:15:15.908
And then our knife, kind of similar
back to that eraser tool but

312
00:15:15.908 --> 00:15:19.431
we're not having that diameter,
everything is just a clean cut, so.

313
00:15:19.431 --> 00:15:20.783
>> So now you can go back and

314
00:15:20.783 --> 00:15:24.363
make all your rock star logos with
that cut out part of the star,

315
00:15:24.363 --> 00:15:28.370
cuz now I'm thinking of band names and
all sorts of different things.

316
00:15:28.370 --> 00:15:30.849
And that should indicate
that I need to stop.

317
00:15:30.849 --> 00:15:32.050
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

318
00:15:32.050 --> 00:15:33.250
>> So why don't we go ahead and

319
00:15:33.250 --> 00:15:34.360
wrap this one up.

320
00:15:34.360 --> 00:15:38.110
Signing off for CREATIVE Pro.TV,
I've been your host Vonne Smith.

321
00:15:38.110 --> 00:15:39.100
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

322
00:15:39.100 --> 00:15:41.314
>> And we will see you soon.

323
00:15:41.314 --> 00:15:45.696
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue to demonstrate the many ways to create paths in Illustrator. In this episode, they explore the shaper and the shape builder tool along with their associated tool options.
episodes.title: Shaper and Shape Builder
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.297
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.297 --> 00:00:10.942
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10.942 --> 00:00:15.290
Hello everyone, and welcome to another
exciting edition of CreativePro TV.

4
00:00:15.290 --> 00:00:18.870
I'm your host Vonne Smith, and
this is Illustrator CC 2017,

5
00:00:18.870 --> 00:00:23.750
and we are talking about the shaper and
the shape builder tool.

6
00:00:23.750 --> 00:00:29.410
Doesn't sound very fun, and very
buildery-like, but they're pretty cool.

7
00:00:29.410 --> 00:00:32.321
And here to help us with our
coolness is Ms. Emily Ramsey.

8
00:00:32.321 --> 00:00:35.820
>> [LAUGH] I'm adding the cool
factor today, I like it!

9
00:00:35.820 --> 00:00:36.560
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> Yeah.

10
00:00:36.560 --> 00:00:40.513
No no no, actually our shape runner,
shape builder, I think to Vonne's point,

11
00:00:40.513 --> 00:00:42.480
don't really sound all that exciting.

12
00:00:42.480 --> 00:00:44.520
But actually, really pretty cool.

13
00:00:44.520 --> 00:00:46.250
So what we're gonna do,
we're gonna go ahead and

14
00:00:46.250 --> 00:00:49.810
start with shape builder which
is kind of like, I would say,

15
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:53.330
Illustrator's more intuitive
Pathfinder panel really.

16
00:00:53.330 --> 00:00:57.550
And both of these are actually
pretty new tools that we can use.

17
00:00:57.550 --> 00:01:00.370
And then our shaper tool is just crazy.

18
00:01:00.370 --> 00:01:01.810
So, we'll get into that in a second.

19
00:01:01.810 --> 00:01:05.810
So, I wanna go ahead and
start with my shape builder tool.

20
00:01:05.810 --> 00:01:09.386
I always get the names, It's easy to get
the names kinda mixed up on this one,

21
00:01:09.386 --> 00:01:12.070
even though they do pretty
different things here.

22
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:13.940
So, you see with my shape builder tool,

23
00:01:13.940 --> 00:01:16.910
I'm basically just starting
out with two different shapes.

24
00:01:16.910 --> 00:01:22.350
And what our shape builder tool does,
is it allows us to combine shapes.

25
00:01:22.350 --> 00:01:24.939
A little bit more easily than
again that Pathfinder panel does.

26
00:01:24.939 --> 00:01:29.444
If you can think back, if you watched
the episode on the Pathfinder panel,

27
00:01:29.444 --> 00:01:33.974
you almost have to click around to
see exactly what each option does.

28
00:01:33.974 --> 00:01:37.671
The shape builder tool they said, makes it
a little bit more intuitive because it's

29
00:01:37.671 --> 00:01:41.090
gonna be easier to see as we
are building something and

30
00:01:41.090 --> 00:01:45.200
modifying things, it's just gonna
be a little bit more visual for us.

31
00:01:45.200 --> 00:01:49.160
So what I'm gonna do, I need to first
select these with our black arrow tool.

32
00:01:49.160 --> 00:01:49.660
Excuse me.

33
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:53.740
And then I'm gonna go ahead and
grab my shape builder tool.

34
00:01:53.740 --> 00:01:57.880
My shape builder tool, I feel like
I always I'm losing here on my.

35
00:01:57.880 --> 00:01:59.985
>> You're doing exactly
what I do every time.

36
00:01:59.985 --> 00:02:00.938
>> Yes.

37
00:02:00.938 --> 00:02:02.170
>> I'm like, where is it located?

38
00:02:03.500 --> 00:02:04.165
There it is.

39
00:02:04.165 --> 00:02:07.400
[LAUGH]
>> The icon explains exactly what it does,

40
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:09.210
but it just gets me every time.

41
00:02:09.210 --> 00:02:11.040
It's just not that obvious for
some reason.

42
00:02:11.040 --> 00:02:15.280
>> Well, I think it's also from us being
old school, like the live paint bucket,

43
00:02:15.280 --> 00:02:16.830
which is right underneath
it where it's hidden.

44
00:02:16.830 --> 00:02:21.220
That was what that button in that
particular space on the toolbar

45
00:02:21.220 --> 00:02:22.410
always occupies.

46
00:02:22.410 --> 00:02:22.940
>> Yeah.

47
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:25.670
>> And so I'm always like,
I don't know why.

48
00:02:25.670 --> 00:02:29.460
It's like this weird mental block
where I can't find that tool.

49
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:32.320
>> You feel like, you're like, no,
that's where my live paint bucket is.

50
00:02:32.320 --> 00:02:34.270
>> Yeah.
>> That's not right, that's not right.

51
00:02:34.270 --> 00:02:37.720
They just, poor live paint bucket
got shoved to the back and

52
00:02:37.720 --> 00:02:40.140
they put the shape builder
tool on top of it.

53
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:42.010
But I'm gonna go ahead and grab that.

54
00:02:42.010 --> 00:02:44.820
Now you'll notice I selected these
with my black error tool first.

55
00:02:44.820 --> 00:02:45.780
That is gonna be essential.

56
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:50.080
You can't actually do anything with
your shape builder tool unless you have

57
00:02:50.080 --> 00:02:52.700
both objects selected with
your block area tool.

58
00:02:52.700 --> 00:02:56.000
And with your shape builder tool, when
you grab that you see you kinda start to

59
00:02:56.000 --> 00:02:58.280

something you wanna see
something kinda cut out of that.

You can use this live shape aspect of this

Now.

What if I go here, okay,

00:18:28.655 --> 00:18:32.140
Okay, deselect off of that, and then now

two, all I have to do is, I want to

[LAUGH]

This is newer.

I would have done all that

00:20:40.780 --> 00:20:41.960
With all the compound patterns

00:20:41.960 --> 00:20:44.850
>> everything just like you just said,
I would have done it that way, and

I'm just watching you do that, that shape.

00:20:47.060 --> 00:20:48.570
The first time, I'm like a map shape.

You mean like on our phones,

like the pin [LAUGH] So I was first

444
00:20:55.726 --> 00:21:00.100
I'm over here in amazement of,
how much easier it is.

445
00:21:00.100 --> 00:21:04.500
It's like, you can have it so much easier
nowadays than we had it back in our days,

446
00:21:04.500 --> 00:21:07.340
so I'm very impressed.

447
00:21:07.340 --> 00:21:09.414
You got me.
You got another moment out of me

00:21:09.414 --> 00:21:11.484

00:21:11.484 --> 00:21:12.412
>> Well, thank you.

00:21:12.412 --> 00:21:13.436
>> [LAUGH]
>> Thank you.

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

455
00:21:19.570 --> 00:21:20.520
Well, that was awesome.

456
00:21:20.520 --> 00:21:22.745

I've learned a lot in this episode,

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne transform paths with the offset path command, the width tool, outline stroke, and envelope distort.
episodes.title: Path Transformations
episodes.transcript:

1

[MUSIC]

In this episode we're talking
about object, no path right?

5
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:23.850
>> Yeah.

6
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:25.432
>> Paths transformation.

7
00:00:25.432 --> 00:00:29.213
[LAUGH] And here to help us tell about
all this cool stuff we're gonna do is Ms.

8
00:00:29.213 --> 00:00:30.640
Emily Ramsey, hi.

9
00:00:30.640 --> 00:00:33.820
>> Hello, hello,
how dare you mess up objects with paths.

10
00:00:33.820 --> 00:00:34.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean,

11
00:00:34.840 --> 00:00:36.318
come on
>> [LAUGH]

12
00:00:36.318 --> 00:00:38.067
>> [LAUGH] Get it together, no, no,

13
00:00:38.067 --> 00:00:42.446
Vonne and I we're kinda joking, we didn't
really know what to call this episode.

14
00:00:42.446 --> 00:00:46.760
Cuz usually I just call it cool tools and
that's how I kinda link it together.

15
00:00:46.760 --> 00:00:47.330
So, yeah.

16
00:00:47.330 --> 00:00:50.040
>> And they are cool tools and

00:00:50.040 --> 00:00:53.130
so we're gonna show the coolness of them,

00:00:53.130 --> 00:00:54.710
>> Yeah.
>> And even the last episode,

00:00:54.710 --> 00:00:58.130
if you're watching in order,
the shape builder and the shaper tool,

00:00:58.130 --> 00:01:02.920
you kinda link that all together

00:01:02.920 --> 00:01:06.387
>> But I'm really creative with
the adjectives, is what we're saying.

22
00:01:06.387 --> 00:01:08.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we were struggling like,

23
00:01:08.470 --> 00:01:09.410
what do we do?

24
00:01:09.410 --> 00:01:11.450
How do we not call this cool tool?

25
00:01:11.450 --> 00:01:14.225
>> How?
>> [LAUGH] So that path transformation.

26
00:01:14.225 --> 00:01:15.940
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes.

27
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:17.720
So what does that mean?

28
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:19.750
What is kind of cool about this?

29
00:01:19.750 --> 00:01:22.110
Okay, so really like we said,

30
00:01:22.110 --> 00:01:24.590
it's just a couple of cool things

00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:27.840
Not only that I think may make

00:01:27.840 --> 00:01:31.500

So, I kind of combined both

A lot of times we talk about

00:01:41.880 --> 00:01:44.100
Brings in a little bit of both I think.

37
00:01:44.100 --> 00:01:49.330
So we are gonna start off with offset

39
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:56.770

Basically what I'm going through here is,

00:02:03.670 --> 00:02:06.180
I'm just totally foregoing

00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:07.990
I'm sticking with cool tools.

44

So I'm gonna show you what we're gonna do.

45
00:02:09.630 --> 00:02:16.230
We're just gonna kind of follow along this
path into making each of these things.

46
00:02:16.230 --> 00:02:19.838
So, I'm gonna start off
with our offset path.

47
00:02:19.838 --> 00:02:23.870
Now, while were looking at
here in my offset path is that

00:02:23.870 --> 00:02:26.180
I have several different squares.

49
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:27.910
Now, kind of ignore the color.

50
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:30.060
