00:13:37.000 --> 00:13:41.550
This is very clearly a stroke I'm
tied to that bar and this is not.

278
00:13:41.550 --> 00:13:45.000
So you wanna just kinda make sure to
pay attention to the difference there.

279
00:13:45.000 --> 00:13:49.110
So with profiles,
all that really cool come in handy.

280
00:13:49.110 --> 00:13:53.060
Something that I actually use a little
bit more frequently though is my envelope

281
00:13:53.060 --> 00:13:53.670
distort.

282
00:13:53.670 --> 00:13:56.790
So envelop distort, awesome.

283
00:13:56.790 --> 00:13:58.080
It just makes some crazy things.

284
00:13:58.080 --> 00:13:59.860
I'm showing you an example
of how this works.

285
00:13:59.860 --> 00:14:03.240
But then I'm showing you example here
of how this worked on multiple shapes.

286
00:14:03.240 --> 00:14:06.820
So I just wanna kind of give you
a practical example of how to use this,

287
00:14:06.820 --> 00:14:10.600
but we're gonna go ahead and
make some distortions if you will.

288
00:14:10.600 --> 00:14:13.640
And what I can do, I'm gonna go ahead and
just create a rectangle.

289
00:14:15.520 --> 00:14:17.528
Go ahead and give it a color,
it doesn't matter what it is.

290
00:14:17.528 --> 00:14:21.560
And now I"m gonna go back
into my objects menu.

291
00:14:21.560 --> 00:14:25.010
And I am going to go
down to Envelope Distort.

292
00:14:25.010 --> 00:14:28.365
The option that I really prefer
to use is Make With Warp.

293
00:14:28.365 --> 00:14:31.637
You can Make With Mesh,
you can Make With Top Object,

294
00:14:31.637 --> 00:14:35.810
I think Warp is probably gonna be
the easiest and best bet to go with.

295
00:14:35.810 --> 00:14:39.230
So Make with Warp and

296
00:14:39.230 --> 00:14:42.070
what you'll see here is you get
these Warp Options that come up.

297
00:14:42.070 --> 00:14:44.960
So go ahead and
just click through a couple of the styles.

298
00:14:44.960 --> 00:14:47.000
Mine started with the style Arch.

299
00:14:47.000 --> 00:14:51.330
The option that I had displayed
there at the top, if I,

300
00:14:51.330 --> 00:14:52.930
I can't scroll back to my example here.

301
00:14:52.930 --> 00:14:57.110
But that was flag that you were
looking at with my little flag icon.

302
00:14:57.110 --> 00:14:58.518
And you can see here, okay, okay and

303
00:14:58.518 --> 00:15:00.571
change the distortion from
horizontal to vertical.

304
00:15:00.571 --> 00:15:06.560
I can adjust the bend maybe I wanted to go
that way, or I can change the distortion.

305
00:15:06.560 --> 00:15:10.580
This will kind of skew it a little bit
more, if I wanna use that example.

306
00:15:10.580 --> 00:15:12.100
Or you can just be like, you know what?

307
00:15:12.100 --> 00:15:13.100
That's okay.

308
00:15:13.100 --> 00:15:14.640
And go ahead and leave it like that.

309
00:15:14.640 --> 00:15:18.000
>> This is reminding me of Photoshop
where they do the text warp.

310
00:15:18.000 --> 00:15:19.020
Or the-
>> Yeah.

311
00:15:19.020 --> 00:15:20.520
>> I think it's text warp?

312
00:15:20.520 --> 00:15:21.110
>> Yeah.

313
00:15:21.110 --> 00:15:25.200
>> It's the same dialog box with the arch,
and the bulge, and the flag,

314
00:15:25.200 --> 00:15:27.510
and stuff, if that looks familiar to you,

315
00:15:27.510 --> 00:15:29.870
if you're a Photoshop person
that's where it comes from.

316
00:15:29.870 --> 00:15:32.670
And this is on one object, but
you could do this with text too,

317
00:15:32.670 --> 00:15:33.430
which is always fun.

318
00:15:33.430 --> 00:15:34.860
>> Yes.
>> Just throwing that out there for you.

319
00:15:34.860 --> 00:15:38.760
>> Yes, yes, you could, which is
sometimes help me if I'm trying to,

320
00:15:38.760 --> 00:15:42.120
if I have text that I want to
sit on this for some reason.

321
00:15:42.120 --> 00:15:46.884
Like, Hello, and I want it to kind
of look like its on top of this.

322
00:15:46.884 --> 00:15:49.786
>> I don't even know,
you might be able to do it all in one but

323
00:15:49.786 --> 00:15:53.357
I usually do it separately object,
and then I go to Envelope Distort,

324
00:15:53.357 --> 00:15:56.100
Make with Warp and
you can kinda get that same effect.

325
00:15:56.100 --> 00:15:57.852
Now that's really distorting my text.

326
00:15:57.852 --> 00:16:00.800
I'd probably adjust that way down.

327
00:16:00.800 --> 00:16:02.622
But you could see how you could
use that to your benefit.

328
00:16:02.622 --> 00:16:06.577
Now, one thing else I wanted to show
you here is like okay, I did this,

329
00:16:06.577 --> 00:16:09.710
now what happens when I
want to kind of edit it?

330
00:16:09.710 --> 00:16:13.560
You can either edit your envelope
distort or you can also just go back and

331
00:16:13.560 --> 00:16:15.590
say, I just want it to
be a different color.

332
00:16:15.590 --> 00:16:18.620
When you go ahead and select this,
you need to look at your control bar here.

333
00:16:18.620 --> 00:16:21.920
So if I go all the way to the left
hand side, you know how by default,

334
00:16:21.920 --> 00:16:26.870
it's set at edit envelope, that's
gonna be editing my envelope distort.

335
00:16:26.870 --> 00:16:30.230
So what I'm gonna do here,
I can go ahead here, and adjust the style.

336
00:16:30.230 --> 00:16:32.146
I really like fish,
I just think it's cute.

337
00:16:32.146 --> 00:16:34.895
[LAUGH] So you can go ahead and
do that, you can change that again, and

338
00:16:34.895 --> 00:16:37.550
that horizontal and vertical,
I can adjust the bend.

339
00:16:37.550 --> 00:16:40.640
All of those options that
came up in that dialogue box,

340
00:16:40.640 --> 00:16:42.750
I have the ability to change here.

341
00:16:42.750 --> 00:16:46.600
But what happens if I want to go here,
and I want to change the color,

342
00:16:46.600 --> 00:16:49.630
nothing's happening, I'm clicking in
my swatches and nothing's happening.

343
00:16:49.630 --> 00:16:52.500
I need to change this to
now edit the content.

344
00:16:52.500 --> 00:16:55.540
So you have to kinda flip back and
forth when you're editing, and

345
00:16:55.540 --> 00:16:58.158
that all comes with these
two icons right here.

346
00:16:58.158 --> 00:17:01.500
The one that looks like the mesh,
versus the one that looks like a star.

347
00:17:01.500 --> 00:17:06.000
So if I click on edit contents,
you'll see now I have the ability

348
00:17:06.000 --> 00:17:09.310
to start changing my strokes and
my fills and all that good stuff.

349
00:17:09.310 --> 00:17:13.650
So it definitely changes depending
on what you have selected,

350
00:17:13.650 --> 00:17:15.820
you need to make sure to go back and
forth, but

351
00:17:15.820 --> 00:17:18.250
it is nice that I don't have to
go back into the dialog box.

352
00:17:18.250 --> 00:17:20.168
I have the ability to change that style.

353
00:17:20.168 --> 00:17:23.594
>> And we went back to the edit
content and if you noticed,

354
00:17:23.594 --> 00:17:27.171
it looks still like a rectangle
when you clicked on that,

355
00:17:27.171 --> 00:17:31.441
because isn't this where it's
using a clipping mask weird thing?

356
00:17:31.441 --> 00:17:34.853
And if you don't want this
any more you can release it?

357
00:17:34.853 --> 00:17:36.660
Am I remembering this correctly?

358
00:17:36.660 --> 00:17:39.713
>> Reading my mind.

359
00:17:39.713 --> 00:17:40.603
>> My gosh it's happening again!

360
00:17:40.603 --> 00:17:42.526
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So I wanna show what happens,

361
00:17:42.526 --> 00:17:44.680
okay, if I decide I
don't want this anymore.

362
00:17:44.680 --> 00:17:45.820
What happens when I release it?

363
00:17:45.820 --> 00:17:49.428
That's kind of an interesting
thing that happens,

364
00:17:49.428 --> 00:17:53.534
so if I go to Object> Envelope Distort,
and I hit Release.

365
00:17:53.534 --> 00:17:58.507
What you're gonna see is,
it's basically made

366
00:17:58.507 --> 00:18:02.860
a clipping mask, but not, if you will.

367
00:18:02.860 --> 00:18:05.544
I don't know, I don't really
know how else to phase that, but

368
00:18:05.544 --> 00:18:08.701
it leaves you with that shape,
in my case it's leaving me with that fish.

369
00:18:08.701 --> 00:18:11.835
And this kind of ties in to that
make with top object option.

370
00:18:11.835 --> 00:18:14.443
>> You just took the words
right out of my mouth.

371
00:18:14.443 --> 00:18:16.115
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH] [LAUGH] I was like,
I've got to get it out,

372
00:18:16.115 --> 00:18:16.809
I've got to get it out.

373
00:18:16.809 --> 00:18:17.588
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

374
00:18:17.588 --> 00:18:20.829
I know she's just lurking in the corner,
and

375
00:18:20.829 --> 00:18:23.259
she's gonna say the same thing,
>> [LAUGH]

376
00:18:23.259 --> 00:18:24.610
>> That I'm about to say.

377
00:18:24.610 --> 00:18:25.708
>> [LAUGH] Okay, I've got to say it first.

378
00:18:25.708 --> 00:18:28.267
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you noticed that when we went to

379
00:18:28.267 --> 00:18:31.708
the object and
Envelope Distort > Make with Top Object.

380
00:18:31.708 --> 00:18:34.594
That's kinda where this
all comes into play,

381
00:18:34.594 --> 00:18:38.592
I'm not entirely positive that
this release option will work.

382
00:18:38.592 --> 00:18:43.150
Hopefully it does, you can see, yep, okay,
that goes ahead and makes that there, so

383
00:18:43.150 --> 00:18:47.396
I don't really have too many occasions
where I need the make with top object, but

384
00:18:47.396 --> 00:18:48.280
it is an option.

385
00:18:48.280 --> 00:18:51.910
Now something else I wanted to point out
to you is that Expand option that we

386
00:18:51.910 --> 00:18:52.520
saw in there.

387
00:18:52.520 --> 00:18:56.149
So it's expanding, I know we've talked
about in a couple other episodes, but

388
00:18:56.149 --> 00:18:59.077
it'll basically break this away
from that Envelope Distort and

389
00:18:59.077 --> 00:19:01.970
give us those paths to work with,
or those points to work with.

390
00:19:01.970 --> 00:19:05.790
So if I go to my Object menu,
I can just go to Object Expand, but

391
00:19:05.790 --> 00:19:09.775
you'll also see it under Object
> Envelope Distort > Expand.

392
00:19:09.775 --> 00:19:14.545
And you'll see now, that kind of takes
away, you see my control bar changed.

393
00:19:14.545 --> 00:19:17.981
You can see really what I'm just
looking at is a group here,

394
00:19:17.981 --> 00:19:22.330
just kinda looks a normal path, and
now I can edit those points if I need to.

395
00:19:22.330 --> 00:19:24.733
So that is one other thing
to pay attention to.

396
00:19:24.733 --> 00:19:28.270
Now I'll just show the make with mesh,
just so we can see it.

397
00:19:28.270 --> 00:19:30.941
So I'm gonna take that rectangle again,

398
00:19:30.941 --> 00:19:33.930
Object > Envelope Distort
> Make with Mesh.

399
00:19:33.930 --> 00:19:37.469
It's almost that Gradient Mesh or
the Mesh Tool,

400
00:19:37.469 --> 00:19:41.850
except you're taking this,
going ahead and hitting OK, and

401
00:19:41.850 --> 00:19:47.670
then you're gonna use your white arrow
to kind of mess it around, if you will.

402
00:19:47.670 --> 00:19:51.051
Again, there have been occasions
when I've used this, but

403
00:19:51.051 --> 00:19:54.112
it's not something that comes
in to play all the time.

404
00:19:54.112 --> 00:19:58.407
>> And it's really, yeah,
when you go to the edge of that, and

405
00:19:58.407 --> 00:20:02.030
then you can kinda take where the fish and
the flag,

406
00:20:02.030 --> 00:20:06.341
those are predetermined shapes
if you wanna say or pattern.

407
00:20:06.341 --> 00:20:10.220
I'm using all these different
words in different contexts here.

408
00:20:10.220 --> 00:20:12.993
But now you can see,
if I wanted to do that fish on top,

409
00:20:12.993 --> 00:20:16.201
I would make sure I just grab
the mesh points, move them down,

410
00:20:16.201 --> 00:20:19.677
change the Bezier handles to make
them kind of curve differently.

411
00:20:19.677 --> 00:20:22.760
So you could see from
all our other lessons,

412
00:20:22.760 --> 00:20:26.268
you could make that exact
same fish from the mesh.

413
00:20:26.268 --> 00:20:27.117
But its a lot more.

414
00:20:27.117 --> 00:20:29.862
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if you wanted to go into this pin

415
00:20:29.862 --> 00:20:34.828
point level accuracy and be able to
control these different envelope

416
00:20:34.828 --> 00:20:40.242
distortions that you wanna do, then
that's the way to go and grab a point.

417
00:20:40.242 --> 00:20:44.832
Go on your merry way, but I'll probably
just go with the fish too, and go.

418
00:20:44.832 --> 00:20:47.366
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] well, it's just fun.

419
00:20:47.366 --> 00:20:48.749
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It's that example.

420
00:20:48.749 --> 00:20:52.592
But I think you can probably see as we're
kind of looking at these things and

421
00:20:52.592 --> 00:20:55.030
looking back,
why we call these cool tools.

422
00:20:55.030 --> 00:20:58.864
They're just interesting things
that you can do in illustrator, so

423
00:20:58.864 --> 00:21:02.711
I really think they're fun,
hopefully, you think they're cool.

424
00:21:02.711 --> 00:21:03.780
Yeah.

425
00:21:03.780 --> 00:21:05.430
>> Yeah?
>> Have a good time, and learn something.

426
00:21:05.430 --> 00:21:06.135
>> They're cool.
>> [LAUGH]

427
00:21:06.135 --> 00:21:07.890
>> They are very cool.

428
00:21:07.890 --> 00:21:11.516
But the coolness doesn't stop here, yes,

429
00:21:11.516 --> 00:21:16.717
we have a few more cool tools to
show you in a part two, so [LAUGH].

430
00:21:16.717 --> 00:21:19.447
>> Yes! [LAUGH] >> So we'll be
coming back with even more, but for

431
00:21:19.447 --> 00:21:22.160
now we're gonna go ahead and wrap this up.

432
00:21:22.160 --> 00:21:24.760
Signing off for CREATIVEPRO.TV,
I'm your host Vaughn Smith.

433
00:21:24.760 --> 00:21:25.970
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

434
00:21:25.970 --> 00:21:27.680
>> And we will see you soon.

435
00:21:27.680 --> 00:21:32.548
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue to transform paths, specifically covering the transform command and how to repeat commands as well as fun ways to use the rotate tool.
episodes.title: Path Transformations Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:06.671 --> 00:00:11.478
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.478 --> 00:00:16.000
Hello everyone and welcome back to another
exciting edition of CreativePro.TV.

3
00:00:16.000 --> 00:00:20.090
I'm your host Vonne Smith and
this is Illustrator CC 2017.

4
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:27.311
And this is a part two of our cool tools,
AKA, known as our path transformations.

5
00:00:27.311 --> 00:00:30.389
And here to continue our coolness is Ms.
Emily Ramsey.

6
00:00:30.389 --> 00:00:31.175
Hi, welcome back.

7
00:00:31.175 --> 00:00:34.788
>> Hello, it will never stop weirding
me out when you say that I'm here to

8
00:00:34.788 --> 00:00:36.086
continue the coolness.

9
00:00:36.086 --> 00:00:37.727
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm here to bring the party guys.

10
00:00:37.727 --> 00:00:41.407
>> [LAUGH]
>> No no, it is cool.

11
00:00:41.407 --> 00:00:41.995
>> It is!

12
00:00:41.995 --> 00:00:46.431
>> Yes, and so we're gonna kind of
continue on with this theme of,

13
00:00:46.431 --> 00:00:50.391
again, things that you can
use to make things look cool.

14
00:00:50.391 --> 00:00:53.260
But then also things that are gonna
make your life easier in Illustrator.

15
00:00:53.260 --> 00:00:57.775
So I'm actually gonna hop back into the
same file that we were using in part one.

16
00:00:57.775 --> 00:01:01.235
This will be available to you guys in the
exercise files, you can even see, okay,

17
00:01:01.235 --> 00:01:04.065
I've got those original things
that I was working with over here.

18
00:01:04.065 --> 00:01:06.760
I'll just scoot ir over to
a different artboard basically.

19
00:01:06.760 --> 00:01:09.799
Now what were gonna start,
we're gonna start of with this example.

20
00:01:09.799 --> 00:01:14.072
Okay you promised me cool, and
this doesn't really lookthat cool, right?

21
00:01:14.072 --> 00:01:17.493
But basically, the way that this is
interesting is how we got there?

22
00:01:17.493 --> 00:01:18.438
So basically,

23
00:01:18.438 --> 00:01:22.738
what I need to do is I need to have
a repeating version of the same thing.

24
00:01:22.738 --> 00:01:25.868
So I used circles at the top,
maybe I'll use squares here.

25
00:01:27.668 --> 00:01:33.598
And basically, why I think this is
interesting is, if I need several squares

26
00:01:33.598 --> 00:01:38.995
in a row the natural tendency is just
to take your Alt drag or whatever.

27
00:01:38.995 --> 00:01:42.836
Maybe use your own line tools to try and
make sure that they're all the same,

28
00:01:42.836 --> 00:01:44.286
distribute, or whatever.

29
00:01:44.286 --> 00:01:45.273
Whatever you wanna use.

30
00:01:45.273 --> 00:01:48.131
Well, I can make my life a lot easier.

31
00:01:48.131 --> 00:01:51.192
So, what I'm going to do is, I'm actually
going to go into my Object menu, and

32
00:01:51.192 --> 00:01:52.348
I'm going to use Transform.

33
00:01:52.348 --> 00:01:55.003
We've kind of alluded to this guy already,

34
00:01:55.003 --> 00:01:59.249
if you watched the episode on patterns,
we used this to kind of scale.

35
00:01:59.249 --> 00:02:02.346
Now I want to use this to move.

36
00:02:02.346 --> 00:02:06.224
So I'm gonna Object Transform Move,
and then, okay,

37
00:02:06.224 --> 00:02:08.708
there's a couple key things here.

38
00:02:08.708 --> 00:02:12.732
One, I want to go ahead and
determine where I want to move and

39
00:02:12.732 --> 00:02:14.352
how much I want to move.

40
00:02:14.352 --> 00:02:16.590
In my case,
I'm actually just moving horizontally.

41
00:02:16.590 --> 00:02:19.695
You can see right here we
could also move vertically.

42
00:02:19.695 --> 00:02:22.617
I think it picks up on
the last motion that you did.

43
00:02:22.617 --> 00:02:26.198
I think I dragged this down a little bit,
I don't know.

44
00:02:26.198 --> 00:02:28.780
You can go ahead and
just type in whatever you want.

45
00:02:28.780 --> 00:02:31.772
Maybe I wanna move this by 0.3 inches.

46
00:02:31.772 --> 00:02:34.995
We'll see if that's enough,
nope, maybe 0.5.

47
00:02:34.995 --> 00:02:38.217
That's where your preview comes in handy,
which is 0.8.

48
00:02:38.217 --> 00:02:39.934
>> This also might be
a little bit with your math.

49
00:02:39.934 --> 00:02:44.061
If you knew that your square was exactly
half inch wide, or whatever, and

50
00:02:44.061 --> 00:02:45.337
I need to move it over.

51
00:02:45.337 --> 00:02:49.764
You need to make sure it goes more than
half inch, if it's gonna go past it.

52
00:02:49.764 --> 00:02:51.912
But we didn't wanna go with the math.

53
00:02:51.912 --> 00:02:55.275
Until it's visually moves over,
turn on that preview and you're good.

54
00:02:55.275 --> 00:02:56.732
>> Yes, I'm visual person.

55
00:02:56.732 --> 00:02:58.696
>> [LAUGH]
>> In case we haven't all figure it out

56
00:02:58.696 --> 00:03:01.366
here, so what I'm going to do,
I'm gonna stick with 0.6.

57
00:03:01.366 --> 00:03:01.983
Looks good enough.

58
00:03:01.983 --> 00:03:06.798
Now, absolute most essential part of this,
you can hit OK, that's great,

59
00:03:06.798 --> 00:03:11.336
that's going to work, but then it's
only going to move this one thing.

60
00:03:11.336 --> 00:03:14.194
What I'm gonna do is I'm gonna hit Copy.

61
00:03:14.194 --> 00:03:16.793
Copy is where the magic and
the cool factor comes in.

00:15:20.552 --> 00:15:24.207
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to create vector paths from an image using image trace. They explore the image trace options using the panel and when and why to expand tracing.  They also demonstrate how to create a live paint group and use the live paint tool easily color artwork.
episodes.title: Image Trace and Live Paint
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

And I'm like it's a Live Paint group.

437
00:20:47.502 --> 00:20:49.320
Of course, I would have known that.

438
00:20:49.320 --> 00:20:49.995
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] duh.

439
00:20:49.995 --> 00:20:52.390
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it just comes from just years,

440
00:20:52.390 --> 00:20:54.040
and years, and years of doing this stuff.

441
00:20:54.040 --> 00:20:59.820
But yeah, it's so much fun to be able to
do the image trace, and the live paint.

442
00:20:59.820 --> 00:21:03.875
It's just, like you said, it's one of
those fun things that makes us a little

443
00:21:03.875 --> 00:21:07.943
easier to be able to paint something by
number, just want to say and grab that.

444
00:21:07.943 --> 00:21:10.570
Do we have anything else
we want to add with this?

445
00:21:10.570 --> 00:21:12.410
>> I don't think so.
Y'all can just enjoy my

446
00:21:12.410 --> 00:21:13.010
flower
>> [LAUGH]

447
00:21:13.010 --> 00:21:15.030
>> To your heart's content to just

448
00:21:15.030 --> 00:21:18.180
take in the beauty [LAUGH]
>> And then you can take this and make

449
00:21:18.180 --> 00:21:23.930
a pattern swatch, you can go ahead and
make a symbol and you can make a brush.

450
00:21:23.930 --> 00:21:26.110
Make this into a scatter [INAUDIBLE].

451
00:21:26.110 --> 00:21:29.060
All the things that we've been
doing through this entire show it's

452
00:21:29.060 --> 00:21:31.980
like you can go crazy
with all of these things.

453
00:21:31.980 --> 00:21:33.170
Because it's just vectors.

454
00:21:33.170 --> 00:21:34.980
So, you wanna make a brush?

455
00:21:34.980 --> 00:21:35.950
You wanna make a pattern?

456
00:21:35.950 --> 00:21:37.330
You wanna make a symbol?

457
00:21:37.330 --> 00:21:41.680
You wanna do some other things things
[LAUGH] you're more than welcome.

458
00:21:41.680 --> 00:21:45.590
And it's an easy way to kinda get
something that isn't in image form

459
00:21:45.590 --> 00:21:48.770
into vector form so yeah.

460
00:21:48.770 --> 00:21:51.740
All right,
well I think that's about it for this one.

461
00:21:51.740 --> 00:21:52.520
Great introduction.

462
00:21:52.520 --> 00:21:57.494
To these two awesome concepts or
commands or things in Illustrator.

463
00:21:57.494 --> 00:22:00.850
[LAUGH] All right,
we're gonna go ahead and wrap this one up.

464
00:22:00.850 --> 00:22:03.840
Signing off for Creative Pro TV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

465
00:22:03.840 --> 00:22:04.700
>> And I'm Emily Ramsey.

466
00:22:04.700 --> 00:22:05.281
>> And we will see you soon.

467
00:22:05.281 --> 00:22:10.704
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily explore drawing and creating paths in perspective using the perspective grid tool. They show how to edit grids, choose planes to add paths, and use the perspective grid selection tool.
episodes.title: Perpective Grid
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:06.025 --> 00:00:11.113
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.113 --> 00:00:12.267
Hello everybody, and

3
00:00:12.267 --> 00:00:15.630
welcome to another another exciting
edition of CreativePro TV.

4
00:00:15.630 --> 00:00:19.220
I'm your host Vonne Smith and
this is Illustrator CC 2017.

5
00:00:19.220 --> 00:00:22.956
And we're continuing on with
the Perspective Grid Tool and

6
00:00:22.956 --> 00:00:25.280
all the fun that comes along with it.

7
00:00:25.280 --> 00:00:27.591
And here to bring the fun,
Ms. Emily Ramsey.

8
00:00:27.591 --> 00:00:28.186
Hi.

9
00:00:28.186 --> 00:00:29.128
>> Yes, I'm bringing the fun.

10
00:00:29.128 --> 00:00:32.728
I'm bringing the perspective
on the perspective grid tool.

11
00:00:32.728 --> 00:00:34.088
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just thought about that as you

12
00:00:34.088 --> 00:00:34.764
were talking.

13
00:00:34.764 --> 00:00:36.086
I was like, I'm so clever.

14
00:00:36.086 --> 00:00:36.799
>> I see what you did there.

15
00:00:36.799 --> 00:00:37.568
>> I'm gonna say that.

16
00:00:37.568 --> 00:00:42.103
[LAUGH] Now, so what we're gonna be
talking about today is the perspective

17
00:00:42.103 --> 00:00:45.150
grid tool, the perspective grid tool.

18
00:00:45.150 --> 00:00:48.669
I feel like is maybe one of those if
you've popped into illustrator and you've

19
00:00:48.669 --> 00:00:52.310
kinda played around and you open it up and
you're like, whoa what is this thing?

20
00:00:52.310 --> 00:00:53.331
And how do I move it?

21
00:00:53.331 --> 00:00:54.930
And what do I do with it?

22
00:00:54.930 --> 00:00:55.905
How to get rid of it?

23
00:00:55.905 --> 00:00:58.225
It's kind of that tool for
a lot of people, I feel like.

24
00:00:58.225 --> 00:01:01.235
Or at least it was for me when I was
just first kind of opening it up and

25
00:01:01.235 --> 00:01:02.355
playing around with illustrator.

26
00:01:02.355 --> 00:01:05.055
But basically,
what our perspective grid tool does,

27
00:01:05.055 --> 00:01:07.635
is it's gonna allow us draw
things in perspective.

28
00:01:07.635 --> 00:01:11.588
So essentially, it's kind of allowing
us to draw things more in a 3D.

29
00:01:11.588 --> 00:01:15.863
So if you kind of think about
the rendering of a house or

30
00:01:15.863 --> 00:01:19.957
some sort of architectural
structure if you will.

31
00:01:19.957 --> 00:01:21.709
>> [LAUGH]
>> I am not an architect.

32
00:01:21.709 --> 00:01:24.560
You can kinda think about how this
would be used to that advantage.

33
00:01:24.560 --> 00:01:26.520
You wanna draw that in that dimension.

34
00:01:26.520 --> 00:01:28.473
So that's basically what
we're gonna be doing today.

35
00:01:28.473 --> 00:01:30.920
Now, I'm gonna do it on
a much smaller scale.

36
00:01:30.920 --> 00:01:36.549
My house is gonna be a little bit less
realistic than maybe an architect,

37
00:01:36.549 --> 00:01:40.043
but same concept, [LAUGH]
>> It's like a kindergarten house, right?

38
00:01:40.043 --> 00:01:40.563
>> Yes.

39
00:01:40.563 --> 00:01:43.518
>> Okay,
we haven't gotten out of kindergarten.

40
00:01:43.518 --> 00:01:46.819
Well, we went to first grade for a little
bit, but now we're back to kindergarten,

41
00:01:46.819 --> 00:01:48.557
and were gonna make
a very primitive house.

42
00:01:48.557 --> 00:01:50.830
How about that?
>> Yes, yes, exactly.

43
00:01:50.830 --> 00:01:52.662
So you can even see I've got
my little flowers going over.

44
00:01:52.662 --> 00:01:54.040
I got My House ready.

45
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:56.259
I even have to title My House.

46
00:01:56.259 --> 00:01:58.662
What we're gonna do, okay,
naturally is the first thing,

47
00:01:58.662 --> 00:02:00.880
we're gonna grab our
perspective grid tool.

48
00:02:00.880 --> 00:02:02.920
I have these things kinda
hanging out over here.

49
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:04.570
But that's just something
I'm gonna deal with later.

50
00:02:04.570 --> 00:02:07.865
So I want to go ahead and
grab my perspective grid tool.

51
00:02:07.865 --> 00:02:14.240
It's gonna be just above the Gradient
tool, if that helps you, on the toolbar.

52
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:17.300
And you pull that up, and you're thinking,
whoa, what just happened to my screen?

53
00:02:17.300 --> 00:02:22.030
So I mentioned that this is gonna be
something that I can draw in perspective.

54
00:02:22.030 --> 00:02:26.460
So I can kinda work with these planes,
if you will.

55
00:02:26.460 --> 00:02:27.760
You can kinda think about it going back.

56
00:02:27.760 --> 00:02:29.236
Is that geometry, what?

57
00:02:29.236 --> 00:02:32.703
>> Did you something like that, [LAUGH]
>> Some sort of class you took in high

58
00:02:32.703 --> 00:02:33.590
school, right?

59
00:02:33.590 --> 00:02:35.626
[LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] In drawing,

60
00:02:35.626 --> 00:02:39.790
cuz I was always in band, so
I didn't take art, that was my elective.

61
00:02:39.790 --> 00:02:42.332
But you know about the vanishing point,

62
00:02:42.332 --> 00:02:45.545
right, of where it goes
back into the horizon, and

63
00:02:45.545 --> 00:02:50.370
those white dots off to the sides,
you can see that's the vanishing point.

64
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:52.241
>> Yes.
>> And there's a whole bunch of, I'm sure,

65
00:02:52.241 --> 00:02:55.720
technical terminology that goes along with
perspective and how it all kind of goes.

66
00:02:55.720 --> 00:02:59.650
We're just gonna use the blue plane,
[LAUGH] and the orange plane, and

67
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:00.590
go on like that.

68
00:03:00.590 --> 00:03:04.160
But there is a whole theory behind this,
obviously.

69
00:03:04.160 --> 00:03:06.525
And there's, yeah,
there's math involved somewhere, [LAUGH]

70
00:03:06.525 --> 00:03:08.540
>> Okay, more math always.

71
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:09.460
Always bringing the math.

72
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:12.350
So what I wanted to point out
with this is you can actually

73
00:03:12.350 --> 00:03:13.560
kind of change your perspective.

74
00:03:13.560 --> 00:03:15.870
So see, you're not necessarily
stuck with the default.

75
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:18.740
This is not your only option
that you have to work with.

76
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:23.500
So you see if I kinda drag really any of
these, like white diamonds, white boxes

77
00:03:23.500 --> 00:03:27.140
you're gonna use here to really adjust
that vanishing point, if you will.

78
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:29.550
I can drag this down and

79
00:03:29.550 --> 00:03:32.660
you can see how it's gonna adjust
all of my perspectives there.

80
00:03:32.660 --> 00:03:36.490
So if I wanna kinda drag in that house,
you have several different options for

81
00:03:36.490 --> 00:03:37.260
moving this.

82
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:38.708
>> Yeah, and
those little gray dots at the bottom.

83
00:03:38.708 --> 00:03:41.305
I always call them swinging the gate open.

84
00:03:41.305 --> 00:03:45.130
And you can push the gate back and
change the vantage point.

85
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:50.825
It's really all about how
the perspective you wanna have.

86
00:03:50.825 --> 00:03:54.986
I know I tend to stay right here
on the defaults cuz after that,

87
00:03:54.986 --> 00:03:58.510
I start to get a little
confused only because I don't

88
00:03:58.510 --> 00:04:01.730
know necessarily the whole
mechanics of that.

89
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:08.374
But you have all of these modifications
that you can make within this grid.

90
00:04:08.374 --> 00:04:13.380
And there's also that plane of the green,
where it's not in perspective.

91
00:04:13.380 --> 00:04:17.545
It's like still in perspective but
flat, it goes pretty crazy.

92
00:04:17.545 --> 00:04:19.675
And if you know about this stuff,
you're probably like, yeah,

93
00:04:19.675 --> 00:04:21.230
you're doing a horrible
job of explaining it.

94
00:04:21.230 --> 00:04:24.979
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yes, yes, [LAUGH] that's funny.

95
00:04:24.979 --> 00:04:28.237
So what I wanna do here to kinda just
demonstrate that point that this is not

96
00:04:28.237 --> 00:04:30.143
the only thing that we're gonna set with.

97
00:04:30.143 --> 00:04:33.524
I'm gonna hop into a separate document
here, and the reason why I'm hopping into

98
00:04:33.524 --> 00:04:36.815
a separate document is because sometimes
this can get a little bit wonky on you.

99
00:04:36.815 --> 00:04:40.115
So I'm gonna go head back and
turn that perspective grid on here.

100
00:04:41.670 --> 00:04:42.304
Here we go.

101
00:04:42.304 --> 00:04:44.250
So I'm gonna go ahead and
turn that perspective grid on.

102
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:45.244
Now I wanna go into my view menus.

103
00:04:45.244 --> 00:04:47.430
So if go to view.

104
00:04:47.430 --> 00:04:49.710
And then, I go down to perspective grid.

105
00:04:49.710 --> 00:04:51.290
This one's almost all
the way at the very bottom.

106
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:53.530
You can see okay,
I've got some things at the top.

107
00:04:53.530 --> 00:04:56.005
But look at this one point perspective,
two point perspective,

108
00:04:56.005 --> 00:04:57.041
three point perspective.

109
00:04:57.041 --> 00:05:01.525
These are different perspectives that
you can use when working with your

110
00:05:01.525 --> 00:05:03.190
perspective grid tools.

111
00:05:03.190 --> 00:05:06.450
If I do this, I do the One Point
Perspective, open up that fly out menu and

112
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:08.174
you can see how that's gonna change.

113
00:05:08.174 --> 00:05:12.580
So you're not stuck with
just the three plane option.

114
00:05:12.580 --> 00:05:16.525
>> Yeah, if you just wanted one,
I think of them as like, walls, right?

115
00:05:16.525 --> 00:05:18.320
>> Yes.
>> I'm going down a sidewalk and

116
00:05:18.320 --> 00:05:20.400
this is the one wall and
that's the one plane.

117
00:05:20.400 --> 00:05:23.940
This is a three plane perspective, and
then you have a two plane perspective.

118
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:27.365
And all the same things we did with
the gates and the vanishing points and

119
00:05:27.365 --> 00:05:28.519
all that kind of stuff.

120
00:05:28.519 --> 00:05:33.120
You can still move all of that to get what
type of one point perspective you want to

121
00:05:33.120 --> 00:05:34.848
have, and so on and so forth.

122
00:05:34.848 --> 00:05:38.630
So but as soon as you put the grid on,
like that,

123
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:43.330
you can't have multiple
grids on the same documents.

124
00:05:43.330 --> 00:05:46.167
That's one of like, here's the grid,
this is what I got.

125
00:05:46.167 --> 00:05:51.480
And that's what's going to kinda stay for
this particular point in time.

126
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:53.800
>> Yes, and I think that's
a great point to mention too.

127
00:05:53.800 --> 00:05:56.520
I can only have one option
here that I'm working with.

128
00:05:56.520 --> 00:06:00.449
And we also have this little circle that
you may have been noticing up in the top.

129
00:06:00.449 --> 00:06:02.280
And we'll kinda get to that in a second.

130
00:06:02.280 --> 00:06:06.890
The way I'm gonna demonstrate that is if I
go here, and I go into my rectangle tool,

131
00:06:06.890 --> 00:06:08.940
now note when I go into my rectangle tool,

132
00:06:08.940 --> 00:06:10.850
it's not taking
the perspective right away.

133
00:06:10.850 --> 00:06:13.150
Often times when I'm working with a tool,
and

134
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:15.635
I switch to another tool,
that one disappears.

135
00:06:15.635 --> 00:06:18.770
So perspective grid works a little bit
differently because its kind of acting

136
00:06:18.770 --> 00:06:21.820
like theirs grid lines, if you can kind of
think about it when we're using grids and

137
00:06:21.820 --> 00:06:23.240
guides and things like that.

138
00:06:23.240 --> 00:06:26.660
So when I go ahead and
jump into my rectangle tool by default,

139
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:28.160
it is gonna draw it that way.

140
00:06:28.160 --> 00:06:32.190
Now, what if I want my rectangle
to go kind of on the flip side,

141
00:06:32.190 --> 00:06:33.390
go on that orange?

142
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:35.450
That's where that little circle comes in.

143
00:06:35.450 --> 00:06:39.360
This is going to activate the specific
planes that you're working on.

144
00:06:39.360 --> 00:06:43.980
So right now, because you see that blue
there, I'm working on that blue plane.

145
00:06:43.980 --> 00:06:50.027
Now, I can just single-click over here and
I can now activate the orange plane.

146
00:06:50.027 --> 00:06:55.499
And now, when I go to draw a rectangle,
it's gonna activate my orange side.

147
00:06:55.499 --> 00:06:59.150
And you can just shift it
depending on what you wanna do.

148
00:06:59.150 --> 00:07:03.980
You can also select just the circle part,
and that's gonna choose no active grid.

149
00:07:03.980 --> 00:07:05.650
So if you don't wanna have an active grid,

150
00:07:05.650 --> 00:07:09.210
maybe you wanna do something over here,
kind of separate it out.

151
00:07:09.210 --> 00:07:12.550
Or you wanted something that actually
looked flat, you could go ahead and

152
00:07:12.550 --> 00:07:13.930
choose no active grid.

153
00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:15.910
So that is an option for you.

154
00:07:15.910 --> 00:07:20.830
Now, what I'm gonna do here, I am not
gonna draw a rectangle, excuse me.

155
00:07:20.830 --> 00:07:24.060
I'm gonna jump to my block air tool, and
I'm just gonna start building My House.

156
00:07:24.060 --> 00:07:26.920
So I wanna go ahead and
start putting these things in place.

157
00:07:28.570 --> 00:07:29.828
She's like uh-huh.
>> [LAUGH]

158
00:07:29.828 --> 00:07:30.738
>> And I may need to

159
00:07:30.738 --> 00:07:35.580
do some adjustments here, like you can
see My House is getting a little wonky.

160
00:07:35.580 --> 00:07:39.540
>> And this is because it's not
sitting in perspective right now,

161
00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:43.600
because you've gone back to the, yes-
>> This is my mistake.

162
00:07:43.600 --> 00:07:47.662
>> I know, this is like the biggest thing
when working in the prospective grid, and

163
00:07:47.662 --> 00:07:51.367
this tool is that, you're just naturally
inclined to go back to the black

164
00:07:51.367 --> 00:07:53.842
arrow tool because that's where we go,
right?

165
00:07:53.842 --> 00:07:55.142
>> Yes.

166
00:07:55.142 --> 00:07:59.695
>> Well, the black arrow tool is gonna
just go ahead and select the object and

167
00:07:59.695 --> 00:08:01.762
just select the object, right?

168
00:08:01.762 --> 00:08:04.097
And if you move it around,
you can see it didn't,

169
00:08:04.097 --> 00:08:07.680
it stopped kinda staying in the grid and
wasn't really moving around.

170
00:08:07.680 --> 00:08:10.170
That's because you don't
grab your black arrow tool.

171
00:08:10.170 --> 00:08:14.070
You have to grab your perspective
grid selection tool thing.

172
00:08:14.070 --> 00:08:17.500
I can't remember its real name, but that's
the one that will keep it in perspective.

173
00:08:17.500 --> 00:08:18.680
>> Gets me every time.

174
00:08:18.680 --> 00:08:19.490
>> Every time.

175
00:08:19.490 --> 00:08:20.154
>> Clearly, every time.

176
00:08:20.154 --> 00:08:20.832
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you see,

177
00:08:20.832 --> 00:08:23.855
okay, as I was shifting that,
I was thinking, okay, you know that,

178
00:08:23.855 --> 00:08:25.000
something's not right.

179
00:08:25.000 --> 00:08:26.000
I'm doing something wrong.

180
00:08:26.000 --> 00:08:27.083
>> And also-
>> It's because I picked

181
00:08:27.083 --> 00:08:27.598
my black arrow tool.

182
00:08:27.598 --> 00:08:30.818
>> And also, sorry to jump in,
if you start moving it,

183
00:08:30.818 --> 00:08:34.260
if you want to say down the grid,
like the whole square,

184
00:08:34.260 --> 00:08:39.120
you see right there, it's not staying
in the actual perspective of the grid.

185
00:08:39.120 --> 00:08:41.280
It's like, wait, no,
it's supposed to kind of like, for

186
00:08:41.280 --> 00:08:43.750
lack of a term like, go backwards-
>> Mm-hm.

187
00:08:43.750 --> 00:08:46.570
>> It's not,
because the black arrow tool is

188
00:08:46.570 --> 00:08:49.130
not the one you want to use
to stay in perspective.

189
00:08:49.130 --> 00:08:53.060
Yes, I do it every single time and
I have to force myself.

190
00:08:53.060 --> 00:08:54.050
Nope, that's not what you gotta do.

191
00:08:54.050 --> 00:08:55.630
You've gotta get a different tool.

192
00:08:55.630 --> 00:08:56.910
And you will do it too.

193
00:08:56.910 --> 00:08:59.550
And so, that is why we're doing that.

194
00:08:59.550 --> 00:09:01.542
We were just a teachable moment, right?

195
00:09:01.542 --> 00:09:03.650
>> [LAUGH]

episodes.description: In this final episode of the series, Vonne and Emily show how to complete a project with save and export options.  They show new and old ways to export files to different raster file types for both print and web.  They explore working with web files with the asset export panel, align to pixel grid, and export for screen.
episodes.title: Saving and Exporting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

Hello everyone, and

13

>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, [LAUGH]

>> It's funny we were talking right before

I like the technical stuff for

So this is the episode, like you said,

well hey, my boss has said, okay,

It does make a huge difference

So that's kind of important.

00:02:12.830 --> 00:02:14.744
And so we're gonna, [LAUGH],
we're gonna start now,

I feel like I'm taking

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Let's jump down into a file,

and I'm gonna Vanna for

So Vonne's gonna kind of walk us through

So I'm like you go, have your fun.

So yeah, what we're going to do is we're

If you can kind of think back

And now we're acting as if

And just like Vonne said, you always give

And also, when I'm designing, and

00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:11.840
Because maybe I have one, I think we have

00:03:11.840 --> 00:03:13.170
okay, let's just make

00:03:13.170 --> 00:03:16.700
The other one is a half,
it's not necessarily a half paper,

we just drew it really quickly.

But just to let you know, when I'm doing

I know we're in Creative.ProTV, but I

And the old one,
this one actually is a lot better.

74
00:03:31.837 --> 00:03:32.337
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

>> But mine was pretty cool too.

I literally had 15 different

00:03:36.828 --> 00:03:39.567
art boards.
Because we had ones that needed to go

00:03:42.084 --> 00:03:42.850

And

And

And then,

Let me go, and just to reiterate,

00:04:05.660 --> 00:04:07.344
If you're working on
something like a logo,

I always have clients with different

00:04:10.092 --> 00:04:11.978
it's like I just have 20

00:04:11.978 --> 00:04:12.714
>> Yeah.

93

>> So yeah.

94

00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:18.360
You can see I have art board one is a

00:04:19.072 --> 00:04:22.580

99

Pretty good.

100
00:04:24.920 --> 00:04:29.868
I have the and the RGB and all these

But understanding the numbers does make a

00:04:35.582 --> 00:04:37.060

So keep that in mind, of knowing what

So lets say that, like I said,

00:04:50.310 --> 00:04:53.880

I'm gonna go the old school way,

Because remember we're

The only way we can do that is go

00:05:15.760 --> 00:05:19.970
So we'll go to Export, Export As, cua

We'll do that, and then we get into,

116
00:05:24.610 --> 00:05:25.550
Where do I want to put it?

00:05:25.550 --> 00:05:26.090

Down at the bottom I have my file formats.

120

Do I want a PNG, do I want a JPEG,
do I want a TIFF?

121
00:05:33.158 --> 00:05:37.080
There's a whole bunch of other things in

122
00:05:37.080 --> 00:05:39.960
[LAUGH] So let's go with,
let's go with JPEG.

123
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:43.205
Okay, we're going to give them

Now one thing that you do need to be

That's pretty big in a couple

00:05:55.122 --> 00:05:56.538

00:05:56.538 --> 00:06:01.072

130
00:06:02.940 --> 00:06:07.900
I'm telling it to use the art boards and
then look at the two little radio

132

If I wasn't paying attention to it,
I'd be exporting all of them.

00:06:14.990 --> 00:06:19.458
And if I had 15 art boards, guess what,
all of them are gonna be exported at my

134
00:06:19.458 --> 00:06:22.260
JPEG and
using the art board dimensions, okay.

135
00:06:22.260 --> 00:06:26.823
If I only wanted to give them the white

136
00:06:26.823 --> 00:06:30.279
I'll go ahead and choose this,
and type in the range of 1,

137
00:06:30.279 --> 00:06:32.520
because that is the art board number.

138
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:34.760
Remember I said,
remember your art board numbers?

139
00:06:34.760 --> 00:06:35.800
That's where it comes into play.

140
00:06:35.800 --> 00:06:38.350
If I wanted to give them one with
a black background, I'd put it in two.

141
00:06:38.350 --> 00:06:43.520
And that way I'd only give that one
specific art board to be exported.

142
00:06:43.520 --> 00:06:46.490
The other thing to watch for, say that
I don't have any art boards, right,

143
00:06:46.490 --> 00:06:48.120
I only have one single art board.

144
00:06:48.120 --> 00:06:50.901
She's thinking,
that check box doesn't matter.

145
00:06:50.901 --> 00:06:53.053
It does, [LAUGH] it does a lot.

146
00:06:53.053 --> 00:06:55.208
Because remember that flower,

00:06:55.208 --> 00:07:00.084
we had it kind of sitting on a big piece
of white paper, if you want to say.

148
00:07:00.084 --> 00:07:02.856
If you do not check that box off,

149
00:07:02.856 --> 00:07:07.870
none of the white on the art
board is going to be exported.

150
00:07:07.870 --> 00:07:11.760
It's basically going to find where
the pixels stop and make it to that exact

151
00:07:11.760 --> 00:07:15.540

flower shop text is at the bottom.

152
00:07:15.540 --> 00:07:19.008
And that's going to be
the size of your JPEG or

153
00:07:19.008 --> 00:07:23.260
the raster information
that lives in there.

154
00:07:23.260 --> 00:07:25.860
And then you threw out another one
that I thought was interesting that

155
00:07:25.860 --> 00:07:27.280
I totally forgot about.

156
00:07:27.280 --> 00:07:28.434
>> it gets me every time.

157
00:07:28.434 --> 00:07:32.000
So if I'm found working,
I'm just gonna hit Cancel just right here.

158
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:35.330
I am a fan of the paste board,
let me tell you.

159
00:07:35.330 --> 00:07:38.510
So a lot of times we'll have, maybe like
I'll have an alternative version just

160
00:07:38.510 --> 00:07:39.860

161
00:07:39.860 --> 00:07:43.785
That was like my old way, pretend I
have different colors or something, or

162
00:07:43.785 --> 00:07:46.670
just something else I was
playing with off to the side.

163
00:07:46.670 --> 00:07:49.842
If you do that export and
you don't choose use art boards,

164
00:07:49.842 --> 00:07:51.990
gonna pick up all this stuff over here.

165
00:07:51.990 --> 00:07:54.004
>> Yes.
>> And it's gonna look really weird,

166
00:07:54.004 --> 00:07:54.850
let me tell you.

167
00:07:54.850 --> 00:07:58.319
>> Yeah, cuz it's finding all
the information that it sees and

168
00:07:58.319 --> 00:08:00.982
making the dimension of
your file from there.

169
00:08:00.982 --> 00:08:06.158
So that's a big one, There to make
sure you understand the checkbox,

170
00:08:06.158 --> 00:08:09.244
and the importance of why you wanna do it.

171
00:08:09.244 --> 00:08:13.774
One other kind of, my tip,
I usually will make an artboard

172
00:08:13.774 --> 00:08:17.942
to where I give enough of a padding,
if you wanna say.

173
00:08:17.942 --> 00:08:20.354
Like the internal margin
of where the art sits,

174
00:08:20.354 --> 00:08:23.731
it's because I used that, and
I always check on, use artboards,

175
00:08:23.731 --> 00:08:27.120
because that's going to be my
final dimension of the file.

176
00:08:27.120 --> 00:08:31.820
That's where a lot of times, hey,
I need a logo that's 600x600 pixels wide.

177
00:08:31.820 --> 00:08:35.963
I'll just use the artboard tool to make
an artboard, type in my dimensions,

178
00:08:35.963 --> 00:08:39.103
move the stuff into it,
by the number, check the box off.

179
00:08:39.103 --> 00:08:43.960
I know I've got an exact 600x600 or
5 inches x 5 inches artboard to know

180
00:08:43.960 --> 00:08:48.260
that that's going to be
the dimension of the files was huge.

181
00:08:48.260 --> 00:08:51.077
Really, again,
this is the boring stuff but it's so

182
00:08:51.077 --> 00:08:54.089
important to make sure you
understand what's going on.

183
00:08:54.089 --> 00:08:56.656
Now let's just go ahead and
say, yeah, that sounds good

184
00:08:56.656 --> 00:09:00.150
even if we have all checked off,
cuz we're gonna cancel this anyways.

185
00:09:00.150 --> 00:09:02.520
The next part when you hit OK from here,

186
00:09:02.520 --> 00:09:07.640
it's this dialogue box that
makes a big difference as well.

187
00:09:07.640 --> 00:09:11.280
This dialogue box is going to come up for
if you choose a TIFF,

188
00:09:11.280 --> 00:09:15.400
if you choose a PNG, if you choose
any of these in the export options.

189
00:09:15.400 --> 00:09:16.930
It's gonna come into, okay,

190
00:09:16.930 --> 00:09:22.230
well with this particular file format,
these are the JPEG options.

191
00:09:22.230 --> 00:09:23.590
You get this a lot in Photoshop.

192
00:09:23.590 --> 00:09:24.423
>> Yeah, you do, right.
>> Right, yeah,

193
00:09:24.423 --> 00:09:25.790
when you do the File > Save As.

194
00:09:25.790 --> 00:09:30.980
So right here, color mode, I would turn
this to RGB if I'm sending it for web.

195
00:09:30.980 --> 00:09:34.568
Or if I was sending
someone a 300 PPI JPEG for

196
00:09:34.568 --> 00:09:39.447

it's not that big of a deal.

197
00:09:39.447 --> 00:09:43.730
As long as you have the color and
the resolution, you're fine.

198
00:09:43.730 --> 00:09:45.422
So I pick my color mode from here.

199
00:09:45.422 --> 00:09:47.875
You also have the quality,
specifically with JPEGs,

200
00:09:47.875 --> 00:09:50.930
like how much you wanna compress it,
8, honestly, just keep it.

201
00:09:50.930 --> 00:09:53.610
Sometimes I bump that up, but
don't bump is lower than eight.

202
00:09:53.610 --> 00:09:57.800
The rest of the stuff, honestly,
I don't really pay attention.

203
00:09:57.800 --> 00:09:59.190
Well, no, wait, my goodness.

204
00:09:59.190 --> 00:10:02.820
>> Yeah, I was gonna say, you're not
paying attention to your resolution.

205
00:10:02.820 --> 00:10:04.461
Vonne, come on,
I know you better than that.

206
00:10:04.461 --> 00:10:06.426
[LAUGH]
>> I was checking to see if Emily was

207
00:10:06.426 --> 00:10:07.691
paying attention over here.

208
00:10:07.691 --> 00:10:09.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, yeah, resolution, my gosh,

209
00:10:09.730 --> 00:10:12.375
I was thinking about this is like
the advanced options and the file new.

210
00:10:12.375 --> 00:10:13.258
>> I know.

211
00:10:13.258 --> 00:10:15.970
>> Whew,
crossing too many streams right here.

212
00:10:15.970 --> 00:10:17.405
This is very important.

213
00:10:17.405 --> 00:10:19.039
>> [LAUGH]
>> What's my resolution?

214
00:10:19.039 --> 00:10:23.309
If I'm setting it for a web, then I would
choose the small, the 72, or the high,

215
00:10:23.309 --> 00:10:26.786
this goes back to the whole like
iPhone stuff and sending pictures,

216
00:10:26.786 --> 00:10:29.580
do you want it to be small,
medium, or large?

217
00:10:29.580 --> 00:10:30.950
Same idea here.

218
00:10:30.950 --> 00:10:35.937
So you know 72 web, 300 print,
you check those off.

219
00:10:35.937 --> 00:10:37.673
You would normally click OK, and

220
00:10:37.673 --> 00:10:42.160
then you’d have your files wherever you
had designated it in your file directory.

221
00:10:42.160 --> 00:10:45.580
We’re gonna click Cancel right here,
just because that’s what we got.

222
00:10:45.580 --> 00:10:46.600
